TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Guidelines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.We are opposed to the childcare guidelines issued by the National Childcare Accreditation Council and the Keating Government, and

2.In particular we find offensive the guidelines relating to Christmas Carols and the misconceived gender statements relating to the childrens toys. We believe that childcare should first and foremost reflect the values of parents and not trendy childcare theorists.
We therefore call upon the Senate to reject the guidelines as they are currently drafted.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, resident in the State of Victoria, draws the attention of the Senate, to our concern regarding the proposed legislation pertaining to the new "Quality Improvement and Accreditation System Handbook" for Child Care Centres. We express deep concern over the proposed changes to the Legislation which would take us from a Judeo-Christian ethic of the raising of children within our Nation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate seriously consider the ramifications of the proposals as they would affect the future generation of citizens toward the twenty first century.

PETITION.TITLE: Leaded Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the reduction of octane quality of leaded petrol from January 1994, resulting from the Government's `Lead Roundtable' meeting. The petitioners note particularly that this reduction in petrol quality:
1. Jeopardises the use of vehicles made prior to 1986 for operation on high octane petrol and could lead to many of those vehicles suffering serious engine damage;
2. Will result in worse vehicle operation, higher emissions and greater fuel consumption for up to three million vehicles;

3. Will have negligible benefit to the community, through reduced lead emissions, because the oil industry proposes to leave lead levels in petrol unchanged in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, and because the use of leaded petrol already is rapidly decreasing;
4. Will disadvantage vehicle enthusiasts and low income members of the community.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to take action to ensure the continued availability of high octane petrol for Australian motorists.

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully submit that:
The High Court's Mabo decision has caused division and dissension, uncertainty, resentment and economic damage in Australia.
Mabo will not solve the social, educational, housing and other problems of Aboriginal people.
Mabo is an attack on our Federal system of government, under which the absolute control of Crown lands and management of land titles have always rested with the States.

The only solution to Mabo is a referendum of the Australian people for a law to overrule the High Court and re-establish equal land rights for all Australians, under the normal procedures of State and Territory laws.
And we strongly urge the Senate to reject any other proposed solution.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned parents and friends of Tiptoes Child Care Centre Oakbank in South Australia draws attention to the Senate that the Federal Government is seeking to link accreditation to eligibility for Childcare Assistance and in the opinion of your petitioners this link will only lead to higher fees for parents and no guarantee for improvement in quality of care for children. We know that quality care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. Please help us help our children.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to reject accreditation being linked to Childcare Assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: 18 November 1993
Senator the Hon Rosemary Crowley
Minister for Family Services
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance), CCA/4B/93/2, made under the Child Care Act 1972, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 18 November 1993.

The Guidelines confer discretions on both the Minister and the Secretary or an authorised officer. The Ministerial discretions appear to affect personal and commercial rights to a significant degree. The Explanatory Statement, however, advises that new child care legislation presently being drafted by the Australian Law Reform Commission will provide for AAT review of ministerial decisions. This is an appropriate safeguard. Nevertheless, the Guidelines commence on 1 January 1994 while the new legislation will only be introduced into Parliament later in 1994. The Committee considers that it would be appropriate to amend the Guidelines to provide for AAT review from 1 January 1994 and would appreciate your advice on this.

The Explanatory Statement gives no such assurance about decisions of the Secretary or an authorised officer. The Committee accepts that these discretions appear to be less important than those exercisable by the Minister. Nevertheless, the Committee would welcome your advice on whether AAT review would also be suitable for these decisions.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
10 December 1993
Senator M. Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston
I refer to your letter of 18 November 1993 concerning the Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance) made under the Child Care Act 1972.

You have raised the matter of review of the discretions conferred by the Guidelines on the Minister, the Secretary or an authorised officer. You also sought my advice on the Committee view that the Guidelines should be amended to provide for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of certain decisions from 1 January 1994.

Under the Guidelines, existing child care centres will be given six months (1 January to 30 June 1994) in which to register under the Quality Improvement and Accreditation System (the System). Accordingly, no decisions that would affect these centres in relation to the System would be made by the Minister until after 1 July 1994. Against this background and because completion of the Australian Law Reform Commission review of child care legislation was scheduled for mid 1994 it was expected that the AAT review provisions for the System would be in place from July 1994.

However, because of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances' concern about possible delays in finalisation of the ALRC reference I agree to table new Guidelines for Determination of Eligible Child Care Centres (Childcare Assistance), CCA/4B/93/2, to provide for AAT review of decisions by the Minister in relation to the System for existing and new centres.
I am prepared to agree to provide this new instrument, as soon as it can be prepared, with a view to the AAT review arrangements for the System being effective from 1 January 1994.

It is proposed that the question of review of decisions currently made by the Minister in relation to all other aspects of the Children's Services Program remain the subject of the ALRC review of the Program. I would of course expect the ALRC to incorporate the proposed AAT review provisions for the System in the new child care legislation.
On the question of a review process for decisions by the Secretary or authorised officers I propose that this issue also remain the subject of the ALRC review of the Program.
If you require further information or clarification please contact Marianna Serghi in my office on telephone 277 7240.
Yours sincerely
Rosemary A. Crowley

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to lack of time, I will not go into the amendment question, but it is difficult to debate something when one does not know the direction the government is taking. The Senate is debating the Native Title Bill 1993—the government's response to the High Court's Mabo decision. The High Court ruled that native title exists and that Aborigines and Islanders can claim unalienated crown land. The Prime Minister has taken that decision and extended it to include land management, reconciliation, mining leases, pastoral leases, stock routes and tourist leases. He has brought forward the most complex and convoluted piece of legislation. The Pandora's box has been well and truly opened.

PARA.TAB: The Native Title Bill will have far-reaching effects on all Australians, both black and white. It will impact on the wealth producers of Australia—the mining, primary and tourist industries—and plunge them all into uncertain financial futures. There is no certainty for any of these industries. The legislation will be interpreted in the courts throughout Australia in a series of cases that will be time consuming and force delays in getting projects under way for all of those industries.

The graziers and the farmers will have to defend expensive native title claims against government-funded organisations. No estimate has been made of the loss to the mining industry as it battles its way through a legal maze of uncertainty of government-funded tribunals and courts, or the impact it will have as it takes its expertise and capital offshore, where governments actually encourage wealth-creating industries that give jobs and prosperity to their citizens instead of putting up barriers.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has thrown around a ballpark figure of $200 million, based on no facts at all. Australians are being asked to sign a blank cheque under this legislation. The legislation is uncosted in every respect. The bill, which the Prime Minister has embraced as his own, is another example of how far out of touch he is with the electorate and how willing he is to put the wellbeing of Australia at risk to fulfil his personal ambitions.

The Prime Minister said in his second reading speech that it would be a failure on our part if we did not recognise the past and that we must acknowledge the past treatment of Aborigines. No-one can condone the treatment Aborigines received in the past; but that does not mean that this generation can exorcise the sins of the past. To compensate for the past only discriminates against future generations of Australians, both black and white. It will discriminate against school leavers and unionists as scarce jobs become scarcer, as the mining industry winds down exploration. With 160,000 people directly employed and 470,000 indirectly employed, the jobs the mining industry creates will fall away.

This legislation will discriminate against every Australian as our living standards drop, as our primary products and mining exports fall from $37 billion. Our trade deficit will rise, our dollar fall and our international debt soar. It will discriminate against farmers, pastoralists, small towns and regional Australia as primary producers fight native title claims and wealth-creating station properties supplying jobs to workers in abattoirs and transport operators are taken out of production, as happened in the Northern Territory. It will discriminate against Aboriginals and Islanders living on communities where native title is vested in another group of people.
I have received advice from Senator Collins which states:

SPEECH.PARA: It would appear likely that in general grants made under laws for the special benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders will not have extinguished native title. It is therefore possible that native title will continue to exist on at least some D.O.G.I.T land.

I suggest that that would be the same in every other state. This bill asks more questions than it answers. While Senator Collins's advice makes it clear that indigenous people who live on Aboriginal communities will have their present rights protected, it is not clear what their position would be if they wanted to grow vegetables, open a caravan park, cut timber or take on some other project in those communities. Will they be fully fledged members of the community or merely tenants tolerated by the community? No doubt that will be determined by court action, when we will see one group of Aboriginals take another group to court to establish their rights: Aborigines against Aborigines.

PARA.TAB: The bill is a disaster. If ever a piece of legislation was designed to kill the goose that laid the golden egg, this is it. This legislation will give Aboriginal people a right to claim native title if they can establish their ties with the land. We have been told by the Aboriginal negotiating team that this legislation will pick up 12,000 Aborigines. There are between 250,000 and 300,000 Aborigines in Australia. This legislation will meet the needs of between five and seven per cent of indigenous people.

The Prime Minister tells us that a land fund will be established to enable indigenous people to acquire land and manage and maintain it in a sustainable way in order to provide economic, social and cultural benefits for future generations. This will provide for the remaining Aboriginal community which will not have access to land under this legislation—those Aborigines who live in regional towns and cities and capital cities and communities throughout Australia. The land fund established under this bill will be set up by regulation.

This legislation does not tell us how much money will be required to be paid into the fund, although Michael Mansell believes that $200 million will barely scratch the surface. We do not know the circumstances in which payments will be made or who will operate the fund. How much will eventually be required in the fund is not spelled out. How can any reasonable or responsible member of parliament vote for a landcare fund without any knowledge of what it will cost, who will run it or how it will work? We are asked to do that by voting for this legislation, and we are told that the details will be fixed up later.

Already, Aboriginal people have large land holdings in every state. In Queensland, under deed of grant in trust, all former state government Aboriginal communities were handed over to the indigenous people on those communities to administer themselves under the Local Government Act. Three million hectares of prime land, much of it beachfront, went to the 30,000 Aborigines who resided in those communities. Each community elected its own council under local government and ran its own operation. The land was vested in elected local councils as trustees and any community dweller that had access to a block of land to engage in farming or grazing or any other business project. Many indigenous people took advantage of this Queensland legislation to start their own small business, but this legislation we are asked to vote on today will kill that. In the Northern Territory, 500,000 square kilometres has gone to Aboriginal communities and 190,000 square kilometres in South Australia. There is a huge amount of land that has been passed over to our indigenous people.

I would like to address some important issues on pastoral leases and how they are affected by this legislation. This bill has raised all sorts of uncertainties in relation to pastoral leases by its discriminatory way of validating only leases granted after 1975 and leaving all previous leases governed solely by the High Court's Mabo decision. This Native Title Bill validates all pastoral leases that have been invalidly granted; that is, all leases granted after 1975, of which there are only around 11. However, the real uncertainty arises in relation to all other pastoral leases—those granted between 1788 and 1975. This legislation does not validate them. This bill adopts the common law in relation to native title as the law of Australia. All pastoral leases bar the 11 granted after 1975 are therefore open to claim under the High Court ruling.

Senator Gareth Evans told the Senate, in answer to questions on this issue, that he did not believe there would be many claims that could succeed. He admitted that they could arise as fiduciary duty claims or other common law claims, such as happened with the Wik claim over the Comalco bauxite mine in Queensland. According to advice from our top legal firms, it seems that under this legislation, if a pastoral lease is not automatically renewable or if the lease contains reservations or conditions for native use, native title probably coexists and revives at the completion of the pastoral lease. Pastoral leases in the Northern Territory, South Australia and Western Australia all contain reservations for present statutory right of access for Aboriginals. The consequence could be that native title will revive on the expiry of the lease.

Do the government and the Australian people understand the areas of land that are caught by this possibility? Over 50 per cent of my home state of Queensland is covered by pastoral lease; that is, 937,000 square kilometres covered by 37,910 pastoral and freehold leases. In Queensland it is unclear whether pastoral leases are automatically renewable. In Queensland a pastoral lease is surrendered and there is a ministerial decision before the lease is reissued. In the Northern Territory, South Australia and Western Australia, pastoral leases contain statutory provisions beneficial to Aboriginals.

Once again, as the government has decided to validate only the post-1975 leases, there is a very real problem with pastoral leases granted prior to 1975 that have statutory reservations for Aboriginals in that native title probably coexists with them. The issue then arises: can these pastoral leases be renewed? According to advice, it seems possible that pastoral leases which coexist with native title and which do not have a legally enforceable right to renew will, as current leases expire, automatically become exclusively native title land, with no capacity for either the current lessees or the state or territory governments which granted the leases to prevent this happening.

There is a major flaw in this legislation in that it cannot be applied nationally because of different land law systems in different states. The consequence for some states will be the possibility of removing major proportions of their land from free use. Marshall Perron, Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, has stated that 90 per cent of the Northern Territory is likely to fall under Aboriginal title of one kind or another, either inalienable freehold title under the Northern Territory land rights legislation or native title under this bill. Nearly half of the Northern Territory is under Aboriginal ownership already. Nearly 80 per cent of Western Australia is either crown land or pastoral lease, and in Western Australia pastoral leases are considered to be crown land. The Land Act in Western Australia provides for Aboriginals to enter any unenclosed or unimproved parts of the land subject to a pastoral lease to seek their sustenance in their accustomed way. As I have already said, these statutory rights may revive native title over these areas of land where access is allowed.

This bill, by throwing up legal intricacies that can be solved only by recourse to the courts, does no-one a service. It is similar in South Australia, where pastoral leases form 43.8 per cent of the state and cover 43,079,340 hectares. South Australian legislation also allows for Aboriginals to enter and use pastoral land in any traditional way. Native title may be extinguished to the extent that it is inconsistent with this provision. But South Australian pastoral leases remain under threat to the extent that leasehold land is used for traditional use. This is very different from the Prime Minister's placating words on 16 November, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably only where there is so-called vacant crown land and in remote areas where traditional Aboriginal life has not been disrupted that native title exists.

We cannot introduce all this uncertainty into the grazing and mining industries and expect things to go along as they have in the past, with these two industries continuing to reliably provide the bulk of our export income. In the pastoral industry, properties are not being bought and sold because of the uncertainty created by this legislation. No doubt bankers are reluctant to lend on title they do not yet have certainty over.

PARA.TAB: The continuation of the mining industry as our big export earner is definitely at risk. Mining companies are not obligated to invest in Australia. Mining is an international industry which can exist only if it has security of title. The attractiveness and development of mining in Australia were based on our stability. Compared with most other countries, we had important advantages when it came to investment. We may have had problems with high labour costs or excessive government red tape, but we always had the fundamental right of secure access to land and security of tenure. This political stability has always provided us with our own special area of comparative advantage.

Mr Keating, by hijacking the High Court Mabo decision, has introduced all sorts of problems and uncertainties from which Australia has been free. At stake is our future. Already the Australian Mining Industry Council has warned that mineral exploration and investment spending are not enough to sustain current production levels, that few projects are under construction and that production growth has fallen over the past two years. Australia is not such a rare source of mineral and agricultural wealth that investment will not be lost overseas and exports replaced by others. Just this week, CRA announced that it would cut its 1994 Australian exploration budget by nearly 40 per cent.

Last year mining earned Australia over $20 billion in export earnings; agriculture, $17 billion; and tourism, $6 billion. All our resource industries—mining, agriculture, forestry, fishing and tourism—need certainty of title. All will be affected in some way by this legislation. We cannot assume that the mining and agricultural industries will continue to underwrite our wealth and continue to employ 160,000 people Australia wide in mining or 390,000 directly in agriculture.

There are certainly aspects of this bill that will affect productivity and impose costs on the pastoral industry. No-one knows what grazing land will be lost from pastoral leases being able to be bought and converted to native title, and there will certainly be plenty of taxpayers' funds around to buy up these pastoral leases. Stock routes, being crown land, will be claimable under native title. There will be disruption from land adjoining river beds being able to form part of native title claims.

Uncertainty is arising from loss of rate contributions to local government. It is not clear under the legislation whether it is possible to convert pastoral leasehold to freehold and then subdivide, which is necessary around expanding rural towns. It is also uncertain whether pastoral leases which have been converted to mining leases may be prevented from reverting to pastoral leases.

Any future grants of pastoral leases will involve lengthy negotiations under this bill. If there has been no previous claim, it has to proceed on the basis that there may be a native title claim and everyone on the list has to be notified. Even if a future act is unopposed, native title is extinguished and claims for compensation may be made at any time after the extinguishment. Also, the rural pastoral leaseholders will not receive the same ready assistance with legal costs as the native title claimants. Legal assistance will be granted only at the discretion of the Attorney-General and only if the hardship test is met, which as yet has not been spelled out.

The NFF, having taken on the role of negotiating with the federal government on this issue, has not looked after its members by its endorsement of legislation that introduces so many uncertainties into rural land holdings. It has been sold a pup by the government and swallowed the government's smooth and soothing words too easily. To leave all pre-1975 pastoral leases open to challenge is to introduce uncertainties to the grazing industry which the NFF should have fought against.

Even Premier Goss saw the error of leaving all leases granted prior to 1975 potentially open to native title claim. He called for all titles back to 1788 to be validated by the Commonwealth. He has called this bill anti-development and a threat to economic growth. Mr Goss also realises the generous gesture by the federal government in loading the lion's share of compensation on the states. He has refused to proclaim the Queensland legislation until a fair agreement has been reached with the federal government.

The question must be asked: will this legislation achieve for Aboriginal Australians what every Australian wants for its indigenous people—the same education, health and housing opportunities as every other Australian and a better lifestyle for Australia's 300,000 Aborigines, many of whom are already living successful lives around Australia? Sadly, I believe that the answer will be no. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Western Australia) (9.30 a.m.). We are debating the Native Title Bill 1993, but there are a couple of comments I would like to make before I speak to the bill. If we want to get through the long list of speakers, I suggest that honourable senators speak in the order they are listed. I refer not only to Senator Murphy, but also to the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot), who was listed to speak much earlier than either Senator Boswell or I was.
—She is still working out what to say.

—She is still making up her mind when to come into the chamber. I would also like to comment on the words of Senator Gareth Evans yesterday when he said that we are going to get this legislation through, even if we have to sit Friday, Saturday, Sunday, Monday or whenever. Senator Evans was also quoted on the 6 a.m. news as saying that. I thought that the jack-boot brigade had finished in May 1945 and I did not expect to be revisited in the Senate in 1993.

PARA.TAB: The other day Senator Gareth Evans said that we should not have a Senate select committee further inquire into this bill because—this was the excuse he used—in January very little work is done in Australia. That is the trouble with Australia these days. In January very little work is done. That is with the exception of the mining, pastoral and farming areas of Australia, which work 366 days of the year, which is different from the attitude of Senator Evans.

I am proud to be part of the group that is opposing this legislation. I fully support the coalition's total opposition to the Native Title Bill, which bill will only lead to uncertainty, complexity and division. I am proud to be a part of the Western Australian group that convinced the coalition to arrive at this position. This bill does not make one iota of difference to the health, education and housing standards of Aborigines in Australia. We are already spending a lot of money—some $1.3 billion—and we are nowhere near making enough use of that to alleviate the Aborigines' position.

The case of Mabo against Queensland was to claim native title on the island of Mer in the Murray Islands. I believe that that was as far as the High Court went. Not one iota of evidence was ever taken after that to try to prove that native title existed in the rest of Australia. The Murray Islanders were not nomadic. They cultivated crops, built permanent housing, had no community titles and were Melanesians.

The Murray Islands were not part of Australia in 1788 and were claimed by Queensland in the late 1870s. So we cannot really say that the Murray Islands were part of what the British Empire claimed in 1788 when the British came here. If the British had not come here in 1788, Australia might have been colonised by someone that might have been tougher on the indigenous people of Australia. The High Court decision that terra nullius did not exist in the Murray Islands was understandable, but that is as far as I believe it should have gone.

The mainland is totally different. It was inhabited by nomadic tribes with no housing and no individual persons having particular title. Yet, without any skerrick of further evidence, this government, headed by Mr Keating, allowed the judgment to spread to all of Australia. If further evidence had been taken and the High Court had found differently, then I would have been happy to accept that; but it did not. I doubt that Aboriginals, with the small number there were in the total area of Australia, could have possibly come near to covering all areas of Australia. I fly over a lot of outback Western Australia and into the Great Victoria Desert, the Gibson Desert and other places; and I believe that there is a lot of land that black man, let alone white man, has never set foot on. How could the High Court say that the Aborigines covered Australia?

I believe that the sum total of this bill is a means for this government—and politically correct, guilt ridden, socially conscious do-gooders, mostly from the eastern seaboard—to clear its collective guilt. It has nothing to do with reconciliation. I will come back to reconciliation later.

I must question how much of Australia was taken from Aborigines. With the advent of white settlement in Australia, a lot of Australia was abandoned by the Aborigines. This argument was favourably explained by former Senator Peter Walsh in the Australian Financial Review of 16 November 1993, which I have here.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very good article.

—It is a very good article. I have told the Senate before that I have known Peter Walsh longer than most people in this chamber have and certainly longer than most of my colleagues on this side of the chamber have. Though we belonged to different political camps, we had a lot in common. Reading the article, one will even see what the Labor side of this House sees as what really happened. I could quote quite a bit from the article, but I have sent it over to the minister in charge and I seek leave for it to be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: MYTHS ON BLACKS PERSIST

In the mid-1950s, Bill Grayden, then a member of the Western Australian Parliament, and a few others visited the Western Desert in a couple of four-wheel-drive vehicles and discovered the Pintubi people, reputedly the indigenous inhabitants of that area.

According to contemporary reports, they had not previously seen white men and were in a wretched condition, partly due to an extended drought. The reports provoked a lot of hand-wringing, charges and confessions of white guilt of having, by neglecting these people, allowed them to sink into such a squalid existence. Shortly afterwards they were taken off the land. Fashions change.

In the 1940s, a 10-year-old boy later known as Jimmy Bienderry walked in with his clan from the Western Desert to a white settlement in the Kimberleys. It was another severe drought period. Bienderry's clan had not seen white men either but had apparently heard about them from other Aborigines living closer to white settlements. They were told, correctly, that a food supply was assured in white settlements. There are numerous other reports of similar incidents.

The point of these stories is that not all Aborigines were driven off their land by white men with guns. Some, possibly quite a lot, left voluntarily to escape from their precarious struggle for survival. Tasmanian Aborigines at the time of white settlement did not know how to make fire or catch fish—technology they are believed to have once had but lost. They wore animal skins but did not make clothing appropriate for a cold climate.

There are, of course, many parts of Australia more hospitable to people with only Stone Age technology at best than the Western Desert and Tasmania, but there is no good reason to believe Aborigines enjoyed the idyllic life that ignorant white romanticists insist they did. It has often been claimed that Aboriginal quality of life at the time of white settlement was at least as good as the masses had in Europe.

That may well have been true in the more favoured areas, but what was the quality of life in the late 18th-century Europe? Cholera, typhoid, smallpox, chronic malnutrition and sporadic starvation. How many people, white or Aboriginal, would be happy to settle for 18th-century living standards?

To sanctimonious whites dedicated to belittling or vilifying the achievements of Western technology, while simultaneously gorging on them, pointing out facts like this is racist. A few weeks ago they asserted we should learn from Aborigines how to live in harmony with nature, as some near-traditional Aborigines allegedly still do.

The reality is that if 20th-century life-support systems—Toyotas, running water, electricity, aircraft, imported food, drink and clothing—were withdrawn from the Western Desert and similar areas, the Aborigines would not want to stay there any more than the Pintubi did nearly 40 years before, let alone the whites who fawn on "traditional" lifestyles.

Running in parallel with this misguided nature worship is a belief that the social and economic problems of most contemporary Aborigines are attributable to "dispossession", and that land rights will fix them up. Leaving aside the fact that not all were "dispossessed", the available statistics do not support that.

The 1991 census data show that Aborigines in Victoria and Tasmania, the most thoroughly "dispossessed", have much higher incomes, significantly longer life expectancy and a better education than Northern Territory Aborigines—the least "dispossessed" and major recipients of land rights. In Western Australia an analysis of ABS census data showed a very strong inverse correlation between income and the propensity to speak an Aboriginal language at home. (Brunton, October `93.)

None of this is terribly surprising. The relatively affluent and healthy Aborigines are those with the highest level of socio-economic "assimilation". It is politically incorrect to say that, but what are our objectives: the material wellbeing of Aborigines—or feeling good about ourselves?

Almost certainly there is a higher proportion of part-Aborigines in the more affluent groups—a function of the duration of their association with white Australia, not biological inheritance. Apparently in the politically correct (brave?) new world, we are not allowed to say part-Aboriginal.

According to the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, any level of biological Aboriginality makes a person Aboriginal. This seems to me a bit racist, which might explain why Hitler had a similar idea about Jews.

Presumably Ghengis Khan and his mob were into rape as well as pillage and murder, so, six or seven hundred years later, most of the population of Eastern Europe probably has a Mongol ancestor. Does that make them Mongol? Twenty generations from now, a majority of Australians will probably have an Aboriginal ancestor.

TALK.START.PARA: —This article sets out the myths that persist about Aborigines. If in the native title or Mabo case it had have been proven that native title existed all around Australia, the government could have legislated around the situation. The government is very quick to act when it is a tax matter. If the High Court decides on any tax scheme in favour of the taxpayer, the government runs down to the High Court the next day to get the decision reversed. It could have done that in this case. If there had been proof that natives or anyone else was dispossessed of anything, then there should have been compensation, and I would have had no argument about that.

PARA.TAB: In the short time I have left, I will talk about the point of view of Western Australia. Western Australia is vastly different in this situation. The government can argue as much as it likes, the Greens—who are supposed to represent WA—can argue as much as they like, and the Democrats can say what they like because I do not take any notice, but Western Australia is altogether different. It is well known that 40 per cent of WA is up for grabs. That 40 per cent includes some of the pastoral areas, all the mining areas and all vacant crown land, which includes all unexplored areas. This legislation says that mining leases do not extinguish native title, but native title can be put into place at the end of the lease. The lease can expire halfway through a mining venture.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it can be renewed.

—It can expire. I have experience with the mining industry and Senator Crowley obviously has not. On 30 June of any year a mining lease may come up for renegotiation, even though the mine is still operating and probably employing 1,000 people. The closure of a mine on the termination of a lease does not mean the end of the resources. I am old enough to have seen the Yilgarn goldfield of Western Australia rise and fall four times. In my father's time, it would have done that another three times. There is a boom, a bust, a boom and a bust. If during one of those busts the land reverted to native title, then I believe those resources would be shut up forever.

PARA.TAB: If we add to the 40 per cent of pastoral leases that are claimable those pastoral leases that Senator Boswell has said are suspect, it comes to around 78 per cent. I am not fully convinced that pastoral leases are safe. Mr Simon Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, was not able to give a full undertaking to the House of Representatives during the debate there. Pastoral leases are not safe while this bill allows them to be converted to native title after purchase by ATSIC. ATSIC is buying a lot of the pastoral areas in the Kimberleys in Western Australia; it is paying for them, and it is quite entitled to do it. I add that it is getting those stations very cheaply because of the unfortunate economic situation of the cattle industry in that area, a lot of it caused by drought. This bill will allow pastoral areas to be changed to native title, which will head the pastoral industry towards extinguishment. I suppose that this fits in with the secret agenda of the Kimberley Land Council in Western Australia. There are other agendas there, such as the burn-out policy, and some station owners have to sell out.

The stakes in Western Australia are very high. Western Australia provides 25 per cent of Australia's exports. It is easy for other states to take a relaxed approach to this, as Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland have. Hopefully, with a Liberal government now, South Australia will be a little different. I believe that not a square metre of Victoria could be claimed under native title, but I note that Mr Kennett has seen the light and is supporting the Western Australian position. The Northern Territory is already beyond this legislation because of the Land Rights Act.

Western Australia stands to lose a great deal. The value of Western Australian mineral production was $12 billion in 1991-92 and the industry paid $344.881 million to government in that year. The mineral trade gave Western Australia a $10.49 billion trade surplus in 1991-92, underpinning a 2.4 per cent gross product against national growth of 0.4 per cent. The mining industry has the highest productivity of any Australian industry, with output per employee being five times that of manufacturing. Over 40 per cent of national mineral exports are produced in Western Australia. In the last decade, private mineral exploration has risen to almost 60 per cent of the total spent in all states. Approximately 36,600 people are directly employed in mining in Western Australia, making up 4.8 per cent of the work force.

Let us look at the Western Australian legislation to see what the Court government has done to protect Western Australia. Its major aims are to ensure that the administration of Western Australian land and its natural resources stay in the control of the state; to provide certainty of land title for existing and future titleholders, which includes Aborigines; and to be part of a wide approach involving strategies to improve the health standard of Aborigines, about which I have spoken time and again in this place because I am at the coalface on that issue. The federal legislation we are debating today will not provide any of that. Western Australia had to produce its own legislation, and I congratulate the Court government for having the intestinal fortitude to do it. This legislation will only cause uncertainty.
The minister's adviser can smile as much as he likes. When he is elected to parliament he can have his say, but I think that he should remain neutral while I am speaking on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know what I have been speaking to the adviser about. It is very presumptuous of you.

—I know what I am talking about. In Western Australia, indeed all over Australia, exploration is moving offshore. For the people who do not believe me, an article in yesterday's Australian headed `Mabo-shy CRA looks offshore' states:

SPEECH.PARA: CRA Ltd will increase its overseas mineral exploration spending by more than 50 per cent to escape the full impact of the Government's native title legislation . . .

I do not have to incorporate that because it is there for everyone to see. That is what this legislation is doing. We are losing exploration money in Australia, along with badly needed jobs and exports.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Aborigines are amongst the most disadvantaged groups in Australia. In the late 1980s the jobless rate was six times that of the national average. That was brought down to three times the national average by the government's CDEP scheme as a stunt to take them off unemployment, but the figures are still there. Aborigines still receive less than other Australians. Child mortality is three times that of other Australians. It is regrettable that this situation exists in the 1990s, but we will not do anything whatsoever about that with this legislation. While it is regrettable that this exists, it is also regrettable that some Aborigines are not doing more, as a lot of them are, to improve their own situation. Former Senator Walsh referred to that in his article.

Expenditure of $1.3 billion a year is being thrown around, compared with only $24 million in 1971, yet among Aborigines we still have alcoholism, high rates of imprisonment and substandard housing. Mabo will not do anything about this. City-based Aboriginals—66,000 of them—will get nothing out of this. The land acquisition fund may help. If we had a land acquisition bill to put aside money to acquire land I would support it. Where do we go from here? Keating's Redfern's speech caused excessive expectations, which Lois O'Donoghue—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Panizza, you will use the Prime Minister's correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do that. I thought I said `the Prime Minister'. The Prime Minister's speech caused excessive expectations. Lois O'Donoghue put out a list which I will refer to in the committee stage or on the motion for the third reading. The government has been quoting in this debate my friends Ian Viner and Fred Chaney, and also Peter Durack this morning. They are good friends of mine, fine gentlemen and fine politicians, but I believe that I have one advantage over the three of them. Mr Graeme Campbell from the other House, former Senator Peter Walsh and I have been at the coalface of this matter and those others have not. One day we have to determine the definition of `Aboriginal' and see who can claim and who cannot.

PARA.TAB: As I said, reconciliation should not be confused with Mabo. The Mabo legislation should have been totally different. I do not have to take part in any reconciliation. If I have to take part in reconciliation with anyone—whether it be the minister, you, Mr Acting Deputy President, Aborigines or anyone else—it means that I have had a fight with them. I have had no fight with any Aborigines. I have had a lot to do with Aborigines, and I believe that it is time I put some home truths on the record. My father started employing Aborigines in the 1940s when he got stock. We have had no arguments with Aborigines.

I have had a lot to do with Aborigines in Kalgoorlie, Derby, Perth and Southern Cross, where I put up. I say to the people of this place and any other place who call me a racist that I have employed Aborigines, as my father did. I have played sport with them; I have associated with them. Up to 35 years ago I had Aborigines at my dinner table, long before it was politically correct to be doing things like that. In 1968 I had the pleasure of escorting an Aboriginal bride to the altar because her father could not be there. It was not taken to be politically correct 27 years ago, but I was proud to do it. I ask those who call me a racist to think about that. I believe that I and probably one other senator on the other side of the chamber have put up with more racist taunts in our lives than anyone else. I paid the supreme price for being called racist many years ago, but I will tell the Senate about that later.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Native Title Bill and in doing so I would like to congratulate the people involved with its development, in particular the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who gave so much of his own time to this issue. The Native Title Bill 1993 in part responds to the High Court Mabo decision but overwhelmingly it addresses a wrongdoing that has been part of this country's history, certainly since European settlement. It addresses the removal of a fundamental right in respect of property ownership—a right that we all hold near and dear to our hearts and a right we have all come to expect will be protected. Sadly, our forebears did not necessarily recognise that right in respect of the indigenous people of this country. We are now at a point in time where we have an opportunity to address that, albeit only in part.

PARA.TAB: This bill will mean many things to many people. Some will believe that it creates problems for industry, whether it be mining, farming or indeed any other industry. Some people will believe that it creates unequal rights. I suppose Aboriginal people could probably say that it does not go far enough. But, regardless of all those issues, we simply cannot ignore the truth of the past. The Native Title Bill—I am not going to pretend that I know it all or understand all of the clauses within it—has some 238 clauses and is set out in a way, in my view, that seeks to ensure a minimum of difficulty with respect to dealing with the principal issue: native title.

The bill provides us with the opportunity to allow the indigenous people of this country to have claims in respect of native title heard and determined. It also provides protection in respect of current land tenure, grants and other land allocations. It also provides for compensation where there may be some effect on current land-holders regardless of how that land was granted.
The unfortunate thing about this bill is the way many people have approached the issue since the bill was introduced. Many people have sought to conduct a scare campaign or a misinformation campaign—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just an information campaign.

—A misinformation campaign. I would like to take the opportunity to address the approach of the opposition in particular, because I think it is very important, particularly Senator Hill's contribution last evening—or, should I say, earlier this morning. In addressing the opposition's approach to this bill I go in the first instance to the speech made at the second reading stage by Dr Hewson. In respect of this bill he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a bill that addresses fundamentally important issues for Australian society. It relates to the rights and future entitlements of all Australians—I emphasise `all Australians'—as citizens of an undivided nation. It relates to the importance of land to Australia's indigenous people . . .

With respect to that statement alone, it is my view that this bill does not seek to address the rights of all Australians. It seeks to address a right for the indigenous people of this country. It seeks to address a right that was taken away from them a long time ago. Dr Hewson went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Let me be very clear at the outset. We on this side of the House accept the existence of native title as declared by the High Court . . .

SPEECH.PARA: If the opposition does that, then it is very difficult for me to accept that it would then turn around and not support this bill and, indeed, go on to say things like this:

PARA.TAB: There is only one criterion that is relevant in determining whether this legislation deserves to be supported, and that is: is it in Australia's national interest?

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I would have to say that this bill is not about Australia's national interest. It is about addressing a wrongdoing of the past. It is about addressing the right, as I said earlier, that we have all come to know and respect and expect. Dr Hewson also said:
That means, is it in the interest of all Australians, indigenous and non-indigenous?
Again, I think it is a contradiction in terms with respect to exactly what this bill is about. He then went on to say:

PARA.TAB: We will be voting against such legislation for one basic reason: it is bad legislation for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, it is not legislation for Australia; it is legislation to address a wrongdoing of the past. Even though we can only ever partly achieve such an objective because we have to recognise that this country has changed over the last 200-odd years, the bill seeks to address a very specific issue. Dr Hewson went on to say:

PARA.TAB: One of the greatest myths created by the government about this legislation is that it is presented as some kind of panacea for Aboriginal and Islander disadvantage. The fact is that it is nothing of the kind. Anyone who has seen at first hand the living conditions and the lack of opportunity in so many Aboriginal and Islander communities will know that a nation such as Australia should never tolerate such a situation. Standards of health, education, life expectancy, infant disease and infection, and many more issues affecting Aboriginals and Islanders, remain totally unacceptable when compared to the standards and conditions enjoyed by other Australians. None of these problems will be addressed by this legislation. This legislation will do nothing about Aboriginal and Islander health. It will do nothing about their education. It will do nothing about their welfare and living conditions. The bill is no shortcut to overturning a legacy of disadvantage and neglect.

SPEECH.PARA: He is dead right, because it does not seek to do that. It never did. With respect to normal day-to-day issues, why should we talk about Aboriginal or indigenous people as though they were different from us? We should not.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what we have been saying.

—Honourable senators on the opposite side of the chamber may make that point with respect to this government and the issues that are confronting the indigenous people, but this bill is not about that. It has never been about that. It is about a totally different issue. That is where the opposition has simply not come to grips with this issue.

PARA.TAB: I could not address the comments of Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition, without addressing the comments of Mr Reith, the opposition's Mabo man.

TALK.START.PARA: —So far you have spent all your speech telling us what Hewson said. You might as well finish it by telling us what Reith said.

—It is really the critical issue because members of the opposition made the point that they will not support the bill. They complained about the fact that there are 30 amendments, that they are not prepared to discuss them, et cetera. I think it is important to look at what the leaders of the opposition have said about this bill and what they believe it does. Mr Reith said:

PARA.TAB: This bill is not going to unite Australians; this bill is going to divide Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly.

—Senator Panizza might say `Exactly'. Because of the attitude that he demonstrates on that side of the chamber, that may be a possibility; because of the campaign of misinformation and misunderstanding—of not even accepting what this bill is about—he is creating that very problem. He is seeking to do it because he does not know how to deal with this issue.

PARA.TAB: Despite all the criticisms that we get from the opposition as to how we have approached this bill—the fact that we have not consulted, et cetera—at least we have put up legislation. The coalition, through Senator Hill last night, said, `We haven't got the 30 amendments so therefore we can't consider the bill'. When questioned about where the opposition's amendments were, if those opposite were going to debate this legislation, he said they did not have any because they did not have the 30 amendments—they had not had time to consider the issues. Mr Reith said:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has given the issue very careful consideration over a long period. Initially, we broadly endorsed the government's program of consultation.
Then Mr Court and people from one or two other Liberal states spoke to Mr Reith and his position evidently changed. He went on to say:
In summary we said that all Australians should be treated equally under the law . . .

That is right, but we started off with an unequal position in respect of the indigenous people of this country, and as I have to keep repeating, because obviously the opposition does not understand this point, this is about rectifying that. It is not about their health, their education or anything else; it is about rectifying a problem that has existed historically in this country. In addressing the details of the bill, Mr Reith said:

PARA.TAB: Before commenting on some of the details of the bill, I want to say something about our first pillar of principle: the recognition of rights.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know how he can say that on the one hand and, on the other, say, as Dr Hewson did, that the bill is about health, education and every other sundry day-to-day item that affects us all, because it is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be.

—It should not be. That really shows the total lack of understanding of Senator Ian Macdonald. This country has a health policy, an education policy and other policies that address day-to-day issues, and they should apply equally to all Australians, be they indigenous or otherwise, and they do. This government's approach is to ensure that they do. Therefore, this bill is not about those issues. If it was about education or addressing problems in that area, we would do that. Mr Reith went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Political parties that promote the private ownership of property and the freedom of the individual must be in the forefront of protecting property rights.
Mr Reith is right. He went on:

Of course, governments can acquire private property but only if they pay compensation and only if they do not discriminate against any citizen or group of citizens. So rights, and in this case property rights, are fundamentally important to Western democratic liberal societies like Australia.

PARA.TAB: I look at this way: some people say that Mabo is a distraction from Australia's real problems of economic mismanagement and particularly high unemployment. Nothing could be further from the truth. The real issues in our society are how we treat each other—how we treat the unemployed, the disadvantaged and our Aboriginal citizens. The weight of evidence suggests that, where citizens enjoy rights and respect the rights of others, those circumstances best foster economic success.

The consequence of this logic is that, to promote material wellbeing, our first priority must be to ensure that our people to people relationships are well-founded. In other words, we have to confront first the rights issues. This approach to rights issues is relevant to the Mabo debate and, for that reason, when canvassing the arguments for and against a referendum on native title in the Canberra Times back on 13 August 1993, I made the point—

SPEECH.PARA: and this is a very important point because this, again, shows the dissension amongst those in the Liberal Party with regard to this issue. Mr Reith then recounted what he had said:
Needless to say no referendum should displace the need to pay compensation in appropriate cases.

Of course, Senator Bishop, who took a very divisive approach to this issue, said that we should have a referendum on it. Of course, we all know what the results of that would be, given the type of campaign that would be conducted in respect of native title. Mr Reith went on to say:
In Adelaide in October, I said:
. . . all Australians, including Aboriginal Australians, are entitled to the enjoyment and protection of their property rights . . .

I accept that, but it is obviously not the position of the opposition now. What they are saying is that they will not support this legislation. In fact, they do not even want to debate it; that is their position. Mr Reith went on to say:
In other words, we have to respect each other's rights.
I agree with that. He continued:

The issue then is to define those rights. No-one questions the legitimacy of the High Court per se. I have made it quite clear that, personally, I do not think the High Court should have overturned the acknowledged law—

On the one hand, Mr Reith says that he supports rights, and then turns around and says that he does not think the High Court should have overturned acknowledged law. But it did so, and its decision is now the law. It has defined rights, and those rights must be respected. I say: good to that, because that is exactly what we should be seeking to do.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the bill is now to be debated in the Senate. Early this morning, I think it was, Senator Hill raised the issue of amendments. I have not been here very long but when we were debating the industrial relations legislation Senator Hill raised the question of amendments as well as the question of time—the time needed to debate this bill, the time needed to consider it to the fullest extent to enable an appropriate result to occur.

Those of us on this side of the chamber who sat through the hours and hours of diatribe about the industrial relations legislation have to wonder just how genuine the opposition is in respect of any issue. During the course of the industrial relations debate we went on for hours with a whole load of rhetoric about nothing. None of the opposition's amendments were of any real substance, other than to defeat the industrial relations bill. We heard rhetoric about how the legislation would ruin the economy of the country and create further unemployment, et cetera. All those claims, all that rhetoric is being contradicted by reports in the press, and we can read them daily.

Then, coming back to Senator Hill, he says, `Well, we haven't got time to consider the Native Title Bill because it's just being rammed down our throats'. I say to Senator Hill that he has had a lot of opportunity. Had he dealt with other legislation that has come before this chamber in a more appropriate way and not wasted so much time, he would have probably given himself some time to actually develop some amendments if he has certain concerns about certain aspects of this bill.

I hope we will get on and debate this issue and it will be done in a positive way, because it is about time that we addressed this fundamental issue of the historic wrongdoing that has existed with us for so long. I urge honourable senators to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those of us on this side of the chamber cannot support the Native Title Bill as it stands. We are yet to see the amendments that the government may seek to move in the committee stage, but there are very good grounds why we on this side of the chamber cannot support the bill that has been brought before us. Those grounds start with the basic assumption of the equality of all Australians. Senator Murphy has just spent 20 minutes exercising the collective guilt of Australia over the last 200 years, as though those on the other side of the chamber are the sole repository of morality and conscience in this country.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps it is a useful start for the consideration of this matter to look at the track record of those on the other side of this chamber in terms of matters of racial discrimination and treatment of Aborigines and see where the guilt may lie. The guilt for many of the wrongdoings in Australia's past, not just against Aborigines but also against other Australians, lies with the Labor Party and the achievements of the Labor Party. I say that as somebody who is half Chinese.

It was the Labor Party that formulated, refined and perfected the most racist immigration policy the world has ever seen—it was called the white Australia policy. It was the Labor Party that consistently maintained that white Australia policy irrespective of the detriment to the people affected. When Singapore was under imminent threat of Japanese occupation, Arthur Calwell, then minister for immigration—one of the great leading lights of the Labor Party—dillied and dallied for weeks, not wanting to allow people of mixed race, Chinese and Malays, to flee Singapore. This was notwithstanding the fact that to prevent those people leaving meant that they would at best be interned in places like Changi and at worst be taken out and summarily executed. It is an interesting point that one of the people who was taken out for summary execution, who was machine-gunned on a beach in Singapore and survived, was in fact Lee Kwan Yew.

It was Arthur Calwell who, after the war when there were only 8,000 people in this country of Chinese extraction, rammed through parliament the wartime refugee repatriation bill, which sought to expel 800 Asiatics, as he referred to them, on the basis that to allow just 800 to stay would undermine the whole basis of Australia's established immigration policy. That is the bona fides of those on the other side of the chamber.

The post-war election was fought in part on the racist immigration policy of the Labor Party, on its racist white Australia policy, and that is why it was thrown out after the war and why it did not return until 1972. I was born in 1965; I was born in the days of the white Australia policy. I grew up with the racism of the Labor Party. I grew up with `Two wongs don't make a white'. I know all about it. But that is the past. If we bring up the next generations of Australians with the guilt, the burden and the chip on the shoulder that previous generations ought to bear, then we do not progress this country one iota.

If we bring up future generations of Australians to believe that they have a never-ending guilt for what may or may not have happened 200 years ago, then we do not bring them up to be fit citizens for the 20th or 21st century; we bring them up in the 18th and 19th centuries. That is what we do.

Let us make one other point clear. Many things were done over the last 200 years to Aboriginal people and others and not all of them have been bad. Even the things that those on the other side complain of as wrong were in many cases done with the best intentions. I do not think one can say that the missionaries who went out to areas like the Cape York Peninsula, outback Queensland and outback New South Wales did it with bad intentions. They did it with what were then good intentions, but we look with hindsight and we look with different eyes. That is why we on this side of the chamber reject the notion that there should be a never-ending guilt to burden generation upon generation of Australians, because that should not be the way in which this country develops.

So much for the overview of the Labor Party's right to talk about who is right and who is wrong in this debate. So much for its right to lecture us on morality. We know all about morality. We know that it was the Labor Party, for example, in Queensland that put in the most pernicious and discriminatory laws against Aborigines, which were repealed after 1957 when the coalition took government. We know all those things. That is the limit of the Labor Party's right to talk about conscience and morality.

We are now here to talk about the Native Title Bill. Looking at this bill, one could, in good conscience, do nothing but oppose this bill. Senator Murphy, for example, challenged us on this side of the chamber saying, `Do you as the coalition support the Mabo High Court decision?'. We have said that we recognise and accept the High Court decision. He said, `If you do, why do you not support this bill?'. We do not support this bill because this bill is not the Mabo High Court decision. This bill is the Mabo High Court decision plus the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at Redfern, plus plus plus.

This bill seeks to extend the bounds of the Mabo High Court decision. It seeks to create opportunities to extend that decision and to extend the challenges that decision poses to all Australians. But in particular this bill seeks to facilitate a wholesale grab by the Commonwealth of the land management functions which are constitutionally and correctly the province of the states and the territories. That is why we cannot support this bill. This bill is about a grab for power by Canberra and yet this bill does very little to improve the rights of Aborigines.

This bill has been the subject of great misrepresentation, but the great misrepresentations about this bill have not come from our side of the chamber; they have not come from the National Party or the Liberal Party. They have come from the other side of the chamber. They have come from individuals in the other place, most notably the Prime Minister.

The Prime Minister and the government have said to the primary industries of Australia, `You are protected under this bill'. They have said to them, `Your properties, your farms, your stations are protected under this bill'. Yet when one delves into this bill one finds that is anything but the case. Let people understand one thing about what is protected by this bill. The only grants of land which are protected by this bill are grants of land which are invalid because of the existence of native title. In 3 1/2 days of hearings, I did not hear one clear explanation of what that meant. The best we can seem to gather is that the principal cause of invalidity for issues of grants of land will be the Racial Discrimination Act.

So the clearest argument is that the only grants of land which are protected by this bill are grants of land which were issued in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act, and therefore cannot include any grants of land issued before 1975. As most of the pastoral properties, most of the farms and most of the stations in this country are based on leases that were issued before 1975, they do not attract the protection of any of the provisions of this bill.

The right to renewal which is claimed to be protected for post-1975 invalid leases is not protected in this bill because the wording of the two relevant clauses is different. So we have one regime for pre-1975 grants of land and one regime for post-1975 grants of land. But the only things that are protected are the invalid, not the valid.

Of course, the other side of the chamber could argue that the Mabo High Court decision said, by three judges to two, that native title appears to be extinguished by a valid grant of leasehold. But this bill does not do anything to confirm the fact that those valid grants of leasehold interest or other interests should be allowed to continue. This bill does nothing about those. In fact, what it does, by dint of bad drafting, is jeopardise the right of renewal for those previously issued pastoral leases.

Let me start with Western Australia. Leaving aside the Court legislation, looking just at this bill and assuming that Western Australia adopted exactly the same regime as this one, by virtue of section 202 of the Western Australian land act, the holder of a pastoral lease is obliged to make continual improvements to the pastoral property. Those improvements, to the extent that they constitute fencing the property and certain other actions, would affect the rights of native titleholders. Irrespective of the right to renew, there would be a problem, because the right to renew is subject to the interests of native titleholders. For the purposes of considering a renewal, the rights of native titleholders are deemed not to be the right to collect firewood, not to be the right to hunt and gather, and not to be the right to fish; they are deemed to be the rights of freeholders.

It is an elementary matter of law that the crown cannot grant a leasehold interest in favour of one person over the top of what is a freehold interest on the part of another person. So, by virtue of this bill, because the renewal of validly issued pastoral leases after 1 January 1994 becomes a future act under this bill, and the operation of section 202 of the Western Australian land act, we have the absurd situation that, even if the West Australian government wanted to adhere to this legislation, it would appear that many pastoral leases will not be able to be renewed by operation of this bill.

In other states, too, we have problems with the renewal of pastoral leases. Those problems revolve around the fact that, for example, in Queensland there is no such thing as a legally enforceable right to renew. One merely has a right to apply for the renewal of a lease. As the minority report of the legal and constitutional affairs committee showed, in Queensland there is a working procedural instruction that advises that when a lease, even if it is a grazing homestead perpetual lease, comes up for surrender, a new lease is to be issued in its place and the previous lease is deemed to have been expired—extinguished—for the purposes of the bill.

That means that the application to renew a pastoral lease or a forestry lease becomes, in effect, a future act. The granting of that lease becomes a future act. Nothing in this bill gives any protection at all to the lessee. Nothing in this bill gives any protection at all to the farmer. Nothing in this bill gives any protection at all to the pastoralist or to the grazier. This bill pitches them into an uncertain void because they are open to challenge by punitive native title claimants who say, `We have native title over this land and it has coexisted with the valid pastoral lease'. It will matter not one jot before the law that that farmer says, `But the High Court argued three to two this way on a matter of obiter dictum'. As long as the native title claimants assert that they have a right to native title, it pitches the person whose lease is being renewed into a legal struggle to get that lease renewed. A very thoughtful opinion dated 13 December 1993 prepared by Messrs Blake Dawson Waldron for the Australian Mining Industry Council said that if there is a future decision about coexistence of native title, we have a very difficult situation indeed. The opinion states:

SPEECH.PARA: Renewal of existing interests, where there is no legally enforceable right to renew. Only after a determination of invalidity will the renewal be able to take place—if valid, the Bill may impede or prevent renewal altogether.

This is what this bill has done. Yet the Prime Minister told the primary industries of this country that our farms, our pastoral properties and our stations were safe. That is nothing, at best, but the grossest misrepresentation and it is doing nothing but selling the primary industries of this country an uncertain future by telling them that their future was safe.

PARA.TAB: This bill creates a difficult regime for our fishing industry because it says that native title claimants can make a claim in respect of land or waters. Waters, in so far as they are onshore waters, would appear to include everything within the state jurisdiction and that is, three miles out from the low watermark. That may seem to be a trifling matter; it is a serious matter if that is how onshore waters are defined for the purposes of this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be all Torres Strait.

—Torres Strait is a big problem, but what is an even bigger problem, as Senator Boswell will be aware, is the problem created on the Great Barrier Reef. All the papers that have been prepared in relation to native title claims over territorial waters—for example, the paper prepared by the Attorney-General's Department, `The Constitutional Law Reform Session No. 1, Mabo: Implications for the Commonwealth'—refer to the operation of international law and matters of state jurisdiction.

PARA.TAB: If we refer to international law, and if it is used for the basis of native title claims—and there seems to be a body of thought that it should be—the relevant case to look at is the Norwegian fisheries case which was decided in the International Court of Justice in 1951 between the UK and Norway. That said that for the purposes of drawing baselines—and baselines are very important for this whole matter—we had to look to what were called drying rocks, that is, rocks or reefs that were exposed at the low watermark. As Senator Boswell well knows, and as other honourable senators from Queensland well know, large chunks of the Great Barrier Reef are exposed at the low watermark. If we draw a three-mile line from one drying rock to the next drying rock along the Great Barrier Reef, we will have an almost contiguous stretch of water which will be subject to native title claims.

The importance of that is that, in so far as native title applies to waters, it applies to the bed under the water. That would restrict the operation of the tourism industry; it could quite clearly restrict the operation of the fishing industry. So this bill does nothing to provide certainty for the fishing or tourism industries.

This bill does nothing to provide certainty for the forestry industry, because the forestry leases upon which the industry relies may well be—by the admission of the government's advisers at the hearing on Monday last week—category D past acts, which do not extinguish native title. That is notwithstanding the fact that the Prime Minister told the National Association of Forestry Industries that it also was safe.

Who is safe under this bill? It appears that the farmers are not safe from claim, it appears that our fishing industries are not safe and that our tourism industry is not safe. It now appears that our forestry industry is also not safe. Nobody is safe under this bill. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is amazing that Senator O'Chee can always manage to include a note of unctuous sanctimony into almost every speech that he gives. He has done it this time in trying to compare Labor's attitude towards race with the attitude of his own party. He talked of the racist nature of former ALP policies and I agree with him. I am not proud of those policies, but they were set at a time which was quite different from this. I remind Senator O'Chee that, unlike his party, we have corrected and changed them.

PARA.TAB: I also remind Senator O'Chee that the coalition was in government from 1949 to 1972, which is a period of 23 years; that is the period for which he was criticising the Labor Party for its racist policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a fool.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! I do not believe it is parliamentary for somebody to call an honourable senator a fool. I ask Senator O'Chee to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President. I withdraw. I get very frustrated when people do not understand what I am saying.

—I remind Senator O'Chee that the coalition was in government during this period related to which he was criticising the then opposition's policies. We did not have the power to do anything about it, even if we had the will. For those 23 years, the coalition was applying the white Australia policy, of which none of us should be proud.
—We abolished the white Australia policy.
—It was only in the late 1960s that you abolished it.
—We fought against the wartime attitudes. You didn't have the guts to take the initiative, did you? You didn't have the guts. You're lily-livered.
—Senator O'Chee, I ask you to contain yourself.

—I remind Senator O'Chee about the unseemly behaviour of one of the coalition's ministers as recently as 1989. I refer to John Howard who, for purely political reasons, began to unearth the prejudices which are seldom far beneath the surface in Australian politics in an attack on immigrants. He tried to set Australian against Australian—immigrant Australians against Australians who had been here for longer.

PARA.TAB: I am absolutely amazed at Senator O'Chee's gall in criticising the Queensland Labor government's attitudes towards race when he is part of the same party as Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, who treated Aboriginals with scarcely disguised contempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. There must be some truth in a statement made by a senator.
—Senator Boswell, what is your point of order?
—My point of order is that the contribution being made by Senator Beahan is grossly untruthful. He does not know what he is saying. No man treated Aboriginals better than Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen.
—Order! Senator Boswell, there is no point of order.
—I will leave honourable senators to judge Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's attitude towards Aboriginals.

PARA.TAB: The High Court's Mabo decision has occupied much of this parliament's time in the last six months. In one respect it has raised the level of political literacy—although some of the contributions opposite are not showing that—in Australia in a way that no public education program could have achieved. Millions of Australians who perhaps had never heard of the High Court, or perhaps only remembered visiting the building near the lake, now know how important its role is in our constitutional and legal system.

There will be other High Court decisions which will affect Australians more and pose problems for government.
