For example, the recent decision on the validity of state franchise taxes might have been one, although the High Court showed a keen sense of pragmatism in avoiding conflict by having two bob each way. However, no decision since the Communist Party Dissolution Act judgment 40 years ago has attracted more public and media comment, informed or otherwise, than the Mabo decision.

Various commentators have suggested that the High Court's decision was some sort of departure from normal judicial reasoning or standards. It is said that the High Court engaged in law making, judicial activism or social engineering. All this is to be condemned, so the critics say.

The reality is that every court makes law from time to time. It is often the failure of legislatures to address important issues that makes citizens turn to the courts for redress. Sometimes those legislative failures are due to the inability of elected governments to get their legislation through malapportioned or gerrymandered state upper houses like those of Western Australia and Tasmania.

Indeed, it is an irony that the colleagues of those opposite in the Western Australian Legislative Council blocked Labor's original land rights legislation which had the support of the mining and pastoral interests of WA in the mid-1980s. That legislation, if passed, would have satisfied Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people and given Western Australian legislation which might have served as a model for other states. The political blindness which afflicted the WA branch of the Liberal Party on Aboriginal matters at that time unfortunately continues today.

When the High Court was confronted with the Mabo claim it was given the opportunity to clarify legal uncertainty. Up until Mabo, the generally accepted conventional wisdom was that Australian law did not recognise the concept of native title. In the early 1970s Aborigines in the Northern Territory had raised similar issues before its Supreme Court in the Nabalco case. Mr Justice Blackburn stated quite clearly that the doctrine of common law native title had no place in a settled colony unless recognised by an act of parliament. The Nabalco case was a disappointment for Aboriginal people all over Australia. However, in a few years, thanks to the commitment of the Whitlam and, I have to say, the Fraser governments, a fair and equitable land rights regime had been established in the Northern Territory.

Legislative success in the territory, followed later by the recognition of Aboriginal land claims in some other states, reduced the focus on the question of native title for many Aboriginal people. However, some lawyers were doing their homework. They were looking at how other jurisdictions such as Canada, New Zealand and the United States had addressed the issue of native title. The Privy Council, as the ultimate appeal court for many former British colonies, had also dealt with the question.

This research revealed that native title was a recognised principle in all common law jurisdictions and had been for some time. In 1823 Chief Justice Marshall of the United States Supreme Court said the `original habitants' should be recognised as having `a legal as well as a just claim to retain the occupancy of their traditional lands.'

The English common law, as stated in numerous Privy Council cases this and last century, also recognised this principle. Indeed, in 1973 Sir Garfield Barwick, Chief Justice of the High Court, said that the `traditional result' of British occupation or settlement was that `the indigenous people were secure in their usufructuary title to land' and that `the ultimate title subject to usufructuary title was vested in the Crown.' The court was dealing with a Papua New Guinea case but it had clearly recognised that, at least in PNG, native title existed.

With this depth of precedent from respected courts of the English-speaking world, it was unlikely our own High Court would fail to acknowledge this line of authority if and when the question was put to it. Despite some Australian cases which had failed to acknowledge the existence of native title at common law, there was enough authority to the contrary to place those judgments in doubt. The High Court did not lightly discard those previous authorities. As Chief Justice Brennan said:

SPEECH.PARA: In discharging its duty to declare the common law of Australia, this Court is not free to adopt rules that accord with contemporary notions of justice and human rights if their adoption would fracture the skeleton of principle which gives the body of our law its shape and internal consistency . . .
Despite the need to adhere to local precedent, the chief justice, when referring to previous decisions denying native title, said:

. . . no case can command unquestioning adherence if the rule it expresses seriously offends the values of justice and human rights (especially equality before the law) which are aspirations of the contemporary Australian legal system.

The skeleton of principle of our Australian common law has not been fractured by the Mabo decision. Indeed, the recognition of native title rights by our High Court has released a few skeletons out of our national closet and confronted us with some hard choices and decisions. A few spectres have also been conjured up by some of the people opposite.

PARA.TAB: One of those decisions is how to address the impact of Mabo on other land users. The reality is that Mabo will have little impact on most Australians—Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal. Most Aboriginal people have ceased to enjoy any traditional relationship with their former land. Most non-Aboriginal Australians occupy land over which any native title interests were extinguished long ago.

The question is: how do we devise a system where rights of use and occupation of remaining land can be enjoyed for the benefit of all Australians? That is a question which this bill addresses. In contrast, the government in Western Australia has, from the outset, attempted to deny the validity of the High Court's decision and its recent legislation, rushed through parliament in a blur of all night sittings, purports to extinguish native title entirely.

It has replaced those rights with inferior rights of traditional usage, the enjoyment of which depends on ministerial whim and discretion. In contrast to the bill before us, it gives government ministers virtually total power to extinguish property rights with limited judicial review. If other property owners in Australia were subject to this sort of arbitrary and secret process in determining their rights over their land, those opposite would be among the first to complain. Instead, we see acquiescence and compliance by the Liberal Party with its WA branch in what I believe is the biggest property rort in our nation's history.

The WA legislation will no doubt be challenged in the High Court. While I do not underestimate the legal artwork that has gone into the WA act, even the smartest draftspersons have come undone before the High Court. We can but wait and see, but I would be very surprised if the High Court fails to see that the substance of the WA act deprives Aboriginal Western Australians of property rights and replaces them with inferior or worthless so-called traditional usage rights.

In contrast, the current bill is a moderate and reasonable attempt to reconcile conflicting rights to land. It reflects our common law traditions of respect for property, which the High Court decision reasserted. It asks only of governments like that of Western Australia to give the people of their state access to an independent tribunal to determine land title questions. That tribunal will be guided by the principle of the High Court's decision which ensures native titleholders' rights are respected.

At the same time, industry's interests are also respected. A mining company operating on vacant crown land will be able to go to a tribunal and ask it to decide whether native title exists over the land. The legislation allows for speedy determination of these issues and encourages dialogue and discussion between the parties.

Most mine operations in Western Australia occupy very little land and disturbance of the surface is frequently minimal. The mining industry is no stranger to negotiating with landowners, local and state governments, environment groups and, of course, its customers here and overseas. In my meetings with industry interests and in the flurry of letters and faxes from some mining lobby groups, there appears to be an irrational fear of having to negotiate with Aboriginal people.

I do not believe the mining industry is inherently racist and there is no doubt that, without the industry, Australia could not sustain its standard of living. However, I do think our industry can be excessively parochial and narrowly focused. When it can manage to get one state government to enact legislation like the WA act, which overturns Aboriginal rights in the most unconscionable way, one has to wonder whether the industry has it own interests at heart. What it has done is guarantee continuing instability.

What could be more designed to turn Australians further away from industry than the WA act? Ill-informed members of the environment lobby based in Sydney or Melbourne have long pilloried the mining and forestry industries in particular. Just when the work of companies such as Alcoa in WA is being recognised as making a substantial contribution to reafforestation measures throughout the world, the industry manages to get itself offside with most fair-minded Australians. I believe that the industry should also avoid any further dabbling with public opinion surveys, which any professional will tell you are designed to produce a particular result and are of propaganda value only. Some elements in the industry who are driven more by religious zealotry than reason are simply giving their opponents free kicks.

While groups such as the National Farmers Federation have worked within the Commonwealth system and have gained an understanding of its processes and are developing working relationships with people around the negotiating table, in WA, the mining industry will be pinning its hopes on Mr Court's late night legislation. I suspect, however, that this same mining industry is heading into a dead end with the Court Land (Titles and Traditional Uses) Act.

Alternatively, if the Senate fails to pass this bill, Australia will be left without a comprehensive process for dealing with the Mabo decision. The queues to the High Court will not get any shorter and the writs will pile up in the various state supreme courts. The patience of Aboriginal people seems inexhaustible but I doubt whether industry and those Australians employed in it will be as tolerant or understanding of further delays in dealing with this issue. I sense a desire in the public for all of us to get on with it, to establish a process and encourage parties to resolve differences. That is what this bill is all about for most Australians.

Surely it is not beyond those opposite to show some generosity of spirit, to welcome this long overdue decision by the High Court and to support the thoughtful and moderate response reflected in this bill; a response which does justice to the Mabo decision in protecting native title while, at the same time, ensuring a workable and certain land management system. I urge the Senate to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We stand at the brink of a moment of great change. Like the Racial Discrimination Act nearly 20 years ago, this bill signals our intent as the parliament of this nation to—before the whole world—put aside the oppression of our colonial past and move forward to owning our history and to forging a new partnership in this land of ours. I want to take a moment to quote a wonderfully wise indigenous Australian Mr Wenten Rubuntja who, like me, is a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia—it's a beautiful country—hasn't got war, hasn't got riots, just people talking. Now we've got to be talking together about living together. Might be two laws—but only one place, one country, one people. We've got to look to our grandchildren sharing this country. That's the road we have to find.

That is what native title is about. In the Mabo judgment, Justices Deane and Gaudron said that the destruction of Aboriginal society had left Australia with a `national legacy of unutterable shame'. Echoing an election promise made nearly 20 years before by Gough Whitlam they said that `the nation as a whole must remain diminished' until past injustices are acknowledged and retreated from.

PARA.TAB: So much of this debate has focused on whether or not particular comments or positions are racist, but it is important that we acknowledge that the main source of racism is not cultural difference in general but unequal power relations. While racism is expressed through prejudice, the purpose of the racist is not merely to vilify an outsider, but to reinforce the authority of one social group over another.

There has been a lot of rhetoric about the inevitability and the desirability of the dispossession of indigenous peoples since white settlement, but that is nothing more than justification of power plays based on race. Anyone who looks behind the rhetoric can see the simple truth, stretching right back to 1888, when Sir Henry Parkes declined to invite Aborigines to the centenary celebrations with the words `and remind them that we have robbed them?'.

It was for going behind the rhetoric and reminding us of this simple truth that the High Court has incurred such criticism in recent times. There is no denying that this rhetoric was founded on the lie of terra nullius and can be defended only by relying on an archaic and Eurocentric view of the world which denied responsibility for our real history. In the Mabo case, the High Court, to its credit, refused to do this. It refused to wash its hands of the truth in the name of precedent.

In early 1985, soon after the Hawke government dropped national legislation to enact land rights for all Aboriginal people, Justice Brennan reminded the political executive of its responsibility to ensure that rights and freedoms are shared by all Australians, whatever their racial group. I believe that men and women of goodwill in Australia in 1993 also believe that Aboriginal people are entitled to justice—not a justice that is qualified by the views of many of those in the opposition. Justice on their terms is where those with business interests have more rights than indigenous people and where land is nothing more than a tradeable commodity.

In 1974 the Woodward royal commission into Aboriginal land rights in the Northern Territory concluded that `the doing of simple justice to a people who have been deprived of their land without their consent and without compensation' requires both `preserving and strengthening all aboriginal interests in land . . . which exist today' and `the provision of some basic compensation . . . for those Aborigines who have been irrevocably deprived of the rights and interests which they would otherwise have inherited'.

Except for the Northern Territory, and except for the Pitjantjatjara lands of South Australia, this recommendation has been largely ignored. Until now, the Commonwealth has refused to use the overriding power it possesses to legislate for Aboriginal people, a power which Australian citizens gave it at the 1967 referendum. In February of 1975, shortly before the Racial Discrimination Act became law, the Senate unanimously passed a motion by former Liberal senator Neville Bonner—still the only Aboriginal elected to federal parliament—urging the government:

SPEECH.PARA: To admit prior ownership by the indigenous people and introduce legislation to compensate the peoples now known as Aboriginal and Torres Strait islanders.

It might be something of a record that it has taken us 18 years to respond to the context of that motion. I remind the Senate that it is a motion which the opposition voted for. So we have this legislation which begins to address the Senate's call—and, I believe, the community's even louder call—over the last 18 years for justice and reparation for Aboriginal Australians. But this Native Title Bill is only a beginning. It does not pretend to be anything more than that. Its purpose is to provide Australia with a means by which it can hear and determine native title claims and validate the interests of others who use and control land.

PARA.TAB: Native title is nothing more than a traditional right based on occupancy which continues after the imposition of colonial sovereignty. The Crown can extinguish title through any grant of land to settlers or any use of land which is consistent with continuing traditional occupation. While native title is recognised by common law, its nature is determined according to the traditional customs of the native titleholders. The crucial issue of the extinguishment or abolition of native title depends upon the interaction of customary and common law, particularly the way in which the former is perceived by the latter.

It is the case that Aboriginal title has disappeared over most of Australia, either because Aboriginal people have disappeared or lost their connection with the land, often in cruel and violent circumstances, or because the Crown has granted the land to other people or put it to uses inconsistent with native title. Most land in Australia is unaffected by the Mabo ruling and most Aboriginal people will not benefit directly from the ruling.

Despite the reprehensible scaremongering from some in the opposition, from some in the mining industry and from the Western Australian state government, people's backyards are not claimable under Mabo. A recent attempt by the Northern Territory media to deliberately confuse Australians by claiming that a case filed concerning some houses in a suburb of Darwin was somehow related to Mabo was spurious indeed. The claim was actually made under the heritage act. It may involve acts of bad faith on the part of the government in disposing of land some time ago, but it is not a native title claim. But it was an example of the upping of the ante on both sides of the debate which came from the original decision and the predictable responses to it.

The authority of the Mabo ruling rests not with the recognition of native title but flowing from the Racial Discrimination Act. It is imperative that in the process of validating existing titles, the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act, especially in relation to compensation, should prevail. At this stage the Democrats intend to move an amendment to clarify that, should there be any ambiguity in future time, the Racial Discrimination Act shall prevail because it provides protection for native title, and an overarching legislative and constitutional protection for that title is essential. It is essential to prevent capricious actions by state governments and, even in the foreseeable future, by the Commonwealth government itself.

The Mabo decision should have meant the recognition of bare legal rights for Aboriginal peoples and some attempt to provide redress for the 90 per cent of indigenous people who will not benefit from Mabo. That is why we believe that the social justice components which complement this bill are very important. Despite the desires of the opposition, we cannot separate native title from reconciliation. To do so displays a blatant lack of understanding of the special attachment that Aboriginal people have for land and that Torres Strait Islanders have for the sea. We cannot just say, `We are just going to deal with this and reconciliation can wait until we are finished'. Reconciliation is an ongoing process. How we respond to an understanding of special attachment to land is a measure of how we are performing our partnership as we move towards reconciliation. Because of this bill we are now in a position to give effect to rights and considerations long denied indigenous Australians.

Among the most unworthy contributions to the fear and hatred whipped up around this legislation, in my opinion, was that of Geoffrey Blainey. There are fundamental fallacies to the argument that Aborigines have too much land. One of the wonderful ironies of Australian history is that most Aboriginal land is land that was unwanted by colonial settlers. It is land that is located in the most remote, inhospitable and desert areas of the country. But we suddenly discovered mineral resources on those lands, and suddenly those lands, on which we forced Aboriginal people, became desirable in our cultural context.

Land rights in Australia can no longer be about largess, sympathy or guilt. They are now about recognition and restoration of legal rights. This bill is not about creating land rights; it is about recognising and restoring them. Unfortunately, the fact is that there are some in this country who simply do not want to share in a new partnership, who have never accepted that the 1967 referendum means that indigenous peoples are full citizens entitled to the same rights and protections under the law as anyone else. These rights extend to land ownership and a special type of land tenure which recognises the special attachment to Aboriginal people.

What is unique about this bill are the processes surrounding its birth. We had the High Court judgment and we had a year of consultation between the Commonwealth government and the states and territories.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not with WA.

—Senator Panizza keeps saying that, but I know for a fact that those consultations went on. They went on for a year; they went on until they broke down. I was very critical of the assumption that only the Commonwealth and state governments would have any stake in the outcome of native title legislation. I said that there should have been a round table. I had my own and I learnt a lot from it. Eventually the Prime Minister found that he had to consult more extensively with miners, the mining peak bodies, the tourism industry and with Aboriginal people directly.

PARA.TAB: There has been a lot of discussion over the legitimacy and the representative nature of various Aboriginal negotiators. I do not need to revisit some of the points I have made in the past on this matter, except to say—I think it needs to be on the public record—that the Aboriginal negotiating team, which includes ATSIC and also representatives of the so-called Aboriginal alliance, including Mr Michael Mansell, are all being consulted on the form and content of any amendments. Nobody is being deliberately excluded. It is on this matter of more extensive consultation, particularly as sought by the West Australian Greens, that I want to refer to the Sydney Morning Herald editorial of 11 December, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Native Title Bill is not perfect but the best way to iron out the problems with it now is by putting it into practice. Tinkering with the legislation to get it right, perfectly right, may destroy the whole initiative.

PARA.TAB: The fundamental flaw in the Greens' approach was highlighted by Mr Hal Wootten, QC, in an address to the Ted Noffs Foundation last week. Delay in voting on the bill now, said Mr Wootten, could not enable full consultation with all Aboriginal people or ever hope to produce general agreement on how the bill might be improved. Instead, it would raise false expectations and hopeless demands among the great majority of Aborigines who can't claim native title anyhow. Most importantly, Mabo has to be kept in perspective. "It is not a basis for a national land rights policy, let alone a general Aboriginal policy," argued Mr Wootten. And while such wider policies are important, he said, they "cannot be an excuse to deny protection to the rights of those who still have their land".

SPEECH.PARA: That is what some people are trying to hijack in this debate. It goes on:
But the risk is that the possible—
Goodness alone knows how difficult achieving the possible has been—
can be lost in hopeless pursuit of the perfect.

PARA.TAB: In his address to Aboriginal leaders last week Mr Keating said that if the Native Title Bill were to be defeated he "could not see in the foreseeable future, the immediate future, where you could, at a Commonwealth level, mount the same kind of bureaucratic, ministerial and political effort to provide the same, by way of statutory title". That isn't political rhetoric; it's political reality.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the political reality we have to deal with in this parliament and in this chamber at the moment. I cannot understand how members of the opposition or the Western Australian government can deny the political reality that this opportunity provides to indigenous Australians. It is a historic opportunity and it will not be revisited by the opposition should it win government at the next election. It is imperative that we embrace the seeds of justice that are embodied in this bill. The indigenous people of Australia have waited 204 years for recognition under white fellows' law of what their own laws have always known—that they too own and have a share in this land of ours.

PARA.TAB: As the Pope said, in recognition of reality, in Alice Springs in 1986:

SPEECH.PARA: What has been done cannot be undone. But what can now be done to remedy the deeds of yesterday must not be put off until tomorrow.

I argue strenuously that, after extensive debate in this chamber, we must not put off the passage of this bill. There will be amendments which improve the bill; that has always been a matter for negotiation. We must recognise the political reality with which this opportunity presents us and must seize it. We must move forward. That is why the Democrats support the passage of the Native Title Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel very overawed in having to address the Native Title Bill. At the outset I declare my interests. I proudly represent the Northern Territory electorate with a constituency that has a high Aboriginal representation—in fact, about 25 per cent of my electorate. I also stand here mindful of the fact that I have nephews and a niece who enjoy an Aboriginal heritage. Therefore, there is a close family interest and concern in this particular matter. I am also mindful of the fact that Aboriginal territorians have enjoyed native title since 1788 in one form or another, totally uninterrupted in fact and in lifestyle.

PARA.TAB: The debate that we must face today is crucial. I want to address it under three broad headings and considerations—what I term retrospective, introspective and prospective. Before the 1967 referendum on issues affecting Aboriginal affairs, there was an inadequate response throughout Australia to the issues of Aboriginality and the proper place of Aboriginal people in the Australian nation.

Since 1967 the debate has raged on a number of occasions and a number of times across a wide range of issues. They culminated in the 1976 Aboriginal Land Rights Act for the Northern Territory. That was a very historic and important occasion in this parliament. It followed various reports—the Gibb report and the Woodward report—of the early 1970s. Again, I remind this chamber that when that 1976 legislation was passed there had been inadequate public debate and consideration of the recommendations of both the Gibb report and the Woodward report of the early 1970s—rather similar to the tensions and demands about the debate and acceptance in the community at this time.

I look back at one of my own speeches which I made on 22 October 1975, when I was a member of the Northern Territory parliament, in the lead-up to the land rights legislation. In that speech I acknowledged that:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be wide-reaching social implications, not only to Aboriginal communities in their own right but also to the commercial, mining and environmental issues of the whole Northern Territory.
I said:

I am more particularly concerned that there will perhaps be a black back-lash. We can always anticipate perhaps a little white back-lash when an issue such as Aboriginal land rights comes up; we are all aware of the politics and the situations that cause that. But in this instance Aboriginal cultural interests in the Northern Territory are really being called into question.
In that same speech, I said:
I fully support land rights but I support this motion in that we must make sure that it is totally consistent with the requirements of the whole Northern Territory community.

I have not moved much from my basic position in 1975. Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that, in the debates here in 1989, 1990 and leading to the formation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, there was a lot of consideration about where we go in addressing this important issue.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to address the issues that arise in the various party political platforms. My own party, the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party, proudly has in its platform statements on Aboriginal people and on Aboriginal communities and the land in which there are full commitments to those issues.

I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the platform statements of the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party, and to table the platform and resolutions of the Australian Labor Party federally, the Australian Labor Party in the Northern Territory, the federal Liberal Party and the federal National Party.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: NORTHERN TERRITORY
COUNTRY LIBERAL PARTY
CONSTITUTION AND PLATFORM 1991
CHAPTER 2. THE WELFARE OF THE INDIVIDUAL
2.11 ABORIGINAL PEOPLE

The Northern Territory Country Liberal Party recognises the fundamental right of Aboriginal People to choose whether they wish to retain their racial identity and traditional way of life or to adopt, partially or wholly, a European lifestyle.
The Party endorses:
A.The encouragement of the principle of the preservation of Aboriginal history and culture.
B.The encouragement of participation by all Aboriginal Peoples in the mainstream of Territory society.
C.The development of Government policies such that Aboriginals, without necessarily abandoning their racial identity, no longer need special treatment as a disadvantaged group within society.
CHAPTER 3. THE COMMUNITY
3.9 ABORIGINAL COMMUNITIES AND THE LAND
The Northern Territory Country Liberal Party recognises the fundamental right of aboriginal people to choose to retain their cultural identity and traditional way of life.
It also believes that aboriginal people should be as free to deal with their land as other land holders in the Territory.
The aim of the party in Government is to:

A.Remain committed to an equitable system of land rights that can satisfy aboriginal aspirations for security of land tenure which ensures that aboriginal land owners hold title on an equal basis with other Territorians.
B.Seek to have transferred to the Northern Territory the responsibility for the administration of aboriginal land tenure.
C.Provide secure tenure of land, sufficient for residential and community service purposes, to eligible aboriginal groups residing on, or have in the recent past resided on pastoral properties.
D.Support the homeland centre (out-station) movement and encourage the efficient development of committed homeland communities.
E.Ensure that aboriginal people have the right to:

PARA.TAB: An adequate level of essential services which will meet basic needs:
A basic level of services in the areas of health, education, social welfare, law and order and justice.

SPEECH.PARA: F.Encourage the participation by aboriginal people in the planning, implementation and management of service delivery programs, and in prioritisation of programs to meet their needs.
G.Encourage the preservation of aboriginal history and culture.
H.Develop policies that enable aboriginal people to become self sufficient without abandoning their cultural identity.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are important documents, and each of the parties should be reminded of what is in them and challenged to look in particular at its own commitments at the basic level. On the whole issue of consultation, the Labor Party said that it would have regard to Aboriginal people's views and:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . implement only those programmes approved of and accepted by them and in particular ensure that—
(a)such consultation is to take account of the way in which such people and communities choose to reach decisions . . .
I am disappointed that the Labor Party has not honoured that obligation of its own platform.

PARA.TAB: In addressing the Senate committee report the other night in this chamber, I commented about the conflicts and issues of Aboriginal people who still live in a ceremonial and traditional way, particularly in the Northern Territory. Since I made that speech, I have been challenged by the Reverend Djiniyini Gondarra of the Uniting Church of northern Australia and the Aboriginal Resource and Development Services. He was disappointed that I had quoted his material to the Senate committee with regard to the legislation, and he seemed to think that I was using his arguments to defer or delay the bill.

I speak for the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory, some of whom hold a different view to mine. I make no apology for saying that the Reverend Gondarra and others would like to see this legislation go much further. None of the Labor Party amendments that have just been put into this chamber this morning addresses the issues that were raised by those Aboriginal people—so they have been sold down the river in that regard.

In the early 1970s the Uniting Church produced a major report, entitled Free to Decide, in which it recorded how Aborigines express their basic rights and concerns, their needs and expectations, and their relationships with those outside their culture. For Aborigines, those relations involve conflicts between cultures, the impact on the prevailing system and the tensions between traditional and modern aspects of Aboriginal community itself. Aboriginal responses are expressed in scattered communities—that is decentralisation—town structures and cultural responses. In addressing the particular issues of Aboriginal communities, the report said:

SPEECH.PARA: Such is the role of power in developing human and community potential, the problems of the `dependent' economy of a small isolated community, educational and vocational development in Aboriginal communities, the consequences of land rights, and the conflict of European law and Aboriginal tradition.
That was in 1974 and I certainly remind Reverend Gondarra of that report of which I am sure he was a part.

PARA.TAB: We need to ask: who are Aboriginal people today? One of the best commentaries I have seen on this is by an eminent physician and surgeon in the Northern Territory, Dr John Hargrave, who is well known for his work on leprosy amongst Aboriginal communities. I will quote his comments on Aboriginal Australia today. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: But, who are the modern Aborigines? That depends on where you come from. The people of Aboriginal descent from Sydney bear no resemblance to Bennelong or Arabanoo. Without mincing words, they are for the most part a brownish (or nearly white), urbanised people who have forgotten their language and know little of their past. By way of sharp contrast, the tribal Aborigines of Arnhem Land are clearly Aboriginal; the dialects they speak are their own and English is a second language. They know their past, they have retained their culture and they own their land. Between the two extremes, across Australia, is a spectrum which ranges from the totally detribalised or urbanised to those with clear identity. This present-day diversity often makes a decision that is acceptable to one group, totally unacceptable to another and since there is no truly credible national spokesman who represents all groups, this makes the problem still more complex. To be sure, there are influential local leaders, but as yet, the modern Aboriginal equivalent of Gandhi has failed to emerge. The nearest we can come to Bennelong today, or even in the recent past are the Aborigines who flocked into Maningrida from the bush in 1957 and the Pintubi we saw at Lake McKay earlier that year.
Further on, Dr Hargrave says:

Overall, however, there has been a progressive detribalization with consequent loss of identity (and we have seen it happen even in the Northern Territory) so that whether we like it or not, modern Aborigines are enormously diverse, with widely differing appearance, opinions, hopes and aspirations. This present-day diversity makes their chances of becoming an identifiable `nation' slimmer now than they were 200 years ago and a `Treaty' ever more likely to be a divisive issue.
I find that an incredible summary of where we are and what we are addressing here today.

PARA.TAB: In 1980 in my maiden speech in the House of Representatives, I made a similar reference to the issues where we needed not to be confrontationist and also needed to guarantee that we did not lock Aboriginal people into an 18th century civilisation.

There are many problems with this legislation which the history of the Northern Territory over the last 20 years has certainly highlighted. These problems were brought to attention clearly by the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Perron, in his evidence before the Senate committee several weeks ago. He stated:

You can imagine why we in the Northern Territory are so incensed at the Commonwealth government's refusal to pull the land rights act into line with the proposals under the Native Title Bill, which is described as a national, uniform response to the High Court's Mabo decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The Northern Territory has been left out as a social experiment once again within consistent rules. Mr Perron went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Considering the enormous complexity of the Native Title Bill and its convoluted style and ambiguous language, together with the fact that seven governments, possibly dozens of Aboriginal funded organisations, industry groups and individual corporations will test every aspect of the bill through several layers of courts, I anticipate an enormous legal log jam . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Further on, he said:
This giant legal bunfight will delay by years, possibly decades, the primary objective of this bill to secure a response to the High Court's decision which is acceptable to the Australian community.
Further on, he said:

PARA.TAB: To pass legislation riddled with ambiguity and open to interpretation on a subject of such significance to Australia would be an abrogation of national leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, Mr Perron and other Northern Territory ministers have addressed a whole range of problems that our experience of the last 20 years has led to—whether it is a national approach or a mining veto; the compulsory acquisition of land or stock routes and stockyards; river banks and beds; the control of waterways; the control of stock diseases, bushfires, soil conservation, noxious weeds, fences, firearms, public water supplies, public health, mining and petroleum exploration; the conflicts between Aboriginal freehold title in the territory, the owners, and Aboriginals with common law rights that will be abrogated by this legislation; or, importantly, mining confidence and investment.

PARA.TAB: The evidence to the Senate committee by industry groups such as the mining community, the pastoral industry and the fishing industry appears to have been ignored by the Labor government. From my first cursory glance of the amendments here today, it appears that the government has certainly not addressed these important issues.

So the government is not even taking note of the important fundamental recommendations that were made by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody report. Many of the issues of psychology and mental illness will be exacerbated by this particular legislation and, as Mr Perron so rightly pointed out, Aboriginal people will get caught up in High Court actions for years and years because this legislation is basically inept and incorrect.

The year of 1993 has been the year of indigenous people but I wonder to what extent we have been driven by an internationalist agenda. Certainly, everyone knows that I have been critical of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, Mr Dodson, who appears to run off to Geneva at public expense once a year to get his running orders from some sort of international agenda. We need to look carefully at the rhetoric, the language, the amendments and the government's motives that address the issues of a separate state that would lead to self-government and autonomy.

There is a difference between people participating and reflecting their proper self-determination in a community and, in effect, creating a different issue. The report of the Resource Assessment Commission on the coastal zone was tabled here last week. Again, it raises very serious issues in this area.

What about the government's program or social justice package that it is not game to put on the table at the same time as this important legislation? It is going to hold that over to February. It is then going to create another major diversionary debate because no-one yet on the government side will be honest about what the formula is for the social justice package—nice rhetoric, nice words. But we know that the government has to find at least $12 billion in next year's budget. Where, therefore, will be the money for social justice?

For too long Aboriginal people have been totally dependent on welfare and government support. Where is the commitment to private sector employment of Aboriginal people? How will that flow from this legislation? It will not. This legislation does not address that issue. In fact, more Aboriginal people are going to be employed within government agencies, within bureaucracies, that are going to create extreme problems.

I certainly have a reputation in this parliament for pursuing the issues of accountability and scrutiny in Aboriginal affairs, because a black crook is no different to a white crook, and there has been such a dreadful history in the area of expenditure of funds. It was exposed yesterday in the Auditor-General's report into the Northern Land Council in which 52 recommendations were made to rectify fundamental errors in administration. The problems outlined in that report will be repeated again and again as they flow through into this legislation and the likely bureaucracies and all the other things that will be necessary.

We need to be sure that the standards and the declarations that apply in company operations which are administered by the Australian Securities Commission apply equally to all Aboriginal communities and organisations. There must be a declaration of interests by people on the government payroll or, again, we are going to see a series of scandals—exacerbated, I predict, by this legislation.

The 1992-93 debate around the Mabo decision has not yet got through to the people who will be most affected by it, the traditional ceremonial Aboriginal; it is being run for a very different agenda. If we look again at the prospective issues, what type of future community do we want? The areas of discrimination in our community are basically alcohol related—violence and the other things that go with—or public health related, such as improving public health facilities, or to do with neighbourliness, issues such as noise, et cetera. They are the areas in which all Australians discriminate no matter where they live and they are problems that Aboriginal people experience just as well.

We have the prospective threat of the Keating agenda relating to republicanism and nationalism, which is now further exacerbated by this legislation and by the threat of Aboriginal self-government motivated by those who are running another secret agenda behind the scenes.

We should put ourselves 20 or 30 years ahead to the next generation and ask about the demography, the change and the numbers of people who are going to have an Aboriginal heritage, such as I do in my family and such as Senator Collins does in his. We should ask about the relationships of our children, their children, and what this legislation is going to do for them. Frankly, it will do nothing. It will cause division and, I believe, major problems in the future. This sociology, when a big sector of the community is totally dependent on the government nipple, cannot be allowed to continue.

What is this going to do for the Prime Minister's thrust towards a very important relationship with Asia for Australia? It is creating a special class of people with different rules and regulations. How is that going to be seen through the eyes of Asians looking at us? The legislation is lousy; it does not meet any of the proper tests that should be applied.

Many of us on this side have argued consistently for a few months to remove the ambiguous confusion that will arise. In the next few days, when we are going to be looking at 100 or so amendments to the legislation that the government has put in place which arrived here this morning, which I have not had a chance to check or test with my constituency, I will proudly stand by the coalition's stance on this whole issue: the legislation is fundamentally flawed. It cannot meet the requirements of Aboriginal Australians or the Australian community in the form that is before the parliament. It needs to go back and be tested by basic fundamentals in each and every community around Australia. Whether it is industry related or Aboriginal community related, everyone has a stake in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the greatest event in my early adult life was when one of my political heroes visited my flat in Ayr and stayed the night. He was one of my heroes because he was a Liberal senator for Queensland—one of the finest men and clearest thinkers of the time. He had a broad and intimate knowledge of a very wide range of issues and had sensible solutions to most of them. He was an Aborigine, but that was not particularly important. What was important to me was the fact that Australia's first Aboriginal federal politician—in fact I think the only Aboriginal politician in any parliament at that time—was a Liberal.

PARA.TAB: It gave substance to the words that the Liberal Party is the party for all people. The Liberal philosophy of tolerance, of freedom and of the individual encourages and attracts good people—people like Neville Bonner. He was a man like most Liberals who, through his own efforts, achieved something in life. Starting from humble beginnings, he had, through his own endeavours, succeeded. He did not sit down and ask others to support him; he did not believe that the government owed him a living. He got out and did it for himself and in politics he did it in a party—the only political party—that allows this to happen. This is where the Liberal Party is so different from the ALP.

But I digress. My involvement in this debate at its second reading stage will not contain terribly technical comments on the bill; they will come in the committee stage, if we are permitted to adequately deal with the bill in the committee stage. Rather my speech will involve some observations which will principally be reflections of the attitudes of, and impacts this legislation will have upon, the people I represent. But I emphasise that the people I represent are all Queenslanders and they have many different racial origins.

Murray Island, the island which contained the land subject of the legal action taken by Eddie Mabo, is in my electorate. It is an island that I have visited and I say in a non-legal or technical way that a visit to this island makes it easy to understand why the High Court came to its conclusion in relation to the plaintiff's claim in that case. It is, apart from being a beautiful and plentiful island, one which has now, and always has had, a system of law and customs which ordered life in a permanent and fixed way in that community.

The state which I represent, and particularly the area of North Queensland in which I live, also contains many people of other different racial backgrounds—the English, the Irish and the Scots, who came with the first wave of European settlement; Aborigines, Torres Strait Islanders and south sea islanders; the Chinese, who came to work in the goldfields; the Germans, the Italians, the Spaniards; and all of the other Australians whose forebears originally came from some other land.

I have grown up with, been to school with and played sport with such people. They are people with whom in my younger days, when I was able to afford it both financially and physically, I had parties that lasted the weekend. Those people were always welcome to my flat. I count among my good friends people of Aboriginal, Torres Strait Island and south sea island origin. I have very many good friends of all other different origins. Some are first generation Australians, some fifth generation Australians, some perhaps twentieth generation Australians. It never made much difference to me—they were all Australians and they were all good people.

In my youth and early adulthood there was no racial discrimination of any note in our community of Ayr. We were all Australians. Many families in the lower Burdekin district have made a lot of money by hard work in the cane fields and it was a comfortable and tolerant community. Your next door neighbour could have been an Italian, a south sea islander, a Spaniard or a Torres Strait Islander—it really did not matter. Those in the community who were disadvantaged received assistance from local, state and federal governments. Those who wanted to buy land and to own their own house had the same opportunity as anyone else to do so. They had to work to obtain the money, purchase the land, and then it was theirs. There was no discrimination because of race or racial background.

I consider myself as Australian as anybody else in Australia. I was born here, as were my parents, I think all of my grandparents and some of my great-grandparents. Nobody will tell me that I am any less an Australian than anyone else who now inhabits this land.

Reading history makes me understand that atrocities have been committed all the way through our so-called civilisation, from the birth of Christ up to the present day. Many of these atrocities have been based on ethnic antagonisms or religious conflicts. This has been going on since time immemorial and it continues today in parts of the world.

I regret the slaughter and carnage and inhumanity of man to his fellow man in Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia today in the same way that I regret the sectarian violence and bloodshed that occurs in Ireland by people claiming to be raging a war of freedom and religious fervour. I regret the slaughter in biblical times of different racial groups, and of the Angles and Saxons. I regret the lives that were lost as a result of the ravages of the Mongols; I regret the lives that were lost in the Napoleonic wars and at the hands of the Germans and Japanese in the Second World War. Similarly, I regret the slaughter of Aborigines in Australia in past centuries and, as well, the slaughter of many white families by Aborigines and islanders in the early days of European history of this country.

Whilst I regret all this killing, I personally feel no guilt. To the best of my conscious knowledge, I have never deliberately hurt or in any other way harmed any person, particularly on the basis of the colour of that person's skin or ethnic origin or the religion he might happen to believe in. I believe that my situation is that of most Australians.

I regret to say that the tolerance which I experienced in my early days has dissipated considerably in recent times. No Australian would deny assistance or sustenance to disadvantaged people. In fact, for the genuinely needy Australians we have always shown generosity—in earlier times, by individual support, then by support from community groups and service clubs, and in more recent times by governments through taxation.

What most Australians do, however, object to is where some people in Australia are seen to be more disadvantaged than others, not because of the extent of their disadvantage but because of the colour of their skin. I can never understand why laws of this nation are not made to compensate those who are disadvantaged.

As one who has travelled reasonably widely in Cape York, the Torres Strait Islands and the Gulf of Carpentaria areas, I concede that there are many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples who, through no fault of their own, are severely disadvantaged and deserve considerable assistance. I have no objection to that and, in fact, I demand that this government help those people. But, by the same token, I have seen many other Australians equally disadvantaged through no fault of their own. It is very difficult for me and for most Australians to understand just why the assistance to the disadvantaged is not allocated on the basis of the extent of the disadvantage but rather on the basis of one's racial origin. I fear, as do a great many other Australians, that simply throwing loads of money into a Commonwealth bureaucracy is not the way to overcome disadvantage and discrimination.

As one who lives in the areas where the worst examples are seen, there is no justification for spending huge amounts of money which seem to end up in all the wrong hands for all the wrong purposes. If the money that was allocated to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander bureaucracies in the last couple of decades had been poured into schools, hospitals and housing, then the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people would have been far better off.

There is currently some $2 billion spent on the `Aboriginal industry', yet anyone who visits places like Doomadgee, learning of the problems first-hand, will see that this money is not solving some very real problems. The sheer criminal waste of money, which is paid to support the bureaucracy, to support the types of criminal actions that were exposed by the Auditor-General's report released yesterday, to favour friends and family and to support those who are neither disadvantaged nor incapable of finding their own way in the world, is what has caused great divisions in recent years in our once tolerant nation. When in Australia different laws are made for different peoples on the basis of their racial origin, I think we are approaching a sad or dangerous day.

If an animal species needs protection for conservation purposes, then it needs protection from everyone, not only from one group of Australians. Whilst people talk about traditional ways of doing things, it is pretty obvious that the world does not now operate in the way it operated 200 years ago. Our tradition and heritage may be constant, but we cannot expect to transpose the way we lived, operated, gathered food, made laws and executed those laws 200 years ago to today's modern Australian community.

I regret the ham-fisted, insensitive and politically motivated ways that Mr Keating has embarked upon the native title legislation as it will cause even greater divisions in the Australian community and will not in the end in any way assist the lot, rights, living standards and peace of mind of those of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander origin. That is my real concern with this legislation.

This legislation will not advance the cause of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. It will set them back years—and, indeed, it already has. It is ironic that nothing will do more to set back a genuine reconciliation than the perceptions borne out of this bill. Yet it is generally accepted that the vast majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people will gain absolutely nothing from this legislation. It will pit one group of Australians against another group of Australians.

For all the criticism from people like Senator Murphy and those of his ilk about how one group of Australians have imposed their systems and laws on another group of Australians, it should never be forgotten that it is the English system of law—a system of law that has been the basis of fairness and justice right throughout the English-speaking world over the centuries; a vital and living system of law—that has, albeit a little belatedly, recognised a form of native title.

The Liberal and National parties acknowledge the High Court's declaration of native title and we accept it as law declared by the High Court. We do now recognise, and always have recognised, the equal right of all people of Australia, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, to the enjoyment and protection of their rights. That is the system of English law.

We are pledged to uphold the Racial Discrimination Act, to ensure that all Australians are treated in a non-discriminatory way. We affirm that any validation of existing grants of title must be accompanied by the payment of just terms compensation and we acknowledge that the responsibility for land management rests with states and territories, not the federal government.

It is not a question of states rights. I am sick to death of hearing voluble spokesmen for the Labor Party saying, `States do not have rights, people do'. What does the Labor Party think states are? They are a collection of people from regional areas who, in a country as vast as Australia, do in fact have regional interests.

The Liberal and National parties propose that the Commonwealth, states and territories legislate to validate past grants of land title and/or to prevent the invalidation of existing land titles where at the time of the grant the land in question was affected, wholly or in part, by the existence of native title or by a combination of native title in the operation of any law.We are resolved that there be no relaxation in the Racial Discrimination Act, except to the extent that it may be necessary to validate past grants, and then only on the proviso that compensation is paid on a non-discriminatory and just basis.

The Liberal and National parties have proposed that where a Commonwealth, state or territory government settles a claim for compensation, but not otherwise, that settlement may in addition to or in substitution for a cash payment as agreed by the applicant include a substitute grant of land or interest in land, the provision of services, facilities, employment or community programs, any other benefit agreed to with the claimant, or a combination of all of those avenues. It is our policy that government funded assistance should be provided on an equal basis both to native title and compensation claimants and to respondents. A Liberal government will reimburse the states and territories for any compensation paid out for the extinguishment of native title associated with the validation of past grants.

We believe that it is essential that Commonwealth legislation enable the states and territories to confirm crown ownership of all minerals and petroleum so that all Australians are subject to the same laws in these regards and that existing rights of public access to and enjoyment of public places, including foreshores, beaches, national parks, recreation reserves, stock routes and the like, are secured for all Australians.

I regret to say that I am contacted daily by concerned constituents in the Townsville and Cairns regions, where applications for tourist permits for many of Australia's unique and beautiful natural resources are being held up. The excuse being used by government is that grants and permits cannot be given and all Australians cannot be given access until this native title legislation is made certain and understood. State and territory laws must continue to apply to land which is the subject of native title, as they always have, because under our constitution it is the states that deal with land and land management matters.

There are, I think, over 100 amendments to this legislation yet to be dealt with—amendments which at the close of business last night we on this side of the parliament, representing more than 50 per cent of the Australian electorate, had not even seen but are expected to debate sensibly today. It is our view that the legislation now before the Parliament is fraught with danger. This is very complex legislation. It fails to remedy the uncertainty that has arisen about land titles. It is impractical in attempting to manage state land systems. It retrospectively makes a grab for state responsibilities over native title and will spark a constitutional wrangle that will cause even more uncertainty in the years ahead.

It is obvious to even the most casual observer that this apology for a Prime Minister who currently runs the Labor Party will do anything to retain power and divert the attention of Australians from the economic mess which he and his government have created. The greatest tragedy confronting Australia today is the two million people actually seeking work without any prospect of getting it. Many of those people, I regret to say, are of Aboriginal and Islander descent.

This current Labor leader will do anything to divert attention from the part his government has played in causing this tragedy. He will talk about the flag; he will talk about the constitution—he will talk about anything to divert attention. The Mabo issue has given him another opportunity to divide the nation and to divert attention from his inadequacies and those of his government.

By contrast, the Liberal Party's approach will not compromise existing rights of any Australians and will not put in danger national development, jobs, or the economic use of land, but it will encourage the further development of Australia's mineral, pastoral and other industries, which can only benefit all Australians. Again, I emphasise `all Australians'.

It is with real sadness that I say that, until Australia is again governed by a party that is compassionate and tolerant, that believes in freedom and in the individual, that genuinely opposes discrimination and that seeks to unite all Australians in a country which has the wealth to assist those who are less fortunate, Australia will continue to be divided by all the tragedy, unpleasantness and hurt which this type of legislation brings to a country. It must be understood that we cannot help the disadvantaged in Australia if we have a country that is poor, that does not have the wealth and the resources to assist those who do need assistance. It is up to the Liberal Party to ensure the advancement of all Australians. The sooner that occurs, the better it will be for our country and for all of its inhabitants.

This legislation should be withdrawn and should be subjected to mature, compassionate and careful consideration which is free from the pressures of time, after consultation with all genuinely representative groups of all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and all other Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Bill 1993 will have far reaching effects on the future of our great country. We in the opposition are opposing this bill because we sincerely believe it will create more problems than it will solve. The legislation flows from the High Court decision about land ownership on the island of Mer in the Murray Islands. The High Court found that the people of the Murray Islands had lived there for hundreds of years, grown subsistence crops and had a clearly defined form of land ownership. They are the facts and they are the bases for the High Court ruling.

PARA.TAB: The Murray Islanders are of Melanesian origin. Anyone interested in their lifestyle, culture and background should read a book written in 1954 called The Pearl Seekers. This very interesting book was written at a time before there was the current high emotion and before there was a concern about land rights. It traces the history of pearling from Broome, across the north, through the Torres Strait, and down the east coast of Queensland.

It is the story of some very rough characters and mentions blackbirding and rape by people of all races, such as Japanese, Malays, Germans and British. It is very multicultural. The Murray Islanders feature in this book as a well-ordered force to be reckoned with—a fierce race of head-hunters and cannibals who frequently used their efficient war canoes to raid the mainland collecting heads as trophies. These people suffered at the hands of the pearlers, but they had a great capacity for retaliation. An example was to climb aboard pearling luggers at night and annihilate complete crews. It was the missionaries, much maligned—improperly—today, who convinced them that headhunting and cannibalism were not an acceptable form of social interaction.

With that background, let us return to the High Court decision. That decision found that Eddie Mabo, who had lived in Townsville for 20 years and was blocked from returning to the Murray Island by his own people, had valid title to the land he claimed on Murray Island. The High Court dismissed the concept of terra nullius and indicated that others may have valid claims on the mainland of Australia under similar circumstances, but it did not define what would or would not constitute a valid claim.

Fuelled by very irresponsible statements from our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his ministers, Australian Aboriginal expectations rose sharply, resulting in a series of what could be claimed—and, in fact, I think Senator Evans in this place has said—were ridiculous ambit native claims. This in turn led to great uncertainty for all Australians who believed that they had valid title, and it destroyed investment confidence. In my own state of Queensland, claims were placed over all the coalfields in the Bowen Basin, the bauxite deposits at Weipa, and so on.

A lot of the debate surrounding this issue involves the mining industry. Over the years the mining industry has been depicted by the looney left in society, aided and abetted by some irresponsible people in the media, as some sort of vandals. The fact is—and it should not be forgotten, but is forgotten by those who would try to rewrite history—that the mining industry kick-started Australia. It is the mining industry which in these very dark economic times has kept Australia out of receivership. Our industries, particularly the mining industry, directly or indirectly pays for all our infrastructure—roads, schools, ports, railways, health and welfare systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The chattering classes, of which Senator Murphy is obviously a member because he cannot stop, have done a thorough job denigrating the greatest export industry in Australia—an industry which has been a milch cow for governments at all levels which, as we all know, have an insatiable appetite for other people's money. What is even worse are government laws and regulations which stand in the way of exploration and continued development, the increase of wealth, and increase in employment.

PARA.TAB: One impediment after another has been applied to this industry by all levels of government. Each impediment delays and substantially increases costs until eventually shareholders' funds dry up. There is, of course, a vocal minority, in which the Democrats would have to be included, who cheer at the prospect of the demise of the mining industry. Those cheers will turn to tears when, as a result of that demise, their sources of incomes are cut off. With diminishing wealth, there is less to distribute; that is a simple fact that not many people understand. It is only with wealth creation in this country that we can generate that wealth that can be distributed in some sort of equitable way.

The mining industry, because of its nature, does not engage in emotional exaggeration or hysterical lies as do its opponents. The legal complexities of this legislation—that is a major problem we have—and the potential difficulties may well be the last straw for this export industry, as reflected in the decision announced in recent days by John Ralph of CRA to cut exploration in Australia by $24 million because it is just too hard in this country, compared with the comparative advantage offered by other countries within the region.

Because of the huge amounts of risk money involved, security of tenure is vital to the mining industry. I mentioned earlier the claims made on the Bowen Basin. It is claimed that valid title exists where there has been a pastoral lease and that pastoral leases will extinguish valid title. However, there is a lot of doubt about this because the renewal of valid title is not often a legal right.

In my own state of Queensland where land was acquired for mining purposes, in many instances, rather than purchase the land, purchase the grazing lease or take freehold, the landowner was compensated to return the land to the crown. The tenure exists only for the period of the lease which means that when it expires it is vacant crown land. That is of major concern. Over the years governments have limited the terms of leases in the hope that they could squeeze the companies further when the lease expired. It was just another tack by governments in years gone by. It raises the spectre of insecurity.

Security of title to land and security of tenure is vital for everyone—not just mining companies, but every individual in this country—whether they be graziers, miners or suburban land holders. Every Australian who wishes to acquire a piece of land first assures himself or herself that they are acquiring a valid, unencumbered title. That is why they go to see a solicitor. Every financial institution processing a loan first assures itself that the loan will be made on a valid, unencumbered title.

Suddenly, because of this decision, the security of land title has been thrown into doubt. As I mentioned earlier, in my own state claims were made over the Weipa bauxite deposits, the Bowen Basin coalfields, Fraser Island, provincial towns and ports. The acquisition of the Gladstone power station and the expansion of the Boyne Island smelter were shelved and placed in jeopardy because of those doubts. Remarks have been made by other operators in the Bowen Basin that they have shelved any plans until this matter is clarified. Hundreds of jobs are currently not being created, at a time when Australia continues to live with some one and a half million people out of work.

The government's response is to bring in a piece of legislation which is devoid of basic principles and which breaches the intent of the constitution. It is also legislation which, on the government's own admission, benefits only 10 per cent of Aborigines. It validates title and provides for compensation where titles may be invalid under the Racial Discrimination Act.

The systems proposed in the bill for claims, regulation, determination and compensation are so complex that, as stated by Mr Walker, the Special Minister of State, they will be a bonanza for the legal profession. Those are his words. Mr Walker went on in an interview to state that—notwithstanding that comment—it was not the government's fault. If it was not the government's fault, will someone tell me and the rest of Australia whose fault it is? It is the government's legislation. Of course it is the government's fault. This time it cannot claim it is the recession—which was also the government's fault—or foreigners.

The Western Australian government, as I understand it, has introduced legislation, the effect of which is to recognise the traditional rights of Aborigines. It was developed in consultation with real Aborigines on the ground in Western Australia. No-one has disputed that. As native title, compared with land title as we know it, has many meanings—and I understand that is the right to transgress, hunt, hold meetings and so on—I would have thought that that was what, over the years, Aborigines were seeking. The only real criticism I have read of the Western Australian legislation is that it does not give proprietary rights.

Proprietary rights—except for the Murray Islands—are a product of English law. If there are to be proprietary rights, it must be held as freehold or leasehold lands with owners having the right to buy, mortgage or dispose of that land. It is either one or the other—proprietary or traditional—but it is not some hybrid system.

The coalition's response to Mabo is based on principles and fact. Firstly, the High Court has made a decision which is now part of our common law. Secondly, all Australians, irrespective of race, religion, colour or sex, must be treated equally before the law. We are in one great country and we are one people. Thirdly, under the constitution, the states have responsibility for land management within their boundaries. This legislation introduces a form of dual land management. Those are the reasons we oppose this bill. Our opposition to it is based on fact and principle and the legislation is not. No-one denies that Aborigines are disadvantaged, notwithstanding the fact that some $2 billion a year is spent on improving their lot. This expenditure has obviously failed in its aim to improve the way of life of Aboriginals. Indeed, there is a lot of evidence to show that the Aborigines have never been more unhappy with or felt more tortured by their lot in life.

Despite claims to the contrary, Australians are not by nature racist. I object, when we raise questions about this matter, to silly journalists branding people as racist. We are entitled to ask questions. However, I believe that this Keating Labor government has engendered hatred and racism on all sides. Australian taxpayers are now questioning the relevance of the huge expenditure of their dollars in this way and whether they are being spent wisely. That is not racist; that is a matter of accountability.

Questions are being raised about definitions of Aboriginality, as there is a growing suspicion that much of the money is not ending up with the most disadvantaged Aborigines—the genuine Aborigines. Why should those questions not be asked? There would be no need for anyone to raise those questions of definition if all Australians in genuine need were treated the same. While a large number of recipients would be of Aboriginal background, such an approach would satisfy the principles of equality and remove the perception of inequality now causing so much trouble.

The views expressed to me privately by Aboriginals is that the root cause of their discontent has been the ongoing patronising attitude of government. The government has a bureaucratic attitude that the Aborigines are incapable of looking after themselves if given a chance to do so. What has obviously failed is the incredible amount of loose money that has been thrown around, which is to the advantage of nobody. It is a sad reflection that those who speak to me in these terms are not prepared to speak out publicly because, as they have explained to me, of the fear of reprisals from extremists within their own ranks.

The government's failure to handle Mabo responsibly—its ducking and diving, fumbling and stumbling—has led to false and misleading expectations. Is it not time it was recognised that the multicultural experiment, as we have it today, has been a failure? All of us are multicultural in background, but we are all Australians. In Australia, we are not Greek-Australian, Italian-Australian, Chinese-Australian, Vietnamese-Australian or Aboriginal-Australian, we are Australians.

I am not, and have never thought of myself as, a New Guinea Australian, an Irish Australian or a Spanish Australian, even though that would be my background going back many years. I would be totally out of place in any of those countries. The only country I have is this country.

I saw the great migration to Australia post World War II. Certainly those who migrated here had an affinity with the land of their birth, but the next generation did not. They do not have the identity problem that seems to plague our Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Recent migrants and our forebears, including Aborigines but with the exception of convicts, all came here for compelling reasons, including poverty, hunger, oppression, better family opportunities and, of course, a better place to live. I think all of us would agree that this is the best place to world in the live.

All Australian citizens must see themselves as one people in one nation, proud of our country and all that it represents. What has happened? Where Australia was at peace and comfortable in the knowledge that we were one nation, it is now a divided nation, split by the thrust for historical greatness by an egocentric megalomaniac who arrogantly and stridently proclaims that he answers to no-one except himself.

As is usual in a disturbed society, it is the young who become most passionate about these things. Regrettably, Mabo has led to violence in our cities and suburbs. In the past two months in Brisbane, we have had a riot. Suburban residential streets have been terrorised and houses have been vandalised. One 60-year old pensioner was hit in the face with a brick for trying to protect his property. Two weeks ago, people were bashed in a city park and, last week, two Brisbane grandmothers were also attacked. Their unit was invaded after doors were kicked in, and rent money was stolen. One elderly victim, who had her phone ripped off the wall and her radio thrown on the floor, was told, `This is our country. It is not your country, white woman'. The police are very vulnerable in this area, they are nervous about intervening, and in this instance, no arrests were made.

Younger Aborigines, because of their rising expectations, take the view that they can do what they like and are above the law. I remind honourable senators of a well-known law of physics which applies equally to social issues: for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. I commented earlier that our approach to this whole thing risks introducing racism into a country where there has not been racism and where there has been tolerance of other people's ideas and origins and so on.

This Labor government has much to answer for. It will go down in history as the government that divided a nation and the one that left Australia in a far worse position than when it gained custody of it in 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is today debating the Native Title Bill 1993. This bill represents the Commonwealth government's first response to the High Court's 1992 Mabo decision. In summary, that six to one decision held that the Meriam people are entitled to possession, occupation and use of the Murray Islands. As a necessary basis for that decision, the court found that the concept of terra nullius had no foundation in fact or law.

PARA.TAB: Having held that the Meriam had inhabited the Murray Islands prior to annexation by Queensland in 1879, and having confirmed that the inhabitants of the islands had their own customs and laws, the High Court held that their native title to the land—in turn, based on the common law of England—has survived the annexation.
