Clearly, this principle applies across Australia, and this is the real significance of the Mabo decision.

For the first time since Europeans colonised this continent and as a direct result of this High Court decision, Aboriginal people across Australia can walk tall. For the first time, they can lay claim to their land, not as supplicants or lobbyists or even as applicants under land rights legislation confined to particular states, but as equals and as a matter of legal right. This is a challenge that we—the rest of the Australian community—must meet. It provides us with a solid, legal basis to construct a common future and an opportunity to achieve reconciliation based on justice. We must not fudge that opportunity.

The High Court also determined that pre-existing property rights—the native title of Aboriginal people—could be extinguished by the new sovereign power either expressly or by necessary implication. This capacity was circumscribed by the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of race.

The challenge of Mabo is to reconcile the legal right to native title with the accumulated body of law, both statutory and common law, governing the property rights of non-Aboriginal people. In doing so, we must not lose sight of the overriding objective of reconciliation and a common future for all Australians based on justice.

Without compromising the right of Aboriginal people to native title, we must construct a formula which is accepted by the majority of people in our community as fair and just. Only then can we expect to build a socially cohesive and stable community with respect for the laws which govern us. It is somewhat regrettable that we apparently are not getting multi-party commitment to that basic principle.

I interpose here and briefly state in response to Senator Parer that the Australian Democrats do not cheer when the mining industry experiences difficulties. We are well aware of the importance of that industry to the country's economy. We just believe that justice should be at least an equal principle in guiding our national decisions and our national future.

The Native Title Bill is the federal government's first response to the High Court's Mabo decision. In terms of the necessary balance between competing interests, achievable through the political process, the government has got it basically right, almost right.

The main purposes of the bill are claimed to be, firstly, the recognition and protection of native title and, secondly, the validation of existing Commonwealth land titles where their validity may be at risk due to the confirmation of the existence of native title, and in particular since the enactment of the Racial Discrimination Act in 1975. It also provides for the right to compensation on just terms if native title is found to have existed, but is subsequently found to have been extinguished by the action of Australian governments. Thirdly, the bill establishes a set of procedures for determining claims to native title and, fourthly, it establishes procedures for dealing with native title once it is found to exist in relation to a particular piece of land.
The High Court's Mabo judgment deals with the proof required to establish native title. The report from the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs states:

SPEECH.PARA: Proof of the existence of native title is relatively difficult to establish. The elements include the need to show the existence of an identifiable community or group; that there be a traditional connection with the land under the laws and customs of the Aboriginal group; and that there has been a substantial maintenance of the connection since Crown sovereignty. These elements will place strict limits upon the making of successful claims to native title.

In recognition of this difficulty, and the fact that over most usable land in Australia native title has been extinguished, this bill contains a provision for the establishment of a land acquisition fund and the government has made a commitment to create a social justice package due to be introduced as the second leg of the government's response to Mabo. Both initiatives are intended to compensate those Aborigines who will not be able to claim native title. It is acknowledged that this is the majority of Aboriginal people in Australia.

PARA.TAB: These two initiatives are also in answer to those who say that Aboriginal people need better health, housing, education and other services rather than native title. The social justice package must be aimed at lifting these services to the standards the rest of the community enjoys. Unemployment and infant mortality rates twice as high as the rest of the population, and life spans two-thirds of ours cannot be tolerated any longer. However, the claim that in pursuing these objectives we should disregard the claim to native title ignores totally the extraordinarily important role played by land in Aboriginal culture and the relationship Aboriginal people have with their land as the basis for the cultural and spiritual life of individuals and their community as a whole. It is far removed from our concept of land. We see land mainly as an item of commercial value to be held, bought and sold for profit.

The Australian Democrats will monitor closely the government's performance in relation to the land acquisition plan and the social justice package. We will seek to ensure that the government's promises to the Aboriginal community are kept.

I return to the Native Title Bill. Whilst agreeing with the basic thrust of the bill, I must point out that there are a range of amendments which are clearly necessary to ensure that the legislation meets the objectives agreed upon by the government and the main Aboriginal negotiating team. Certainly it was not possible for me to agree with the committee's majority report which advocated speedy passage of the bill as drafted. I firmly believe, however, that the bill must be passed in this parliamentary sitting. To leave it in limbo would give its opponents an opportunity to intensify their scare campaign and create a constituency bent on destroying the spirit and substance of Mabo. In this context, we should note the large number of leases now being granted in Western Australia under the WA native title legislation which, in fact, extinguishes native title and substitutes an inferior licence.

The so-called fragile consensus could easily be blown away if more time were given to the reactionary elements in our community. Some people, with little or no hesitation, use racial prejudice, as is evidenced by the destructive campaigns in the past. Thus, speedy passage is indeed necessary and urgent. However, the bill is not good enough in some areas and before it can be passed, it requires a range of amendments to meet the concerns identified in consultations with Aboriginal and other community groups and industries and in discussions during the Senate inquiry.

The first and foremost task is to ensure that the bill does not conflict with the Racial Discrimination Act. There is general agreement that this needs to be done. The Democrats' amendment designed to achieve this was published some days ago as an additional statement in the report, together with some other 35 suggested amendments.

Other amendments which the Democrats believe are absolutely essential are those which guarantee that the Commonwealth Native Title Bill can override the WA legislation and other states' legislation which is in conflict with the basic principle. It is urgent that we all accept this. Amongst the other amendments that are necessary are those of the type that we have suggested to ensure that the compulsory acquisition provisions are not used to circumvent the intent of legislation to guarantee Aboriginal people access to native title. We must ensure that where land is reserved for a public purpose, native title is not extinguished until the actual public purpose for which it was acquired is put in place.

These are just examples of one or two indicative amendments that the Australian Democrats believe need to be incorporated in this bill before it achieves its purpose. The Australian Democrats support the thrust and purpose of the bill and believe that until Aboriginal people can hold up their heads in our community, no Australian can hold up his or her head.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Native Title Bill 1993. This bill will obviously be vastly different when we are eventually given the courtesy of being able to absorb all of the amendments that have just been distributed. I have had these amendments for something like 25 minutes. There are some 74 amendments to the government's legislation.

PARA.TAB: The government knew for many, many months that this piece of legislation was going to be around and yet we started debating this bill last night without the benefit of seeing these amendments. We started debating this bill again this morning—once more without the benefit of seeing these amendments. We had the most idiotic interjections from members of the government last night, who were saying, `What would change if you did see the amendments?'

That purely and simply typifies the attitude of this government. It could not care less about the contempt with which it treats this parliament. Yet the Democrats and the Greens are quite happy to be compliant with this government's wish to totally and utterly disregard the effective debating of such an important piece of legislation.

This clearly demonstrates the contempt which the Labor Party, the Greens and the Democrats have for this parliament. We still do not know the final product. I am on my feet talking 20 minutes or so after I received these amendments. I have not had a chance to have a look through them to see how they impact on the actual bill. Therefore, all I can do at the moment is operate on the piece of legislation that we have had before us. Quite frankly, even to consider trying to amend such a flawed piece of legislation to start with is absolutely and utterly pointless.

It will come as no surprise to anyone to learn that I wish to put the view of Western Australia, my home state. Western Australia is the state that is being totally and utterly disregarded by this Labor government and, sadly, by two other Western Australians senators—the Greens. I would have thought that, as new senators, they would have had a responsibility to their state of Western Australia. I would have thought that, as people who profess to look after the underdog, in many cases they would have had the decency to listen to the Aborigines—the people on the land who do not want a bar of this legislation. But what has happened? They have obviously been pressured by the government and particular interest groups in the Aboriginal industry to support this piece of legislation and not let it be sent off for further scrutiny.

This government continually avoids public scrutiny, and this is but another case of that. The Greens have equally disregarded the real interests of people who do not want anything to do with this legislation. Therefore, I do not think the Greens can ever claim to be concerned about the welfare of Aborigines when they declare that they will vote for this bill which will do the Aborigines no service; rather, it will do them a total and utter disservice.

Let us look at the reality of what can and should happen. The Western Australian legislation does serve a purpose in making sure that the interests of all Australians, particularly all Western Australians, are safeguarded. The Western Australian bill that was passed a few weeks ago in the Western Australian parliament is certainly an infinitely more workable solution to the High Court's decision than this bill will ever be. That Western Australian bill recognises the traditional use of land by Aboriginal people and, where traditional use is impaired or extinguished in any way, compensation will be paid.

Western Australians will have equal access to land titles. The acknowledgment of the traditional use of land by the Aboriginal people is to become part of formal process before title is approved. I might say that, contrary to what the Labor Party will try to have people believe, the new Western Australian law enshrines statutory rights to traditional use of land or water. As part of the approval process, Aboriginal people must be notified and become part of formal negotiations. That is a very important fact which is totally and utterly misrepresented, distorted and lied about repeatedly. We need to get the message across one way or the other, without having to listen to the bag of lies, that there is compensation and that there is consultation. If traditional Aboriginal use is extinguished or impaired, reasonable compensation will be paid. Therein lies the difference between what that bill does to protect the rights of Aboriginal people and what this bill does in terms of just ignoring many of the facts that should surround such a decision.

My state of Western Australia generates 25 per cent of Australia's export income. That is not an insignificant amount, but it is an issue that is totally disregarded and ignored by this Labor government. It is the largest export income earning state—another factor totally ignored by this Labor government. It produces, per head $9,000 worth of exports each year and the national average is $3,500. That is totally and utterly disregarded by this Labor government. Private investment in Western Australia has escalated at a rate of 30 per cent, compared with the national growth rate of 6.4 per cent. New investment by the private sector is increasing at five times the national average.

I do not hear any galahs on the other side saying that that is something that should be downgraded, that we should try to bring Western Australia's investment down to the national average. But, effectively, that is what will happen if this bill is put through in its current form. It is estimated that as much as 43.89 per cent of the state of Western Australia, or over one million square kilometres of land, is at stake. Does someone from Tasmania or Victoria worry about that? Not in the slightest, because they are not affected. It is nothing short of outrageous for them, in supporting a piece of legislation such as this, to get on some high horse or sit on a pedestal and claim that they have an intimate knowledge of this subject.

If pastoral leases were added to that figure, the total Western Australian land in contention would rise from 43.89 per cent to 78.88 per cent. More than 15 per cent of Western Australia is already subject to Mabo-style claims. I would have thought that every Australian would have been most concerned about exactly what was going to happen to much of the developments in the tourism industry and many of the other wealth producing industries in Western Australia and in Australia generally. But the bill that we are debating today will simply be unworkable in Western Australia. It completely fails to acknowledge in any way the special land title arrangements and industry structure of the state. The bill also fails to recognise the most fundamental of points—that is, the significance of the state's resource industries, how those industries rely on certainty of title and how the uncertainty impacts on the entire industry and future investment.

What we are seeing, and have already seen through the uncertainty that this Labor government has sought to create—and I say that quite deliberately—is investment going offshore. I would have thought this Labor government had a pretty flash record already of driving this country downward instead of upward and backward instead of forward. But it has not been satisfied to do that over the past 10 years. It spent another year ensuring that, through the uncertainty of the whole Mabo issue, the country will go further backward.

The bill raises the levels of concern about the economic impact because it really does add to the complexity and the uncertainty. There are many mining companies which simply say, `We are not going to invest while there is this uncertainty'. Yet we have the Democrats and the Greens aiding and abetting this uncertainty and the reduction of investment in this country. How they can sit here in this parliament, elected by the people to serve the people in their best interests, and support something that will be a negative for Australia and Australia's investment and therefore jobs and security, is beyond me. I simply cannot understand it.

Instead of trying to resolve these concerns by allowing sufficient time for community consultation on the actual bill, this wad of amendments and all the silly amendments put up by the Australian Democrats et al, we will have this rammed through prior to Christmas. The legislation is not the type of legislation that should be rammed through in such a short period. There is no point in any person in the Labor Party saying, `You've had adequate time to have a look at it'. We got the amendments 20 minutes ago. So how much time does that give us to have a look at it? So there is no point in anyone trying to defend it. But we will have it rammed through because Australia's most arrogant and supercilious Prime Minister has said there would be `the difficulty of holding together the necessary coalitions of interests—the fragile consensus' if the bill were deferred until February or March.

If there is such a fragile consensus, surely the people of Australia have the right to know and understand its contents more fully. The Prime Minister recognises that, but this says it all. Vainglorious and all as the Prime Minister is, he at least knows that the voices of concerned and affected Aborigines will be heard loudly and clearly if there is time for greater scrutiny. He also knows, in his pontifical way, that more and more concern will be expressed by Australians in general and by investors. What this bill is doing, like so many other pieces of legislation coming from the Labor government, with the aid of the Democrats, is getting the Commonwealth involved in land management, which has always been, and should be, the exclusive domain of the states.

I mentioned the uncertainty for investors. I also mentioned mining companies moving offshore. The President of the Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy, Allister McLeod, has said that more than 30 per cent of mining companies listed on the Australian Stock Exchange are currently involved in overseas operations, compared with less than 10 per cent 15 years ago. That is a classic example of what this Labor government has done. Yet the government prides itself on sending investment offshore. It virtually prides itself on increased unemployment, which is the net by-product of what it has done by forcing investment offshore.

The government has created such an aura of uncertainty that the Foreign Investment Review Board reported that resource processing in 1991-92 was down to $59 million, compared with $870 million in 1990-91. Investors in the mining industry are certainly looking away from Australia. They have simply lost confidence. Last year, only eight small projects, valued at $510 million, began. The previous year, 11 new mines started, generating $2.6 billion in development expenditure. That is $2.6 billion one year earlier, compared to $560 million the following year. Is that not a great achievement by a Labor government, just to make sure that there are fewer jobs, just to make sure that there is less security for people? It is a deliberate attempt to grind this country into the ground.

Mining and petroleum explorationists simply will not bother. Why should they under this Labor government? Why should they under this legislation? If they must go through the same exercise in Western Australia as they have had to go through in Papua New Guinea or other countries where traditional owners must be identified and agreements reached with them and so forth, they may as well be working in Papua New Guinea, where the prospects and financial rewards are better. One of the significant reasons for Western Australia's success in mining during the past decade has been the ease of access to land. That is why the Western Australian government has sought to reach a position whereby the Aboriginal communities are assured of land but they are also assured of compensation. We are constantly having furphies put forward by the Labor Party.

Let us look at the issue of pastoral leases. Forty-three per cent of Australia's land mass is held under pastoral lease, and Western Australian pastoral leaseholds affect 55 per cent of the state and cover 95 million hectares. The impact of the Native Title Bill simply cannot be underestimated in this case. Aboriginal interests already own 14 per cent of Australia and 13 per cent of Western Australia. Aboriginal negotiators are saying that just five per cent of their people will benefit from the High Court decision. Twelve and a half thousand people—0.075 of one per cent—is the number we are talking about.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his cohorts do not want to hear the case put forward by the very people whom John Hewson and many of us visited in the remote parts of Australia this year. When Dr Hewson and some of us shadow ministers went up to the north of Western Australia, we spoke to many Aboriginal communities who wanted not a bar of this Mabo decision. They simply wanted to be left alone to run their properties in the successful way in which they had been running them in the past. Of course, over in the Labor Party, they do not want to hear this side of the story. In other words, to gag those people—the very Aborigines who do not want a bar of this bill—they will ram it through the parliament before Christmas. That is totally and utterly unacceptable.

I have, in my nine years in this place, talked to many of the Aborigines in Western Australia who do not like the way in which they are treated by this Labor Government. They want to get something done. They do not want to be part of some nanny state and they do not want the white advisers telling them what to do. They want to have an opportunity to do what they do well. Senator Collins can perform like a trained seal over there, huffing and puffing and blurting about, but he knows full well that there are Aboriginal communities who do not want any part of this legislation. It is not in the interests of Western Australia. We will not countenance amendments; we will not be putting forward amendments; we will simply be voting against legislation that is not in the interests of Western Australia and is most certainly not in the interests of wider Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand here to speak for the average Australian. I am not going to use the words `native title' or `mining leases' or `pastoral leases'. In all this debate, average Australians have been left out. I speak as an average Australian, a member of the community, who—like nearly everybody else—has had nothing to do with the Aboriginal community. It was an eye-opener to me last year when I undertook, as part of my duties, to go around the Aboriginal communities of Queensland. For the first time in my life, at my age, I became acquainted with what is occurring in those communities. It was one of the most fascinating experiences of my life, and it is to my shame that I had not done it previously. The only reason that I had that opportunity is that I am a member of this chamber. Very few of us have the opportunity to do that, and it is part of the privileges of being a senator. I recommend it to Senator Murphy over there—
—I lived in Aboriginal communities for a long period of time, so I do know a little about it.
—In Tasmania.

—Yes, in Tasmania. I thank Senator Knowles for that. I would recommend it to any honourable senators. It was a great privilege to have done it, and I learned something from it. Average Australians have no concept of what this is all about, no concept whatsoever. They are starting to get concerned about the rush to judgment that is going on with the legislation that is coming through. They want to know how it is going to affect them, and the hackles on the backs of their necks are getting up at the thought of what might occur as a result of this. Average Australians do not believe that this bill will achieve reconciliation with the Aboriginal community. Average Australians are comfortable with what is occurring within the community, but they are concerned about the problems the Aboriginal communities have.

PARA.TAB: As I went around these communities in Queensland, it was interesting to see that half of the Aboriginals are in community areas and the other half are in an urban situation, absorbed into the communities in one way or another, albeit unhappily and unsuccessfully.Ninety per cent of those that are in those communities are not affected by this legislation. There are only 75,000 Aboriginals in Queensland, and their problems vary. I once told Senator Collins, for whom I have a great deal of respect, that I had learnt what immense diversity exists in the Aboriginal community in Queensland and that every community was different. I am sure he will not mind my quoting his response, which was, `You are starting to get a bit of wisdom in relation to this matter'. I acknowledge the truth of that.

Since then I have taken a keen interest in everything that has been said in both chambers. I think any solution to the problems faced by the Aboriginals has to come from the Aboriginals themselves; it is not going to come from white Australians. We have been shoving money at them—$1.3 billion, on the latest estimate—but when one goes into these communities it is apparent that, somewhere along the line, it is not getting to the people in the communities. I do not know where it is going but, as Senator Knowles, the previous speaker, pointed out, a lot of it is being shunted off into administration. It is being used by people who seem to represent no-one but themselves. I have seen blue-eyed flaxen-haired white Aboriginals in some communities that had been infiltrated once the Aboriginal community had been accepted by the local community. These are facts that are apparent to all of those who have had direct involvement. It is a very great problem.

I will not digress to the health problem of the Aboriginal community. It is an enormous problem in some communities and in other communities it is not. There are certain communities where the opportunity has been grasped, and it would do a lot of us good to see some of those communities that have taken the money and are using it properly by getting the young people to work for the dole and do road construction. How these problems are dealt with depends on the people themselves.

I have no difficulty with the prospect of reconciliation, if that is the word to use, but it will not be achieved by this bill. It will be achieved only when the average Australian understands and is conversant with the situation. The average Australian sees the litigation that is going to go on in the same light as does one of my close and respected friends, who believes that it will be a dark day in Australia's history when this legislation goes through and that it will be looked back upon, in years to come, as impeding the reconciliation.

I am upset when I read in the speeches of members of the government in the other chamber that they are proud to be members of the government as this legislation is going through. When we look back in 10 years we will realise what a total shambles has been produced by the legislation before us. I saw somewhere that Mabo—I did not say that I would not use that word—stood for `money available, barristers only'. Certainly, that is an impression the average Australian has in relation to this matter.

I conclude with the statement I made previously: reconciliation will not occur until the Aboriginal communities themselves take responsibility for their health care, take responsibility for their employment, take responsibility for controlling their own lives in the way that other Australian communities do.

With regard to the legislation, I ask: what will it do for our nation? Will it improve the lifestyle of the average Aboriginal? Will it improve the job prospects of Aboriginals? Will it improve their health? Will it improve the manner in which they react with the rest of the community? To all of these questions, the answer is no.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to follow Senator John Herron in this debate. He is a very distinguished Queenslander and has a very fine social conscience.

PARA.TAB: The High Court's Mabo decision never promised to right 205 years of wrongs between Aboriginal and white Australia; nor, I am sure, did the judges expect it to do so. It was a particular case with a peculiar history, with the Murray Islands in mind. We accept the High Court's decision, but it never promised reconciliation between black and white Australians. It did promise, however, to provide a major challenge to the federal government to come up with a reasoned and realistic approach to the decision. It can be seen now that this challenge was beyond the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He has failed in the challenge and in doing so has raised expectations to unrealistic levels. He has failed in the most important legislation to come before this parliament in recent times. His endless somersaults have culminated in an unworkable, unrealistic, untenable document that will divide this nation by law. I repeat: it will divide this nation by law. He has failed to build on the `fragile consensus' that the government itself says is essential. The Prime Minister has created a situation where one group of Australians has been set apart from another group of Australians. We are under threat of being a house divided; and, in the words of Abraham Lincoln, a house divided against itself cannot stand. At a time when we should be drawing together, we are creating the seeds of social disharmony that this country does not need or deserve.

This Prime Minister is a very divisive man. An overwhelming percentage of Australians believe everybody should be treated equally in terms of land title; an overwhelming percentage of Australians believe that land management should remain a state responsibility; and an overwhelming percentage of Australians believe that native title holders should not have special rights of permanent ownership. Any resolution of the issues raised by Mabo should proceed on the basis that all Australians are entitled to equal treatment under the law. There appears to be some doubt about that now.

We live in the best nation on earth, relatively free of racial tension, political problems and other serious difficulties; but we now face a substantial threat to our future as a cohesive sovereign state. I believe that; the great majority of Australians believe that; a substantial number of Aboriginal Australians believe that.

The first fundamental error the Prime Minister has made is to cause an enormous amount of concern to miners and farmers, predominantly in Queensland and Western Australia. Some companies have already moved divisions of their operations overseas; others are not investing while uncertainty remains, and they will leave if a credible solution is not found. The National Farmers Federation has not fully appreciated the differences in protection for freehold and leasehold land. The first time a forestry or pastoral lease comes up for grabs, the National Native Title Tribunal could well be asked to grant native title on the basis of a valid coexistence of native title and other rights. This is contrary to the undertaking to primary producers that pastoral leases will be safe. There is no certainty here.

Mr Keating has grossly overstepped the High Court. The fundamental error he has made in responding to the High Court's decision is to tie reconciliation and the question of compensation to his revision of our land management system. I believe he has done this to give respectability to his native title package, because he continues to believe that a fair and equitable solution for Aboriginal Australians is provided mainly by money; that money is the panacea.

Money has never been the answer and, even if it were, this government—and, in fact, every government—appears to be incapable of effectively targeting help for disadvantaged groups. Millions and millions of dollars have been wasted and will continue to be wasted in the attempt to identify areas of need. Honourable senators would all have first-hand knowledge of situations where Aboriginal funds have been wasted.

Very few people in Australia would deny that Aborigines are among the most disadvantaged in our community. The living conditions of, and opportunities for, many Aborigines are a national disgrace. However, the living conditions of, and opportunities for, many white Australians are not much to be proud of either. We must have the courage to tackle Mabo and these social issues separately if we are serious about addressing the urgent need to improve the standard of living of all Australians, but particularly of Aboriginal Australians.

In this era of political correctness the following figures probably do not sit comfortably, but they are the truth and I do not shy away from them. In the 16 years from 1971 to 1986, the median age for Aboriginal school leavers increased by only 10 weeks. That is an incremental increase of only 3 1/2 school days per year. The jobless rate for Aboriginal men went from 6.6 per cent in 1971 to 32 per cent in 1991.

Further, Aboriginal people still earn only half the income earned by white Australians. The life expectancy of Aborigines is 20 years less than that of other Australians. Child mortality for Aborigines is three times higher than the national average, and yet the amount of money allocated to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people has ballooned from $24 million in 1971 to $1.3 billion annually.

Before social security expenditure exploded, in a time when there was comparative goodwill and cohesion in this nation, Aboriginal identity generated considerably more pride than it does today. No-one would honestly dispute that. Aboriginal Australians were disadvantaged then, but at least at that time they had some dignity. They had dignity because the handout mentality, for which all Australian governments can be blamed, had not developed.

Now reconciliation can come only from the Aborigines themselves. The Aboriginal industry—the hangers-on, the do-gooders, the social engineers—should get off the backs of the Aborigines. They are the people who continually tell Aboriginal Australians that they are hard done by, and they confirm it in perpetuity as a result.

Giving some Aborigines native title will not help the thousands of other Aborigines who will not be eligible. It appears that only between five and 10 per cent of the 250,000 Aborigines in Australia will have a chance to claim land under the Mabo decision. In other words, less than a quarter of one per cent of the Australian population may benefit from this legislation.

Aboriginal Australians already have property rights to 14 per cent of our landmass. That is the equivalent of a seventh of the landmass for less than two per cent of the total population, and I understand that there are land claims for another 12 per cent of the country. Presently, the area held by Aborigines in one form or another covers just over one million square kilometres: an area as large as Victoria and New South Wales combined.

The combined total area of the land now held and claimed by Aborigines is as large as the area covered by the three eastern states. I believe that the principle of one people and one nation should apply to every person living in this country, no matter what his or her racial origin. A nation of minority groups with separate agendas can only lead to national destruction.

Under the Mabo legislation which is now being considered, the Prime Minister has handed a blank cheque to Aboriginal Australians at the expense of all taxpayers. Very little has been made public about the cost of the package. Michael Mansell is reported to have said that $200 million might not scratch the surface with respect to financing the land fund.

The Prime Minister fails to realise that this commitment will cost all Australian taxpayers—both black and white—dearly. It will create unprecedented racial tension. Australia is well known as an egalitarian society, and clearly this legislation threatens the very fabric of our society. It must not be allowed to become law.

Mr Keating has been very critical of Premier Court's state legislation, but the truth is that the Western Australian position is more consistent with the Mabo judgment than is Mr Keating's bill. The replacement of native title with a statutory title which identifies the land usage that is appropriate is a sensible compromise. With the Prime Minister's bill, we are facing legislation that will create a bureaucratic nightmare and will consume millions and millions of dollars a year in administration.

The bureaucracy created will involve a complex series of tribunals, assessors and registrars. In its wake will be a mass of dissatisfied people: Aboriginal Australians with a claim to native title; dispossessed urban Aborigines hoping for money from the land acquisition fund; and always the great majority of Australians, all shaking their heads. Our job is to look to the future and work towards providing better prospects for everybody. That is why each and every one of us is in politics.

As a country, we face enough problems outside our shores without tearing ourselves apart internally. We must get on with the job and address issues that affect all Australians, such as the enormous waste of talent in our one million unemployed. Australia's wealth is vast, both in its resources and in its population. We must capitalise on this. The grab for power—at the expense of the constitutional rights of the states for land management—inherent in the Native Title Bill will cost Australian taxpayers dearly. Except for the need to validate titles, the real motive for this bill is to significantly go beyond the Mabo decision, which has already declared that native title exists and has given a guarantee to indigenous Australians that the courts will act to protect native title. In his usual arrogant manner, Mr Keating has gone off on an unrealistic tangent and his attitude will be disastrous for this country.

The bill provides for a right of negotiation which amounts to a de facto right of veto. This will impede economic development in this country. It puts at risk our biggest export earners in the agricultural and mining industries. In relation to mining, it will create massive uncertainty in investment, and produce unworkable delays and huge compliance costs. The Australian economy will suffer badly.

This week, 16 chief executive officers of major Australian companies confirmed that the Native Title Bill is both unworkable and inconsistent with the High Court's Mabo ruling. That the High Court has changed the property law of Australia is not in doubt; the great change is that the High Court's decision provides no certainty to existing titleholders. These 16 executives included Mr John Prescott, Managing Director of BHP, who is reported to have said that reading the bill was a little like reading porridge. They argued that the certainty the Prime Minister promised is not provided.

Firstly, they believe that existing titles must be properly validated and that a workable and fair system for future land dealings must be established. Secondly, they assert that the legislation is far too complex and will lead to uncertainty because of its very nature, since it appears to be legislation that is all things to all people. I would add that good legislation is simple legislation and that the complexity of this must lead to the conclusion that the government is hiding behind its own uncertainty. Thirdly, they argue that traditional state responsibility for land management and title should not be confused with other issues.

We would all agree that improvements should be addressed for health care, education, job opportunities, and all other inequities that exist in this comparatively fair country. But those improvements should not be addressed in this porridge-like legislation. The Prime Minister's view on leadership—his modus operandi, if you like—is to crash through regardless. He has pushed this incredibly complex legislation through to distract us from the more pressing issues of unemployment and economic stagnation, and to appear to be doing something. I will be generous to him and say that he is doing this possibly through a genuine desire to provide some certainty, but he is mistaken.

The bill will make land management very difficult and it leaves open more questions than it answers. It will require a great deal of intervention by the courts. This will lead to considerable delay, expense and, above all, uncertainty. This uncertainty will jeopardise development and may well diminish and delay investment. It will reduce economic activity and growth. It will divert investment from Australia. All Australians, including Aboriginal Australians, will bear the ultimate cost.

Australia's land usage has changed beyond comprehension in the 205 years since the beginnings of Western civilisation in this distant land. We could not turn the clock back even if we wanted to. I bear no historical guilt, but I do bear responsibility for the future. That future requires Australia to be able to take its place among the most advanced Western nations. To do that, we must keep an agricultural base that is already feeding 50 million to 60 million people through exports essential for our survival and the requirements of domestic food consumption. We must have a land management policy that allows that to continue. It is not helped by this Native Title Bill, which is an expensive exercise in gladhanding so complicated that the Prime Minister thinks he has fooled us and wishes to rush it through.It will not provide the dignity and respectability that I wish for Aboriginal Australians. I hope one day we can achieve that, and I look forward to that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Native Title Bill is the government's response to probably the most controversial and revolutionary decision by the High Court in its history. Without doubt the Mabo judgment has caused more confusion, uncertainty and division than any other decision by that court. It quite clearly has upset a very long tradition of evolution, not revolution, in the development of the common law in this country. It is clear that this decision has politicised the High Court like no other. It is interesting to observe that in its most recent judgment in the Capital Duplicators case, which concerned the issue of excise, the court has been far more pragmatic in its attitude than it was in the Mabo judgment. The majority in the Capital Duplicators case said:

SPEECH.PARA: Considerations of certainty and the ability of legislatures and governments to make arrangements on the faith of the Court's interpretation of the Constitution are formidable arguments against a reconsideration of Dennis Hotels and Dickensons Arcade.

They were the cases that underpinned the states' right to impose licence fees. I regard it as a considerable pity that such considerations of certainty which weighed upon the court in that case were not as influential in the Mabo judgment. It is often overlooked by commentators and others in the Labor Party that one very prominent and well-respected member of the High Court, Mr Justice Dawson, actually gave a dissenting judgment in Mabo; he did not agree with the ultimate judgment. There are two most significant passages in Mr Justice Dawson's judgment, and I would like to put them on the record. At page 145 of his judgment, in talking about the history of European settlement, he said:

A dispassionate appraisal of what occurred is essential to the determination of the legal consequences, notwithstanding the degree of condemnation which is nowadays apt to accompany any account. The policy which lay behind the legal regime was determined politically and, however insensitive the politics may now seem to have been, a change in view does not of itself mean a change in the law. It requires the implementation of a new policy to do that and that is a matter for government rather than the courts. In the meantime it would be wrong to attempt to revise history or to fail to recognise its legal impact, however unpalatable it may now seem. To do so would be to impugn the foundations of the very legal system under which this case must be decided.
Quite clearly, that is what occurred. Mr Justice Dawson concludes in his judgment:

Any traditional land rights which the plaintiffs may have had were extinguished under the assumption of sovereignty by the Crown over the Murray Islands and any fiduciary or trust obligation that might otherwise have existed in relation to such rights is precluded by the terms of the relevant legislation.

So, in my view, the majority decision was truly revolutionary in overturning the system of land title in this country. We acknowledge that judges make law, but they should certainly never be revolutionaries.

PARA.TAB: I think ordinary Australians instinctively sense that in that judgment the High Court went way beyond what is the norm for that court. I think the High Court and the government are quite out of step with public opinion. We are here as representatives of the public and of their opinions and the government is completely out of step with current public opinion. A Newspoll in the Australian of 24 November showed that 67 per cent of Australians believed that the government should be holding a referendum to decide the outcome of the native title issue. That is an overwhelming expression of public opinion against the direction the government has taken.

Australians, I believe, have an innate sense of fairness. They are very suspicious about this judgment and this bill in the sense that it creates a new form of title which is inherently racist, and it is racist because only people of a particular race can now claim this new title. That is a completely foreign concept to Australians, who have a very deep sense of egalitarianism. They believe that the rule of law should apply equally to all of us, regardless of the colour of our skin, and certainly should not condone a system whereby one's title to land can be determined by one's race. That is a concept which, if we asked ordinary Australians in the street, they would associate with South Africa and not with this country. Australians, certainly, are happy to have resources directed to Australian Aboriginals as individuals to the extent that they need assistance, like any other individual Australian, but to single them out as a group and base assistance on the colour of their skin is a foreign concept to Australians. They innately sense that there is something wrong with a form of title based on race.

That brings us to consideration of the government's response to the judgment, the Native Title Bill. It is the coalition's strongly held view, and I think it is backed up by a majority of Australians and by many Aborigines, that this is bad law and cannot be supported. It is an unbelievably complex bill. It will now challenge the Income Tax Assessment Act for the title of the most extraordinarily complex legislation on the books. The explanatory memorandum is in two parts and runs to 118 pages, and even has to have diagrams so that we simple legislators can understand what it is we are passing. The bill itself is 115 pages long and there are no fewer than 24 pages of definitions in it. It will no doubt be the most extraordinary picnic the lawyers of this country have had handed to them.

The racism I refer to in the Mabo judgment is carried through and consolidated in the bill, and there are a couple of examples of that. Under this bill, the Federal Court is required to appoint assessors to assist it in its processes. These assessors are, as far as practicable, to be Aboriginals or Torres Strait Islanders. In other words, the bill provides that these judicial officers are to be appointed on the basis of their race; it is a strictly racist basis for the appointment of officers of a court. That is an utterly offensive provision.

Further, the bill instructs the Federal Court to take account of the cultural and customary concerns of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders and `is not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence'. What an unbelievable instruction from the parliament to the judiciary. It is a most reprehensible undermining of a superior court of this country, and really is, at its essence, contrary to the whole principle of the separation of the executive, legislature and judiciary. As I say, it confirms that this bill is fundamentally based on race.

Of necessity, this legislation must raise the issue of the definition of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander. After all, a native title claimant has to be of the relevant race, just as an assessor appointed to the Federal Court has to be of the relevant race. We then run into the problem of how we define a person of that race. How does the court decide whether a given person is actually of the race that is prescribed in the bill? The bill does provide a definition among the 24 pages of definitions, but it is utterly useless. It says that Aboriginal peoples means peoples of the Aboriginal race of Australia. What an utter non-sequitur; it is meaningless. In my view, this race-based law is highly dangerous to this country, and I think we are setting off a very dangerous powder keg.

I turn to another major objection to this bill, and that is its very destructive impact on federalism. The Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Greens have absolutely no respect for the federal compact that underlies this country and its constitution. They would happily see the states disappear and see us become a unitary state. This bill takes that process one very unfortunate step further. This is an extraordinary interference in the states' responsibilities for land management and represents a profound undermining of the sovereignty of the states.

It is distressing that this is another nail in the coffin of our federal system. I do not know why it is that the Left of this country has such a paranoia about federal structures. There are many successful federal structures around the world. It is one of the greatest safeguards against the arbitrary use of power. I would have thought people of the Left would be the greatest guardians of that and therefore of federalism. To the extent that it impinges on the states, it raises very significant constitutional questions, which others on this side will be raising. The bill could well be unconstitutional. It will, no doubt, lead to significant constitutional problems over the years ahead.

There is an objection which must be raised by a country with the kinds of economic problems this one has, and that is an objection to the very cost of this whole process, which the government has ignored. The financial impact section in the explanatory memorandum is a mere 10 lines in 118 pages of bill, yet this must be one of the most important considerations. There are very vague statements about the financial impact of this bill. They suggest that the financial impact on the Commonwealth is completely open ended. We have the cost of establishing what will clearly be a vast new bureaucracy. The bill itself says that it is not possible to identify the amount of any direct liability for compensation the Commonwealth may have. So this parliament is literally being asked to sign a blank cheque. It does go on to say that these sums may be considerable. That is reassuring!

This government, with its $16,000 million deficit and another huge deficit forecast for next financial year, does not have any idea of how much the taxpayers of this country are going to be up for as a result of the passage of this bill and is asking us to sign a blank cheque. That does not even take account of the land acquisition fund, for which we are going to legislate next year. It is going to be provided with `significant capital'. What on earth does that mean? The bill also contemplates a very big liability falling on the states and territories. That is not costed. The states are all running deficits. Their taxpayers are paying taxes they cannot afford. Yet they are being told that they will be up for immeasurable sums of money.

A particular objection I refer to relates to the bill's effect on pastoral leases. I represent the state of South Australia, which has a vested interest in this issue. Forty-three per cent of the land mass of South Australia is leasehold, most of that being pastoral leases. So it is an issue of great significance to the state I represent. The government has been boasting of the support it has received for this bill from the Executive Director of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Rick Farley. I had the dubious pleasure of attending a meeting of an NFF group in the far north of South Australia in the last couple of weeks, which was addressed by Mr Farley. The pastoralists who attended that meeting, who represent a vast slice of South Australia, certainly told Mr Farley what they thought of his support for the government. That meeting passed a motion of no confidence in Mr Farley as a result of his support for this bill.

Mr Farley and the government were unable to answer the leaseholders' very legitimate fears about this bill. He and the government can give absolutely no satisfaction on the question of pre-1975 leases, which are the overwhelming majority of pastoral leases. This bill does not validate such leases, so there is automatically a very big question mark over the status of those leases. Pastoralists, like every other Australian, having been dudded by this government and fooled by this government on so many issues, are simply not going to accept the government's view that there is no problem with pre-1975 leases. Why on earth would they simply trust the government in expressing this view?

There is absolutely no guaranteed security for the whole of the pre-1975 leases. What happens when current pre-1975 leases expire? Again we have no idea; there are just vague assurances from the government. Pastoralists investing money to employ Aborigines on their pastoral leases get no security of tenure from this bill at all. Mr Farley could not answer questions about the effect on the value of leases of current claims. There are current claims over pastoral leases in South Australia, and there will no doubt be future claims. He could not give any assurances about the effect of such claims on the value of those leases or about whether or not such claims would be withdrawn. He could give no assurances about the prospects of coexisting rights being granted by tribunals hearing claims for native title. That is a major concern for pastoral leaseholders. Again, there is no satisfaction on that issue in this bill.

There is no satisfaction either, nor was there from Mr Farley, on the potential legal costs for pastoralists who might, either voluntarily or otherwise, be joined in actions affecting their leases under this bill. Mr Farley, as I say, could not give satisfactory answers, nor can the government. From the perspective of South Australian pastoral leaseholders whom I have the privilege of representing, this bill is wholly unsatisfactory.

In conclusion, the opposition opposes this bill because, in essence, it is bad law; it is racist law; it is centralist; it is highly divisive; and it is complex. I think it is potentially a financial time bomb and we cannot accept the proposition that we will be asked to sign a blank cheque. From a political point of view—and I cannot understand the government not taking it into account—I think this legislation does have the potential, on its own, to end the prospects of this government at the next election. I think it is that explosive.

The coalition thought very long and hard about its policy on Mabo and that was set out in the statement released by our leader on 18 November. That policy provides a just, workable and practical—and I emphasise `practical'—response to the High Court judgment. It is a response which is eminently preferable to this bill, and this bill should be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this legislation and, in doing so, perhaps I could indicate my thanks to honourable senators opposite for giving me the consideration to proceed at this time. There has been a slight change in the running order of speakers. I indicate at this point that I understand leave will be granted for me to incorporate the second part of my remarks. Of course, government senators are seeking to save as much time as possible because of the very busy schedule the Senate has before it and to ensure that this great legislation is, in fact, passed. I thank honourable senators opposite for granting me that leave, although I will formally seek that arrangement in the proper manner in a moment.

PARA.TAB: This bill is yet another great landmark for the Labor government and for me it is a pleasure to be able to participate in these events as a Labor senator. In my first year here, it is very pleasing to be able to say that great measures have been introduced, the industrial relations legislation and this matter being but two. In my experience, many Labor Party members would be very pleased to have the opportunity to participate in great historic moments such as this.

The Native Title Bill starts to address the problems faced by the Aboriginal people of this country. In this debate, it is often said that we should shy away from concern about the shameful things that have occurred in the history of this country; we should not be motivated by the so-called guilt industry; we should not adopt the so-called black arm band school of history. What has to be understood—particularly in terms of the electorate that I represent in this chamber—is that savage wars were fought in this country. Great casualties were inflicted upon the native inhabitants of this country. There were many thousands of deaths in those wars, particularly in the southern part of this continent. Whole generations of people were removed from the face of the earth in our move as a society to invade and to conquer this country.

The indigenous people of this country suffered enormously in that war and, as a consequence of their defeat in war, they lost possession of their country. This is important, especially in the southern parts of this continent, where many people have misunderstood what actually has happened in our history. In the Western District of Victoria, and in Gippsland, littered across the landscape are sites of massacres and of battles fought throughout the 19th century. It is not just for recognition of that that we should be embarked upon a course of action such as we are on today, because not to recognise that would be shameful but, in my view, if we were to do nothing about the future, which is the real issue, we would be suffering an enduring guilt as to our responsibilities to this country as a whole.

In my judgment, this particular bill before the chamber is historic legislation. It is legislation with enormous implications for the indigenous people and, of course, for non-indigenous Australians. It lays the foundation for a real and lasting justice for both Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, while establishing a just and workable framework for land management. The High Court ruling on Mabo was remarkable in that it recognised that some Aboriginal people still have rights, despite the destruction and dispossession of their culture. The Native Title Bill acknowledges that within the law; it acknowledges the historic legacy; and it outlines clear mechanisms for dealing with native title claims in the future. This bill will set a solid foundation for a genuine reconciliation between black and white Australians.

Given the historic context in which we are operating, and the more recent developments since the 1967 referendum, it is important to recognise that this government is doing more than just talking about change. It is actually moving in a historic and courageous way to address those basic issues of social justice for all Australians. Taken in the historical context, this step forward has developed over quite a considerable period. It has been more than 20 years since the federal referendum in which 97 per cent of Australian people—an overwhelming majority—voted that Aboriginal people had the right to become citizens. Indigenous Australians are still the most disadvantaged Australians despite that. What this measure does is move towards closing Australian society to ensure that all people are able to participate within it and be more actively involved; and allowing all people who live in this country to be part of that society. Of course, in doing that we have to recognise that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people still suffer enormous disadvantages and enormous injustice in terms of unemployment rates, health, education and basic housing. No matter what measure is chosen, those disadvantages are there.

Particularly for people in the south of Australia, this legislation provides enormous opportunities, but not necessarily for the granting of land through the claiming of native title, as has been indicated by other honourable senators here. This legislation will not do much in terms of just claiming a title for the Yorta Yorta people in Victoria—that is, unless their claim is actually granted; and I believe their claim should be granted. But apart from people such as the Yorta Yorta, for most Victorian Aboriginal people there is not a lot of opportunity for the granting of land. So the social justice measures contained within this provision are going to be very important. The Yorta Yorta people of Barmah are one group that has a continuing link to the land. Great amounts of evidence are available to support that claim and I trust that, under this legislation, they will be able to achieve real justice very soon. At this point, I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The dispossession, systematic subordination, sustained prejudice and persistent discrimination suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait people in the key areas of education, health, housing and employment opportunities did not automatically cease with the referendum result.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander unemployment rates are still approximately three to four times that of the population in general. Their level of mortality at every age is between two to four times that of the total population and their life expectancy is 12-20 years less than that of other Australians.

The Mabo decision recognises after the event that Aboriginal people cannot be excluded from full Commonwealth citizenship. This bill establishes a uniform national approach to the Mabo High Court decision and acknowledges the federal government's special responsibility to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. The Keating Labor government has chosen to respond to the challenge of the Mabo ruling in a substantive way, confronting the complexities and difficulties to arrive at a workable solution.
The process adopted by the government has been a necessarily slow one of extensive consultation and negotiation over one year following the Mabo High Court ruling in April 1992.

The government has consulted with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community representatives, state and territory governments and all key industry groups to produce a balanced and workable national system to deal with key issues left unresolved by the Mabo High Court decision.
The result of the process adopted in this bill reflects and extends the "fair deal for Aboriginal people" attitude held by an overwhelming majority of Australians in the 1967 referendum.

The essential elements of the bill are being supported by a cross-section of the national community. I am proud to be part of a Labour government committed to ensuring justice for Aboriginal people. Clearly, not everyone in this society shares this commitment.

The native title legislation seeks to resolve uncertainties created by the High Court Mabo decision while ensuring that native title is treated with fairness and justice. The bill delivers a flexible approach to land management while maintaining the principles of just and equitable outcomes for Australia's indigenous people.
THIS BILL PROVIDES:
FOR ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER PEOPLE—
A. Recognition and protection of native title, particularly in respect of future actions by governments;
B. Establishment of fair and accessible procedures for the determination of claims of native title, including the choice of Commonwealth or state system;
Designation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations to assist and represent native title claimants with funding;
C. Limitation of the effects of validation of some grants on native title rights as in the case of mining where native title will resume at the end of the life of the mine;
D. The requirement that compensation for extinguishment of native title be provided on just terms even where state/territory laws do not currently require it.
FOR THE STATES—
A. The ability to validate past grants and actions with confidence;
B. Where they have legislated co-operatively they will be able to exercise an override of a tribunal decision on the basis of state or national interest;
C. An expedited procedure available where proposed grants will have only a small impact and meet set down criteria.
FOR INDUSTRY
A. Validation of existing grants with no need to wait for determination of either the existence of native title of invalidity before being able to make sure that a grant is valid;
B. Payment of compensation due to native title holders for past grants by governments not industry;
C. A clear timely process for determining native title claims.
FOR THE MINING INDUSTRY
A. Predictability and security of processes involved in an existing mining grant;
B. Tight but fair time periods specified for negotiations and arbitration which will be unlikely to result in significant delays in the processing of applications for mining interests.
The legislation will constitute a special measure for the protection and advancement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people under the Racial Discrimination Act.

This is the best legislation possible under the circumstances. The government has recognised the legitimate rights and concerns of all major interest groups and produced a balanced response. The bill has the support of many private sector bodies, particularly the National Farmers Federation. Mr Rick Farley, National Secretary of the Farmers Federation agrees that the Mabo response is not perfect but the best deal that could be struck for those concerned at this time.
Large sections of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community see this bill as a more than reasonable starting point given the circumstances.

The federal government realises that this legislation will not deliver anything to those indigenous communities who are unable to establish continuous links with their traditional land due to dispersal and dispossession. A land acquisition fund will be established under legislation to allow such groups to purchase land and thus satisfy their land needs.

A key aspect of this legislative package is the government's intention, as part of its comprehensive response, to formulate the social justice package of measures to address the land, cultural and economic aspirations of indigenous people in consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community representatives.

This is, of course, of fundamental importance to Victoria's Aboriginal community. A majority of Victorian Kooris are the descendants of past generations of Aboriginal people who were forcibly removed from their traditional lands, systematically dispossessed and thereby deprived of their native title.

The Yorta Yorta Aboriginal community from northern Victoria have an unbroken record of using and protecting the land around the Barmah and Moira forests for traditional cultural and other pursuits. There is ample archaeological evidence of a continuous indigenous presence over many thousands of years. The local Aboriginal community have been claiming a special relationship with the land on either side of the Murray River for over one hundred years. Their's is a reasonable claim which will be facilitated by this act.

The mining sector has the right to express concerns related to possible impediments to their economic activities. However these concerns have to be put in perspective. Reasonable people with an appreciation of the larger picture agree that you can't measure everything in terms of economic gain for one sector of the community. The diverse claims and expectations have to be recognised and reconciled and the bill before us has the capacity to provide a viable result.

A great deal has already been stated about this bill by the opposition. The overreaction to the High Court's response by the conservative forces in this country are based on a minimal number of assertions which, if you scan the records of the Aboriginal struggle for recognition have been trotted out many times in the past.

Unfortunate public statements on the matter by the likes of Tim Fischer, Ian McLachlan, Henry Bosch, Richard Court and Hugh Morgan attempt to perpetrate the myth of racial inferiority. They clearly regard the land aspirations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as not worthy of consideration. They see progress in this area as running counter to their own interests and those they purport to represent.
There has been a disturbing lack of substantial statement on Mabo from the opposition. They have attempted to whip up hysteria and mistrust on this process rather than enunciate a position.

The opposition have chosen to treat "native title" as a recent invention of the Australian High Court. They have failed to publicly acknowledge that it is a concept which can be traced as far back to the United States Supreme Court in the 1820s and 1830s. The treaties and settlements with the North American Indians and Inuits in Canada was and is based on the settlement of native title. Closer to these shores, in New Zealand the concept of native title as part of the common law was applied in 1847.

The opposition has shown their desire to entrench the convenient view that what happened in the past should be forgotten. The conservative fear campaign has elevated the principle of "potential uncertainty" to new heights of absurdity. There is constant reference to Mabo generating economic confusion and being socially divisive. It is the conservatives themselves that have deliberately spread alarm and fear over this issue. They have consistently misrepresented the consequences of this legislation. In fact, they complain about the consequences of their own actions.

Comments made in this chamber in recent months go to the heart of the coalition's moral malaise. They have reduced key principles in this issue to simplistic terms. They have turned their back on a mature response to a complex issue and applied the ideological blinkers of the new right.

Senator Kemp's statements in the adjournment debate on 19 August have illustrated how far he has strayed from the "true liberalism" of his party. He has betrayed a tradition that even Bob Menzies espoused, an understanding that liberalism had to affirm responsibility for the disadvantaged. Senator Kemp has confused "liberalism" with "reactionary conservatism".

Senator Kemp made reference to the "unitary Australia of the federal fathers" and cites the motto—"one people with one destiny". This seeks to deny the historical truth. In the past the fact is that the Commonwealth ignored the existence of another people. It failed to incorporate the Aborigines as citizens. It allowed that if they had state voting rights, they would have federal voting rights, but otherwise denied them the vote. It provided that Aboriginal people were not to be counted in state populations for the purpose of working out Commonwealth representations. It denied them social welfare benefits. The current Mabo decision recognises long after the event that Aborigines cannot be excluded from full Commonwealth citizenship.

Senator Kemp in the same speech also cites Professor Geoffrey Blainey who has been properly accused by Henry Reynolds of Promoting the black armband view of Australian history. Professor Blainey is a nostalgic conservative who refuses to see that Aboriginal dispossession might be righted. He promotes publicly whenever he gets the chance the concept of indigenous Australians being the "enemy within" and perpetrates the notion of "irreconcilable differences" being a justification for no change to race relations in this country.

It is telling that, in coming to terms with the Mabo decision, Senator Kemp chose again in the adjournment debate speech to cite a paper given to the Samuel Griffiths Society. Of course it was Samuel Griffith, former Premier of Queensland and Chief Justice of the High Court, who helped formulate the exclusionary and monocultural version of Australian nationhood that Senator Kemp and his side of politics wish to perpetuate.

Senator Kemp joined the black armband bandwagon to suggest that the High Court has failed to provide analysis to support the Mabo decision. This denies well documented historical evidence that in the early 19th century the British authorities were concerned that Australian colonists were acting illegally in their expropriating the land of the native peoples. The High Court has belatedly acknowledged this. It has not "indulged in specious reasoning". It has rectified an injustice.

What we have to accept is that we are not dealing with legislation that delivers perfection. The Native Title Bill 1993 is the culmination of a long process of negotiation and consultation with a wide range of interest groups including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, state and territory governments, mining and pastoral and other industry groups. The outcome is a reasoned and reasonable response. It must be appreciated that this is a complex piece of legislation which responds to a complex situation and has resulted in compromise. The Mabo judgement and the government's response have established the foundation for just future land dealings.

It is now incumbent on states to formally recognise and embrace the principles and practice of indigenous rights under the law and set up a statutory land claims procedure to ensure that native title holders enjoy property rights to the same degree as others.
Developers, pastoralists and miners will have to deal with indigenous people on an equal footing.

The referendum of 1967 recognised Aboriginal people as citizens. Following the High Court Mabo decision and this bill, the conservative reactionaries cannot retreat but finally accept that indigenous Australians are part of the constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I will quote from the evidence given by Ms George before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in Perth on Friday, 3 December 1993. I might say that Ms George is a woman who has worked for the Aboriginal community in Western Australia and is a woman of Aboriginal descent. At the end of her evidence, she stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years Aboriginal people, especially the older generation, my mother's generation, have been subjected to the full range of inhumane treatment referred to in the bill as dispossession and the injustices of the past. Those injustices include direct knowledge in their lifetime of massacres, murders, exploitation of labour, dispossession, rape, the exploitation of women and the ripping apart of families. However, the only way in which the marginalisation of Aboriginal people can be turned around, in my opinion, is if we become participants—not passive, powerless victims becoming increasingly dependent on welfare, and I must say that it pains me to see the state in which most Aboriginal people continue to live in this state, notwithstanding huge injections of government funding.

Since the founding of this continent in 1788, the history of this country has been largely one of hardship and endurance. In that process, the record of treatment of Australia's indigenous people has not been an enviable one, and I do not shy away from that for one instant.

PARA.TAB: Despite these historical aspects, Australia as a country has achieved much and offers great opportunity for its inhabitants. It is with this in mind that I say that the Mabo decision is one of the most significant decisions made by the High Court since Federation. The coalition has stated that it acknowledges the High Court decision and the relevant definition of native title. The coalition is of the view that the Racial Discrimination Act is of ongoing application and should be followed. The coalition is also of the view that the constitution of this country should be followed without exception. Therefore, it is within that framework that we look at this legislation.

The government states that this Native Title Bill purports to provide a legislative response to the High Court's decision in Mabo No. 2. In the process of doing this, the government maintains that it has acted to protect the rights of all its citizens. Let us look firstly at the efficacy and constitutionality of this bill. If the bill is to achieve either of the purposes stated by the government, it firstly must be constitutional. This bill is of no use to anyone if it is bad at law. I dismiss entirely any suggestion that I am taking too legalistic a view in starting with this premise. The legislation must also be competent; it must achieve what it sets out to do. The efficacy of any legislation is the primary responsibility of the legislators, and we, being a house of review, bear that responsibility even more.

During the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, of which I was a member, concerns were expressed that the Commonwealth could not exercise its powers pursuant to subsection 51(xxvi), being the one dealing with race laws, and 51(xxix), dealing with the external affairs power, to the exclusion of the state's absolute jurisdiction to involve itself in land management. In 1901, when this Federation was formed, the states ceded power to the Commonwealth, but one of the powers they did not cede was that of land management.

Specific powers upon which the Commonwealth exercises its authority can be found in section 51 of the constitution, and so the Commonwealth sets out to rely on those two powers I have mentioned. There was a good deal of concern expressed that it could use those powers to prevail over that exclusive jurisdiction of the states on land management.
