Furthermore, the Commonwealth would need to justify in clause 11 the retrospective enforcement over the states of an indefinite doctrine of common law. The bill also purports to place an undue financial burden on the states, and I refer to clause 203, which could be seen as infringing the rule in the boilermakers case.

I have touched briefly on those constitutional concerns. I will leave it there because other speakers will deal with them. However, honourable senators must remember that not one Aboriginal will be helped, not one Australian will be helped, if a bad law is passed. Not one citizen of this country will be helped if the law is incompetent and does not achieve what it sets out to do. I ask honourable senators to remember that. I place those remarks on the record, and history will prove me right. I will not hesitate for one moment to remind this chamber of my comments today.

The other matters dealt with by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs were concerns involving the Aboriginal people of this country. In our dissenting report, appendix 2, some 50 witnesses are listed—if one includes the witnesses from the Northern Territory who were unfortunately omitted—who stated that further time was needed for consultation and consideration of this bill. The majority of those witnesses listed in appendix 2 were representatives of Aboriginal communities, and they all asked for more time.

The concerns expressed covered a wide spectrum. They ranged from the fact that the Racial Discrimination Act was being overborne by this bill—and I share that concern—to the fact that native title was not vested in the Aboriginal native titleholders, as Mabo No. 2 said it should be, but was vested in a prescribed corporate body. That could be done without the consent of the native titleholder. There are no checks and balances in the bill in relation to those prescribed corporate bodies. That was also of concern to some witnesses who appeared before the committee.

During that hearing I questioned David Ross, from the Central Land Council of the Northern Territory, about whether there had been any improvement in the lot of Aborigines in the Northern Territory as a result of the Aboriginal land rights legislation brought in by the Fraser government in the late 1970s. His answer was that, socially, there had been no improvement. Unfortunately, Aborigines are still drinking themselves to death on the outskirts of townships and communities. I refer to the comments from Ms George which I read at the outset. Huge injections of money will not solve any problem, especially the complex problem associated with the process of reconciliation or native title. We have to have a piece of legislation which accommodates the rights and interests of indigenous people as this country moves into the next millennium.

We have to look at other aspects of the bill as well. I say unreservedly, and I think the government agrees, that this bill will have more effect on my state of Western Australia than on any other state or territory. Western Australia has the third highest population of Aboriginal people of all states and territories. Some 76 per cent of all pastoral leases are in Western Australia. Some 36 per cent of Western Australia is vacant crown land. The mining industry in Western Australia contributes 15 cent of the total income of this country. So Western Australia, with its mix of farmers, miners, Aborigines and vacant crown land, has the greatest potential under this bill for claims, for conflict, and for litigation to occur under this bill.

Bearing that in mind, we have to look at this vast continent on a state by state or regional basis. Considerations that apply to a factory worker in Dandenong in Victoria cannot be applied to someone who lives in the remote area of the north-west of Australia. I asked David Ross from the Central Land Council whether he was saying that considerations for Aboriginal people in other states might be different from considerations for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. He replied:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes. I do not think it would be appropriate. You have got to remember that Aboriginal people here on the east coast and throughout the southern areas of Australia have been colonised for the 206 years that colonisation has taken place. Throughout the north, it has probably been for much less. So you have the differences there in Aboriginal people still being a lot more culture oriented, whereas the people in other areas have been stripped of a lot of that because of the welfare mentality that existed. We all grew up under different rules and regulations and so we have to survive under different ways, and that is just the way things are.

That was a very perceptive comment from Mr Ross, because the considerations that apply to Aboriginals in the Kimberley and the Pilbara in the north-west corner of this continent are very different from those that apply to Aboriginals living in Redfern, Sydney. At the moment, 16 per cent of Western Australia is subject to a Mabo-style claim, and it appears that there are more claims to follow. So the question of native title in Western Australia is very much a live issue.

PARA.TAB: I note that the National Farmers Federation did not take into account the effect this bill would have on pastoral leases in Western Australia in particular. I believe that in Western Australia future acts, as described under this bill, will provide problems for the renewal of pastoral leases. All pastoral leases have to be renewed by the year 2015 in Western Australia. The fishing industry in Western Australia, notably pearling and aquaculture, could face problems of access to their beds and waterways as a result of the artificial definition in the bill of the difference between onshore and offshore areas.

As a result of this move by the Commonwealth, the Western Australian government moved to legislate for Western Australia, and we now have enacted the Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Bill 1993. With regard to comments that have been made in relation to that bill, I refer to Senator Chris Evans's comments that the bill was not ratified or upheld by any independent legal opinion and that there had been a Law Society committee opinion to the effect that it conferred lesser rights and was incompetent law. I point out to the chamber that the three members of that committee, Ian Viner QC, Stephen Churches and Michael Barker, are lawyers who have been involved in the Aboriginal cause. For years Ian Viner has stood by his introduction, when he was a minister, of the Aboriginal land rights legislation in the Northern Territory. Stephen Churches has acted for Aboriginal plaintiffs in the Utemorrah claim, and Michael Barker has already made known his philosophical criticism of the Western Australian legislation. I merely place that on record because, if Senator Chris Evans is to rely on that legal advice as being independent, it is important that this chamber know the details I have just summarised.

Senator Spindler mentioned that numerous grants were going ahead in Western Australia as a result of the enactment of the legislation. My inquiries of the Crown Law Department have revealed that in that state the Crown grants are being processed in the number and in the normal manner the department would be using in any other circumstance. In fact, when Mr Morland, from the Department of Land Administration of Western Australia, appeared before the Senate committee, he stated that there were no plans to flood the system with land grants in order to extinguish native title. Whilst I am on the Western Australian legislation, it was Father Frank Brennan who said that he thought that piece of legislation would not be ruled invalid by virtue of the Racial Discrimination Act and that its compensation scheme would, to use his expression, `pass muster'.

I have traversed a good deal of ground. Before closing, I wish to touch on just one more matter, which is of economic importance. This bill has to be a balance of interests and rights. I do not wish to place any undue emphasis on economic matters at the expense of others. I say this merely to balance the ledger. Fifteen per cent of Australia's total exports come from mining in Western Australia. Mining in Western Australia is not just a parochial concern; it is one that has substantial ramifications for the nation's economy. In fact, the export earnings for the mining industry in Australia in 1992-93 came to a total of $16 billion, or 26 per cent of the total income of this country. That is a feature that cannot be ignored.

We have had figures bandied around today to show that funding for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders is in the region of $1.3 billion to $2 billion. What we have to recognise is that, if the money is not earned, a government cannot bestow adequate services on its citizens. We cannot for one moment deny the economic considerations. Just this week the mining company CRA stated that it is going to increase its overseas exploration by 50 per cent as a result of this bill. As a result of this bill, the mining industry could face delays of up to 18 months for approval of any developments. Any future acts involving mining have to go through a native title determination process, followed by compensation.

At the outset I mentioned that this legislation should be competent. To be competent, it has to offer to the citizens of this country a judicial process which is efficient. It is not only the mining industry that is going to suffer by these delays, but also any native title claimants. They could well be tied up in courts and tribunals for that period. In Western Australia last year, 5,702 mining applications were processed. If there are going to be the attendant delays with those applications, we will be looking at a situation of chaos and great expense to the taxpayer.

There was a recommendation by the coalition that this bill be referred for further consideration. That, unfortunately, was defeated. I believe that further consideration could have improved—in fact, revised entirely—the operation of this bill, which I see as incompetent and bad at law. I believe that it offers no-one in this country anything and, if implemented, it will only involve the judicial system in chaos.

I note that the government has seen fit to put forward 74 amendments, which it says come from the majority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. When I read the majority report I am afraid I could see only four recommendations. I could not see where the 74 came from. I will tell honourable senators where they came from. They came from recommendations in the minority report. We annexed in appendix 1 some 150 amendments from Aboriginal groups and the mining industry. We put them forward to show the people of Australia just what concerns there were out there with this bill. People who support a headlong rush to pass this bill are short-sighted and will one day rue that enthusiasm. They will rue the fact that in the first instance we did not get it right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate my colleague Senator Ellison on his contribution to this debate. I also congratulate him on his detailed examination and his intimate knowledge of this bill, which gives him a better background for speaking on it than many of the previous speakers I have heard from the government side. I listened with interest today to many of the speakers. I noticed that my colleague Senator Herron qualified his comments on this bill by saying that he had had very little to do with Aboriginal people all of his life. I think he said that, until 12 months ago, he had not actually visited Aboriginal communities. So he prefaced his remarks by saying that he personally had not had a lot to do with Aboriginals.

PARA.TAB: It is a pity that some of the speakers on the other side have not been prepared to indicate their non-involvement with Aboriginals. The people this bill is addressing, the people that are really going to be affected by this bill, are supposedly the Aboriginals of Australia, yet we have people speaking with little knowledge and little experience. Senator Murphy, who often sits in this chamber and chips away at opposition speakers, said this morning in his contribution that he did not fully understand the bill, but he believes his own party's propaganda to such an extent that he believes implicitly that it is the right bill for Australia and the right bill for Aborigines. When I came into the chamber I heard Senator Carr attempt to rewrite history when talking about wars and battles in southern Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Factional battles in the Victorian ALP.

—There might be factional battles with the left of the ALP in Victoria. It is a pity that his colleague Senator Cooney did not take his rightful place on the speakers' list and let Senator Carr take his place. Senator Cooney's remarks are heard with respect in this place, and I am quite sure that he would not have attempted to rewrite some of the history Senator Carr did in making his contribution to the debate.

PARA.TAB: I guess I should say that I have had some involvement with Aboriginals, living very close to an Aboriginal community all my life. My children attended school for 12 years with Aboriginal children. In my younger days I played football both with and against Aboriginals and knew many of them very well. That does not mean that I have any particular knowledge about Aborigines that nobody else has, but at least I have had contact with Aborigines for all of that time.

I rise to speak on this bill particularly as a concerned Australian, but also with concern for the future of Australians. I may repeat some of the statements that have already been made, both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate, but I feel very strongly that this bill should not be passed, and I would like my opposition to this bill to be placed on record. I do not believe that this Native Title Bill is, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) claims, a well-intentioned social justice policy. It is in fact yet another example of the Keating government's arrogant deal making. The bill is arrogant because it will benefit only a very small proportion of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, and because at the same time it attempts to take away the states' rights to manage the land within their state boundaries. In his address to the nation on Mabo on 15 November this year the Prime Minister said that the world and future generations will judge Australians on Mabo.

SPEECH.PARA: His argument is that the rejection of this bill will see Australia branded as a racist nation. That may be so in his opinion, but I totally resent and reject the Prime Minister's attempt to stifle debate, publicly in particular, on the principle of native title by implying that supporters of the bill are politically correct and opponents of the bill are racist. To me, political correctness lies in ensuring that we are all treated equally by the law, that is, that all men, all women, all races, all cultures and all religions are treated equally, no-one better than anyone else, and that everyone has the same rights and the same responsibilities and, in my opinion, the same right to own land in the nation we call home, Australia.

PARA.TAB: I realise that there is a difference between the theory of being treated equally by the law and what actually happens in our society. We do not approve of racism and sexism and lots of other `isms', but they still occur. We all know that sometimes, maybe even often, women are discriminated against in the work force, children are brought up in appalling circumstances and migrants suffer racial discrimination. I am sure that my colleague Senator Panizza, during his lifetime in Australia, could give us many instances where he personally, and many people he knew, suffered discrimination because of their migrant origins.

We all know that many Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders have suffered terribly at the hands of our ancestors. Many died because of introduced diseases or, in some cases, were killed. They lost their land and, in many cases, had children taken away from them and from their surroundings. But I believe we have to put all this in context. When our ancestors took Aborigines from the land or when, in some cases, Aborigines were put into missions and their children were sometimes taken away and sent to live with white people they honestly thought what they were doing was the right thing. It was not done with malice. Many of those people involved at that time with the taking of children thought they were giving those children a better opportunity. It was done for all the right reasons, not the wrong reasons, although we know now it was not the correct thing to do. It is certainly not something that we would approve of today.

The same thing applies to declaring Australia terra nullius—an empty land. I cannot really imagine that the first white people to arrive in Australia in 1788 really thought that no-one lived here, but at that time it would not have occurred to them, or probably to people of any other nation in the world, to classify the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders as anything but the primitive inhabitants of the land. In those days it was not considered the wrong thing to treat them in that way.

In the 1990s, this view is obviously totally and completely unacceptable. I think it is also wrong to state or imply that the first white Australians should have acted according to what would be acceptable today. Two hundred years ago what they did was acceptable, and it is wrong for us to imply that they should have acted according to what we would call current standards of the 1990s. We cannot rewrite history. I would like to point out to senators that in the year 2193 some of the decisions that we may be taking, maybe even the decision that the government would want us to take today, may also be the cause of much discussion and much criticism and much anguish. There really is no point worrying about how society will judge us in 200 years time because we have no idea how things will have changed by then, just as the first white Australians in 1788 would have had no idea that their actions would be the subject of so much argument in 1993.

Standing here in 1993, I believe the real issue facing us is the equality of the indigenous Australians in our society. I am not placing any value judgments on that statement. It is not for me or any other white Australian to decide that equality of indigenous Australians means that they should become completely assimilated into our largely Anglo-Saxon society, nor should we perhaps suggest that they should assume a lifestyle as close to their traditional lifestyle as possible. I believe if we had true equality before the law indigenous Australians would have the freedom and the power to choose to follow whichever path they desired, and this is something we should be striving to achieve.

I know in some small way as a senator I have played a very small part in trying to prevent, in one instance, an Aboriginal hostel—the Wami Kata Hostel at Port Augusta—from being closed. I was truly disgusted, not only at the reports of the terrible conditions at this hostel, which would not be considered acceptable in a non-Aboriginal hostel for the elderly, but also that the then Federal Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services could even consider closing Wami Kata Hostel knowing the majority of the residents would have no choice but to go back to their remote communities or live on the streets of Port Augusta.

It saddens me to say that just last year this government, which talks about reconciliation with indigenous Australians, wanted to close an Aboriginal hostel putting people like 103-year-old Beno Murray, who was an Aboriginal veteran of Gallipoli, out onto the streets. It saddens me that, despite all the money that Australian governments, state and federal, have spent in the last 30 years or so, we are really no closer to a healthy or happy indigenous community.

Despite this genuine sadness, I do not feel any personal guilt over the actions of white Australians previously, and I am angered that the Prime Minister should suggest that any of this guilt should be placed on me and that, because of this, I should support the Native Title Bill. This bill will do nothing for the residents of Wami Kata, nothing for Aborigines at Point Pearce—a community near where I live in South Australia—and nothing for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who no longer live on their land. Yes, it will enable some land to be handed back to Aborigines who can demonstrate a connection with the land and, yes, I can see that the concept of native title is, for many Aborigines, attractive. Some would claim that it is a victory for Aborigines. I believe that it will be a hollow victory. There will be a price to be paid, that is, the goodwill of the majority of everyday, ordinary working Australians who, like me, believe that in 1993 all Australians should be treated equally, in every respect.

I am sure that most Australians agree that one of the most fundamental rights we cherish in this democracy is equality before the law. I am also sure that this bill seeks to entrench in the law a fundamental inequality which I believe is un-Australian. I know that it is not considered politically correct to say that this Native Title Bill discriminates against non-Aborigines and non-Torres Strait Islanders but, in truth, that is what it does. This bill says that only indigenous Australians can hold native title so, by virtue of my ancestry, I am excluded. It is true that most non-indigenous Australians are in a far better position to buy a house and land than Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. I do not dispute that. I agree that the actions of many of our ancestors has resulted in indigenous Australians being in a poorer position to buy land than are other Australians. However, I do not believe that the Native Title Bill will overcome this.

The issue of the lack of land ownership by the majority of indigenous Australians is one of economics and the availability of money. We must turn our minds to the issue of what we can do to change that, so that the majority of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders have the same access to income, the same access to an opportunity for jobs, and the same access to loans, so that they too can use this to their benefit. The Native Title Bill creates a separate class of title based on a person's race.

Regardless of all the good intentions expressed in this chamber, I cannot see how entrenching racial discrimination will remove it from our society. Societies do not move forward and progress by using discrimination to try to overcome discrimination. Creating a separate classification of land title based on race is a retrograde step. I never thought I would see the day when multicultural Australia would be divided into two: the indigenous and the non-indigenous Australians.

I would like to make it clear that I do not oppose the government giving land to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in circumstances where they can show a connection with the land, under the terms that have been laid out; but this can be done without the introduction of a separate title known as native title. Of course, the issues of the preservation of the land and the sacred sites arise, but these are not insoluble. I am positive that there are ways to achieve the preservation of land owned by indigenous Australians without resorting to the creation of a separate class of title.

Senator Kernot spoke earlier about the concept of one Australia and how the Native Title Bill will contribute to that. For all of the reasons I have outlined, I cannot disagree more strongly with Senator Kernot. In fact, I think the government and the supporters of native title are in grave danger of being incredibly hypocritical. On the one hand, the government says that Australia is a multicultural society and that we should encourage people from all over the world to contribute to producing a truly multiracial and multicultural society. On the other hand, we are promoting separatism and distinguishing Australians by virtue of their race.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask the minister whether he agrees that growth in small business provides the best opportunity for creating large numbers of real, sustainable jobs. If so, how will adding a new jobs tax to the many new and additional taxes his government has already imposed—including the training guarantee levy, the superannuation guarantee charge and the increases in wholesale sales tax and fuel taxes—encourage the investment necessary to create such job opportunities? Will not this tax just be another burden on the wider tax-paying community and on small business, in particular, and result in fewer real jobs, rather than more?

—Certainly there is no argument but that growth in the economy is overwhelmingly the best means by which jobs can be created. The problem with long-term unemployment—probably the most crucial social and economic problem we have in this country at the moment—can be best addressed in that context. Equally, I have no disagreement with the proposition that a good deal of the mechanism by which that growth in the economy at large is likely to be translated into employment is through growth of small and medium businesses and job opportunities within those businesses.

PARA.TAB: So, untroubled as I am by the opening propositions of Senator Hill's question, the suggestion, however, that the government is in some way committed to a jobs levy or a jobs tax and the suggestion, in turn, that if we were to be so committed this would have some wholly negative impact on the small and medium employment sector are both propositions to which I do not accede at this stage. Certainly the government has not made any decision at all about the funding of the kind of job compact that we are talking about, the mechanism by which that would be achieved. That is a matter for decision. One of the things that will have to be taken into account in making that decision is the very question at issue of whether such a tax, if it were to be introduced, would have these sorts of negative impacts or whether, in fact, they are exaggerated. That is very much the kind of issue that will need to be debated, along with a lot of other related policy issues. So it is simply quite premature to be making the sorts of assumptions that underlie Senator Hill's question.

Might I take this opportunity to say how much the government welcomes the green paper, the report of the committee on employment opportunities, entitled Restoring full employment. It will be a major contribution to the resolution of the unemployment problem, which is the No. 1 priority issue for the government. The report is the product of a wide-ranging examination by the committee. It canvasses a whole range of options on which the government is and will be seeking comment before we consider our response to it. I add that the committee will undertake an extensive process of consultation and report back to the government on the outcomes of that process at the end of March.

This will involve meetings throughout the country and feedback will also be received via a toll-free number and written submissions in response to the report. Our intention is then to respond to all of this process in the form of a white paper in May 1994. Until we reach that particular point, until we have completed that process, it really is quite premature to be proceeding on the kinds of assumptions which underlie Senator Hill's question. I conclude by formally tabling the discussion paper, the green paper, and the accompanying summary document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I find it astonishing that the minister can conclude that a new jobs tax may not have a negative impact upon small business and the capacity of small business to expand and provide more jobs.
—That's because you're a dill.

—No, I think it is because government members are ignorant. They do not understand that if they add to their anti-small business industrial relations policy of last night all these extra taxes, all these new burdens, must have a negative impact. Therefore, I am asking the minister to explain how he can possibly conclude that a new tax on top of all the other existing taxes may not have a negative impact.
—We are in the process of formulating, adopting and implementing good policy. We are not in the business of vulgar, populist posturing.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the preliminary results from the Russian elections which show strong support for the nationalist leader, Zhirinovsky? What implications does this have for the character of President Yeltsin's government and the prospects for the evolution of democracy in Russia?

—The first thing that should be said about the Russian elections is that the consensus among international observers is that they were conducted on a free and fair basis. That was certainly the conclusion of our own parliamentary observers, Senator Loosley and Michael MacKellar, who reported no major irregularities in the area that they were scrutinising or monitoring in Pacific Russia. That experience has been repeated, as I say, throughout the country.

PARA.TAB: Preliminary figures show a fairly low turnout, with only 53 per cent of registered voters participating. Of these, some 55 per cent did support the draft constitution and Russia now at least has a popularly endorsed constitution, and that is a very important stabilising factor in the period immediately ahead. So far as the parliament itself is concerned, initial and official estimates do suggest very strong support for the nationalist leader, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, leader of the rather incongruously named Liberal Democratic Party, which looks like winning on present projections 67 out of the 225 seats that were contested on a party list basis.

Other projections based on initial results are as follows: on the conservative side of the ledger, in addition to the seats won by Zhirinovsky's group with some 25 per cent of the vote, 11 per cent of the vote, or 31 seats, looks like going to the communists, who are properly regarded as conservatives in this context, and eight per cent of the vote, translating to something like 29 seats, to the Agrarian Party. On the pro-reform side of the ledger there is 15 per cent of votes translating to some 38 seats for the pro-Yeltsin bloc led by Minister Gaidar; seven per cent, or 15 seats, for Grigory Yavlinsky's group; 5.7 per cent, or 13 seats, for the Party of Russian Unity and Accord; and 5.5 per cent, or 12 seats, for the Democratic Party of Russia. There is no doubt that this result is a setback for those favouring continued radical economic reform and reflects a strong protest vote against the hardships of the reform process to date and certainly in addition, one should say, the upsurge in crime that has accompanied that.

It is important to bear in mind that the figures available on voting for the new parliament are still very incomplete. For a start, they only represent half the lower house seats, namely, those to be elected from party lists. The remaining 225 seats are single member constituencies where over 60 per cent of the candidates in fact stood as independents and where it may be that reformers will fare better than in the party list constituencies. Moreover, no figures at all are available for the 176 seats in the upper house. So the composition of the new parliament will not be known for some weeks, and it may be even longer than that before the kinds of alignments of forces emerge with any clarity.

The final point I would make is this: under the new Russian constitution, powers are very much concentrated in the hands of the president, rather than the parliament. The selection of the prime minister and cabinet is the prerogative of the president; it does not depend in any direct way on the composition of the legislature. Parliament's role is basically limited to that of passing legislation. It does seem that Prime Minister Chernomyrdin is likely to continue in office, not least because Zhirinovsky has indicated he would not oppose that.

The real significance of Zhirinovsky's ascendancy is probably to be seen not just in the difficulties that are likely to be apparent in the legislature versus executive relations in the period immediately ahead; the real problem is what this might presage for the emergence of this character as a credible presidential candidate by virtue of the exposure that he will now have and the status that he will have by virtue of this election which, when combined with the extraordinary powers vested in the presidency as a result of the new constitution, does create a situation which is a cause at the moment of very genuine concern right around the world given Mr Zhirinovsky's track record. Whether he will prove to be any more moderate in practice than he has been as a campaigner in the past remains, of course, again to be seen.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to the jobs levy options set out on page 199 of the employment discussion paper. The three options set out include a levy of 1.4 per cent starting at an income level of a low $21,000 or, alternatively, a levy of one per cent starting at an income level of $25,000 rising to two per cent at $40,000. I ask the minister: is the government keeping open the options of a levy on what clearly are lower income earners; or will the government rule out those options immediately?

—I have already made very clear that this is a report to the government; it is not a report in any way by the government. We have committed ourselves to a process of consultation and further consideration, which I have described. It would be quite premature to rule out any option. If those opposite have strong arguments against any option, they should by all means articulate them, and they might do the committee the courtesy of forwarding their views or those of their party to the committee. If there are credible and coherent reasons why one particular option ought to be less preferred than another, this is exactly the kind of contribution that we would welcome in the public debate process in the months ahead. But I make no assumptions of that kind at this stage, nor does the government. All options are open.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. May I clarify that answer. Is the minister saying, 10 days before Christmas, that every lower income family in Australia now has to live in contemplation of the possibility of a tax increase to fund the proposed job compact?

—I am saying, once again, that we are not in the business of populist posturing, unlike those opposite. We are in the business of trying to tackle, in a systematic, thoughtful and coherent way, obviously the biggest economic and social problem this country has. We are totally aware of the plight of the unemployed in this country, and totally aware in particular of the plight of the long-term unemployed. The whole point of this green paper exercise and the governmental process that will follow it is to try to mount some systematic attack on the problem. We will not be diverted by cheap point scoring of that kind.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Is the minister aware of suggestions that his proposed health reforms will result in a new subsidy to the private sector of $1.3 billion? Is there any basis for these reports?

—I thank Senator Zakharov for her question, which I am sure relates to an article by Laura Tingle in the Australian this morning. It is that article that I am sure prompted Senator Zakharov's interest, as it has prompted the interest of Senator Bolkus and a number of others.

PARA.TAB: I think it has to be understood that, since 1984 when Medicare was introduced, there has been a subsidy paid for private patients in public and private hospitals. Obviously, that has escaped the notice of some people in the gallery, some people in the opposition and one or two on my own side, I suspect, as well. That private subsidy is made up of two things: 75 per cent of the medical benefits schedule, which is paid to the doctor who is performing whatever procedure is taking place; and also a reduced hospital charge for private patients in public hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty-five per cent.
—No, 75 per cent for in-hospital services; that is what I am talking about. Having been the recipient of this government's largess for many years, I know that Senator Herron would know.

PARA.TAB: These indirect subsidies are worth about $1.4 billion this year. All that has happened in respect of my proposals is that the government will look at allowing state governments to get full cost recovery from the funds. Obviously that simply means that if they are to get the money from the funds they will not need it from the Commonwealth. Therefore, the Commonwealth will cash out the subsidy which will go to the funds and, one would have thought, save one further administrative step.

In terms of the Medicare benefits schedule payments, it is the same thing. Rather than have payments made to patients who then have to run to Medicare offices, funds, doctors' offices and hospitals trying to pay bills, we will simply have that money cashed out. The patient will get one bill in the end, so there will be a saving at least to the consumer.

The important thing to note is that this is a zero sum game; there are no winners or losers in terms of money. The states are well and truly aware of the fact that we will be taking back the windfall gain. They expect it; they support it. There is no argument from them about it. It will have no effect on the number of private patients or private beds in public hospitals, which is running at about 20 per cent of public hospital beds at the moment. That will not be changing and the Medicare agreements, as honourable senators would all be aware, guarantee that public bed days will rise over time.

As far as public hospitals are concerned, they will get the same as they do now for their existing private patient numbers. They will just get the money from the insurers rather than from a mixture of insurers and Commonwealth grants. I think that in the papers this morning there was a complete misunderstanding of what the real arrangements are. While one expects criticism whenever one seeks change and reform, one would at least hope that the criticism was informed and accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you tell the states?
—At the meeting three weeks ago.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to yesterday's statements by the Treasurer predicting a growth in jobs in excess of budget forecasts and implying that ongoing fiscal stimulus was now unnecessary as employment has risen by 100,000 since July. Is it not far too premature to be winding back the fiscal stimulus when revised budget projections still leave 800,000 Australians out of work in 1996? Does the minister accept that that will be an acceptable position in 1996? Does the government accept that its decision to reduce public investment in infrastructure, which is already at a 40-year low, by $1.3 billion over the next three years will actually cost jobs?

—I am not aware that the Treasurer said yesterday that ongoing fiscal stimulus was unnecessary. I think he did say that we do not need as much fiscal stimulus in times of improving economic growth as we would otherwise. The important thing is that it is very welcome news that employment is growing faster than the budget estimates. Honourable senators will remember that the budget predicted that 100,000 jobs would be created this year, which a large number of people said we would not achieve, and we have a created 100,000 already. That is good news.

PARA.TAB: The budget projections, the forward estimates of getting the budget deficit down to one per cent of GDP over the next three financial years, do not include an assessment that there would be no fiscal stimulus, just that there would be less. They still envisage a significant deficit next fiscal year but less than this fiscal year as economic recovery picks up and also because with economic recovery, as Senator Kernot would know, the deficit tends to fix itself because revenue improves and expenditure goes down. That always happens. It is just a matter of arithmetic.
Senator MacGibbon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Only one party ever budgeted for a surplus in this country and it was not the Liberal Party. Does the government consider it is acceptable to have 800,000 Australians out of work by 1996? No, obviously we do not. That is why we commissioned the green paper which was brought down today. The government recognises that growth is an absolutely necessary precondition to solving the unemployment problem. But it is not a sufficient condition to solving the problem of the long-term unemployed, so we are looking at alternatives to do more to assist those people.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the issue of investment in infrastructure, there has been no explicit decision by the government to reduce infrastructure investment by $1.3 billion. I do not know the origin of the figure but it may well flow from the fact that the One Nation spending will wind down. It may well also flow from the way some investment decisions of future years are presented in the forward estimates. I am not sure whether it is a presentational issue or a matter of substance. There would be a little of both in that figure. I do not know the origin of the figure so I cannot be certain, but I assume that it has to be either one of those two or a combination of the two.

Nobody in Australia can be happy that unemployment is as high as it is or that it is reducing as slowly as it is, but everybody should be pleased that employment is growing as quickly as it is and that all the prospects are that the situation will continue to improve. The Bureau of Industry Economics is indicating for the first time in several years that large employers are starting to re-employ. So these things are a plus; they are welcome. They are not sufficient, but they are an important indicator of an improved employment outcome.

The initiatives outlined in the green paper, after they have been reviewed by the government as a result of the consultative process that Senator Gareth Evans referred to, should provide the basis to build on that economic improvement to assist the circumstances, particularly of the long-term unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister referred to today's green paper. An important part of my question was about public investment in infrastructure. This green paper says that the decline in public sector investment in infrastructure needs to be seen against increases in private sector infrastructure investment. The government has taken a policy decision, in my view, to actually discriminate in favour of this private investment. What does the government see as the real advantages of private investment in infrastructure as compared with public investment? Why is the government embarking on that different partnership?

—It is not a question of private or public investment in infrastructure being inherently better, but there are, for example, some states in which toll roads are being built by the private sector. If Senator Kernot is concerned about the creation of jobs—

—It is not necessarily good or bad; it is a judgment that other states have made. It is not a decision we have made; they did. What we want is investment. Investment creates jobs and we were trying to encourage private sector investment, including in infrastructure, because that leads to more investment and more jobs.
—But more so than public?

—Not necessarily more, not necessarily less. It depends on the circumstances of the case. What the green paper is saying is that one cannot look at public sector infrastructure investment in isolation because there has been growing private sector investment, and a road is a road is a road and a job is a job is a job.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the fact that two of every three dollars paid by Australia's 7.7 million PAYE and other individual taxpaying workers supports 3.4 million non-working pensioners and beneficiaries through social security payments, has the government calculated how many more people will elect to leave the work force if there is further disincentive for them to continue working because of the impact on those workers of, say, a five per cent job levy?

—Senator Panizza can do calculations till the cows come home and they may or may not be persuasive. He should contribute any thoughts he might have on this subject through an appropriately thoughtful submission to the committee, rather than trying to score points in here at a time when it is manifestly premature to do so.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am not trying to score points. I am merely trying to get some information. I ask the minister, as he is obviously sold on the idea, how such a scheme would work. Will levy funds go into capital infrastructure or will they be dealt out at the whim of a minister, as has happened already in another place?
—I have no further answer, Mr President.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I understand that the road toll statistics for the month of November will be released today. Can the minister advise the Senate whether the recent downward trend in Australian road deaths is continuing?

—If no further deaths occurred between now and New Year's Day—and regrettably, this is highly unlikely—Australia would achieve its lowest annual road toll since 1954. However, a very worrying trend has emerged in the statistics over recent months. The road toll from January to November this year stands at 1,744 deaths, which is a drop of 2.9 per cent from the corresponding period last year. In the last four months the national road toll has been 10 per cent higher than in the corresponding period last year.

PARA.TAB: New South Wales, Tasmania and the ACT have all recorded lower road tolls so far this year. Victoria has not quite been able to repeat the significant reduction it made last year. Of major concern is a dramatic increase in road deaths in South Australia. In the first 11 months of 1993, deaths on South Australian roads increased by 27.7 per cent, but in the last three months the toll in South Australia has been 152 per cent higher than in the same period last year. Just to give an indication of how real that concern is, I note that 58 deaths have occurred in South Australia, compared with 23 last year. The November statistics, released today, maintain this disappointing national trend, with 165 people dying on the roads, compared with 150 in November 1992. Police and other authorities throughout Australia will be doing their best to ensure that this national tragedy is not continued during December.

On two occasions recently I have indicated the concern we all feel about the problems that occur on the roads over the December and New Year holiday period, when the traffic is so heavy, particularly with people either going away or coming back from holidays. Alcohol, speed and seat belts will be targeted by road safety authorities and the police forces across Australia in both advertising and enforcement campaigns over the Christmas holiday period.

The sad thing about these statistics is the undeniable fact, statistically that, if people did not drink, did not speed and wore seat belts, we would have significantly lower road figures than we have at the moment. Some states will be organising a network of fatigue stops, which will be staffed around the clock by volunteers and supplied by sponsoring companies. I urge motorists to take the opportunity to use these driver reviver stops so that they can fully concentrate on the next part of their journey.

In December last year, 178 people died as a result of road accidents. The spate of tragic accidents on our roads so far this month threatens, unfortunately, to end the dramatic decline in the road toll that has occurred in recent years. I am sure that all honourable senators will join me in calling on all Australians to exercise care and patience when they drive on Australian roads this Christmas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Last night, in an interview with Paul Lyneham, with reference to his proposal to introduce a two-tiered Medicare levy, the minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: I would readily concede that a jobs levy would make my proposal impossible.
In the light of the minister's statement last night, does he concede that the ACTU's strong support for a jobs levy effectively torpedoes his two-tier levy proposal?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are drawing a long bow.

—As I stood up, Senator Bolkus, my esteemed colleague, who has always been one for excellent advice, said, `You are drawing a long bow'. The bow is long indeed. I have a view that there is a limit to the number of times we can add to the tax bill for Australians. If there is going to be a jobs levy, I would have to concede that my levy proposal would be in a great deal of trouble. That is something I have conceded all the way through. They are separate arguments, and the government will have to sift through them.

PARA.TAB: The government will have ample time to make its decisions on employment levies before it has to make any decision on the proposal that I am floating, but not seeking endorsement for this week, on a higher levy. I think they are legitimate arguments and they can both run. The government can make its decisions on them at the appropriate time, but it is some months off. I look forward to the debate.

There is no reason to suggest that, because I seek some change, other ministers—or, indeed, the cabinet or the caucus as a whole—are not able to seek alternative routes for what they would probably see as bigger problems that need to be dealt with. Everyone has a right to their own priorities, and the government has to set its priorities. If a priority that I have has to take a second rung to a priority on long-term employment, so be it; I can live with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That would suggest that it is not just floating; it has sunk. Surely the minister would concede that it was just a cynical exercise on his part and a classical ploy of his to bring forward something that he knew was doomed from the start. Not only is the Prime Minister against it—
—Put a question, not an argument.
—It is a question. Surely he will now concede defeat. He ought to concede defeat. Does the minister not concede defeat?

—No. I will not concede defeat at all. It is not unusual on this side of politics for people to have ideas. On the other side they have to break their duck, but over here ideas actually happen. As I said yesterday, once you have them, it is an ideas market and you do your best to sell them.

—There is a virgin mind for ideas over there; do not worry about it. I do not believe that there should be any reason why we cannot, over six months, go through this proposal from top to bottom with the union movement and with my colleagues in the caucus. I believe I have every chance of convincing them, and I will be trying. That having been said, I add that if there is an employment levy for other reasons that the government regards as greater imperatives, then so be it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I note that the HMAS Newcastle, the last of the FFG-7 class, was commissioned into service last weekend. Can the minister inform the Senate how these ships and the Anzac frigates will affect the working and living conditions for those personnel serving on them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —HMAS Newcastle is the latest addition to the Royal Australian Navy fleet and was commissioned in Newcastle last Saturday. Newcastle is the sixth and last FFG-7 Oliver Hazard Perry class to be purchased by the navy and was built by Transfield Shipbuilding in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: The FFG-7 class introduced mess decks with separate recreational and sleeping areas. This meant that watch-keeping personnel were less likely to be disturbed during normal working hours. The FFG-7 has a more capable airconditioning plant than older ships, and this results in much improved crew efficiency, particularly in tropical regions. Passageways which run the length of the ship provide access to most areas without passing through accommodation and living areas. The FFG-7 airconditioning vents are designed to reduce ambient noise, while an ergonomic central office layout improves working conditions in the ship.

The Anzac ship living and working conditions will be equal, or superior, to conditions in other Royal Australian Navy combatants. The Anzac ship has, on average, 40 per cent more habitable space per person than exists on board an FFG-7.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very interesting!

—I am glad that Senator Boswell is interested; I wish some of his colleagues were. Accommodation will be provided for 163 personnel on an Anzac frigate. Minor modifications will be made to increase the privacy of the crew. These will be complete by the time the HMAS Anzac is commissioned in early 1996.

PARA.TAB: The commanding officer and heads of departments will have single cabins with ensuite facilities. The FFG-7 class ships have set a new and higher standard of both working and living conditions for the Royal Australian Navy, which will be maintained and further improved with the delivery of the Anzac ships from 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —That last answer was an amazing abuse of question time. My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services. Will the government be responding to the Burdekin report in the context of the 1994 budget or will people with mental illness, their families and carers now be made to wait until the 1995 budget at the earliest before any resources are devoted to overcoming the dearth of services highlighted in this damning report?

—I have not heard from my colleague the Deputy Prime Minister and the minister responsible, Brian Howe, as to the timing of these arrangements. I will certainly check that for Senator Patterson. My understanding is that we are to proceed with all haste in looking at a proper assessment of the issues that Mr Burdekin has correctly raised. In fact, I discussed in part some of this with Mr Howe today.

PARA.TAB: My understanding is that we are proceeding. I did not ask him whether we would be ready to do so by 10 May. I suspect the response may take a little extra time, but that would not preclude the possibility of Mr Howe and any other ministers who were involved seeking further funds outside the budget context in a rare, but nonetheless important, circumstance. So, if it were not ready by 10 May, that would not mean it could not be proceeded with later on in the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I thank the minister and ask a supplementary question. Would Senator Richardson, as the Minister for Health—given that this is also a health issue—be concerned if we did not see budgetary implications until the 1995 budget? If we do not see this until 1995, how many more older Australians will have to be unnecessarily restrained by drugs, how many more young Australians will be driven to suicide and how many more Australians with mental illness will be forced to spend another Christmas alone or on the streets? Is 1995 too far away? The minister has suggested that he would like to see it earlier—maybe in the additional budget estimates. Is that what will happen?

—I would certainly like to see it happen earlier, but I am reluctant to put an exact time on it. As I said, I have not checked with my colleague. Obviously, I have an interest and I would like to see it done as soon as possible. Equally, I would like to make sure that we get it right. That being the case, we have to make sure that we have a proper examination of the issues that Mr Burdekin has placed before us. That will probably take a bit longer than the three or so months that we would need. Our budget submissions will be in in early February and I am sure that they will not be ready for that.
—Will it take till 1995?

—I imagine that it will take longer than 10 May. But I hope that we will be able to do something at some stage during that financial year. That is certainly what I will try to do and work towards doing.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. On how many occasions over the last three years has either the present Minister for Resources, Mr Lee, or the previous minister acted on advice from the Australian Heritage Commission with respect to the protection of old-growth forests with high conservation value when considering the granting of woodchip licences? Will the minister table the advice that has been received together with the results of his consideration of that advice?

—In the last few days the minister has made perfectly clear that he does, in accordance with his legal obligations, on every occasion fully consider the advice that he receives from the Australian Heritage Commission in respect of all woodchip licence applications that come before him.
—How many times has he acted on it?

—Presumably at least part of the decision is taken as a result of the advice received. The Australian Heritage Commission is one of the bodies from which the minister receives advice. Those woodchip applications which have the potential to impact on National Estate areas have to be examined pretty carefully. I know from talking to the minister that he does take that advice seriously on every occasion.

PARA.TAB: I do not actually have an assurance, in any of the information I have received, that the previous Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, acted in the same way. But I am sure that he would have because he is an honourable person and an excellent minister. I am sure he would have followed the same procedures and sought and considered the advice on every occasion. I will check with him whether there were any occasions when that was not done and I will let Senator Coulter know. I suspect there are not any. The minister has been contacted in relation to tabling that advice. According to my information, he is declining to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to reports that the government's green paper on unemployment and the task force proposal will have a temporary jobs levy of one per cent for low wage earners which rises to five per cent for high income earners. Does the government not realise that any job levy will only drive jobs offshore and increase unemployment? Why does the government not listen this time to the Reserve Bank which has rejected the jobs levy as a disguise for unemployment in favour of increased economic growth?

—Firstly, I refer to the answer which the Leader of the Government gave when he comprehensively explained that this is not a government document. This is a document that the government has commissioned. People have reported to the government. They have not made recommendations. If those opposite read the document they will find that those people have pursued a few options. They are entitled to pursue the jobs levy option. Those opposite do not fully understand it if they describe it like that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell is quite right when he says that if all we did was put a tax on and not spend the money then it would reduce employment. If we put a tax on and spend that money—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not put 100 per cent tax on it; that would create a lot more—

—If Senator Boswell would like a private economics tutorial I will come around to see him some other time. This is really not the time. Senator Patterson would complain if I used question time to do that.

PARA.TAB: If we spend the money on labour market programs at the very least it will create the situation where the long-term unemployed will not be picked up by economic growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator O'Chee would keep quiet those opposite would be able to hear. Even when we had the fastest economic growth of OECD countries from 1983 to 1990 the long-term unemployed did not get the benefit of that growth. Economic growth is necessary but not sufficient. It is the core to solving the problem of unemployment. But in order to provide assistance to the long-term unemployed we have to do more. I have not read the report in full but apparently Senator Boswell has. I understand that the green paper indicates that this is an option that should be considered.

PARA.TAB: It is proposed in the green paper that we should introduce a job compact to ensure that long-term unemployed people get work. It has said that, if we want to fund it, an option to fund it is the jobs levy. The government will look at that and look at the responses from the public in the debate, as Senator Gareth Evans invited during question time. If we decide to have a jobs levy, we will explain why and how we will spend the money if and when we make such a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Last year the government spent $1.2 billion on employment programs. This year a further $120 million has been allocated. I ask the minister: how will this new jobs levy help the unemployed and underemployed when all programs over the past couple of years have failed to get the unemployment rate below 10 per cent?

—Substantially, I answered that question in my original answer. I add that it is not true to say that the labour market programs have not been of assistance. There are an enormous number of Australians who have been in work or who have had work experience during the last 12 months as a result of labour market programs. Nobody is arguing that those programs have been of no value. It is also true that there has not been sufficient underlying economic growth to get unemployment down as far as we would wish.

PARA.TAB: So the green paper and any rational commentator would be saying that we need to do two things: we need to be doing things about economic growth and we need to be doing things to assist the long-term unemployed. As the Prime Minister said on the night of the election, we cannot leave those people behind. As a society we have an obligation to assist the long-term unemployed. That is the issue addressed by the task force reporting in the green paper, and it is a proper one to be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. My question relates to Australian export markets and, in particular, whether such markets have been developed by the aviation industry. In this regard, can the minister advise the Senate of the extent to which this industry was represented at the recent Australian export awards? If the industry was well represented, can the minister provide details of the level of success of the aviation industry in establishing valuable export markets?
—Mr President—
—Has the CAA finished rewriting its minutes yet?

—In response to that interjection, I think it is about time that Senator Macdonald started appreciating the fact that most Australians appreciate—that is that we have an aviation industry in Australia which is second to none in the world. It is now carving out a niche for itself by both developing and exporting world-class avionics systems. It is about time that Senator Macdonald and others stopped this nauseous Australian habit of bagging Australian industry and Australian initiatives. When the world recognises—
—Senator Ian Macdonald!

—That is right, Senator Ian Macdonald. I thank Senator McMullan. I am pleased to advise the Senate that at the recent 1993 export awards the aviation industry was well represented. It was especially pleasing to see that the prestigious new exporter award went to Lochard Environmental Systems Pty Ltd, a Melbourne based firm. This was particularly pleasing as this company has been operating for only three years. The company produces an airport noise and flight track monitoring system which is currently operating at Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane airports. The system allows real-time recording of aircraft movement rates and noise levels in the vicinity of airports.

PARA.TAB: The system, which is known as global environmental monitoring systems, has already been exported and installed at Manchester, Zurich, Amsterdam and Madrid airports. Only recently the company won a further contract to install the system at San Diego airport. Export orders for the company have increased from $60,000 a year only a few years ago to an anticipated $6 million this year.

I can also inform the Senate that two other companies mentioned at the export awards were also aviation-related service companies: Static Engineering and the well-known Australian company, AWA Defence Industries. My colleague Senator Schacht mentioned in the chamber an example of Australian companies expanding into Asian export markets such as China. AWA is another company which, in September this year, won a $33 million export contract to export landing systems to 75 airports in China.

Australia has also had the opportunity to become a leading provider of aviation training services. Australian flying schools are already successfully training pilots from countries such as Indonesia, Vietnam, Japan and Malaysia. In this regard, I understand that an organisation called Aviation Training Australia is being established by the industry itself in conjunction with Austrade and government organisations to promote Australia as a leading provider of aviation training as an export industry as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the minister accept Mickey Kantor's and Sir Leon Brittan's assessment today that the breakthrough has come and that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will be concluded in the next 24 hours? I ask the minister: what significant difficulties does he feel still remain and, in particular, what remains to be won for Australia in the final hours of negotiations for our market access to Europe, North America and Japan?

—We certainly do accept the assessment by Mickey Kantor and Leon Brittan that the US and Europe have concluded a deal which has cleared the way to finalise the round within the subsequent 24 hours. It has to be appreciated, as is implicit in Senator Teague's question, that the US-European union deal is not by itself the end of the story; other countries are still negotiating, and that includes us. Our efforts, which are still going on hour by hour, are aimed at improving our market access with a whole range of countries. We have until later today—in fact, until about 11 o'clock tonight Australian time—to achieve better deals on a variety of access issues. I do not think there is much utility at this stage in trying to define where we are at on each of those issues; in fact, in some small respects, it would perhaps be counterproductive to do so. All I can say is that intense negotiations are still under way.

PARA.TAB: At around 4 o'clock this afternoon, the Prime Minister will be making a major announcement on the outcome so far for Australia. That will need to be supplemented tomorrow by a further announcement which he or I will make—or Senator Cook will make in Geneva—about what further has been able to be achieved. It is very much an active environment at the moment. Within the overall framework that has been set, there is still scope for a great many bilateral, multilateral or pluri-lateral add-on deals, and the effort is proceeding at the moment across the whole range of issues in which Australia has an interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. I note reports in this morning's press that artist Arthur Boyd has given copyright of all his artworks to the nation. Could the minister please advise exactly what this means, and what the implications for Australian cultural development are?

—I am sure everybody was as pleased as I was to be advised of this very generous initiative by Arthur Boyd and the statement by the Prime Minister about it last night. I think it is worthy of proper recognition. I realise that the delicate sensibilities of some opposition senators are offended by people raising such positive messages around here, but I intend to do it anyway.

PARA.TAB: Arthur Boyd has assigned the copyright on all his works equally to his children and to the nation, and I think that has very profound significance for our cultural development. As most would be aware—and I know everybody on this side welcomed it—Arthur and his wife, Yvonne, generously gave `Bundanon', that wonderful property on the Shoalhaven, to the nation to be developed as a living arts centre. In March, the government made a commitment to provide $5.4 million to the Bundanon trust to develop and manage the property.

I had the opportunity to visit the property. It is an outstanding property in its own right and a great base for an art centre to be developed in Australia's interest, as it has been the inspiration for that wonderful Shoalhaven series of paintings for which Arthur Boyd is particularly famous. I am sure some of our Victorian colleagues welcome this initiative because so much of this work is on public display in the Victorian Arts Centre. As his art has been an inspiration to Australians, so should his generosity also.

Let me explain the significance of the gift of copyright in these circumstances. What we are talking about here is a collection of more than 400 works, which contains works by four generations of Boyds, including more than 150 watercolours and pastel works by Arthur Boyd, and paintings by Sir Sidney Nolan, Albert Tucker and Charles Blackman. Income from the reproduction or publication of these works will flow to the Bundanon trust and will be used to continue to develop Bundanon as a living cultural centre for the creation and presentation of art, music, dance and other performance works.

It is possible to conceive that over the years the value of what flows from this will be a more significant contribution than the $5.4 million contribution which the Commonwealth has made. It is that sort of partnership between government, artists and individuals through their individual acts of generosity that will over the years enhance the cultural development of the nation, make the best that is provided by Australians available to all Australians and give young Australians with talent the facilities in places like Bundanon to develop that talent and turn it into a career.

By any measure Arthur Boyd is an outstanding artist. I think his generosity, with regard to both Bundanon and this contribution to the trust, says he is far more than that. He is an outstanding Australian. On behalf of the government, and I think the whole Senate—notwithstanding some earlier interjections—I am sure that everybody would share the view that this is an outstanding act of generosity which we all welcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to an answer to a question to Senator McMullan when debating the ACTU's new industrial reform bill. I asked Senator McMullan whether or not an industrial boycott could be put on the export of live sheep and whether the boycott action would be legal under the new laws. In his answer, he admitted that there would be instances when this would occur. Why has the government, in concert with the now anti-business Democrats led by Senator Kernot, passed a law that will force farmers to go back on to the wharves and load live sheep to protect their livelihood and their markets?
—With due respect to whatever Senator McMullan might have said, I am not going to give a kerbside legal opinion on the matters in issue which constitute the premise of the question.

—I am indebted to Senator Ian Macdonald for that remark, made with his usual grace and charm, which we are quite used to in this place. If there is anything I can usefully add to that answer, I will be happy to do so by way of taking it on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Could the minister inform the Senate of the ongoing work of the Australian Institute for Family Studies and the role that the institute will play during International Year of the Family 1994?

—The AIFS, the Australian Institute of Family Studies, plays a very important role in promoting the wellbeing of Australian families. It has established a world reputation as a research institute, and that reputation continues and only grows. The AIFS, it is fair to say, is one of the key sources, if not the only source, of information and research on families in this country. The work it produces is an invaluable resource in assisting both the government and the community in looking at how best to assist families.

PARA.TAB: Much of the work of the AIFS is ongoing research. At the moment it is producing a series of reports contributing to the Australian living standards studies. That reference was given by predecessor minister Brian Howe in this portfolio area. Already two of the reports from that study have come out. I launched one of them about Box Hill not too long ago—a very interesting series of data about Australian living and what Australians say are important issues for them in terms of where they live and what sorts of factors are important in how they make their decisions about where to live. I refer to things such as transport, access to schools, child care and so on which feature in these considerations, as so also do decisions about the cost of housing—although interestingly enough, the report shows that the cost of housing is not the highest priority.

The AIFS will be playing a very critical role in 1994—the International Year of the Family. It will be introducing a series of studies for the IYF, including an important study on family values in a multicultural society. It will be developing an important publication for service providers on the rights of children and an important compendium of study and research on work and family issues in Australia, which will tie in very much with the work done by the Department of Industrial Relations and Minister Laurie Brereton on just that issue.

The institute is also aware of the importance of making what it does known to the community. It produces a quarterly publication called Family Matters. I suspect many honourable senators have already received copies or looked through that publication. Its intention in 1994 is to make sure that it contributes to community discussion about issues of the family for the year. It will be devoting more of its resources to distributing that information and participating in the debate.

I am delighted that this week we released the annual report of the AIFS. It reinforces just how significant this institute is. I heard my colleague Senator Collins say earlier that some opposite seem to be delighted in talking down achievements in Australia. They should certainly know about the AIFS. It is not only one not to talk down, it is one to talk up. It will be playing a very important and significant role in the International Year of the Family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Yesterday Senator Calvert asked Senator Richardson, the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, a question regarding Norfolk Island and the Native Title Bill. Initial inquiries this morning have revealed that the Mabo unit, which is located within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, has not been able to find any representations from the Norfolk Island government. Should Senator Calvert have a copy of any representations, it would expedite the matter greatly if he could provide me with a copy that I can pass on to the Mabo unit. It has looked and cannot find any representations from the Norfolk Island government. I will endeavour to seek answers to the remainder of Senator Calvert's question as soon as I can.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to a question that Senator MacGibbon asked yesterday regarding the resignation of pilots. In the period since 1 July 1993 no F111 or FA18 pilots have separated from the air force. In the same period, six FA18 and two F111 pilots have applied for resignation or transfer but are yet to leave the service. The air force is aware of one further FA18 pilot who is considering his resignation. Any RAAF officer may submit an application for resignation or transfer to the reserve, which is considered on its merits. In the case of FA18 and F111 pilots, the air force is naturally concerned to retain their valuable expertise. Hence, if such pilots have not paid back a return of service obligation incurred for basic pilot training, a conversion course or similar training, their applications would normally be rejected. Where pilots do not have a return of service obligation, providing the required notice is given, their applications for resignation are normally accepted.

PARA.TAB: There are provisions under air force regulations for applications to be rejected in certain circumstances, such as in time of war and defence emergency, but these do not apply at this time. Pilots resign from various units throughout the year but the training system is designed to provide graduates to replace losses through separation or posting. Additionally, where necessary, experienced pilots may be posted back to flying units from non-flying positions to boost experience levels. While there has been a recent increase in applications for separation from FA18 pilots, providing no further separations occur before mid-1994, graduates from present training courses will replace these losses. Similarly, the two F111 pilots will be replaced through training and posting action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), to a question without notice asked by Senator Patterson this day, relating to mental health and the Burdekin Report.

SPEECH.PARA: The question posed by Senator Patterson today was very important and went to the heart of the recent Burdekin report into mental illness. It is obvious that there is a major difference of opinion between the senior portfolio ministers.
