Senator Richardson today mumbled and fumbled, walked away and implied that somehow the government was going to get back into the budget process next year and look at this report.

PARA.TAB: That is contrary to what the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, said in the House of Representatives yesterday. At question time he clearly indicated that this process of considering the Burdekin report into mental illness would not be responded to overall for a period of, I think, 12 months. That is shameful. I think that certainly would heighten the concerns that Senator Patterson rightly brought to us this afternoon in her question about the effects on many Australians, both old and young, with mental illness.

Mr Howe, of course, is seeking to protract, delay and get out of the budget process. He wants to introduce this into another debate and transfer it to next year. Of course, he will say that he will want to have the time to consult with the states and territories. They will be the scapegoats. If Mr Howe cannot get on with the job simply by calling Commissioner Burdekin into his office for a chat about the report and identifying some of the principal and major issues that were raised in the Burdekin report, he has a serious problem.

I also notice that Mr Howe yesterday referred to complex solutions and a change in culture—a bit like the culture change that obviously Senator Richardson is seeking to impose in the health portfolio. What culture change is so necessary in the area of mental illness or mental health? The fact is that Mr Howe yesterday went in to bat by saying that it would not be in next year's budget process; that it would be towards the end of the year before we start to get any consideration. And then today he came out with a press release which talked about surveys and studies of attitudes in employment for people with mental illness.

Surely there is an absolute dichotomy here between what the minister says one day and his then seeking to pass the buck by conducting more surveys, et cetera. This is the way in which this government approaches culture change that it wants to achieve. It carries out more assessments, reviews and inquiries, and then conducts surveys to convince people about what it wants. It is a matter that the minister must address with priority. My concern today is that Senator Richardson and Mr Howe obviously are not talking about the same issue.

Members of the coalition task force on mental health met and had comprehensive and satisfactory discussions with Commissioner Burdekin a week ago. I would share Commissioner Burdekin's concerns that budget priorities should be flowing in the first part of next year. I am a bit suspicious about this 12-month deferral, because Commissioner Burdekin's own appointment currently has only been renewed on a limited tenure for another 12 months. Is this matter designed to keep the monkey off the government's back? Commissioner Burdekin has identified a lot of issues that need thorough and proper consideration. Mr Howe, by now pushing it out for another 12 months, is obviously trying to keep Commissioner Burdekin at bay—and I find that intolerable.

This is an issue that needs major consideration. I certainly know that Dr Hewson and members of our coalition task force have given this matter priority. We certainly accept that initiatives must be taken to ensure that the response is positive and that inroads are made to the problems faced by people with mental illness, their families and carers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, have very grave concerns about the response that Mr Howe gave yesterday in the House of Representatives. When talking about the consultation process, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will do that in a way which will allow us to consult relevant ministers at state level in March or April next year and to respond to the Burdekin report overall in 12 months.

That is not good enough. Where there is a will there is a way. It is obvious from the Deputy Prime Minister's response that there is not a will and the government cannot find a way. At least Senator Richardson had the judgment to suggest that if the government could not do it by May, it should try to do it earlier. I was pressing him on whether it should be before the 1995 budget and he seemed to indicate that a possibility would be to have some sort of additional estimates to look at that. I call on the government to do that.

PARA.TAB: When I go into nursing homes and hostels, which I do over and over again, I see that the lack of flexibility in nursing home and hostel funding is a major issue, especially with regard to people who have dementia. For example, when I was in a country town in eastern Victoria there was a gentleman with a wife who was only in her early 50s with full blown Alzheimer's disease—the early onset of dementia. He had been locking her up at home so he could continue to go to work. Obviously, that was not satisfactory.

There was no way that he could get assistance until a local hostel, because it received some bequests, had some money and was able to take this man's wife during the day and for two evenings a week to enable him to meet with some of his friends in the evening and maintain some semblance of social life. In that way he was able to look after his wife and, at the same time, maintain his employment and have status in the community in the sense that he was caring for his wife at home with assistance. There is no funding for that—it is so inflexible that he was unable to get any—yet if he had stayed at home, he would have got a carer's pension.

I see case after case—and that could be any one of us caring for people in their early 50s with full blown Alzheimer's disease. Another friend who was in a youth organisation with me when I was young has a husband who is 51 with full blown Alzheimer's disease. She leaves him at home for three days a week on his own and for one day a week leaves him in a facility for young people with brain damage. That is the way we are dealing with things—people are making do. These people have been put at the bottom of the pile, and the government has put them at the bottom of the pile yet again.

I call on Mr Howe to go and talk to some of those people, especially those who are caring for people with dementia at home. All these people were highlighted in the Burdekin report. Obviously, as the shadow minister for aged care, I have taken particular interest in that area. When one goes out to special facilities for people with dementia, one finds that they are threatened with closure because there is no funding for people with dementia in that sense in the aged care sector.

So we see those people and their carers being deprived and having to wait longer than they should have to wait—and longer than I think Senator Richardson thinks they have to wait. I call on Senator Richardson to put pressure on Mr Howe for this government to respond to the Burdekin report and respond to the very real needs that exist in our community for both young and older people with problems associated with mental illness, and do it by the May budget.

The government wanted this budget early and it should not now use the excuse that because the budget is early it cannot do things. The government cannot have it both ways. Either it brings on the budget and speeds up the process, or it leaves the budget until later, addresses all the issues and brings the budget back in due course when it has been planned. Obviously the government has not planned for this and the excuse will now be, `Because the budget is early, we can't deal with it'. I call on the government to deal with it because those carers out there—thousands of them throughout Australia—demand action and demand a response to the Burdekin report sooner than Mr Howe would give us one.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Resources (Senator Richardson), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to advice from the Australian Heritage Commission on forest management.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will recall the question was: on how many occasions has the Minister for Resources—either this minister or the previous minister—actually taken advice and acted on advice from the Australian Heritage Commission with respect to the protection of old-growth forests with high conservation value? Honourable senators will recall that Senator Richardson's reply was that he refused to table either the advice or details of the action which the minister has taken. The reason for that, quite simply, is that in the last three years neither this minister nor the previous minister has ever acted on advice from the Australian Heritage Commission. As a consequence, one has seen the destruction of old-growth forests being driven very much by exploitation at any cost.

PARA.TAB: The factors which the Australian Heritage Commission, and indeed the conservation organisations and the departments in the various states, are feeding in in relation to the damage which is going on, the threatened species which are disappearing, the habitats which are being destroyed, are carrying no weight whatsoever in the decisions in relation to the renewal of woodchip licences.

While I was asking my question, there were interjections also from Senator Boswell, who said, `There the Democrats go again—only concerned about the forests, not concerned about jobs'. The Senate will also recall that this morning I gave notice of a motion stating that Manildra, a company operating out of Nowra, as a direct consequence of the bounty scheme which the Democrats negotiated with the government in the last budget, has now committed itself to a $37 million investment.

This relates very much to the forest because what we are primarily concerned about is not just development at any cost but development which is sustainable, development which does not destroy the job opportunities for the next generation by destroying the very environment on which those jobs are going to be based—development which in fact produces jobs now and at the same time protects the environment on which future jobs will be based.

As a direct consequence of that $37 million investment, Manildra, which is currently making 1.825 million litres—these figures are significant—of ethanol a year, will make 33.3 million litres in the next financial year, 44 million litres in the following year and 60 million litres in the year after that. This is a fuel which will substantially replace petroleum for transport. It is a fuel which is totally renewable. It is a fuel which is produced in regional centres. It provides the sort of employment which should not be provided by tearing down old-growth forests and sending away low-value woodchips and provides a solution to many of the environmental problems which the present consumption of petroleum is causing.

It also launches us on a massive attack on our balance of trade problems. Last year we imported $4 billion worth of petroleum. The bureau of resources and the Australian Institute of Petroleum both say that we have seven years supply of petroleum left in this country and that by the year 2000 we will be importing over $9 billion worth of petroleum.

The development of alternative sources of energy in this country, particularly for transport, is absolutely crucial if we are going to bring together a solution to those three problems: an attack on our balance of trade, a move towards sustainability, and producing the sorts of industries which will provide employment in the long term. So, quite contrary to Senator Boswell's interjection, the Australian Democrats are very concerned about job creation, but job creation which is sustainable and which is not at the expense of the environment.

Again, I enjoin Minister Lee to take on board the advice which he gets from the Australian Heritage Commission, which is coming from state departments of conservation and land management and other departments around Australia, to recognise that there are very few jobs in the forests and that those jobs are temporary because other countries have done what we have not done. They went into plantation timbers, including eucalypt, years ago. There will be lower cost chips available from Chile, Spain and other countries in a few short years. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), to a question asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: We had another classic example today of Senator Richardson's technique of trying to obscure what was a direct question to him. You will recall, Mr Deputy President, that in reply to my question he said that he had consulted with the state health ministers and that they were aware of the figures and the clawback of the funds from the treatment of private patients in public hospitals.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy President, I am delighted to tell you that one of the great virtues of this country at the moment is that all states except my own suffering state of Queensland have Liberal governments. Since question time ended, I have had the opportunity of consulting with my Liberal colleagues. I can categorically state that they were not told any figures whatsoever as to the clawback. There were generalities—the classical technique that Senator Richardson uses—such as `Leave it to me. We've already discussed this'. Those figures were not given.

I encourage the press gallery, represented as it is at the moment by just a sole figure who is valiantly taking notes—but hopefully others are listening to this session—to contact the state health ministers and check the veracity of the statement that Senator Richardson made this afternoon in relation to the figures that he gave us here. He is obviously in trouble with his own caucus and he is obviously in trouble with some of the members of cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—The minister actually told me that he was. Senator Collins may well shake his head, but I can tell him that Senator Richardson is, and he can ask him.

PARA.TAB: The first thing is that the jobs levy has sunk. Senator Richardson has already conceded that in the answer that he gave me this afternoon. He said it was floating. It has sunk. He has not told us that 83 per cent of people in this country who have private insurance are covered by only seven insurance organisations; that nine per cent are in closed funds; and that eight per cent are actually covered by 23 minor, or small—although they might not consider themselves small—insurance funds, 11 of them being regionally based. That is in the CEDA paper, if honourable senators wish to refer to it.

The third tier, as Senator Richardson calls it, is a furphy. These things are all getting knocked over, one by one. His increased levy has gone. His third tier really does not amount to anything. The second tier of his program is to get the insurance organisations to go with the private hospitals and then negotiate capping fees for doctors who treat patients within those private hospitals. That just will not work. It has been tried in the US with preferred provider organisations and it just did not work. Those organisations, those hospitals, do not want to admit patients that are going to go over the diagnosis related groupings.

Senator Richardson does not even understand diagnosis related groupings. He said to Paul Lyneham last night, `It's far too complicated. I can't spend the time trying to explain it to you because it is too complicated'. In politics, if somebody cannot explain it within one sentence, he does not understand it himself. He gave a classic example of that last night.

For the minister's benefit, I will explain to him what diagnosis related groupings are. When somebody is admitted to hospital, the hospital has a fixed sum with which to treat that patient for that disease. It is as simple as that. He could have said that in one sentence last night. But he did not understand himself, so we cannot blame him for not being able to explain it to Paul Lyneham. That system will not work. It has not worked in the United States; it has not worked anywhere in the world. Private hospitals do not want to treat patients that are going to cause them to exceed the fixed sum allowed for that disease process. As somebody said, it gets the patients through faster and sicker, and they are put back into the community.

What the minister is doing is trying to treat a haemorrhage with a bandaid when it needs radical surgery. He knows that. This little bandaid that he is putting on in relation to this so-called reform is no reform; it is tinkering at the edges. Senator Richardson knows the problem, and we know the answer—and that is to encourage low and middle income earners to take out private insurance. Then we will get Medicare working in conjunction with the private health system, as it was 15 or 20 years ago, when about half the patients were treated in public hospitals and half were treated in private hospital. People should be encouraged to take out private insurance so as to correct the imbalance.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 22 of 1993-94: Efficiency audit: cash management in Commonwealth government departments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not delay the Senate for too long on this matter because I know we are all so keen to get back to the Native Title Bill and have it passed. The obvious line to start any address to the Auditor-General's report No. 22 of 1993-94, which deals with the cash management of Commonwealth government departments, would be: another day, another Auditor-General's report and another wastage of millions and millions of dollars by this Commonwealth government.

PARA.TAB: The report that we considered yesterday, which dealt with the Commonwealth government's corporate card, identified millions and millions of dollars wasted in unnecessary transaction costs within the Australian government. After I had addressed yesterday's report, I found out that the Commonwealth government is now using its corporate card—or the Commonwealth credit card, as it has become known over the past couple of days—to pay itself. One Commonwealth government agency is using the corporate card to pay bills owing to another Commonwealth government agency. Last year one agency—I think it was Telecom—incurred costs of $823,000 just in unnecessary transaction fees by using credit cards to pay itself. It is quite phenomenal.

Furthermore, most of us know that Commonwealth public servants and many people employed by the Commonwealth have access to fuel cards. That is the way that the Commonwealth ensures that, because of its massive purchases of fuel, it receives significant benefits from bulk purchasing agreements and also from exemption from excises. Yesterday's report, which deals with the management of the Commonwealth's cash and how the Commonwealth pays for things, found that the corporate credit cards—not the fuel cards—are also being used to purchase fuel and are costing the Commonwealth taxpayer roughly $800,000 a year. That was the amount incurred just from the small sample of departments that the Auditor-General looked at. An amount of $800,000 a year is being wasted because the Commonwealth is not getting the benefit of agreements, such as bulk purchasing, that have been negotiated. So yesterday I found that a few more millions dollars are being wasted.

In the report the Auditor-General refers to the Commonwealth adopting more sensible cash management policies in the way that it deals with cash moving around the Commonwealth and going out to its suppliers, payment of wages and all of the other enormous flows of cash that we could only be horrified at which are moving around this amorphous mass of Commonwealth government. On the first page of the report, the Auditor-General states:

SPEECH.PARA: Arising from the audit findings to date, a number of issues have emerged which have common application across a range of departments and which have the propensity to save many millions of dollars of the Commonwealth's net cost of borrowing.

All of us know that the Commonwealth has enormous borrowings, that we owe enormous debts to international banks and other financiers and that we have an enormous deficit problem in this country. As I said, here we have another day and another Auditor-General's report showing that inefficiency in handling money by this Commonwealth government is costing taxpayers millions of dollars that do not need to be spent.

PARA.TAB: It just reinforces the view that many taxpayers have reached, particularly since the March election—and it is a shame that they did not come to that realisation before the March election—that this Labor government cannot be trusted with people's money. It could not be trusted to run a local corner grocery store; it would mess that up. But in running this enormous business called the Commonwealth government of Australia it wastes millions and millions of dollars every day. I remind honourable senators on both sides and anyone who is listening the Senate today, including those people in the gallery who look fascinated by this, that all of these dollars are extracted from the back pockets of Australian taxpayers who are already struggling under higher taxes. They are about to be hit by jobs levies, Mabo levies, Medicare levies and every other levy that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and his ministers can think of.

The Auditor-General has identified once more inefficiency, mismanagement of cash handling and money within the Australian Labor government. The opposition calls on the government not to keep passing the buck and saying that it is someone else's fault. Let us find a minister—be it the Minister for Finance or the Treasurer or the Minister for Administrative Services—who will take responsibility for some of these issues and say, `We have the evidence. We know how to fix it. Let us get financial management in the Commonwealth back on track. Let us make it accountable. Let us make sure it can be scrutinised properly. Let us try to save the poor old over-burdened Australian taxpayer some money and ensure that what taxes are raised are spent on areas of need—those tens of thousands of Australians who are living in poverty, the Aboriginals and other people who are suffering under this government. Let us make sure that when we do raise taxes, the money goes to those people in need and not to organisations like Westpac in transaction fees that are totally unnecessary'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 23 of 1993-94, efficiency audit, Department of Social Security, protection of confidential client information from unauthorised disclosure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report relates to the protection of confidential client information from unauthorised disclosure. On 16 April 1991, I gave notice that the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs: The question of whether there are effective legal and administrative deterrents to prevent the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of information, as discussed on pages 14 to 16 of the Privacy Commissioner's 1989-90 Annual Report.
This inquiry was conducted by that Senate committee. In its report to the Senate, the committee recommended:

That the government provide as a matter of urgency its response as to action it has taken, is taking or intends to take in relation to the matters raised in the report, in particular: sanctions against public servants who disclose personal information held by a government agency without authorisation; the criminal law as it applies to those who procure the unauthorised disclosure of personal information held by a government agency; and the coverage of the Privacy Act in relation to the Privacy Commissioner's power (a) to investigate the unauthorised procurement and disclosure of personal information held by a government agency; and (b) to award damages to those who have been harmed by the unauthorised disclosure of personal information held by a government agency.

I bring these recommendations to the Senate's attention because they demonstrate that the issue of the `protection of confidential client information from unauthorised disclosure', which is the subject of this audit report, has been in the public arena for a considerable length of time. In fact, this issue goes back even further. One of the first tasks of the New South Wales ICAC, or Independent Commission Against Corruption, was to examine the unauthorised disclosure of government information. In each of his first three annual reports to the parliament, the Privacy Commissioner referred specifically to this particular issue.

PARA.TAB: More recently, upon the release of the report of the ICAC inquiry, this issue has been the subject of a committee of inquiry in the House of Representatives. This audit report relates specifically to the Department of Social Security, and this is pertinent because social security holds personal details about vast numbers of Australians. Social security was also mentioned by ICAC as a source of personal information which had been disclosed to third parties on an unauthorised basis for financial gain.

Given this background, what has the auditor concluded about the protective mechanisms that social security has in place to prevent the unauthorised disclosure of personal information? In summary, the auditor has concluded that social security does have a commitment to the protection of confidential client information. I would be horrified if it did not, given the amount of information that it holds. However, the auditor has found that there are significant vulnerabilities in DSS's protection procedures. Obviously, policy formulation in the area of information protection involves striking an appropriate balance between managing the risks of unauthorised disclosure and measuring the financial and other costs of such procedures.

It is apparent from this report that the auditor does not believe that DSS has struck the appropriate balance. The auditor has highlighted two areas in which DSS's current procedures are deficient. First, the auditor is concerned about the number of officers who have access to confidential information. In the introductory note, the Auditor-General refers to the fact that part-time staff members who have not necessarily had security checks are included in this group, which I find fairly amazing. I am sure that most Australians who have anything to do with social security would also find it fairly amazing.

Secondly, the auditor is concerned that DSS does not have any effective audit trails which can be used to track the use of personal information by departmental officers. Despite the widespread attention this issue has attracted in recent times, the auditor found that DSS has not conducted a cost-benefit analysis or evaluation of its procedures since 1985. Again, I find that fairly amazing, given the enormous pressure involved and the interest that has been taken by both senators and House of Representatives members in this issue.

Disturbingly, the auditor has also noted a degree of confusion in DSS about who has responsibility for ensuring the confidentiality of client information. There should be no confusion; it should be very clear both to the senior officers and to the junior officers, some of whom may wish to bring some concern to the attention of the relevant person. They should know exactly who is responsible for the protection and control of the very personal information that is kept in the Department of Social Security.

The auditor has concluded that DSS's information technology systems do provide some protection against the unauthorised disclosure of personal information, but they do not provide maximum protection, and there is significant room for improvement. For example, currently virtually all DSS officers have access to the personal details of DSS clients throughout Australia. Obviously, there are valid reasons for making this information universally accessible within the department. However, it must be debatable whether every DSS officers requires this amount of information to carry out his or her daily duties. I presume it would be possible to restrict accessibility of the details of interstate clients and clients from other social security areas and have some mechanism when somebody wants to get from one state to another into that database. Why is it not possible to introduce a two-tiered system of inquiries? Surely this could be done without jeopardising the services provided to clients.

The auditor has also identified a distinct lack of audit trails of personal information accessed by departmental officers. It was found that such trails are virtually non-existent unless a specific allegation has been made. It is a case of shutting the door after the horse has bolted. It was also found that the printing facilities attached to personal computers are not subject to an audit trail. I raised concern about the very issue of personal computers and the amount of data they would hold when officers went out into the field with these personal computers. I remember asking—it was in estimates or somewhere—what sorts of safeguards were in place as a result of these personal computers being used.

It was also found that printing facilities attached to personal computers are not subject to an audit trail. This allows officers unquestioned access to information both on their screens and in printed form. More disturbingly, the auditor found that no audit trails apply to the hundreds of DSS application programmers who, if they were so inclined, would be able to download data onto computer discs. Nobody need question the commercial value of large databases of information regarding people on social security who may not be in a position to afford a certain item and who could be integrated into another mailing list. There are all sorts of applications. It is totally inappropriate that this data should be available in this form.
I am not questioning the honesty of these officers, but appropriate procedures ought to be put in place to ensure that the mass disclosure of personal information does not go unnoticed or unaudited.

It is also noteworthy that the Auditor-General has expressed concern about the administration of the DSS's new protection file system. This system was set up specifically to ensure the protection of sensitive information—for example, where somebody could be subjected to violence if that information got out. There appears to be a lack of clarity and understanding of the appropriate procedures in relation to this system. I am sure that Senator Reynolds and other colleagues would have great concern if information about, say, women who may be vulnerable in this system was available. I call on the department to very quickly address the problem of the protection file system that has been identified by the Auditor-General.

The Department of Social Security is currently replacing its entire computer network at a cost of some $100 million. It continually keeps telling us it is right at the forefront of technology—it can datamatch and do all these things. It ought to be at the forefront of technology in the protection of personal information as well. We ought to see those audit trails. Even if it cannot afford to do all of them, there ought to be random audit trails at least so that officers know there is a process of surveillance and they are discouraged from the possibility of thinking about disclosing information.

In the light of the Auditor-General's findings, one must ask whether the appropriate questions have been asked as to whether this new network will ensure the confidentiality of client information. As I have been pursuing this issue—both with the Health Insurance Commission, which holds very personal data about our visits to doctors, any tests we have and all drugs that have been dispensed, and with the Department of Social Security—it seems to me that privacy often plays second fiddle.

The Auditor-General has also indicated that the technology does exist to provide appropriate audit trails and to protect client information. The Department of Social Security has never been backward in ensuring that it has the most up-to-date technology. The Auditor has indicated that he will be releasing best practice guidelines in the area of protecting the privacy of client information, which it believes will assist not only federal departments but also state departments in addressing the issue of confidentiality of client information held by government authorities.

The Privacy Commissioner has also welcomed this audit report. It means that all necessary attributes are readily available—the technology, the best practice guidelines and the support of the Privacy Commissioner. The ball is now in the court of the Department of Social Security and other Commonwealth service agencies. I commend this report for the examination of honourable senators so that they can see that the department is not up to scratch in terms of protecting client information. On behalf of the citizens whom we represent, we ought to be very concerned about that because it exposes a large number of Australians to the possibility of having their data disclosed illegally.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Acting Chairman of the Standing Committee of Privileges for the purposes of its two inquiries relating to the Eros Foundation, I present the committee's 43rd report entitled Possible threats to Senate Select Committee or senators, together with the volume of documents.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.PARA: On 5 May 1993 the following matters were referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges on the motions of Senator Reynolds and Senator Walters respectively:

(a)whether the letter dated 17 December 1992 addressed to the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies by Fiona Patten, spokesperson for the Eros Foundation, contained a threat to the Committee or to Senators in relation to the performance of their duties, and, if so, whether the making of that threat constituted a contempt; and

(b)whether threats were made by persons associated with the Eros Foundation against Senators in relation to decisions concerning x-rated videos, and, if so, whether the making of those threats constituted a contempt.

Briefly, the first matter was referred on behalf of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies of the previous parliament and related to a letter from Ms Fiona Patten, spokesperson for the Eros Foundation. The second matter resulted from a letter by the then Senator Shirley Walters drawing attention to an alleged threat by the Eros Foundation `to out Liberal Party figures if the party adopted what it claimed was a leaked policy document proposing a sex industry crackdown'.

PARA.TAB: For reasons set out in chapter 2 of the report, the committee does not find that a contempt of the Senate has been committed in relation to either matter, but draws attention in the report to the gross invasion of privacy involved in relation to the second matter, in particular, and the incompetence of Mr Robert Swann and Ms Fiona Patten, public relations consultants to the Eros Foundation, in the performance of their lobbying functions. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks.

On 30 August 1993 the following matter was referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges on the motion of the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Senator Barney Cooney:

Whether the advertisement placed in various newspapers by the Watchdog Association Incorporated, which refers to the inquiry by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into the Australian Securities Commission, constituted an improper interference with the Senate's and the committee's exercise of their inquiry functions, or a false or misleading report of the proceedings of the Senate or the committee, and whether any contempt was committed by the placing of the advertisement.
The question which the committee was required to determine was contained in the President's statement when giving the matter of privilege precedence as follows:

. . . the advertisement could be regarded as an interference with the ability of the Senate and the Committee to perform their inquiry functions, and as a false or misleading report of the proceedings of the Senate and the Committee.

Having considered the question, the committee has concluded that no contempt of the Senate should be found in the advertisement by the Watchdog Association Incorporated. While the committee has noted that the advertisement had the capacity to mislead persons reading it, in that it could have left them with an inaccurate impression of the inquiry to be undertaken by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the committee has determined that the relevant officer of the association did not intend to mislead readers and has expressed a willingness to correct any misunderstanding that may have arisen.

PARA.TAB: The committee considers that the association should take appropriate action to remedy the situation in accordance with that commitment. Accordingly, as reflected in the motion which I have moved, the committee has made the following recommendation:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Watchdog Association Incorporated place an appropriate notification of the matters raised in this report, and the Committee's conclusions, in The Watchdog Reporter as soon as possible after the Senate has considered and adopted this recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: The 97th report of the committee is a case study of the safeguards in the Acts Interpretation Act under which parliament exercises its sovereignty over all forms of legislation, both acts and legislative instruments made under acts.

PARA.TAB: The report examines the operation of these safeguards upon two important statutory programs, the administrative details of which are provided by delegated legislation. It then describes the various defects detected in this legislation by the committee and the effect of the Acts Interpretation Act upon these defects.

The Administrative Review Council has recommended the repeal of the present provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act dealing with delegated legislation and their replacement with a new scheme of safeguards providing even greater parliamentary control. This report, however, examines the considerable safeguards presently available to the Senate to assert its control over delegated legislation. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I had almost completed my remarks prior to question time, I would make only one or two more brief comments. Just before question time being called on, I was making quite clear that I personally had no opposition to the government giving land to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in circumstances where they can show a connection with the land under the terms laid out by the High Court. But for this to happen, with the current freehold and leasehold titles that are available, I do not believe there is the special requirement for a new type of title to be created.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that Senator Collins is in the chamber. I recall that, during my speech on marine native title during debate on the establishment of the Torres Strait Regional Authority, I made comment about some matters. Senator Collins, in responding to my speech during that debate, said that I was wrong to worry about indigenous Australians being treated differently under the law because the Racial Discrimination Act ensured that every Australian is treated the same. I strongly disagreed with Senator Collins on that point. That is simply a fallacy.

Whether we are talking about Aborigines in particular cases perhaps being allowed to catch and eat fish which are endangered species or the creation of native title, the fact is that the Racial Discrimination Act is used to justify select groups of Australians being treated differently under the law. If the Racial Discrimination Act operated and were used exactly as Senator Collins told me it was, no-one would be able to catch and eat endangered species and there would be no such thing as native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —The capacity for Aboriginal people to do that has nothing to do with the Racial Discrimination Act.

—It has because people can be treated differently. There is no doubt that many problems must be resolved in terms of education, health, employment and other areas for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. When compared to the national average, the unemployment rate for Aboriginal people is six times higher; their average income is significantly lower; their life expectancy is 20 years less; and their child mortality is three times higher than the national average. But I do not believe that this bill will help solve these problems in any way in the areas where the need is greatest.

PARA.TAB: There are some 66,000 urban Aborigines who will not benefit from the government's Native Title Bill and they are, at the same time, those in most need of effective assistance. The massive legal expense and the massive compensation costs which will surely result from the passing of this bill could be used far more effectively in solving the problems which are currently facing all Aboriginal communities, especially those in urban areas.
On November 6 this year at the National Goals and Directions conference, the Hon. Adrian Roden QC, in regard to Mabo, stated:

. . . it is likely to bring direct benefit to relatively few Aboriginal people. The greater part of the land must now be lost to them. Those who have suffered most, and who stand in greatest need, are least likely to benefit directly from the decisions the High Court has made.

In conclusion, I would like to quote the opinion of a woolgrower from the upper north region of South Australia, who participated in and was a respondent to a survey which my office conducted earlier this year. In his response, he said that the government:
. . . must not be allowed to divide and create separate classes of Australians. Equity must be maintained in that any titles issued or reissued must not be greater (or lesser) on the basis of race.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Bill 1993 will be remembered in Australian history long after our words in this place are committed to the archives. Indeed, almost anything that we as senators say here is irrelevant because, in my view, the die is cast; whether the legislation stands or falls, the expectations and attitudes of Australians, white and black, are already set in place.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is undoubtedly the most damaging and divisive ever introduced into this place because it goes to the heart of Australian culture. If the intention of the federal government in this bill was to unite black and white Australia, it has failed. If it was designed to compensate black Australians for past white transgressions, it has not done so. If it was to establish in concrete rights of ownership of land, it has merely served to make land title more complex and legally muddled.

This legislation has the potential to unleash a racial backlash the like of which we have never witnessed in this country. It will unleash a run of legal challenges for which, ultimately, the taxpayer will be charged. This legislation has cruelly raised expectations amongst Aboriginal groups; it has brought out the greed in many and the hatred in others. This federal Labor government, this Keating government, will undoubtedly be written up in the history books as the most misguided and mischievous of any government since federation.

If the Green senators are seeking to become legends in their own lunchtimes, they will probably succeed with their support for this bill. However, I suggest that all famous lunchtime legends are forgotten by afternoon tea, and so it will be with the current brace. The Native Title Bill itself is some 155 pages; the explanatory memorandum, in two parts, is no shorter; so to suggest that the government has made every effort to produce a concise and clear document is patently wrong.

The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is to be commended for its efforts to canvass genuinely the views of a cross-section of Australians. I congratulate its members, especially those from my side. Senator O'Chee, who was on that committee, did a fantastic job, and I commend him and the others for the work that they did.

Reading the Hansard of these meetings demonstrates the anger, frustration and concern about this legislation. Mr Wayne Wharton, member of the Keooma and Birri Gubba in Townsville, quoted a document to the committee, which stated:

Chairman of the . . . Birri Gubba Land Council, Mr Norman Johnson, said today, that a meeting of over 120 Birri Gubba people, held over the weekend, have decided to "Reject" the proposed Mabo Legislation and condemn the Federal Government of their disastrous consultation process.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether the government consulted many people at all. This same man claimed that the whole consultative process and the $1.4 million given to ATSIC was concentrated on the central Australian Land Council. He claimed that New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland got nothing and were not consulted. His views are shared by the Chairman of the Birri Gubba Land Council and, indeed, all the Birri Gubba people who are traditional owners of an area bounded by Townsville, Charters Towers, Clermont and Marlboro.

PARA.TAB: Mr Paul Coe from the Wiradjuri Nation expressed similar views, particularly about the unseemly rush. He called the legislation a `hall of mirrors', `an illusion'. The New South Wales Legal Service says:

SPEECH.PARA: Our request to you is that you may consider deferring the present legislation until the Aboriginal issues are placed, and all Aboriginal people are accorded the internationally recognised right to self-determination and consequently the right to free and informed consent. Since the Native Title Bill makes reference to international conventions and minimum standards on human rights—those standards have to be applied.
That is coming from the other side of the debate.

PARA.TAB: Dr Michael Back, the executive director of the Northern Territory Cattleman's Association, expressed concern that what could and should have been legislation accessible to all Australians is instead a non-lawyer's nightmare. Everywhere the committee went it spoke with people who felt that they should have been consulted but had not been. I am quite sure Senator O'Chee would agree with that. The committee spoke to representatives from industry groups and companies, individuals—young and old, black and white. That is hardly a sound basis for reconciliation and hardly a basis from which Australia should launch itself into the 21st century.

There are a number of objections being raised by the coalition and I will deal briefly with a few of them. The questions of states rights is germane to the whole philosophy of the bill. Other honourable senators have spoken at length about this. As Senator Ian Macdonald said earlier in this debate, states rights are the same as people's rights. Mr Sam Hulme, QC, as legal counsel for Western Australia, asserted to the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: The practical result is to wholly subordinate state land administration to Commonwealth control, and in Western Australia, of course, that is more than half the land of Western Australia. We list there the kinds of matters which arise, such as fishing, tourism, social welfare, water supply, mining and commerce of all kinds. These will all come under Commonwealth control. We say there is very little left of the state function in that enormous area and that the implications of that are particularly a matter for inquiry by the Senate committee, this Senate which was established as a states house.

His colleague, also legal counsel for the Western Australian state government, expressed similar views claiming the legislation was flawed and that given more time we would find some more flaws; it is not only flawed but also complex. For example, in evidence Mr Michael Eggleston, the executive director of the Department of Mines in Western Australia, said:

PARA.TAB: To understand the bill you have to understand the definitions.

SPEECH.PARA: A past act can occur in the future—that is, after the commencement of the bill. A future act can occur in the past—that is, before the commencement of the bill. A permissible future act can be impermissible in certain circumstances, and an impermissible future act can be permissible also in certain circumstances. I put it to you that it is extraordinarily confusing—almost incomprehensible—to the user.
He went on to say:
. . . how can land administrators, miners, farmers, fishermen, pearlers, tourist operators and the Aboriginal community hope to even begin to make this work?

For rural Australians, the legislation is a potential legal nightmare. Where do farmers with pastoral leases stand? The noted legal firm, Blake Dawson Waldron, in an opinion it gave to the Mining Industry Council on co-existence of native title with pastoral leases, said:
There are arguments extant that the grant of many leases, including pastoral leases, will not have extinguished Native Title, and that those leases and Native Title can co-exist.
The firm went on to say:

There is nothing in the NTB which would prevent such claims being made, nor to prevent the registration of a claim for determination of Native Title to areas covered by pastoral leases. The Registrar may refuse to register the claim, but he is not obliged to so refuse. If claims of co-existence succeed, the following will transpire:-
1.Real problems will occur if any of the arguments suggesting that Native Title co-exists with existing valid leases are ultimately accepted.
Indeed, the mining industry is already gearing up to move offshore, as the coalition has said it would be forced to do. An article in yesterday's Australian written by Daniel Moss stated:

PARA.TAB: CRA Ltd will increase its overseas mineral exploration spending by more than 50 per cent to escape the full impact of the Government's native title legislation, the group's managing director, Mr John Ralph, said yesterday.
Mr Ralph reaffirmed the base metal producer's commitment to greenfields growth but said exploration expenditure was being reoriented to get around the provisions of the Native Title Bill.

"Exploration in Australia is being made more difficult at a time when a number of other countries are improving their attraction as a destination for the exploration dollar," he told a Securities Institute of Australia forum in Sydney . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Here we are, a country with all the resources, with all the things that could make our country bigger and greater, forcing our industries offshore with this legislation. So this federal Labor government, not content with wrecking the economy with high interest rates which stayed for so long and soaring inflation which knocked so many people around in the late 1980s, is now about to put in place legislation that will drive our mining industry offshore.

PARA.TAB: I heard similar comments from numerous sources in Europe earlier this year. People will not invest in Australia given that we have legislation that is a legal nightmare, open to challenge at every turn and likely to create economic and social mayhem. The coalition wants a just and workable solution to the issues of native title, but it must include validation of past grants of land titles; there can be no relaxation of the Racial Discrimination Act; and compensation must be non-discriminatory and available to be sought on equal terms by all Australians.

There is overwhelming evidence to suggest that this legislation ought to sit on the table to allow more discussion, more debate and more understanding. It is imperative that we get it right. But the timetable and tactics of the Labor Party and others in this place—such as Senator Chamarette on my left—guarantee that the bill will not be debated calmly and considered deeply. In the end, the outcome will depend on the last deal made by the Democrats or the Green senators in this place. This is no way to run a country but it is an excellent way to ruin one, and that is what this bill will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to say a few words on the Native Title Bill 1993. Like my colleagues—those on this side of the house anyway—I have received numerous representations from different groups and different people in my state of Tasmania. They have genuine concerns about this bill and they have genuine concerns about the lack of community consultation which has occurred. I therefore take this opportunity to place some of my concerns on record.

PARA.TAB: The Native Title Bill 1993 has served to divide Australians rather than unite them. It is not the blueprint for reconciliation which our community needs, nor is it the blueprint which Aboriginal people deserve. As has been said by just about everybody who has spoken in this place, this bill is being rushed through at the end of the year. It is being rushed through so that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) can achieve his own political objectives. As such, this bill is sadly lacking. If we ever needed any evidence that this bill is being rushed through, I remind the Senate that only this morning some 70 amendments to this bill turned up. That just proves the point that the legislation has not been well thought out. No doubt, more and more amendments will come forward as time goes by.

The coalition's position, as has been stated, was to refer this bill to a Senate committee. We believe that that would have allowed the opportunity for all Australians to have more input. But because of the deals which are done in this place, that opportunity has been lost.

I really cannot understand why we need to have this great rush. At worst, a Senate committee would report back to this parliament in three months. What problem is there with another three months when Europeans have been settled in Australia for some 200 years? Why do we suddenly have to rush in and try to justify the High Court decision and put that decision into some sort of order? A lot of evidence could have been given to us, as happens in the case of a lot of other bills we consider. There is no problem with referring those bills to committees. But in this case, because the Prime Minister, for his own political reasons, wants to rush this legislation through, proper process has not been followed.

The bill should be about cooperation and consultation. Instead, the government has driven a divisive wedge between the Commonwealth and the states and territories, and between non-Aboriginals and the Aboriginal community. Even within the Aboriginal community itself there are varying views that have not been heard.

No matter where one goes, one will find that the failure to consult with the community will only make this bill more divisive. In fact, only yesterday I asked a question to which Senator Collins has been trying to get an answer. Today he came into the Senate and said, `Look, as far as I am aware, we have not had any communications from the government of Norfolk Island'. I have now furnished him with a letter which clearly shows that the Norfolk Island government wrote to Warren Snowdon, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, on 22 November making known its concerns about the lack of consultation.

One would have thought that as Norfolk is part of Australia, the government of Norfolk Island would have been consulted. But, from what I can understand, there has been no consultation whatsoever. The Norfolk Island government is very concerned because it is of the view that terra nullius does not have any relevance to the island and therefore it wonders why it should be roped in by this legislation. That seems to be the general consensus of the government there.

In fact, only a few moments ago I was speaking by phone to a representative of the Norfolk Island government because I wanted to make sure that what I had accused the federal government of was correct. And it is correct. The federal government had not consulted with Norfolk Island in any shape or form. Tomorrow I will be interested to see what answer I get from the minister's department as to why consultation did not occur. After all is said and done, the department has a Mabo unit for that very reason. Here again, because of the rushed passage of this bill, a very important part of Australia has been ignored.

We on this side of the Senate have always supported the principle that all Australians, regardless of their race or creed, should be treated equally. We initially endorsed the government's consultative process in relation to the Mabo decision, but in June 1993 at the heads of government meeting in Sydney it was made very clear by the Prime Minister that as the state and territory leaders would not accept his legal response to land management issues, that response was going to be forced upon them. That is what we are doing right here and now.

In June of this year, the coalition's Mabo subcommittee released its detailed discussion paper on the Mabo issue. In that paper we outlined our views that all Australians should be treated equally under the law, that title should be validated immediately, that native title is law, that jobs and development should not be jeopardised and that mineral rights should be protected. I think Senator Brownhill covered those concerns very adequately in his presentation just a while ago.

We further endorsed the viewpoint that, whilst reconciliation was an issue which should be resolved, it was important that the Mabo issue and reconciliation should be dealt with as separate matters. But for some reason or other, the Prime Minister has tried to muddy the waters by putting them together.

The government's legislation was fundamentally flawed from the outset in that it claims that the purpose of the bill is to ensure the recognition and protection of native title. Anybody with a basic understanding of the law would appreciate that native title is already recognised by our legal system and is already protected by federal law. Native title was recognised in the High Court decision of June 1992. We know that the plaintiffs obtained a declaration of their native title and this means that the bill is an unnecessary duplication of a position which has already been ratified by the High Court.

There are many reasons why this parliament should be more concerned about ensuring that the legislation we pass is correct in the first instance, rather than rushing it through for expedient political reasons. There are those who have argued that the bill should be passed immediately because of the divisive debate which would ensue in the interim period. If that is the case, surely that demonstrates that the basis on which the bill is founded is not one of the views that the widespread community understands. Therefore, this is another reason why this bill should be delayed.

There is no doubt that there are many legal arguments at present—they seem to be coming forward on a daily basis—as to the constitutional validity of this bill. I believe it is inevitable that the legislation will be challenged in the High Court at some stage further down the track. It is also inevitable that any legislation which is passed in this place in haste will not stand up to the detailed scrutiny of High Court examination. Therefore, inevitably, it will be shown to be flawed and all this debate and all this worry will be for virtually nothing.

Perhaps the greatest reason why this legislation should be deferred is the obvious divergence of opinion which is apparent in our Aboriginal population regarding this bill. Not only are sections of our Aboriginal community demonstrating differing opinions; in many cases they are also demonstrating a lack of understanding and consultation. Whilst the government may be pleading that it is seeking to assist the Aboriginal community, what in fact it is doing, again, is trying to push the views of the non-Aboriginal community onto the Aboriginal community.

I know of instances in my own state of Tasmania of differing views between the Tasmanian Aboriginals. We had a situation at Woolnorth, on the north-west coast, in which a group of local descendants of Aboriginals made it quite clear that they were not interested in native title; they were only interested in having access to some of the lands that are sacred to them. On the other hand, we had Mr Michael Mansell and his group attacking them for having that view.

It seems that even in my own little state of Tasmania, which in the early days had a reasonably small population of Tasmanian Aboriginals and where there are many fine sacred sites that need to be preserved, a lot of descendants of Aboriginal people are not interested in native title. Because of confusion and lack of consultation, they are arguing amongst themselves, with other groups and, I suppose it is fair to say, with the Aboriginal industry in Australia, because that is what Michael Mansell represents. Yet to be resolved, as Senator Brownhill said, is what effect this bill in its current form will have on the mining, pastoral, fishing, tourism and forestry industries. They are all very important industries in my state, so we have more than a passing interest in this matter.

My colleagues from Tasmania and I have all received many letters of concern from industry—in fact, some of them have even been published in the press—trying to make the public aware of the effect that this legislation will have on business investment. I know from my overseas experience, as Senator Brownhill does, that many overseas investors are of the view that this legislation will certainly not be in our best interests. It is not good enough at this time in our history, when our economy needs to be improved—it is showing signs of recovery, but it does not take much to reverse that—to have the confusion in the community which is caused by this bill. It is not what we want. At the end of the day, it is certainly going to cost potential jobs in our country.

There have been many criticisms of this bill. These have not been confined just to the coalition. It is a very complicated bill. The bill itself, its explanatory memoranda and the introductory speech comprise something like 250 pages, and the bill has 238 clauses. As of today, another 70 amendments have come in. Goodness knows how many more we will see in the committee stage.

There are certainly grave concerns all over Australia in the rural community about the effect that this bill will have on existing land titles. It is possible that the pre-1975 pastoral leases could be subject to a claim for co-existing native title. Any farmers who find themselves in that position will be forced into the courts. Unlike some of the Aboriginal community, they will be unable to receive the legal assistance they will need to defend their rights.

I was talking to a farmer only last night. With the low wool prices, the overburdening of bureaucracy upon him, and droughts, he is just about at the stage where he thinks he might walk away from it. He and his family have been in the farming game all their lives. This is just another burden, coming on top of the hardships it has experienced over the last decade, that the rural community can do without.

There is no doubt that this bill will lead to expensive and prolonged constitutional argument between the Commonwealth and the states. I believe it is totally unacceptable for the Commonwealth to attempt to manage state land systems and for the Commonwealth to impose its will upon the states undemocratically. The states are never going to accept this scenario. Once again, because the opportunity for consensus has been lost, we will end up with a bill which will only be more divisive.

I have already spoken about the effect that this bill will have on the rural and mining communities. Currently, something like 330 million hectares, or about 43 per cent of our total land, are held under pastoral lease. Areas such as South Australia and Western Australia, where the figures are up to 55 and 44 per cent, respectively, certainly must have a lot of worries about this bill. The bill will provide the native titleholders with the right to veto and impede the economic development of such land. This will place directly at risk some of our large export earning industries.

The question of compensation has yet to be fully addressed. As has been said earlier, it seems that the Prime Minister has virtually said that there is going to be an open chequebook. I do not believe that that is a situation the Australian taxpayer should be placed in. We have to look ahead and just wonder what effect that will have on future budgets. We know that we will have an early budget next year, in May. I wonder what allowance is being made in the budget for compensation claims.

There is no doubt that what we are debating today is not just another chapter in the entire Mabo scenario. This says very little for the government's real ability to assist the Aboriginal community. Our Prime Minister has chosen to play politics and, as usual, to prefer confrontation rather than mediation. Even the government acknowledges that this legislation will assist only between five and 10 per cent of the Aboriginal community. The other 90 per cent will gain nothing.

The bill will not solve the concerns of most of the Aboriginals in this country. It will do little to assist them in areas such as health. Recently a fellow Tasmanian, the Federal President of the Australian Medical Association, Dr Brendan Nelson, claimed that health was the most important issue facing the Aboriginal community today—not native title.

This bill will set back for many years the ultimate resolution of the problems concerning the Aboriginal community. I believe it is inevitable that the government, the Democrats and the Independents will regret that they were not prepared to adopt the views of the coalition and submit this bill to a committee for more detailed and thoughtful analysis, as it should have been.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 June 1992 the High Court of Australia handed down its historic decision on native title in Australia. The decision was greeted by Aboriginal people and many of their supporters with jubilation, joy and hope. After 200 years, the prior occupancy of Australia by Aboriginal peoples was acknowledged by white law. Incidentally, Australia was 175 years behind the United States in taking this position, but it, too, had come to this point 200 years after the foreign occupation and invasion of American Indian people's lands.

PARA.TAB: To Aboriginal peoples, this is one of the first steps on the path to true recognition and justice, but it still falls far short of what they really want. What they really want is an equivalent to the treaty that former Prime Minister Bob Hawke offered them in 1988, which would finally recognise them as equals in this land and, in fact, as the original owners and occupants of this land. These are the words with which Kevin Gilbert crystallised the Aboriginal demands for sovereignty in practical terms:

SPEECH.PARA: A sovereign treaty is the only mechanism in law by which our sovereignty can be recognised.
A sovereign treaty is negotiated between equals.
A sovereign treaty is automatically in the constitution.
A sovereign treaty over-rides state and federal laws.
A sovereign treaty must never extinguish Aboriginal rights, but enshrine and protect our rights forever, under the Vienna convention on the law of treaties.
With all domestic options exhausted, a sovereign treaty is our only peaceful way to justice.
There can be no reconciliation without a sovereign treaty.

We owe it to the oldest continuing culture in the world to do the right thing. It is not only the people who have been calling for a treaty who see the High Court judgment as extremely conservative. It was a very conservative judgment. It was trying to balance the interests and rights of all of us who now live in Australia. It tried to act in a way that would be least disruptive to the status quo.

PARA.TAB: Although it recognised that Aboriginal land had been illegally taken since 1788, it did not order that such lands be returned. It recognised that to do so would be unfair to all those who legally, by way of grant or purchase, own land now. It also said that Aboriginal people could not claim compensation for the theft of the past, except where such dispossession contravenes existing laws—importantly, the Racial Discrimination Act of 1975. It further said that, where land had been validly granted in the past, native title had been completely extinguished in most cases.

The High Court decision was extremely disappointing. The one seed of truth in it, which was the exposure of terra nullius as a legal lie, led us to a different position than the one that this present legislation is taking. Because the High Court went on to say that native title still exists, or potentially exists, on all vacant crown land and that future grants over such land could still extinguish any native title on that land but could only do so in a non-discriminatory way—that is, by doing it in a way that paralleled the process of extinguishing other titles—the High Court decision gave this country an opportunity to refound itself in a totally new way, on a basis of justice. I quote from Xavier Herbert:

SPEECH.PARA: Until we give back to the black man some of what we have taken from him, and give it back in the same spirit that it was taken—without provisos or strings to snatch it back, we shall remain what we have always been, a people without a soul, not a nation, but a community of thieves.

There was the spirit of opportunity to redress the injustice of 200 years; nevertheless, there was good news and bad news for Aboriginal people. The good news was that opportunity, and the bad news was that the authorisation was given to governments to extinguish it. That does not mean that, at this point in time, we have to continue that extinguishment.

PARA.TAB: For non-Aboriginal Australians there was also some good news and some bad news. The good news was that their valid titles were not at risk. The bad news—at least to some sections of the non-Aboriginal community—was that Aboriginal native title interests in land would have to be taken into account in future land dealings. For many of us, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, the High Court decision has presented an opportunity to see a genuine process of reconciliation between Aboriginal people and non-Aboriginal people and a measure of restitution and reparation for the wrongs of the past.

Unfortunately, the brutal and self-serving campaign run by conservative vested interests over the last few months has seen those opportunities recede further and further, to the stage that we are in danger that Aboriginal people will lose what little the High Court felt able to give them. Let us remember that the High Court decision was only about the six or so per cent of Aboriginal people who have been able to maintain their traditional links with the land—the traditional people with the remnants of a culture and a way of life that once covered this vast land.

The irony is that the High Court decision favoured those who have been least dispossessed and offered nothing to those who have been most badly affected or dispossessed by colonisation. The government had an opportunity to redress that and the Greens want to raise the issue and speak on behalf of non-Aboriginal people who believe that even the High Court decision was a travesty of justice to those people who have suffered most in the last 200 years. To detract further from the High Court judgment would indeed be a further travesty of justice.

Traditional people want their rights to land, culture and their way of life to be recognised and protected. They want to no longer feel under continual threat of dispossession. They want to be masters and mistresses of their own destiny and they want to be in control of their own sacred places in ways that accord with their tradition and laws.

I will read into the record a letter sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) by the Mindibungu Aboriginal Corporation. It expresses all of this much better than I could ever hope to. I met with the corporation at Kununurra when it was discussing the implications of this legislation. It filled me with humility that people held out the hope to the government. It filled me with shame that this legislation is all that we can offer them. The corporation gave me permission to read this letter during this second reading debate. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Prime Minister,
Thank you for this opportunity to express ourselves in relation to Mabo.

We are concerned that people have been misinformed on the basis of Mabo, that Kartiya people in the cities and the towns, are suspicious or scared, the way this subject has been discussed. We the people of Billiluna, do not want other peoples land or houses. We accept the Kartiya (white person) and wish to be one in friendship.
We would like the Kartiya to know the truth, our story.

We are the first people of this land, that because we have not put up rock walls or barbed wire fences, we have as strong a right to our homelands. By our nature, it is not our way to keep people out, nor to lock ourselves in.
In our culture the land is our Mother. We are born of this land; we live of this land and ultimately we are returned to our Mother.

Our language is the corner stone and the fence posts that determine where we live. Our tongue may differ from that of the other tribes, but that is what determines where we live. In friendship we recognise the strength of the other tribes language boundaries. Here in the Kimberley as in the rest of Australia our culture is one.
We do not possess land, we are a part of it. In Kartiya ways, even with title, over time possession is just a fleeting moment. A lifetime in the existence of this land is nothing.
As aboriginal people we would like you to understand we are not greedy; but we want it clearly understood that we want rights to our mother land. Rights that cannot be taken from us.

Of importance is the right to have use of the land for our purpose. Be it hunting for gundi (bush potatoe), linga (snake), and other bush tucker; the freedom to move through our lands without being impeded; the right to perform business and law of significance to our culture. The right to determine the use of the land, whether it is good or not good for us.

We understand time does not stand still; that development is needed for the growth of this country. It is not our desire to stand in the way of development, providing progress will be good for all people of this country.

We want to share in this growth, accordingly we want a fair deal for our people, our children and our future generations, that will follow in our footsteps. We are honest and fair people in our dealings and appreciate honesty and respect in negotiations. If Companies wish to use our land they must understand our culture and respect our ways.

We would like development to be done in consultation with us on these understandings. Special areas of the land hold deep significance to our culture and cannot be disturbed. We would not dream of digging up a Kartiya burial ground or drilling for oil in a Church.
With mutual respect and understanding we can make a way for the future. Develop strong links and forge fast partnerships in development, be it mining, forestry or industry.

Although we are people of an ancient land and an old culture, our eyes follow the sun to the dawn; that of a new tomorrow. We look forward to the day when Australia acknowledges our past. That we were here before the flag of the Union Jack pierced our soil. For in our time it is but a brief tear drop.
With your assistance, perhaps Mabo can unite us all. It will give to us our rightful recognition and respect, and destroy the hatred, bigotry and suspicions of the colonial past.
We thank you for listening to us.
The Chairman and Councillors of Mindibungu.

So how far does this legislation enshrine the High Court decision and match the hopes of Aboriginal people like the Mindibungu? Certainly, the rhetoric from the Prime Minister and others supporting this legislation has been very high sounding. But words come cheap, and nowhere more so than on the subject of justice for Aboriginal people. No issue has been so studied and investigated. No issue has generated so many reports. In no area has correspondingly so little been achieved.

PARA.TAB: We have had the Woodward lands rights inquiry, the Seaman land inquiry, the Commission into Racism in Australia, the Law Reform Commission report into Aboriginal customary law and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. How fine were all the words written in these reports; how often the actions fell much short of the rhetoric. The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody is a very good example. Of the 339 recommendations put forward in its report, very few have been implemented.
So how does the legislation measure up? Paul Keating, in his address to the nation on 15 November this year, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this week I will be proposing legislation to Parliament which meets both the spirit of the High Court's decision and Australia's responsibilities and needs.

Does this legislation really meet the Prime Minister's own benchmark? Does it meet the spirit of the High Court decision? Will it ensure that whatever the High Court gave will not be taken away and cannot be taken away by any government acting in bad faith?

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the Greens believe that this legislation falls well short of the Prime Minister's own words in a number of significant areas. It takes away from the High Court decision, and in some cases gives less to Aboriginal people than what the High Court judgment gives. In other instances, it closes off avenues that should have been left to the High Court to decide in the future.
