The Greens WA will not be a party to legislation that leaves Aboriginal people worse off than they would have been under the High Court decision.

One area of real concern is the relationship of the bill to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. While the Prime Minister says that the bill is a special measure in relation to this act, in our view in order to be a special measure it has to discriminate in favour of Aboriginal people. But many of the provisions of this bill discriminate against Aboriginal people. For example, where the bill extinguishes property rights, they are the property rights of Aboriginal people.

In addition, the bill validates past discriminatory legislation based on the legal lie of terra nullius, which could again be used to authorise further discriminatory acts. This bill does not make it clear that, where such inconsistencies occur, the Racial Discrimination Act prevails. It must be amended in order to make that quite clear.

One of the stated aims is to preserve native title to the maximum extent possible. The bill does the opposite. Native title rights to waterways and fishing have been extinguished in a wholesale way. This could have serious implications for coastal Aboriginal communities who rely on them as a source of sustenance. In the area of commercial leases, be they pastoral, tourist or other leases, native title will be extinguished if the lease is found to be invalid due to native title.

This is not required in order to validate. Leases could be validated with the concept of coexistence. There is a certain irony in the fact that, while it does not seem to be obvious to the government in the way that it has introduced the legislation, it is, surprisingly, an area where Richard Court is in agreement with our perception. I quote a letter from him which I received this week. He referred to the federal legislation and said:

SPEECH.PARA: . It contains major departures from the Mabo principles;

-it requires the extinguishment of native title rights as a condition of the validation of pastoral leases. Under the Mabo principles, native title rights are capable of co-existing with pastoral leases and other interests in land . . .
Another reason he cites for the failure of the federal legislation is that:

-it requires the extinguishment of native title rights by compulsory acquisition before pastoral leases and certain other interests in land and waters can be granted in the future. Under the Mabo principles, native title and other interests can co-exist in respect of the same area.

I hasten to add that this in no way indicates my support for the WA legislation, which extinguishes native title and replaces it with a form of traditional usage. But it indicates how ironic it is that the Premier of Western Australia, who has put up such discriminatory legislation, is also capable of seeing the way in which the federal legislation discriminates.

PARA.TAB: The question of pastoral leases is a very serious one to the Greens. It is of fundamental importance because many traditional communities in Western Australia live on pastoral leases. What is very worrying is that little effort has been made to find out exactly who and where the people are whose native title rights will be extinguished by the action of this legislation that is under consideration today. It may well be that these people will not know until the day arrives when they are denied access or are thrown off their traditional lands.

The Prime Minister, in his address to the nation, described this legislation as an opportunity to restore the age-old link between Aboriginal land and culture. If native title is summarily extinguished on traditional lands under pastoral lease, this bill will achieve just the opposite.

A good example of this is the Miriuwung and Gajerrong people in the Ord River areas of Western Australia and the Northern Territory. Ninety per cent of their traditional lands are under pastoral lease, yet they have never given up their connection to their country. They have maintained their traditional connection, despite the disruptions and dispossessions.

They wrote to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. In their submission, they said that they simply refuse to accept the extinguishment of their rights by this legislation. They believe that the coexistence of native title and leases is the right way to go. I will quote from their submission:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the Council's view—
that is, the Miriuwung Gajerrong council—

that native title is extinguished on nearly all Miriuwung and Gajerrong land as a result of this Bill and as such it is unjust, contravenes the Racial Discrimination Act, and destroys the traditional social structure of the Miriuwung and Gajerrong Traditional Owners, and traditional groups across the north of the continent generally.

Even though existing statutory usage and habitation rights are confirmed by this Bill they remain statutory rights only not common law rights. As such they can be removed from the statutes depending on the policies of successive administrations.

Vested pastoral interests are already pressing an uncompromising and aggressive line with this Council in stating that they consider native title to be extinguished as a result of the High Court's decision and the impending Bill. Therefore the Council's constituents register their mounting fears in this area and seek an advice from the Senate Committee and the Party members concerned what their Committee and Party position is on this matter.

That is a plea from people who, in Paul Keating's words, had a ribbon of rights that has been exchanged for a basketful of rights. That is, the provisions in this bill for the conversion of pastoral lease to the native title equivalent, if it is in the control of Aboriginal people, has been done on the proviso that Aboriginal people who would have had a potential for native title rights are having that extinguished. This bill validates any pastoral lease which may be regarded as invalid because of native title rights.

PARA.TAB: I pause at this point to seek leave to take further time than the 20 minutes that has been allocated. We did say when we voted to reduce the time from half an hour to 20 minutes that on occasions there may be exceptions and exceptionally serious matters that would require an extension. I seek the leave of the Senate to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we have an indication as to how long?
—I request a further five minutes. Perhaps I could incorporate the rest of my speech, if that is permissible.

—I guess that we would be happy to accede to it. But I am fairly embarrassed in that I have been pressing my people to keep their speeches as short and crisp as possible and to be mindful of the fact that the government, the Greens and the Democrats have between them literally dozens of amendments which still have to be dealt with. It is a pity that we are asked this, especially on the run, so to speak. It is certainly very embarrassing for me, given that I have been pushing my people all week.

—A further point is involved here. Senator Chamarette may not be aware of it, but it is not the practice of the Senate, except for published documents, to allow incorporations. Unless we know what is in them, we are giving them parliamentary protection in the form of privilege. It certainly has not been the practice of this chamber to allow senators to incorporate speeches. I ask Senator Chamarette to wind up her remarks within five minutes and cover the essential points. I imagine that most of the things she has to say will come up in the committee stage later.

—I support the granting of an extension of time to Senator Chamarette. This matter is very important to all of Australia, but it is of particular importance to the state of Western Australia, which both she and I represent in this place.

PARA.TAB: I think there is a lot of material to cover in addressing this matter. I think we should be as accommodating as possible. I am sure that if the request had come from the other side of the chamber we would have been equally pleased to grant the extension. I certainly support an extension of time for Senator Chamarette.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the point that Senator Reid has made. We all appreciate the time restrictions and I believe Senator Chamarette acknowledges that in her request to speak for a few extra minutes. I also think we should take note of Senator MacGibbon's point that it is not usual to incorporate speeches that have not been circulated in the chamber. It would be by leave that we would do that and I suspect that leave may not be given. Senator Chamarette should be allowed to take five minutes. Senator Chamarette should appreciate Senator Reid's point that she will have many opportunities in the committee stage to incorporate any other points.

—I seek a point of clarification. Mr Acting Deputy President, you know that I was at least five minutes short this morning when making my speech. I want to know whether I will be given leave to finish my speech later.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—That is a question for the Senate.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to Senator McKiernan because he has agreed to reduce his speech by the amount of extra time I take. I accept his offer very gratefully. I hope I can cover my remarks in the time available. I will omit all the bits that refer to the failings of this present legislation because, as has been pointed out, there will be an opportunity to discuss them in the committee stage. There has been detailed scrutiny given to this bill by the Greens and other groups which have brought submissions to us. We have severe concerns. Those concerns are not being addressed by the government's proposed amendments. If the bill remains in its present form it will be clearly unacceptable to the Greens. The bill requires amendments that are far greater than the government's proposed amendments. While there are some good points they really do go back on the intentions of the bill. That is an unsatisfactory position from the Greens (WA) point of view.

PARA.TAB: Despite such glaring faults in the bill there are many people who believe the bill has merit and want to see it passed. They claim that the land acquisition fund, the social justice package, the conversion of pastoral leases to native title, the recognition of native title, the possible overriding effect of the Western Australian legislation and the tribunal claims system make up for any deficiencies in this bill. I am afraid that the Greens cannot agree with that. The reality does not come up to the rhetoric. While there will be some Aboriginal people who will benefit under this legislation, it will mostly be those who already have something in 1993 and those who have very little may have even less.

Mabo was about traditional people and their traditional lands and customs. Nothing in this bill should detract from that. However, there is an obligation on Australia as a country to deal with those people for whom Mabo did not represent justice or a fair reparation for the treatment that they have received at the hands of the non-Aboriginal community for 200 years.

I will also comment on the process used to design this bill. The whole thing has been done in a very political way, like a deal. It is a very white rather than an Aboriginal way. This has marginalised and distressed the very people that this legislation was meant to be all about—that is, the traditional Aboriginal elders, lawmen and women. The way Aboriginal law would have dealt with this would be to let the elders of each community speak for their land. They respect the right of other Aboriginal communities to speak for their own lands and they stay silent on it. What we have done is try to use our white bureaucratic system to wash over the voices and the needs of those communities.

A small and self-selected group of Aboriginal people who do represent very different groups within the Aboriginal community have chosen to negotiate this with the government. In doing that they have been dealing with the rights of other Aboriginal people. Make no mistake, despite the claims to the contrary, the traditional people have not been fully consulted as anyone who heard the evidence given to the Senate committee would know.

Particularly saddening is the response of the opposition to this whole issue. I would like to make it quite clear that there are not just two positions in the chamber; there are three. Firstly, there is the opposition's denial of the need to redress the injustices of the past 200 years and a view that it is unjust to positively discriminate for Aboriginal people. The second is the government's position. It has a fear of fully dealing with the historical injustice because of anxiety about the consequences on the country and a desire to placate everyone, including Aboriginal interests. The Democrats are supporting the government's view and are also speaking out on behalf of those negotiating with the government for Aboriginal rights not to be further undermined.

The Greens position is that until the truth of the historical injustice is acknowledged no healing or reconciliation is possible. If this legislation fails to at least protect existing native title rights based on the High Court's decisions it is unacceptable. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to the Native Title Bill. It is an important bill. I want to put on the record my opposition to it. I do not propose to deal with the technicalities of the bill because we are going to have a very long committee stage.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with a few broad principles. I think the principles transcend all else in this case. The first principle that I want to enunciate is that Australia's destiny as a nation is as one people, as Australians, in one land, Australia. The common link that binds us all is the link of Australian citizenship. It links us all irrespective of our ethnic backgrounds.
The second principle that is very important in this case is the equality of everyone before the law. There are no special cases. There can be only one law. We are all equally judged before it.

I accept the Racial Discrimination Act and its provisions. I also accept the High Court decision in relation to Mabo. Having read the determination of the High Court twice, I must note that the High Court had enough sense to carefully define the nature of native title. It certainly did not promote the general transposition of what it found in relation to Mabo to the Australian mainland.

This bill is quite unnecessary in its present form. It is far worse than that. It is socially very divisive for the fabric of the Australian community. That probably is its greatest defect. It is unconstitutional. It moves against the provisions of the constitution into the whole subject of land title—something which has always been the preserve of the state and is legally the province of the state.

It is confusing legislation. As the Chairman of BHP said, `it is like reading porridge'. It is complex. It is also commercially very destructive for Australia. Let us not have any criticism from the other side about the economic welfare of Australia because the welfare of all of us turns on having a strong Australian economy. We all have a vested interest in that. There are no exceptions.

The legislation is commercially very destructive for Australia because it operates to create uncertainty and extremely high risk in two industries—the pastoral industry and the mining industry. They are two industries which provide between them about 80 per cent of Australia's export earnings.

The final criticism of the bill is that it is totally unfunded. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) on many occasions was forced to admit in question time, the government simply has no idea what this bill will cost the Australian taxpayer. The funding of bodies, such as the land acquisition scheme, for those Aboriginals who do not have the legal pathway to claim native title for land, the huge bureaucracy, the appeals tribunals and all the other things that this bill sets up, result in an enormous cost—a cost which runs into billions of dollars. It would be quite irresponsible for any legislature or any legislator to give the government an open cheque until it has done an economic analysis of what is involved here.

The High Court judgment was handed down about 18 months ago on 3 June 1992. It is only very recently that the Native Title Bill has been presented to the parliament. Late last night we had a dispute in this chamber when it was revealed that the government had more than 50 amendments to it. Goodness knows how many amendments the Democrats and the Greens have. We were asked to go into a debate on this bill without having seen probably well in excess of 100 amendments.

It is appalling management that the parliament is presented again with a blank cheque. We just do not know what we are voting on. We have not had time to study the amendments. There is absolutely no hurry on this. The High Court decision was handed down 18 months ago, and yet the government is telling us that it has to have this bill by tomorrow night or Friday. There is no justification for that at all.

I want to deal with the principal defect of the bill, namely, its divisiveness of the Australian society. It is very sad and very unnecessary. There is an enormous store of goodwill in the Australian population towards Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. Australians are genuinely horrified at the child and adult mortality rates in that community—Aboriginals have a life expectancy about 20 years less than that of European citizens of Australia—and as to the public health of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, to say nothing of standards of living in general and the educational standards attained by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. There are very real concerns in the Australian community about public health, welfare and education. Above all, there is a readiness to pay big money to correct them, provided it meets the target of improving public health, reducing infant mortality and prolonging the lives of members of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community.

I find there is very genuine support in the community to look after those genuine welfare problems. But I have found no support at all in the Australian community for the Native Title Bill per se. The reason is quite simple: the public knows that there is nothing in this bill which will improve the real problems that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community faces. The protagonists of this bill have admitted that 95 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders will not be affected. The things the people in that community suffer from, with respect to public health and education, will not be addressed in any way at all by the provisions of this bill. There is a real possibility, because of the divisiveness that could be created in the community, that they may well be worse off. That would be a tragedy. It is an avoidable tragedy and it need not happen.

As a community we have to address the health and educational problems of the Aboriginal community. They can be addressed and they must be addressed, but they have to be addressed on the basis of need, not on the basis of race. All Australians are entitled to the same standards of public health, education and welfare. That is not held in dispute at all by the Australian community.

I come back to my first principle, whereby one people in one country are equal before the law. It is a bit worse than that because this bill has exposed to the Australian community some people who are pushing socially extreme views. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) technically has committed an act in relation to this which would be described as a folie de grandeur. His emotion has completely replaced any reason in dealing with the matter. His Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs is in precisely the same emotional state. Some commentators in the community have also presented a false and unbalanced view, and I will come to them in a moment.

I will not demean the Senate by descending to the Prime Minister's level and engaging in racist arguments. Suffice it to say though, that I will never be intimidated by the Prime Minister or anyone else who alleges that anyone who questions this bill is promoting a racist argument. Those people ought to reflect on the fate of Senator McCarthy in the United States nearly 30 years ago.

My concern is for the living—for the present and for the future. I cannot undo the wrongs of the past and I will have no part of the guilt industry. I think there is a rather unbalanced view of history about which seems to say that all the faults of previous centuries were by the Europeans against the Aboriginals. If we go back and look at what happened sociologically in Europe with the predecessors of the Western democracies, we find that all social conditions were very repressive according to contemporary standards at that time. Some of the convicts were shipped to Australia because they stole goods that did not exceed half a crown in value. If the goods exceeded half a crown, they were hung; they were not transported. In those days society was terribly oppressive.

We can only try to see that fairness prevails in the Australian community with respect to contemporary standards. With the best will in the world we cannot go back and correct the wrongs of years ago. By all means let us correct the welfare and the health deficiencies that I was talking about before, but let us not bog ourselves down, flagellating ourselves about the wrongs that occurred in the past. They are beyond change; they just cannot be altered.

The other point that concerns me is the argument from the Prime Minister that somehow or other one group of Australians has a prior claim over another to support from the government in this direction. I do not feel inferior to the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander community at all because it has been here for thousands of years longer than my forebears. My forebears have all been here for probably 130 or 140 years on average. For my own part, I do not feel superior to any migrant who came to Australia last week or last year. I see us all as Australian citizens and equal before the law in this country. If we have needs, those needs are to be supported, but we do that because of the condition that we are in—not because of the number of years we have been here, the colour of our skin or our ethnic background.

I mentioned earlier some of the commentators who have got into the public debate. There have been some people with a rather dubious and revisionist view of history. Tragically, they have incited the Aboriginal community to have higher expectations than can be attained or delivered by this government. Some of them even go so far as to virtually incite violence if those expectations are not fulfilled and talk about the comparison of minorities in other countries. I think that it is grossly and wilfully irresponsible of those people to take such a position in public.

This bill is unworkable. There is no legal authority in this country that thinks that this bill can be turned into an act and implemented. The best that could be said about it is that it will be a paradise for lawyers and that hundreds of millions of dollars will be spent in legal fees. But the faults are far worse than the transfer of funds into the pockets of the lawyers. The bill is characterised by its directionless complexity. It will have an enormous effect on the pastoral and the mining industries because it creates massive uncertainty. I believe that as a consequence of that it will affect the welfare of all Australians because it will have a major economic impact on us. The bill cannot survive. If it passes this parliament, it will be repealed at some future date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am acutely aware of the commitment I have made privately to Senator Chamarette that the extension of her time will be taken off my time. That is a sacrifice to me but I have done so because of her interest in this legislation, and knowing the pressure that she is under as a representative of the state of Western Australia. Obviously, coming from a smaller party, she is under much more pressure than I am. She is also under pressure, I believe, because of the indecision that she and her party have espoused in the community. That indecision has made her and her party the subject of pressure from all sorts of interest groups in our society. With that in mind, I made that commitment to her in the spirit of cooperation, in order to assist the passage of legislation through this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, if I do get wound up in my contribution here this afternoon, I ask that you take steps to remind me of that commitment and ensure that I live up to it because I might end up just being a little provocative. I could very easily have been provoked by the previous speaker, who talked about divisiveness in our society. That is perhaps the thing that is motivating me most of all in support of this legislation—the need, the urgency, to avoid division in our community. I am not going to embark on a history lesson as to how our nation has evolved and the length of time that the Aboriginal people have inhabited in country. As the Senate knows, I am a migrant, a newcomer, to this country and to this place. As such, I do not seek to give any history lessons to anybody.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—Senator Panizza should remember the history lesson; I have something more to say about history in a minute. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was reminded of the relatively short history—just going back a few years—of my state of Western Australia when we took evidence in Perth on 3 December from an eminent ex-senator from this place, Mr Fred Chaney. I want to quote just a short paragraph from what Mr Chaney said, on page 447 of the Senate committee Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: There was also a history of extremely effective industry campaigns against attempts to legislate in favour of Aboriginals and land and no Western Australian can forget the harshness and I think the powerful impact on the Western Australian community of a quite brilliant anti-Aboriginal campaign waged in the mid 1980s, with the spectre of a black hand building a brick wall, presumably between the island residents of my own town in Perth and the El Dorado of the riches of the interior. It was powerful anti-Aboriginal propaganda, and I have absolutely no doubt that the capacity of people to whip up hatred against Aboriginal people is very great.
That is a former distinguished senator of this place, a member of the Liberal Party of Australia. They are his views in support of the passage of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that while he was here.

—In actual fact, he did say it when he was here. That is part of the reason why he did not get preselection for the seat of Curtin in his home state, if Senator Panizza recalls. Senator Panizza probably would know that a nickname attributed to former Senator Chaney was `red Fred'. So retribution happens in all political parties. I have outlined one reason why I think we should proceed with this legislation. Already in my state of Western Australia and in the national newspapers of Australia we are witnessing the hate campaign that is being whipped up against Aboriginal people. All sorts of stupid and misleading stories, distortion of the High Court decision and distortion of the content of this bill are being whipped up in our society. It is showing itself on the ground.

PARA.TAB: At that same hearing in Perth I asked Mr Rob Riley a question. Mr Riley is the executive officer with the Australian Legal Service of Western Australia. I asked him if there were any incidents where the impact of the scare tactics was being shown. Mr Riley said:

SPEECH.PARA: Without a doubt, that is the case. We have already had instances where parents have made approaches to us about their children being subjected to a whole range of negative criticism and derisive comments being made in respect to the Mabo decision. We have already had instances where people are subjected to physical violence. In fact, there was an incident the night before last as a result of which a man is in hospital with two broken legs, two broken arms and quite a number of ribs broken.

That incident came about not only because of disagreement over the actions of the state government but also because of the information that people were repeating—that Aboriginal people are going to be claiming 80 per cent of the state and that backyards are under threat. Our organisation is seeing instances of that happening.

PARA.TAB: Where are they getting the information from? I have already mentioned newspaper articles and newspaper advertising. They are also getting it from a pamphlet which was produced by the mining industry sources and circulated to every household in Western Australia—a complete fabrication, a complete distortion of the truth, and a total disgrace to the organisations that produced it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the one with the bodgie map in it?

—Yes, and a very difficult one to read. The hate campaign is coming from other sources as well. Unfortunately, distinguished members of our community are also to blame for making claims and creating hatred, bitterness and bigotry in our society. Senator Panizza a little while ago invited me to quote Mr Campbell, Mr Grill and some others. I will not do so, but I will quote one of Senator Panizza's elected members of parliament, a Mr Ross Lightfoot, a person who made the most disgraceful statement that I have heard this year—the Year of the Indigenous People. What did Mr Lightfoot have to say? Mr Lightfoot said on the 7.30 Report on 10 November 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: Aborigines were never civilised. Even in their primitive state today, they are only the bottom colour of the civilisation spectrum.
That was an elected member of the Western Australian Legislative Council making comments like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame.
—The shame is that Mr Lightfoot has never been condemned in this chamber or even in the other place.
—You humbug!

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! That is unparliamentary. I ask the honourable senator to withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unparliamentary, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—I am asking you to withdraw it.

—I am getting to that; I am withdrawing it. I would also like to remind Senator McKiernan that that statement by Ross Lightfoot in Western Australia was disowned by everyone else, including our party president.
—Senator Panizza, I have asked you to withdraw, not to make a statement. You can make your points at a future time.

—In the Legislative Council of Western Australia on Wednesday, 17 November 1993, Mr Lightfoot is shown in the Hansard as interjecting, `There never was an Aboriginal civilisation'. The evidence is there.

PARA.TAB: I received a letter dated 10 December 1993 from the Australian Mining Industry Council. Included with the letter was a booklet. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I attach for your information a booklet prepared by Messrs Freehill, Hollingdale and Page entitled "Native Title in Australia". The booklet was not prepared at the mining industry's request.
Those words led me to think that this might be an impartial document. The letter says:
Some of the comments made in the booklet certainly reinforce many of the points which the mining industry has been making—for instance:

I carried out a little further examination. I noted that the authors of the booklet were Bruno Camarri and Peter van Hattem. The two gentlemen named are not impartial to this whole debate. It cannot be said that the authors of that booklet, which was not commissioned by the mining industry, are impartial.

PARA.TAB: When the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs took evidence at public hearings in Perth on Friday, 3 December, Mr van Hattem appeared before the committee. He gave his name and address as Peter van Hattem, partner in Freehill, Hollingdale and Page, 15 William Street, Perth. His opening comments were:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to explain that I am a legal practitioner. I have been asked to assist the pastoralists today and later the fishing representatives and also the mining industry.

Mr Camarri, the other author, also appeared at the hearing. According to the Hansard report, he is Mr Bruno Giovanni Camarri, legal adviser to the Western Australian government, 19th Floor, Capita Centre, 197 St Georges Terrace, Perth. His opening comments were:
I am here in my capacity as legal adviser to the West Australian government. The submission that I am part of has been prepared in conjunction with Mr Humphrey.

He was also with the Western Australian government. Clearly, the AMIC is attempting to distort the truth and change things around. Really, it does not need to do that. This is complex legislation, it is important legislation and it is valued legislation. The AMIC should merely address the facts. The subterfuge that has been brought to the fore and then exposed in respect of this letter and booklet says more about the representatives of the Australian Mining Industry Council than it does about the subject matter of the debate.

PARA.TAB: Another Liberal Senate colleague of mine, Senator Sue Knowles, has also contributed to this debate. Senator Knowles was very indignant about the fact that a large number of government amendments were presented to the Senate today. She expressed some difficulty in dealing with them. I have looked at the amendments that the government has prepared. Some of them reflect the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which met for over four days, not three and a half days, as Senator O'Chee said. Included in the very first amendment is one of the recommendations that the committee made about setting up some form of monitoring body—a joint parliamentary committee—to oversee how the legislation is geared up. From memory, the government has presented to the Senate 14 pages of amendments. Western Australia has legislation which is supposed to reflect the High Court's decision on Mabo. This government inspired bill was introduced into the Legislative Assembly in Western Australia. How many pages of amendments did the Western Australian government present when its legislation reached the second reading stage? It had 20 pages—not 14 pages—full of amendments to put into its own legislation. This feigned indignation that we heard from Senator Knowles here today has not made its mark at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Liberal governments never do that!
—It was indeed a liberal government.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the great sacrifice that I made to enable Senator Chamarette to extend her speaking time, I will conclude my remarks. I think we are on the same side on this very important matter. Indeed, all 12 senators in this chamber from Western Australia have responsibilities to the electors who put us here. They made their decisions at two general elections. We have responsibilities to them. I know it is a vain hope, but I make a plea to my colleagues on the other side of the chamber to stand by their constituents and act in a way that reflects the common law of Australia that was made in the High Court decision in June last year. They should forget their vested interests. They should not worry—all they can give them is a quid. By voting the right way on this piece of legislation, they will be protecting their own dignity. It is, after all, the Year of Indigenous People. It will only be so for a few more days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Bill obviously generates a great deal of emotion and a great deal of feeling. Senator McKiernan's contribution to the debate shows that par excellence. I do not wish to go into all the points that Senator McKiernan raised. Many of them have been dealt with and debated already and I am sure that many others will also be dealt with.

PARA.TAB: Senator McKiernan raised one point that I cannot let go without comment. I say very sincerely and very seriously that it really concerns me greatly as an Australian to find accusations made that somehow or other, because people are opposed, for whatever reason, to the particular bill that is now before the parliament, they are somehow or other engaged in a campaign of hate. In my view, that is a quite unacceptable statement to make. I certainly reject it absolutely and totally on behalf of myself, I am sure all members of the coalition and, I would think, all those millions of Australians who have expressed genuine concern about aspects of this bill. I would have to say that the old argument of Lenin, `If you are not for me, you're my enemy' is a very dangerous route to go.

There is no doubt that the consequence of the debate that has been taking place not just in this parliament but in the community for a long time now and certainly since the High Court's Mabo decision came down in June 1992, particularly as reflected in the legislation now produced by the government and being debated here, is that that bill will divide Australians rather than unite us. Indeed, the debate is showing the extreme way in which that is happening now. From my own personal position as the coalition's shadow minister for multicultural Australia, citizenship and immigration, I have a very deep abiding interest, as do all Australians, in ensuring that what we do in our very culturally rich and tolerant society does not work against the unity and strength in diversity that we have in our society. This bill does in fact do that.

This bill for that reason—let alone the technical and other problems associated with it—really ought to be taken back to the drawing board and given much longer and more detailed consideration. Although I know it is late in the day and a further plea will probably fall on stony ground, once again I continue to urge the Australian Democrats to think much more carefully and closely about this bill having to be rushed through before Christmas. If this bill is to be passed before Christmas, despite the fact that we will have a very long debate on it here, it is still being rushed through.

The one reason that the government wants to have this bill passed before Christmas is based on the claim that, if it is not passed in that period, it would have difficulty in holding together the necessary coalitions of interest. In other words, the fragile consensus would fall apart if the bill were deferred until February or March.

This is perhaps the most important piece of legislation that any of us here will ever debate while we are in the parliament. To think that this legislation will be based on a fragile consensus which, in the government's own thinking, will fall apart if its passage is deferred for a couple of months is surely the strongest statement that one could make to urge its deferment and further consideration. As I think was said by my colleagues who were members of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which produced the report on the Native Title Bill, national legislation on such a vital policy issue should not stand on such fragile foundations. For the government to suggest also that somehow or other this bill is the only appropriate response to the High Court's decision on Mabo is absolutely improper.

I pay great tribute to my colleagues Senators Vanstone, Ellison and O'Chee for the great job they did on the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in the very limited time available to them, because the minor parties were not prepared to see this bill given proper legislative committee consideration. My colleagues have rightly made the point that there are many responses, legislatively or in terms of the parliament, to the High Court's decision on Mabo which in no way would take away from the High Court decision but, on the contrary, enable it to be recognised in administrative law in a proper way that brings the nation together and does not divide it. It could be done in a way that brings Australians together and does not divide them, that seeks a cooperative approach between the Commonwealth and the states rather than the approach contained in this bill, which is a truly centralist bill of enormous proportions. Because of that, this bill strikes at the whole fabric of our federal system. But even worse or equally bad, it smacks of the worst possible form of paternalism that one could imagine.

It is surely the ultimate and bitter irony for this government—a government that preaches that it wants to enhance the rights of all Australians and to enable them properly to participate in the running and decision making of this country—to take such a paternalistic approach to arguably the most important piece of legislation we are ever going to deal with.

That is not just being said by people on this side of politics; it is being said across the spectrum. It is being said by many leaders in the Aboriginal communities. It is being said by people like Charles Perkins, by people like Pat O'Shane, and by people like Lois O'Donoghue. It was said in my own state, in my local newspaper in Brunswick a couple of weeks ago, by the Chief Executive Officer of the Aborigines Advancement League, Reg Blow. He quite rightly said that this bill will affect only 10 per cent of the total Aboriginal population in Australia. Therefore, by definition it will disadvantage the other 90 per cent, particularly those members of the Aboriginal community who are urban Australians. They are just some of the reasons why the coalition feels so strongly, along with so many other Australians, about the difficulties and the dangers of this bill.

The Native Title Bill will have major effects on the future economic, social, judicial and probably political structure of this country. First, let me say—and others have said it, but I think it bears repeating—that the High Court's decision on Mabo 2 really was an extremely dangerous example of the court making a political and social statement under the auspices of legal interpretation. Overturning terra nullius and establishing a new form of land right, native title, regardless of whether one thinks that is a good or bad idea, is surely the proper responsibility of the parliament and of the people, not of the judiciary.

The High Court in effectively parading itself as an alternative legislature is irrevocably politicising itself, its decisions and its members. As my colleagues have said, it will inevitably embroil the High Court in political controversy; it is certainly a new direction for the High Court. There are already signs that this approach has lowered and will further lower its standing in the community. That outcome would be most regrettable because the High Court is the pinnacle of our judiciary and the judiciary, of course, is one the fundamental cornerstones of our system of government and institutional arrangements in Australia. It is of the utmost importance that that court maintain and be seen to maintain its integrity.

The real criticism that has been levelled at the High Court's decision is not, as the Chief Justice has suggested, that courts do not make law. The real criticism has focused on the revolutionary nature of the court's Mabo decision in overturning 205 years of settled land law. This issue or principle of the role of the High Court is critical and of national importance. As I have said, the parliament is the fundamental element of our basic institutions that should make the law, not unelected judges. As my colleague Mr Reith said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any attempt by the High Court to make the law and usurp the role of the Parliament, in circumstances where it concludes that the Parliament has abrogated its responsibility, will only ignite a furious and damaging debate in which the Court's reputation could be severely damaged . . .
I would add, that would be accompanied by all the dangers that holds in respect to our whole system of institutions, institutional arrangements and federation in this country.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's approach to the bill has been based on three essential pillars of principle. They are worth restating because I think there is an impression in some areas of the community, fanned by quite false and misleading interpretations of the coalition's attitude to this matter, that somehow or other we want to buck the High Court decision on Mabo. That is absolutely wrong.

The first basic pillar of principle on which our whole approach to this is based is in fact a recognition of the High Court's decision that native title exists nationally at common law. We may have differing views amongst ourselves as to whether the High Court decision was good or bad but the fact remains that we recognise that the High Court decision does exist nationally at common law.

The second basic pillar of principle is the recognition that native title is protected by the existing federal law; namely, the Racial Discrimination Act. We reaffirm our support of the Racial Discrimination Act. The third basic pillar of principle is our recognition that the states have constitutional responsibility for land management and the need for this to be maintained, because to do otherwise would, as I said earlier, undermine the whole functioning of our federal system.

Those three principles which we have brought to our approach to this particular bill are based on a detailed discussion paper released in June this year by the coalition's Mabo subcommittee after very extensive consultation with Aboriginal communities throughout Australia—a process of consultation that I must say is absolutely unparalleled and totally unmatched by anything that this government has done. This government has adopted the same corporatist approach to this piece of legislation as it has adopted to government during its period in office; that is, it picks out half a dozen people to talk to, namely, the big players in what the particular game is, forgets everyone else in the community who may have a vital interest in it and then presents to the rest of the community as a fait accompli findings, results and decisions based on that corporatist approach.

So our discussion paper was produced only after very extensive consultation with Aboriginal communities and others throughout Australia. The main points of that discussion paper very clearly demonstrated the consistency of our whole approach to this quite crucial subject.

In summary, that paper said: first, that all Australians should be treated equally under the law; secondly, that titles should be validated immediately; thirdly, that native title is the law—we accept that; we recognise that—fourthly, that jobs and development should not be jeopardised; fifthly, that mineral rights should be protected; and, sixthly, that the process of reconciliation should certainly continue to be pursued but that the Mabo issue and reconciliation are two quite separate things and should be settled separately. Indeed, I would go further and say that the basic reason for our view on that is that if the government does not separate the two, it will muck them both up. That is precisely what is happening with this bill.

Economically, the bill will lead to continued uncertainty about property titles and rights; hence, a reduction in investment in key mining, pastoral, exploration, fisheries, tourist industries and others. Jobs and export creating developments, which are currently under consideration, will either be shelved altogether, postponed indefinitely or reassessed to achieve higher returns in lieu of the higher risks or scaled back to minimise exposure.

Many business leaders in Australia have expressed their concerns. They are not the run of the mill business people; they are amongst the most responsible and non-political business people. I cannot think of too many others who would want less to get into a political fight than some of them—people like Mr Prescott from BHP, Mr Barnett from Pasminco, Michael Folie from Shell Australia and so on. They have felt so strongly about this matter that they have been taking out advertisements throughout the nation pointing out the dangers of this legislation and urging, not that the whole thing be scrapped, not that we forget about everything that has happened—we cannot do that because there is a High Court decision, which we all accept—but rather that the politicians, in particular, should go back and have another look at it to see whether there is not a better way of achieving the results that we all want.

I am pleased to see Senator Margetts here because I say to her, and particularly the Democrats: please, let us have another look at this legislation; let us take our time on it. Another couple of months will not make any difference. Let us hope that we can produce something that will unite rather than divide this nation.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! I understand that an arrangement has been made between Senator Burns and the Whips about restricting his speaking time. He has asked for the clock to be set for five minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to rise to support the Native Title Bill and I want to briefly refute a couple of comments that have been made. Reconciliation is not possible without addressing the land rights concerned with native title. That is a clear attitude of Aboriginal people and it takes two people to bring about a reconciliation.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to hear people on the other side talk about people being equal before the law. Senator O'Chee made much about the White Australia Policy and I agree totally with his condemnation of that sort of attitude. I do not think I would agree with him on too many other issues, but he is right about that.

If one looks at the constitution, which was negotiated virtually by conservative parties who were then in charge of the colonies, it quite consciously froze out the Aboriginal people from being recognised in terms of their right to vote and their right to be recognised as people in the community.

Comments have been made about the divisions that will occur in the community. That was always inevitable. When people are given some rights, whether they are entitled to them or not, and there is some argument about it, there will always be division in the community. If our concern about possible division leads us not to give justice to the Aboriginal people, then I, for one, would be totally ashamed of this nation.

When one looks at the role of the states, which of course looked after the Aboriginal issue up until 1967, when the referendum gave rights to the Commonwealth government, their record is shocking. The record of Labor and non-Labor—the National Party, the Liberal Party, the UAP; all of them—over the years whenever they have had anything to do with Aboriginals has been quite shocking. I, for one, am glad that the Commonwealth government got that opportunity in 1967.

For many years back in the 1960s I was involved in an organisation called the Federal Council for the Advancement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. Its only support was its own activities and many of the left wing and fairly moderate trade unions. It did not get any assistance from governments as such, but it certainly did from some politicians on both sides of the house. For that, the council was grateful, and I recall `Nugget' Coombs being very helpful in that area.

This bill has been brought about because people have not been dealt with equally before the law over time. I must reflect that there are many people on the other side of the house who say that people should be equal before the law but who have belonged to organisations that have never before raised this question when Aboriginals have been disadvantaged. In the 1970s we had situations like the one in the gulf where the police came in one day in boats and took away a group of people who had lived in a particular area for many years and burnt down their accommodation because it was not convenient for them to be in that area as far as a particular mining company was concerned.

I cannot say that this bill is absolutely perfect and that there will not be some problems that will have to be dealt with. It would be quite unusual if it were perfect, because I know of no legislation that has gone through this parliament that has not later been amended for one reason or another. But I would suggest that, if it is not perfect, the committee stage will offer the opportunity for people to use their creativity to put forward some views.

Previous speakers talked about the lack of consultation and the lack of time available to come forward with a document that is as near perfect as possible—that we need further time. I suggest to Senator Short that he has either been hoodwinked or he is trying to hoodwink people in this nation. If we give time to people with enormous resources like the mining lobby—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have listened to Senator Burns in silence and I think he respects that. I just point out that he suggested that Senator Short may be trying to hoodwink people. While I know he is making a debating point, that goes a little too far. I think it is offensive and suggest that he be asked to withdraw it.

—I withdraw and put it this way: I believe that Senator Short cannot see that people are trying to hoodwink him into believing that what he says is factual. Given time, they will use their resources to try to destroy this bill, to try to prevent Aborigines from getting justice in terms of land rights.

PARA.TAB: As Aborigines say time and again, they belong to the land; the land does not belong to them. They do not see land like we do, so it is tremendously important, as far as they are concerned, that they get some justice in this regard. For the first time, to my knowledge, there has been unity amongst the main Aboriginal organisations. Those organisations have certainly talked to a caucus committee which I chair and have asked us to support certain aspects of the bill. There has been tremendous consultation. I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short pointed out, the Native Title Bill is arguably one of the most important bills to come before this parliament, certainly in the experience of those in the chamber and possibly since Federation. I think it is true to say it is conceded by all those for or against this bill that it will have significant consequences for our nation. I believe, along with my party, that the consequences of this bill for Australia will be adverse to Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people alike.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal Party is opposing this bill, and Senator Short outlined very carefully the reasons why. In summary, the bill is unjust and unworkable. The High Court decision on Mabo should have been left to the states to implement. Nothing the judges said in their decisions required this bill or anything like it to come before this parliament. The bill tramples on our constitution, which gives the states responsibility for land control and management. I say to those who support the bill: when you trample on a nation's constitution, you do so at great peril because that establishes rules which apply to one and all—your opponents and your friends.

Inevitably, the Mabo decision of the High Court was going to cause a legal upheaval of significant magnitude, but this bill complicates an already difficult decision. Some 102 years ago, Sir Henry Parkes, one of the driving forces of our federation, made a speech in the Sydney Town Hall. The speech was entitled `One people: one destiny'. These words became the slogan of the federation movement which created Australia as we know it today. It aptly describes, in my view, the philosophy with which this nation should continue to move forward.

You will be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are radical groups with a separatist agenda. There is a move to encourage the United Nations to reinterpret the self-determination clauses in human rights conventions so that they apply to indigenous peoples who are already part of a sovereign country. Such a reinterpretation would enable Aboriginal radicals to argue that they had a right to establish a separate Aboriginal nation. This notion, happily, is rejected by most people in the Aboriginal community. Nevertheless, there are those who, rather than talking about one people with one destiny, would see a divided nation with separate destinies. I regret this Keating bill—and that is what it is—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! You will address the Prime Minister by his correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that this bill, designed and developed by Mr Keating, can only encourage separatist tendencies in this nation. One people, one destiny—the slogan of Sir Henry Parkes—embodies two important values. The first is that all our people, regardless of race or ethnic origin, should be subject to one law. The second stresses the community of interest between all groups—that we should move forward as one people with a single destiny.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that there is profound disquiet in the Australian community about the Mabo bill. I think this has been acknowledged by even a number of Labor Party speakers who have pointed to the fact that support for the bill is so fragile that should it be held over until parliament resumes in February, even this support may collapse.

There is great unease in the community about Mabo. This is not due to any lack of concern about the appalling conditions under which so many Aboriginal people live in this country. There is no question that many Aboriginal people suffer serious unemployment, health, educational and housing problems. Of course, Australia and the Aboriginal communities themselves must address these problems. There is no doubt that the ALP government's policies in these areas have failed to date and it is the expectation of us all that as serious problems have been identified they should be addressed.

The deep-seated concern about the Native Title Bill is not due, as some would allege—I think Senator McKiernan may have raised this issue—to complaints from the mining and pastoral industries, well based as those complaints are. It is fundamentally due, I believe, to the fact that there is a fear in the Australian community that we are setting up laws which, however much we attempt to gloss over it, address disadvantage on the basis of race, rather than the disadvantage itself.
I thought Senator Ian Macdonald expressed this point very eloquently in his speech earlier in this debate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is very difficult for me and for most Australians to understand just why the assistance to the disadvantaged is not allocated on the basis of the extent of the disadvantage but rather on the basis of one's racial origin.

As in virtually all significant political debates, there are clashing principles which are very difficult to reconcile. On the one hand, as I have said, there is the great Australian value that all people are equal under the law and that laws should apply to all, regardless of race, religion or creed. I think Senator O'Chee made that point rather well. On the other hand, there is a view—and this is stressed by people on the other side of the chamber—that a historical wrong has been committed and the only way to right this wrong is through special laws which apply to particular groups. Senator Chamarette expressed the view in her speech that unless this historical injustice is acknowledged, there is no chance of reconciliation.

PARA.TAB: It is true that for much of our history, Aboriginal people did not enjoy the same rights as others—and of course that is to be deplored—but in the last 20 or 30 years we have ensured, through quite a number of ways, and above all with the goodwill and support of our people, that all Australians must be equal under law. It is my fear that we are going to reverse this principled position.

I believe that no-one would look back on Australia's history of relations with Aboriginal people and feel anything but despair. Nevertheless, there is one lesson to be learnt from this appalling record. Governments, time and time again,—and, in more recent times, often despite the best of intentions—have made things worse rather than better. If this bill passes the Senate, it will be seen as another historical failure.

I wonder whether we make a mistake when we think we can only deal with the Aboriginal issue on the basis of thinking about a collective and a community. This chamber, with its diversity of people with different values and different views, deals with those people, essentially, by emphasising the individual relations between people. To an extent, we can look at what are seen to be common problems with the Aboriginal people and address those, but essentially reconciliation takes place between the individual people in the suburbs of our cities and in the country towns. The worst way to affect that process is to give people special rights and privileges.

There will be an argument as to whether a bill granting native title is inherently racist or, as some would argue, is merely recognising a particular group of people who happened by historical circumstance to be the first settlers in this country. That is an intellectual debate, and people of goodwill will take different views. In my view, there is no argument that this bill, in the way it seeks to define native title and the legal superstructure with which it constructs that definition, does confer special and particular rights. For example, there is no reason why mining or the compulsory acquisition of land should be restricted in native title land in a way that is different from virtually all other interests in land.

The tribunals and the Federal Court, which will be used to assess native title claims, require that there be an Aboriginal assessor. This can be interpreted in no other way than as an attempt to bias the court decision. The original Mabo decision required no such assessment. This is a Mr Keating addition to the original Mabo decision.

The National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Fund applies only to people of Aboriginal origin. The purpose of this fund is to address the problems of Aboriginal people who will not be able to benefit directly from the Mabo decision—on some estimates, up to 90 per cent. This fund applies only to people of Aboriginal origin. We should be mindful of the comments of Senator Ian Macdonald on this issue.

The High Court Mabo decision required no such fund. This has nothing to do with what the judges were talking about. There is an expectation that this fund will enable Aboriginal people in cities to purchase land. A non-Aboriginal person in exactly the same circumstances has no such entitlement or claim on the fund.

It is of great concern that this bill does not spell out in any detail how this fund will operate. I believe the government is being deliberately deceptive in the bill. The operation of the fund will be left entirely to subordinate legislation. These regulations come into effect until they are disallowed in this chamber—if they are. I would be very interested to see why the scrutiny of bills committee allowed this clause to go through without comment. With these actions, the government has raised fears in the community that special rights and privileges are being established. That is why support for this bill is eroding and will continue to erode. In my view, the Australian people will not accept a position which allows for two people with two destinies.

Let me briefly list the huge uncertainties which Australia is now facing as a result of this bill. There is a question of whether the bill is constitutional. I think Mr Court has already signalled that there will be a High Court challenge. Under this bill, at this stage, there are no accredited states to administer the bill, and the Commonwealth has no titles office. How can anyone in Australia acquire a secure title with such uncertainty? The terms of the bill are so profoundly complex that they would encourage interpretations and legal challenges for every matter handled under it. The procedures specified in the bill create the potential for an effective veto on exploration and mining.
Let there be no doubt that this bill will have a major adverse impact on the future develop-

SPEECH.PARA: ment of Australia and on the future living standards of all Australians, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal alike. Already, native title claims extending from the High Court Mabo decision now cover an area roughly the size of Victoria and New South Wales. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a map prepared by Arthur Robinson and Hedderwicks, a leading Australian legal firm.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many would say that these claims will not be successful, but the very fact that they have been made and are currently on foot will in itself be a serious impediment to future investment.

PARA.TAB: Recently, a Queensland company, QCT Resources, said that the Birri Gubbi claim, which has been dismissed by Senator Reynolds as having no proper standing, has temporarily delayed development of the Longwall Coalmine and made negotiations over refinancing and group borrowings more difficult. This underlines a fundamental problem with this bill.

Such industries as mining, pastoral, tourism and fisheries need secure titles on which they can invest. The bill provides no clear way of dealing with these claims, which are already holding up necessary developments. The government, through the extension of the principles of the Mabo judgment, has encouraged people to make these claims, which the government now calls vexatious. The fact is that they have to be dealt with and are causing huge investor uncertainty.

An immense legal structure has been set up, largely funded by the taxpayer, which will pursue as far as possible native title claims. As a number of speakers have pointed out, Mr Prescott, the Managing Director of BHP, Australia's largest company, has described the bill as porridge. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Examining the proposed bill is like reading porridge. It is far too complex, far too difficult to understand and fraught with the danger of leading us into additional uncertainty and unnecessary conflict . . . we are going to be left with a legacy of confusion and rules which won't work.
Just yesterday, Mr John Ralph, Deputy Chairman of CRA, indicated that his company will be investing more of its exploration funds overseas because of the uncertainties created by the Mabo bill.

PARA.TAB: Fifteen of Australia's leading executives, while recognising the High Court decision, have stated that this bill is extraordinarily complex and unworkable and leaves open many questions which would require resort to the courts. Such a statement, I believe, is of profound importance to future employment opportunities in Australia, particularly opportunities for our children.

Everyone recognises that the key issue facing this country is jobs. I wonder how many jobs are now going to be lost as a result of the uncertainties created by this bill—jobs which would have been created largely for the traditional supporters of the Labor Party. I believe—as my colleagues have said; indeed, we are all in agreement—that this bill is of profound importance. I believe that the Labor Party has made a disastrous decision. It has not decided to treat the nation as a single people with one great destiny; it has decided to go down a route which is fraught with immense danger for the future of this country.

The debate on Mabo will not end with the passing of this legislation in the next few days—if, indeed, it does get passed. The uncertainties are so great that the Mabo debate will run on right up to and past the next election. Labor Party members who have so foolishly adopted the philosophy of Mr Keating and his cabinet will pay a heavy price for what they have done. I regret that, if this bill goes through, all Australians will be paying a heavy price.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recognition of the Senate's leeway earlier, I will not be using my full allocated time so that it will not be seen that the Greens are using more than our allocation in this debate. It is important at the outset to clarify what we are debating here today. The Native Title Bill is a response to the so-called Mabo High Court decision and, as a consequence, should be dealing with the concerns and needs of the Aboriginal people, not the desire of the mining and pastoral industries. I have used the word `should' advisedly, because the bill as it is presented here is more accurately described as a resource security bill. It is one of the most crucial aspects of the concerns of the Greens (WA).

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette and I have been criticised in this place for striving for the perfect, the unattainable. This criticism is unwarranted. We have acknowledged in our discussions and negotiations on this bill that we cannot turn back the clock and, unfortunately, cannot undo the injustices perpetrated on the Aboriginal people in this country. Our concern, however, is that the compromises that are the inevitable result of negotiations on issues such as this have favoured white landowners and leaseholders at the expense of Aboriginal people—the creation of a new terra nullius.

The mining industry, perhaps surprisingly, has been very critical of this bill. The President of the Mining Industry Council, Peter Barnett, was reported as saying that this bill will jeopardise development and diminish and delay investment in Australia because of the uncertainty it created. CRA Chief Executive, John Ralph, also jumped on the bandwagon recently to claim that his company would be increasing overseas investment at the expense of local spending due to the uncertainty associated with this bill.

I can only suggest that such statements are part of the ongoing lobbying campaign by these industry groups whose only concern is their profit margins. In that regard, however, recent reports in the financial pages confirm that the statements by Mr Ralph and Mr Barnett are not supported by facts. I note from a recent article in the Australian dated 8 December 1993 that the minerals industry earned $2.3 billion in profit in the last financial year despite the `supposed threat of Mabo' hanging over its head.

One of the often quoted claims from mining industry representatives is that mining investments and projects create local employment, both directly and through trickle down and multiplier effects. On a recent visit I made to Kalgoorlie, this claim was refuted by many locals who cited evidence of fly-in fly-out work forces who take their money back to New Zealand or the eastern states. Much of the profit from mining ventures also travels overseas with the foreign companies that invest in this country and earn substantial rewards from using Australia as a quarry for the rest of the world. This is the industry that the government is so keen to placate and for which we wish to provide resource security. The need for such security is questionable. Currently, the mining industry has the right to claim over 90 per cent of the land in Australia for mining, exploration and associated activities. What more does it want?

The other point that I wish to make in this debate is a philosophical one and relates to the need for all Australian people to learn from the Aboriginal people who have lived on and with this land for many thousands of years. Europeans are only newcomers to this country and, despite their legal control over much of the land, have failed to realise that it is not ownership that is the most important issue here but being part of the land and caring for the land.

We have much to learn from indigenous people all over the world about the spiritual and physical connection with the land. In the short time that we have lived on this land we have managed to destroy much of the ecological value of the country. This is nowhere more evident than in the pastoral industry where pastures have been overgrazed and pastoral leases mismanaged to such an extent that many of these properties are virtually worthless.

In Western Australia, for example, 47 per cent of the pastoral leases south of the Kimberley were found to be non-viable in the recent inquiry into the pastoral industry. In the Kimberley region, the Kimberley pastoral industry inquiry found that only 21 per cent of the 103 leases in the region had the productive resource capability to maintain a viable operation in the long term. The agriculture department has estimated that the annual cost of the resource lost to the pastoral industry in Western Australia as a result of land degradation is $37 million.

It is interesting to note that in that context, and in the context of this debate, the pastoral industry is lobbying the Western Australian government for perpetual tenure when the current leases expire in 2015. This will result a situation where 38 per cent of Western Australia will be effectively granted to less than 500 people. Where is the equity in that?

The Aboriginal people have lived with this land for thousands of years and learnt to care for it because they realised, as many from the green movement realise today, that the ecosystems in which we live—the land, air, water and biodiversity—are our life support systems. Destroy them and we put our own wellbeing at risk. The point is crucial in the context of this debate.

We should not be examining this issue in the context of ownership, economics, and profits. We should be addressing the concerns of future generations and looking for ways in which we can all live together in this land in a truly sustainable manner. A perpetuation of the economic rationalist approach to these issues will not address the fundamental concerns of social justice, social equity and ecological sustainability.

The Native Title Bill is seriously flawed in its current form in that it does not adequately address the concerns the Greens have raised and it does not provide Aboriginal people—the first people of this land—with the opportunity to maintain or re-establish their connections with the land of which they are such an integral part.

I fear that this bill will continue to lock many Aboriginal people into a dependency cycle—a dependency cycle which is controlled by the descendants of the very people who robbed them of their heritage over 200 years ago. I trust that the government will at last realise that it needs to match its rhetoric with reality when we move into the committee stage and examine the various proposed amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Native Title Bill. There have been many words and many views expressed in this chamber over the last 24 hours. This is the most important piece of legislation that will pass through this chamber—certainly in my experience of nearly 11 years in this place.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of groups that I would like to refer to in paying tribute to the level of tolerance and patience of those many indigenous people who have given so much time to develop, with the government, acceptable legislation which maintains that fine balance between the rights of indigenous and other Australians. There are far too many of them to name, but obviously I would want to place on record the particular role of Lois O'Donoghue and the negotiating team. I also want to place on record the work that has been done by people from my home state, Queensland, including Marcia Langton, Peter Costello, Noel Pearson, Bob Weatherall and others.

I acknowledge the alienation that a number of Aborigines and Islanders do feel about this process. I think I would be the first to acknowledge that, when a government is involved in responding to a High Court decision of this magnitude, it is going to be a process that can alienate people simply because that is how governments have to operate.

I acknowledge the alienation that some Aborigines feel about our process. As a government, we have spent 18 months very closely concentrating on the issues in this legislation. There has been consultation. In the latter stages, there has been quite historic negotiation. I pay tribute to both the negotiators and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

As Michael Mansell has said, we should not really be surprised that Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders have different opinions about issues. Why should they not have different opinions? Other Australians have a wide variety of views. It is said, in opposition to this bill, in this place and elsewhere, `But not all Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders agree with this legislation'. It would be surprising to get a unanimous view about any issue, just as it is impossible to get a unanimous view among non-indigenous Australians.

I hope that the reality of the land acquisition fund and the social justice package can provide new opportunities for those thousands of Aborigines who have already been dispossessed of their land. I hope that the tragedy of the circumstances of that dispossession will be recognised and incorporated into the Australian tradition so that we understand the relationship between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians and move forward to reconciliation.

No legislation or social justice package can fully atone for the events of the past and I do not think the government would even start to imagine that it can. Nor can the legislation change community attitudes that have been developed over 204 years of cultural arrogance and ignorance. We have seen those attitudes come to the fore in the last 18 months. It is very difficult to change that legacy of cultural arrogance and ignorance.
A leading churchman from the Uniting Church has said:

SPEECH.PARA: In presenting the proposed legislation, the Government has already run ahead of public opinion as evidenced in all polling to date.

PARA.TAB: We applaud this as we believe that governments should give creative leads towards the building of a more just and reconciled society.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what is so commendable about the way in which my government has been prepared to run ahead of public opinion. It has been prepared to really deal with the hard issue of this decision in the High Court and accept the challenge. It has seen the High Court's decision not as a problem but as an opportunity.

PARA.TAB: It is true that there is not unanimous support for this legislation, and I have already acknowledged that with regard to those indigenous people who do not accept the legislation. But I believe that the list of supporters includes a powerful coalition of major Aboriginal organisations, including ATSIC, legal services and land councils; the Anglican, Uniting and Catholic churches; a range of human rights lawyers, academics and community organisations; the ACTU; the National Farmers Federation; and the tourism industry.
