Clearly, it is in the best interests of indigenous people that this legislation be speedily put through this parliament to put an end to the uncertainty and many of the myths that exist about what the High Court has decided. In that way, Australia will at last catch up with those countries—the United States, Canada and New Zealand—that have incorporated native title within their societies without the sky falling in and without there being an absolute collapse of economic certainty.

I believe it is in the best interests of indigenous people that the legislation goes through speedily. Because of that, I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my speech. However, before doing so, I will read briefly from a letter from the Hon. Ernie Bridge, who is the shadow minister for trade and Aboriginal affairs in the north-west and the honourable member for Kimberley in Western Australia. His letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I represent the electorate of Kimberley in the Parliament of Western Australia. Approximately half of my constituents are Aborigines. I too am an Aboriginal.
Before I entered State Parliament 13 years ago, I spent 18 years as a councillor . . .
I am the first and only Aboriginal to be a member of a State or Federal Cabinet in this country . . .
When the Mabo judgment was handed down in June last year I felt that a new era had arrived . . .

But I have been disheartened. Through astute campaigns of misinformation and fear, mounted by some of our political and industry leaders, many of my fellow Australians have baulked at accepting the High Court's ruling.
It is inevitable however that some Senators may have differing views on some aspects of the legislation. This is not unusual and it is why we have a parliamentary system . . .
At the end of the day, it is the overall philosophy and thrust of the legislation . . .

As an Aboriginal and an elected Parliamentarian, I am in no doubt that this legislation is the most profound law which Australia has ever contemplated. It is deeply symbolic of our claim to be a fair and accepting society.
I urge you to give this proposed legislation your full support in the Senate so that it becomes law before the year's end.
I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my speech.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Discussion of what the High Court's "native title" decision really means has been obscured by legalistic terminology and extremist interpretations from both sides of the debate. An editorial in the Australian (July 31) summed up the need for rational consideration of the issue when it commended Deaths in Custody Royal Commissioner Hal Wootten's succinct explanation:

"Mabo simply recognised that this continent once belonged to many Aboriginal peoples, each part being occupied by a particular group who had customary rights to it. Over two centuries most of it had been irretrievably taken from them piece by piece without compensation. Where this had happened, it could not now be undone. But, through all the travail of 200 years, some groups had managed to maintain their connections with their land, usually because it was in a remote area and was so economically uninviting that no white person wanted it. Simple justice required that the law respect their rights, no less than it respects the rights of other Australians who have inherited land."
The editorial writer concluded:

"who really believes those Aborigines who can lay claim to an uninterrupted habitation of tribal land throughout 205 years of white settlement, not to mention the thousands of years before that, should not be allowed a form of secure title now?"

Certainly the experience of 170 years of North American jurisprudence should enable Australians to more rationally consider the implications of our common law finally catching up with international legal practice. Last year I had the opportunity to meet Canadian government and indigenous peoples representatives to find out more about the effect of "native title" recognition in that country which shares a social, cultural, legal and political heritage similar to Australia. The articulated position of a conservative Minister for Native Affairs, Tom Siddons, was remarkable then and is even more radical when contrasted with the hysterical rantings of conservative spokespeople throughout the current Mabo debate.
Former Canadian Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney, in May this year said at the signing of the Nunavut Land Claim in the North West Territories:

"My Government has a dream—a vision of economic and social development in the North in which all Northerners participate, a vision in which territorial governments will continue to acquire more jurisdictional rights and responsibilities."

Here then we have a conservative Prime Minister linking indigenous rights with economic development and looking forward to indigenous self-government! This policy position remains unchanged as the Canadian government, now boasting a woman leader, faces a general election later this year.

A study comparing Indigenous Resource Rights and Mining Companies in North America and Australia (McGill and Crough, 1986) highlights the different ways in which the international business community has responded to indigenous rights and native title.

"The Indian Act of 1876 is still the main instrument of Canadian Indian Policy (Johnson 1984:65). Its origins lie in a policy of assimilation and accordingly it still has a very paternalistic style. There have been demands for the replacement of the Act both at the time of the proposed termination of special Indian status in 1969 and in more recent years as a policy of self-determination has come to be accepted at Government level. . .

In regard to the veto rights that are contained in the Indian Act, it is surprising to find that despite the assimilationist policy embodied in the broad powers and discretions conferred upon the Minister, the veto powers of Indian people are absolute. The basic mechanism of this veto power is contained in the idea that no development may occur unless the Indians voluntarily agree to surrender their land. Accordingly, the Act provides as follows—

PARA.TAB: `37.Except where this Act otherwise provides, lands in a reserve shall not be sold, alienated, leased or otherwise disposed of until they have been surrendered to Her Majesty by the band for whose use and benefit in common the reserve set apart.'

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, in the United States, the regulations made under the Indian Mineral Leasing Act are the starting point in a discussion of resource agreements on US Indian land.

These regulations specify, among other things, the rents and royalties payable for mining and petroleum production on Indian land. As the legislative scheme follows the US practice of utilising competitive bidding, tribes may also receive the amount of any successful bid. In the case of tribal land, the relevant minimum royalty rates are 12.5% of the gross value of any petroleum (Section 211.12), approximately 10% of the value of other minerals, and 10 US cents per ton of coal (Section 211.15). However, these royalty rates are now largely of historical interest (particularly in the case of coal), as not only are higher royalties required to induce tribal consent, but also the 1938 Act has been supplemented by the 1982 Act."

Obviously if the High Court ruling recognising "native title" is a threat to investment in Australia, one can only speculate about why the international business community has been able to accommodate "native title" in North America for many years.

One of the problems for Australians adapting to the new reality of "native title" at common law is a general ignorance of Aboriginal culture and the experience of early contact between Aborigines and Europeans.

Many sections of the Australian community are unfamiliar with the national economic contribution made by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in developing our pastoral, mining and fishing industries. While critics continue to dismiss Aboriginal culture as "stone age", they are perpetuating the myth that only Anglo Saxon settlers were responsible for Australia's early development. However, even the most cursory study of the history 19th century European/Aboriginal relations will reveal the dependence of pioneers on indigenous peoples' local knowledge and skills.

It was Aboriginal land use practice of fire-stick farming which created an open landscape facilitating rapid pastoral development in many parts of the country. Similarly, Aboriginal labour incorporating tracking skills made possible an open range pastoral industry which Europeans could not have initiated alone. Early explorers were reliant on the local Aborigines who provided food, water, shelter, translation and diplomacy. They were in modern terms the unpaid "expert consultants".

It is interesting to recall that the recently declared North West Queensland Mineral Province was actually first located in the 1870's by Ernest Henry whose Aboriginal guide led him to the mineral deposits of Cloncurry, Dajarra and Mount Isa. Therefore, it would not seem unreasonable for local Aboriginal communities today to participate in the economic activity of this region and to share some benefits of an expanded mining interest in the region.

The major challenge for governments and business interests as a result of the long overdue recognition of "native title" is to accept third party involvement in development so that Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders take their place at the negotiating table. Just as early settlers faced the reality of utilising indigenous skills to facilitate development in the 19th century, this generation of "developers" must accept the reality of working in genuine partnership with Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, especially in remote areas of Northern Australia.

Mining, business and government leaders concerned about the impact of legal challenges in relation to the High Court's recognition of "native title" have the solution within their own power. They can accept indigenous people as having legitimate land and economic interests. They can negotiate with local indigenous communities. They can respect their leaders and accord them the same dignity and status as other business colleagues.

A number of mining companies already have responded to this obvious solution and their negotiated practice should be regarded as models for more conservative companies whose leaders continue to sit on the sidelines predicting national economic disaster.
There is every reason to be optimistic about future negotiations between the business and mining sector and indigenous "native title" owners.

Mount Todd near Katherine is just such an example where the Jawoyn Association has negotiated with Zapopan NL to reach an agreement suitable to both parties. The Executive Director of Zapopan, Terry Strapp, is quoted in The Age (3/7/93) as saying that they were always happy to negotiate:
"None of us were going to win if we had court action. . .

"Instead," he says, "negotiations led to a win for both sides. The Jawoyn have waived any right to native title over the mine site and in return they have been granted freehold title to the rest of the lease (and to the mine site when mining is finished) and to a package of benefits including jobs, training and houses for Jawoyn workers at the mine, environmental safeguards, as well as inalienable title to other land."

In making reference to this landmark agreement it is important to recall that it was the same Jawoyn people who fought the proposal to mine at Coronation Hill because of the significance of the area as a sacred site, yet successful negotiations for a totally different area has been possible to the mutual benefit of traditional land owners and the company concerned.

Another example of how compatibly Aborigines and mining companies can work together is the recent agreement reached between traditional owners and the mining company "Sons of Gwalia" over access to lands for the purpose of exploration near the south-eastern area of the Tanami Desert. Traditional owners will receive, under the terms of agreement, a five percent premium based on the amount of dollars expended on exploration of their home lands. There is also a commitment to providing training to Aborigines and exploration personnel will be counselled in Aboriginal culture.

Equally welcome is "Exploring for Common Ground", a report prepared by the mining committee of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. This committee brought Aboriginal and mining groups together with the objective of drawing up recommendations focussing on improving relationships between Australia's indigenous peoples and the mining industry. This report has been welcomed by Aboriginal groups and the Australian Mining Industry Council so it is encouraging that Aboriginal Affairs Committee Chairman, Campbell Anderson, quoted in The Age (2/7/93) acknowledges that this report
"does provide a real opportunity for bridging gaps between Aboriginal communities, the broader community at large and the mining industry".

A key recommendation of this report is the establishment of a joint council of Aborigines and miners, called J-CALM, to provide for on-going direct communication at a national level between Aboriginal and mining leaders.
As Rosemary West concludes (The Age 2/7/93):

"Will shareholders prefer to see their investment funds spent on litigation than on employing Aborigines? And how will they feel about putting their money into a company—and a country—that looks as if it is pointedly blocking the legitimate land needs of Aboriginal people in the UN International Year for Indigenous Peoples."

There can be no greater irony for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who have long sought legal recognition for economic independence to find that now in 1993 it is the company directors, bankers and premiers who are seeking legislative protection of their economic interests!

Surely, we do not need endless legal challenges to accept that Australia has an obligation to finally come to terms with the reality of indigenous land rights as practised in comparable countries for nearly two centuries.

In reconciling traditional land interest with current economic imperatives will assist in promoting community acceptance that Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders have an equal concern about development and prosperity. They merely seek a voice in negotiations and a share of that prosperity.
I am proud of my government's ability to so effectively develop this legislative response to the High Court decision particularly I commend the role of the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision of the High Court in Mabo No. 2 has created the enormous problem of a lack of certainty in the area of title to land. The only thing that is certain about the Mabo No. 2 decision is that the law has now become uncertain. The decision of the High Court in Mabo No. 2 has raised the problem of sovereign risk for Australia. In effect, it made law, which is the province and function of this parliament. It has created problems which have to be remedied by legislature, not by the courts.

PARA.TAB: I will begin by quoting the decision of Mr Justice Sir Anthony Mason in State Government Insurance Commission (SA) v. Trigwill in 1979. In this decision, Mr Justice Mason explains very adequately why courts cannot and should not make law. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not doubt that there are some cases in which an ultimate court of appeal can and should vary or modify what has been thought to be a settled rule or principle of the common law on the ground that it is ill-adapted to modern circumstances. If it should emerge that a specific common law rule was based on the existence of particular conditions or circumstances, whether social or economic, and that they have undergone a radical change, then in a simple or clear case the court may be justified in moulding the rule to meet the new conditions and circumstances. But there are very powerful reasons why the court should be reluctant to engage in such an exercise. The court is neither a legislature nor a law reform agency. Its responsibility is to decide cases by applying the law to the facts as found. The court's facilities, techniques and procedures are adapted to that responsibility; they are not adapted to legislative functions or to law reform activities. The court does not, and cannot, carry out investigations or inquiries with a view to ascertaining whether particular common law rules are working well, whether they are adjusted to the needs of the community and whether they command popular assent. Nor can the court call for, and examine, submissions from groups and individuals who may be vitally interested in the making of changes in the law. In short, the court cannot, and does not, engage in the wide-ranging inquiries and assessments which are made by governments and law reform agencies as a desirable, if not essential, preliminary to the enactment of legislation by an elected legislature.
These considerations must deter a court from departing too readily from a settled rule of the common law and from replacing it with a new rule.
Very wise words indeed. I wonder what happened in the 10 years or so that intervened. In the judgment of Mabo No. 2 the High Court quite radically changed its mind on that principle.

PARA.TAB: In order to understand the difficulties and complexities that have been introduced into title law in this country we have to understand what the High Court found. Firstly, it said that sovereignty was obtained by the crown by 1788 and that that was an act of state and it was beyond the competence of the court to go behind. Secondly, it upheld the doctrine of tenure that we all hold from the crown. Thirdly, it upheld the Blackstone doctrine that Australia was a settled land and was neither ceded nor conquered. Fourthly, it held that title to land, ownership of land, was acquired by the crown at the time that sovereignty was acquired.

Up to that point nothing new had occurred. But at that point the High Court then made it up. It overturned all precedent, as it is entitled to do—it is the only court in the land which may—and said that ownership came in two bits: ownership consisted of radical title and beneficial title. It said that radical title was that title which the crown could exercise to extinguish the beneficial title which was in existence at the time of obtaining sovereignty and which has become known as native title.

It is from that point on that the uncertainty has arisen. Because the High Court is the only court in the land which can overrule itself and is not bound by precedent, it could have done one of three things in the future with the existing Mabo No. 2 decision. Firstly, it could have overturned itself again and said that it got it wrong. There is plenty of precedent for that decision. We saw the overturning of all case law with regard to the interpretation of section 92 in the Cole and Whitfield case. Secondly, it could have said that it will distinguish any future case. It could have said that it will apply the ratio of the case in Mabo No. 2 only if the facts are similar—that is, if there is a defined area of land, Melanesian people, villages, gardens trading in surpluses from the gardens. Or it could have said that it will take the broad principles that emerge from the various pieces of obiter dicta—that is, all the things the judges had to say—create a broad principle and apply that. The only thing we can say with certainty is that nobody but nobody can tell us which way the court would have gone.

The decision of Mabo No. 2, therefore, was precisely that until the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) chose to make his infamous Redfern speech. It was a speech made with all the prudence of a man driving along next to a tinder dry bushland and throwing in a match. It raised the expectations, it raised the hopes way past those which were reasonable. We confused from that point on the two questions of solving the uncertainty that arose from the High Court judgment of Mabo No. 2 and the most important principle of reconciliation.

If there is one thing that needs to be done it is to keep the two things separate. The government's legislation as it is before this parliament confuses those two issues. It does nothing to solve the uncertainty.

Uncertainty comes in two parts. Firstly, there is the uncertainty that the court may find against a person and one may find that a investment one has made is lost because of the court's finding. Secondly, there is the uncertainty that arises from the fact that claims may be made and an investment that one has made can be tied up in the courts for 10 years, just as the Mabo case was tied up in the courts for 10 years.

That is what is known as sovereign risk. This country of ours has been free of sovereign risk and therefore we have been a very attractive destination for investment funds. As a nation, we have always been the net importers of capital. It has enabled us to develop our resources, to improve our standard of living and let all citizens share in that improved standard of living.

Because we have been a safe destination and title has been certain, investment has come and the servicing of that investment has been reasonable in terms of the length of time that an investor expects for a return on that investment and also the amount of return expected. There are plenty of countries that have sovereign risk and we are now competing with them. They are countries in our own region. This occurs when an investment is not certain but the return expected and the shortness of time in which that return is expected is far greater than we have had to pay before. Empirical evidence is that firms which would have made investments and developments in Australia are simply not doing so. Within my files I have empirical evidence of precisely that.

So Australia is now suffering from sovereign risk. This legislation does absolutely nothing to solve that problem. It sets up competing jurisdictions and competing tribunals where the final outcome may not necessarily be the one that is accepted. It has executive function intervening. When we look at it and the 74 amendments that came in this morning from the government, one could be pardoned for saying that it makes the income tax act look simple. It is highly complex, it is highly obtuse and it is not good law. That is why the opposition is opposing it.

On the other hand, Richard Court's legislation is relatively simple. It is easy to comprehend. It means that by extinguishing, that is excising, that radical title all so-called beneficial title as pronounced by the High Court he has supplanted that with statutory recognition of rights which Aboriginal people presently enjoy. They do not have to go to a court to prove them. They were theirs as of right from the moment the legislation received assent. If anybody wants to deal or change those rights of usage that Aboriginal people have, compensation must be paid. It is straightforward. It is easy to comprehend and the people who enjoy the native statutory rights have those not because they have to go and fight before a tribunal and/or a court but because it has been enacted that way.

The simple truth is that when the opposition comes into office we will have to clean up the mess that this government has left behind. Because the Greens have acquiesced, succumbed, or whichever verb one chooses to use, to pressure that has been thrust upon them, this legislation will probably pass through this parliament. Nothing will be solved. The law will be more complex. The costs of investing in this country will be greater and, very simply, the investment will be less.

There are two other things that arise from the findings of Mabo—the finding in Mabo No. 1 and the implications for the Racial Discrimination Act. The 1975 legislation was tested in the early 1980s in Mabo No. 1 against legislation passed by the Queensland government. It could foresee some of the difficulties that might arise from the way in which the High Court may deal with the question of possessory title, for want of a better term.

The High Court held that the legislation passed in Queensland was invalid because it was struck down by the Racial Discrimination Act of 1975. That means that all leases, grants and alienations of land by the crown since that date are at risk and need to be validated. The reason they are clearly at risk is, in part, due to the fact that, under our constitution, where there is a compulsory or other acquisition of land, just terms must be paid. So that complication also has to be dealt with.

The government, in relying as it does upon the convention from which the Racial Discrimination Act flows, is open to question itself. As we know, under that act, one may not discriminate against people on the basis of race, but in certain circumstances one may discriminate in favour of people on the basis of race. But that discrimination is qualified within the act itself and within the articles of the convention. It is far from certain that this legislation meets the criteria as laid down pursuant to those two instruments.

So not only do we have legislation which does not solve the problem of sovereign risk, but also it is questionable as to whether or not it is within the power granted by the constitution for the legislation to be passed at all. That will be tested in the courts. Without putting too fine a point on it, as I said, what we will have is a highly complex mess which, when we come into office, we will have to clean up.

One of the options that has to be looked at—and we have to see what the state of that mess is by the time we have an election—and an option that must remain open is what I call a dose of democracy: a referendum. I am not going to stand here tonight and be an instant draftsman, but I simply say that it is an option that must remain open and on the agenda.

I oppose the bill because it in no way solves the problems as they have arisen from the decision of the High Court, which has become an adventuresome court. The High Court is not above criticism, nor should it be. The only way that judges can be accountable is through criticism and discussion. The question of reconciliation must not be confused with this question of solving the uncertainties that result from that decision of the High Court. I would like to say a word about that. To me, reconciliation is one of most important items that can be on the agenda between now and the next century. To me, it means building respect between indigenous Australians and those of us who have come more latterly.

I would like to give a little example. Fairly recently I bought a painting in Darwin. It is a painting by an Aboriginal artist called Mary Kannyi. She is 68 years old and she has been painting for only two years. She has been painting for only two years because in traditional Aboriginal society it is the men who are allowed to paint, not the women. But more and more women are taking up the talent that they have and taking the knowledge that they have of their environment—the beauty of the flowering desert, the waterholes and the plants that are used for medicine—and are expressing it in an artistic form. They want to share the knowledge that they have.

Mary Kannyi lives at Daly River. She has lived there all her life by the billabong. I respect her knowledge; I respect her talent; I respect the fact that she wants to share both her knowledge and her talent. In return I want to see us share things with Mary Kannyi and other Aboriginal people. But I do not want it imposed in a paternalistic way.

Clearly, education and medicine are two areas where it is essential that there is a sharing, but merely to impose it upon a culture and say, `Here, take this and use it in the way we tell you' is not done with respect and it will not benefit those people who clearly need that knowledge. Fairly recently, one of the Boyer lectures was given by an Aboriginal doctor. He explained very well why there needs to be a change in attitude to the way in which I have said knowledge is to shared. The building of respect is key to reconciliation.

I met Oodgeroo Noonuccal on one only occasion and that was at the Expo in Brisbane. I would disagree with her on almost every political point, but I admired her enormously. She was a woman who had taken her talent and exercised her will. She had reached a position in her society which would have been banned to her before as a woman. She stood for saying, `My people are entitled to respect'. I can only say she earned mine. That is why I say that reconciliation is a vital issue and must not be mixed up with the solution to the problems created by the High Court in Mabo No.2. This legislation offends on both counts: it confuses the issues and solves nothing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the basis of the decision in Mabo No.2, a number of Australian citizens have, where the necessary confluence of facts occurs, vested rights in particular land. To deny that is to be radical and revolutionary because the High Court has judged that to be the case. It has been said again and again during the day that the High Court decision is final in this matter and binds us.

PARA.TAB: The point that must be made again and again is that, because of the Mabo decision, people may have vested rights in land. Whatever is done about that affects their rights in that land. This is not a matter where we say, `Look, the court has made a decision. It's not a bad sort of a day today. After all, we've got to feel generous towards a certain group of people; therefore, we'll give them the rights that we feel they ought to be given—not the rights that are declared by the High Court and not the rights that six of the seven judges so solemnly pronounced that they had, but some rights that we will determine in some way they should have'. That is a very dangerous, radical and revolutionary approach to take to the established structures under which we live. The constitution that contains those sacred institutions must not be violated in the way that has been referred to today.

Having said that, I want to make some further points. Australian mining companies have a good case for being given security of title over the sites in which they are working. Pastoralists have a good case for being given safe tenure over their holdings. Fishing interests have a good case for being guaranteed access to relevant waters. The forestry industry has a good case for having its due entitlement protected.

Those Aboriginal Australians—all of whom must, by dint of the judgment of the High Court have Aboriginal ancestry—who have title to the land under the Mabo decision have a good case for that to be preserved. All those groups of people I have mentioned have rights, but if all exercised those rights to their utmost limit there would be awful tension. So, as everybody has concluded, there has to be legislation to overcome that.

It is said that the legislation fails to be perfect. That is absolutely true. Of course it fails to be perfect. It cannot be perfect, given the number of rights that people of different groups allege and assert they have over the same piece of land. That is what this legislation does. Amendments are proposed to the legislation by the government itself, by the Democrats and by the Greens but, as I understand it, none are proposed by the coalition because it says that there should be no legislation at all of this sort.

All the great goals in football are kicked from the spectators' side of the fence. The same goes for all the great sixes that are hit in cricket. It is only when we get onto the field and enter the play that we can make a contribution. Unfortunately, the coalition has not done that as yet, although while this debate is still going there is plenty of opportunity for those on the other side to do it. The opposition has made many points which are valid and true.

Mr Acting Deputy President, may I quote a couple of lines by Banquo? You used, perhaps, at times to consider him when you were reading your Shakespeare. There are a couple of good lines, and they go this way:

SPEECH.PARA: And oftentimes to win us to our harm,
The instruments of darkness tell us truths;

As I have listened to the debate on this matter—and it has been a very good debate—those lines have come to me. A lot of truths have been put forward in debate over the last couple of days, but the conclusions that have been drawn from them are flawed. In the pursuit of perfection, perhaps, the good that might be otherwise done in legislation such as the government has put forward is lost, and lost tragically.

PARA.TAB: Any issue over land is going to raise problems and generate high emotion. That has been the case with the land law that we enjoy, which has come from the land law of England, with all the sorts of different rights that were enjoyed in that land. The history of that land law has been full of strife and stress. Even in Australia, there were the fights between the emancipists and the exclusivists and the difference between the view Commissioner Bigge took in his attitude to the emancipists and the view taken by Lachlan Macquarie is an example. The fight between selectors and squatters was much the same. But people went ahead and legislated. The famous Charles Gavan Duffy, from the country you used to grace, Mr Acting Deputy President, passed the laws in Victoria in the 1860s which led to the settlement of the problems down there. Some sort of action had to be taken, and he took good action.

The same thing has been done here with the Mabo legislation. It is a not a unique incident in the history of land law. It is in many ways typical of what happened before Mabo. It was not until 1677, I think—certainly Senator Vanstone will help me here—with the enactment of the Statute of Frauds that the conveyance of land had to be in writing. In the centuries before, not enough people were literate to put the transactions involving land into writing. So it was in a general way the same sort of system that operated, as far as we can gather, amongst the Aboriginals before 1788. In other words, the common law, in picking up native title, is picking up something that is not as unique and as strange as people might think.

Like everybody else, I could say a lot more but I want to conclude by saying this: this legislation has been brought forward because it needs to be brought forward and needs to be brought forward expeditiously. People, whether they are miners or pastoralists, want certainty of title. Australian citizens of Aboriginal background, who have a claim under Mabo to land, want that matter resolved as soon as possible. I would have thought that this legislation could have been used as a basis for such amendments as people might want to make and can agree upon. But simply to throw it out holus-bolus without even having an alternative to put in its place is a stance which cannot be helpful at this time in the development of our land law. It is important that this legislation go through with the proper amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Bill 1993 is very important legislation but I believe that there has been insufficient examination of its implications for all Australians. There has been no mention from the government of the costs and the benefits associated with the legislation. The bill proposes to greatly increase land options for a small proportion of the Aboriginal population. Land is important for the Aborigines, but it is also important for the economic and social wellbeing of all Australians. In that regard, let me quote the words of an 18th century American Red Indian chief:

SPEECH.PARA: Land belongs to the people, of whom many are dead, a few are living and countless millions still to come.

All Australians, whether their ancestors arrived 40,000 years ago from Asia, whether they arrived 200 years ago from Europe, or whether they arrived yesterday, should feel proud and privileged to have their ancient links with the past in our land.

PARA.TAB: As something so important for Aborigines and for all Australians, and when the constitution clearly leaves land management to the states in our federal system, the bill before us should have the agreement of the states. As one of the state premiers said following the breakup of the heads of government meeting, negotiations should have continued over a complete weekend in order to get resolution on this matter. However, our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) presented the states with a take it or leave it position. As a result, cooperation went out the window.

Many months ago the government made a political decision to go along the path of dealing with the Australian Democrats and the Greens. Basically, it said, `To hell with the states and to hell with industry'. Today we have a bill which most of the states agree has major problems attached to it. We should remember again that it is the states who have to manage the land. Our most important export and development industry—the mining and mineral processing industry—has been ignored.

Today I will concentrate on the implications of this bill for the Australian economy, and hence for all Australians. We need strong economic growth to give hope to the unemployed and to offer material help to disadvantaged Australians. To achieve this we need increased investment and increased exports. Whilst all our industry sectors are important, I would like to concentrate on the mining industry, which I believe will be the industry most seriously affected by this legislation. This industry currently contributes seven per cent of our nation's GDP. It contributes 25 per cent of our nation's exports. Last year it contributed 24 per cent of all the investment by the private sector in the economy. This is investment which we are trying to build to get this economy going again. This bill puts that quarter at risk.

For continued economic growth of our resource based industries and for continuing mining investment for these industries, we need appropriate property rights and economic incentives. Property rights must be clearly defined and stable. Uncertainty about property rights leads to economic losses. Contrary to the traditional views of economists who have always relied upon interest rates, incentives, tax rates, et cetera, to provide a major explanation of the investment cycle, there is now a strong view that the major determinant for investment is confidence and security. The greater the uncertainty, the lower the investment. I have stressed in this place many times that the level of private sector investment in this country is the lowest it has been since World War II. We need to boost investment to create sustained economic growth.

The view of the business community is that the most urgent task post-Mabo is the removal of uncertainty in relation to property rights. In addition, economic incentives are needed to encourage people to respond. The Industry Commission, in its report in 1991 on the mining and mineral processing industry, said that following the Aboriginal land rights experience in the Northern Territory—a matter about which I will comment more later—the most appropriate system was one in which either Aborigines had full property rights to minerals as well as land or they had no rights to minerals at all. A half-way house destroys all incentive to make the most economic use of those resources.

The Northern Territory situation provides some sort of example of what could happen with a prohibitive mining policy, such as is possible under this bill. In the Northern Territory the traditional system of crown ownership of mineral resources was replaced in 1976 with a system of Aboriginal rights under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The act initially gave the Aboriginal owners a two-stage veto over exploration and subsequent mining. Because of the difficulties involved in such a system, the act was amended in 1987 to permit the veto only at the exploration stage. The evidence suggests that the implications of this system have been devastating for the mining industry in the Northern Territory.

Even following the 1987 amendments, there was an average of only five exploration licences per year processed on Aboriginal land compared with 150 received, processed and granted on non-Aboriginal land in the territory. By comparing mining licence outcomes on Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal land, it can be estimated that some 3,000 exploration licences that would otherwise have been taken out over the past 20 years have not been pursued in that region. On the basis of average success rates, this has probably meant that three mines have failed to come to fruition in the Northern Territory.

The 1991 Industry Commission report on that industry that I referred to earlier found that there was a general dissatisfaction with the aboriginal land rights act in the Northern Territory. In spite of the findings of that inquiry, no substantial changes have been made to that act and many of its features are evident in the Native Title Bill. As one respected commentator put it:

SPEECH.PARA: The history of land rights in the Northern Territory has been that of 20 years of lost opportunity. The mining companies, the Australian community in general, and the Aboriginals in particular, are clear losers from unnecessary impediments and delays. The lessons from the Northern Territory experience are clear. Where unwieldy negotiation and veto processes are allowed to overlay a system of tradeable property rights, the impact on costs and consequent investment is stifling.

The attitude of prospective mineral exploration companies is just as important as the actual physical barriers they face in gaining security of mineral rights and access to land. In Tasmania, for example, a succession of attempts by the radical conservation movement in the early 1980s resulted in significant downturns in prospective mineral exploration investment. This phenomenon verifies much of the earlier argument about economic certainty being a very important determinant of investment decisions.

PARA.TAB: In my home state of Tasmania, exploration investment expenditure fell from $18 million in 1983-84 to only $8 million in 1992-93—a decline of 56 per cent. That decline, started by the creation of uncertainty about access to or tenure of potential mining areas that were the subject of argument as to usage, was further exacerbated by the election of a Labor-Green government in the latter part of the 1980s. The ongoing uncertainty and insecurity in the business community, particularly in the mining sector, virtually brought to a halt investment in exploration in my state.

Mining rights in the Northern Territory are currently based on a system with a negotiation phase, followed by a land council phase, with the land council having a yes or no say on each application. There is also an arbitration system which exists to determine the necessary terms and conditions if land council approval is given. This arbitration system has never been used. The current Native Title Bill also provides for a negotiation phase. But in this case it is the appropriate tribunal which will have the yes or no say and which will also establish the terms and conditions. Thus, the outcome in each of the cases brought before it will depend on the workings of the tribunal.

Let us look around as to what experience there has been in Australia to gain some insight as to how tribunals are likely to work. One good example is the case of Coronation Hill. This development was considered contentious on environmental grounds at the time, largely because there was a federal election coming up. The matter was passed to the Resource Assessment Commission, headed by a judge with appropriate experts. We should note the similarities that are proposed in this bill. It carried out a 12-month study.

The subsequent report found that there was no environmental problem with the mining of Coronation Hill. However, issues relating to Aboriginals' spiritual matters were raised with the Resource Assessment Commission, which recommended against mining at this site. It is no wonder the mining industry is worried about this bill. Such an approval process could, in effect, turn out to be a de facto veto process. Furthermore, the economic incentives are wrong. The Commonwealth has set a limit on compensation for disturbance on the basis of state compensation schemes. There is little incentive for native titleholders to negotiate. In reality, therefore, it would probably pay them to push for a veto of mining.

The attitudes, arguments and concerns of the mining industry have been clearly put to the recent hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Mr Jerry Ellis from BHP Minerals argued, firstly, that the question of the validity of existing mining leases has not been totally clarified and, secondly, that the major issue is that the procedures put in place by the bill would be:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . time consuming—unnecessarily so in our view—and sometimes so time consuming that we believe market opportunities will be lost.

Again, Mr de Crespigney from Normandy Poseidon argued that the bill is too complex, it is unworkable, and the tribunal procedures are neither fair nor practical. I quote two important passages from Mr de Crespigney's submission to the Senate committee. First, he says:
Having fulfilled that urgent need—
that is, to tackle the Mabo challenge—

except in relation to the validation of existing titles, urgency ceases to be a requirement, and the point I cannot stress enough is that we are in a marathon, not a sprint, and all parties interested in reconciliation should now carefully, diligently, dispassionately and not hurriedly, review and address the whole reconciliation challenge, of which land is but one.
Finally, he goes on to say:

The Bill in its present form, particularly because of the significant delays it will create, will completely fetter our ability to provide wealth for our shareholders, taxes for the nation and employment opportunities generally, but in particular for Aborigines. Obviously, if it will have that effect on Normandy Poseidon, just imagine the impact on national wealth and national job opportunities if the BHPs and CRAs and the Western Minings are all having the same problems. Remember, lost opportunities means lost jobs.
The Senate will be aware that CRA announced on Monday of this week that it is reducing its level of exploration in Australia by a further 10 per cent and will be investing overseas instead.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, there is no hurry with this bill—it is a marathon. This is a very serious matter for all Australians, and it is imperative that we, as parliamentarians, get it right for all Australians, for all Aborigines. I oppose the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is actually a pleasure to follow Senator Gibson after such a considered contribution to the debate. I will not be covering the areas he has so eloquently and sensibly covered, and many of my colleagues have covered the very serious issues involved in this Native Title Bill.

PARA.TAB: It would be no surprise to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I am vehemently opposed to this legislation on a number of grounds. I do not want to go through the minutiae of the states rights angles and so forth but I will try to cover some of the more emotional aspects from a Liberal perspective.

Clearly, since the election in March and particularly since April and May, Australian politics have been dominated by what has been called `the Mabo debate' after Eddie Mabo and the Mabo No. 2 High Court ruling which came as somewhat of a shock to most of the nation, although I am sure that for those who were closely associated with it, it was well understood.

The ramifications have taken many months—indeed, over a year—to flow through to the broader community, but there is no doubt that the so-called Mabo debate has dominated Australian political debate for most of the last 12 months. It has done that for a number of reasons. It involves a cocktail of issues which affect all Australians, some of whom have strongly felt views on those issues.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As quickly as I can, I will put those issues to the Senate. Of course, there is the crucial issue of the plight of Australian Aboriginals, particularly those who are suffering most—those who live in abject poverty, those who miss out when it comes to health care, educational opportunities, access to land, housing and the many opportunities that most of us, who live in a privileged part of Australian society have access to. By `privileged' I mean anyone who has a suit of clothes, a roof over their heads, access to education, and a family environment. I call that privileged because there are so many Australians who do not share that privilege—and many Aboriginals simply do not.

PARA.TAB: Those issues are vital issues for Australia. I do not think anyone in this chamber or any Australians, no matter what their views on Aboriginal issues may be or are perceived to be, would dispute the fact that all Australians would like to see the welfare and opportunities for Aboriginal or indigenous Australians increased. Of course, it has been debated for decades as to how best achieve that. I am extremely sceptical about the approach that we have taken in the last 10 to 15 years—or at least those years that I have been cognisant of political debate—to the debate about Aboriginal affairs.

A further issue is the control of land and whether that should be carried out by state governments, as has been the case since and before federation. That, of course, is a crucial issue. It is an issue that has been canvassed in the Senate, and shortly I will just canvass it a little more.

Of course, the issues which have dominated the debate are security of land title and the economic debate and the issues of sovereign risk and individual property rights, which are crucial to economic development and the fabric of our society, were particularly well canvassed by my colleague Senator Bishop. People do need to have some sense of belonging and certainty in relation to their own economic future—and that applies, of course, equally to all Australians. Of course, people from different backgrounds may put different emphases on the form of land title they hold. But amongst all human beings there is an essential feeling that we need a place to call home. Of course, some nomadic human beings on this earth may have a different sense of being when it comes to land, and that is something that we need to understand as well.

The other crucial issue, which has made this a very hot political debate, a very important political debate, a divisive one, relates to Australia's economic future. But division is not all bad because it can bring out the best and worst in our society. At least if we have an active public debate on these issues, it involves the community and gets people thinking about bigger issues than their day to day woes—and that is perhaps a good thing.

Economic development is a crucial part of this debate. Whenever Australia's economic future is put at risk, be it by this sort of legislation or by industrial relations legislation, taxation legislation, health legislation—any sort of legislation that may impinge on Australia's economic development—the debate becomes heated, emotional and involves a lot of vested interests and, more often than not, the interests of those who are most affected are sometimes ignored.

In the current climate in Australia, in 1993, one of those interests is that of the army of unemployed and underemployed people. They are an extremely underprivileged group in Australia because they get up in the morning, see their friends and relatives going off to work and they wonder when the hell they will have the opportunity to do so themselves, to forge their own economic security in the world and to have self-esteem. So economic development is not only crucial for the security and future of all Australians; I am sure it is also a matter of genuine concern to all senators on all sides of the chamber—no matter how many political points we might want to score in the economic and unemployment debate—and all members of this parliament in trying to solve the unemployment crisis. This, again, has made the so-called Mabo debate a highly emotional and highly important debate.

The other important issue is that of race, which many people do not like to bring out, but a piece of legislation like this which will create a form of title which will only be available to one race of people naturally inflames debate over race generally.

Even though I am happy to accept that the Mabo ruling exists and that we need to understand that it is reality, my opposition to it in the first place is that where we divide Australia on the basis that there will be various systems of titles throughout the states which are available to all Australians, regardless of their ethnic background, race or colour, and then create a form of title that will be available to only one race of people who have black skin, of course we inflame tensions within society, which none of us enjoy. One needs to address that. My fundamental starting point in this debate is that once we divide Australia by setting up a system of land titles based on race, we can set up as many councils for reconciliation as we could want, but it will create tensions within a society which no Commonwealth or state government or highly motivated politician will ever solve.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about land titles based on inheritance?
—That is another—
—The London central business district is owned by about half a dozen people just because their ancestors could swing an axe a bit faster than somebody else. It still applies today.
—I am glad I invited the minister to interject, but I am trying to make a genuine contribution to this debate, and I am sure that Senator Collins has very strong feelings on this issue as well.
—It is not race at all. You are wrong. It is a question of inheritance.
—As this is a most important debate, I invite the minister to put his views on the record. I am trying to make a genuine contribution, speaking from my heart about issues that I feel strongly about.
—It is not title based on race.

—I recognise that the minister has strongly felt views as well. The Native Title Bill is inherently a form of title which is only available to one race. It is a title based on race and the minister can deny it as much as he wants.
—It is based on inheritance, just like our system is.

—I look forward to hearing the minister's views if he puts them forward. He obviously feels very strongly about it, but he may choose, because he wants this bill passed as quickly as possible through this chamber, not to speak at all. That would probably be very sad.
—That may be the case.
—I would listen very carefully to the arguments he put forward. Clearly he will not listen to me but we will both be judged sooner or later on our ability to listen.

PARA.TAB: This bill has been described by Senator Reynolds as a most important bill. I have been here for only just over three years and I have come across a number of debates where the bills have been described as the most important ever to come before this chamber, but there is absolutely no doubt that this bill is a crucial one. I shall never fall into the trap of calling a bill the most important one to come before this chamber because we never know when Mabo will come around the corner again. This bill is important because it changes some fundamental aspects of Australian society. One of the most crucial changes will be to the entire land management system. It will have crucial effects on the security of title, which Senator Bishop and my colleagues have already referred to.

One of the saddest aspects of this bill is the corporatist approach which has been adopted in solving the problem. It does not take any cognisance of individual Australians, be they indigenous Australians or other Australians. It has gone through the normal Labor Party-Paul Keating approach to solving a problem; that is, pull in a few heads of a few groups—be it trade unions, Aboriginal groups, industry, state governments, whatever—and put together a deal.

It has put together a deal in the process of coming to this lowest common denominator so-called solution to the so-called Mabo problem which I know that even my Green colleagues from Western Australia doubt is a solution. In fact, just about every honourable senator who has made a contribution, including Senator Cooney and my former colleague Fred Chaney in Western Australia, has said, `This is far from perfect but, gee whiz, we have to rush it through, because if we do not get it through, it will be worse and there will be these nasty political campaigns which will hurt Aboriginals'. That may or may not be true, but what is very worrying about this is the corporatist approach that has been taken.

My friend and colleague Senator Ellison described one of the other corporatist aspects of this bill—that native title under this bill will not be vested in individuals or communities; it will be invested in some sort of corporate body. I think one of the most crucial things that we can do to reconcile Aboriginals and the rest of the Australian community is to ensure that wherever possible, and as far as possible, the rights and responsibilities of Australian citizens are equal, regardless of one's ethnic background, where one was born or the colour of one's skin.

By creating a set of titles which can only be vested in some sort of corporate entity and another set of titles which can be vested in an individual or another corporate entity, we are creating more separatism; we are dividing this nation even more on race. Again, it is a corporatist approach which offends my Liberal philosophies where the individual should be pre-eminent. Corporate bodies are an artificial creation which in many ways—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand.
—I am sure I do not understand. When I am as old and wise as Senator Burns I am sure I will have absolute wisdom but, in the meantime, I will do my very best and I will do it without his help.

PARA.TAB: The problem with this corporatist approach is that it subjugates the rights of individuals. If there is one thing that we can do as a parliament and as a nation to help Aboriginal people it is to give them the opportunity to fulfil their own self in an individual way, and to try to break down the corporatist approach to Aboriginal affairs that we have seen through bodies like ATSIC and this community—almost communist—establishment that has been built up over the last 15 to 20 years.
I only have five minutes to go through a lot of material that I am clearly not going to get time to go through. I look forward to contributing to the committee stage of this debate.

In relation to control of land and states rights, honourable senators on both sides of this chamber, including my Western Australian colleague Senator Chris Evans, from the Labor Party, have said that they believe in individual rights and not states rights. Of course, the Liberal commitment to a federal system is based on keeping government close to the people. Land and land management have been controlled by state governments before and since Federation. The value of that is that management of land—the issuance of titles, control of land, licences to mine or conduct other activities—requires day-to-day management. It must, just in a practical sense, be managed as close to the ground as possible. That is the value of our Federation.

I have no intrinsic faith in state governments. I have little faith in governments as a solution to woes or problems at all. But if one has to choose a government to try to create an environment where people can maximise their own liberty and freedom, it is better to have that government as close to the people as possible. So if that government infringes on people's liberties, at the next election the people can pass their democratic judgment on that government.

In the end, the people of Australia and the people of Western Australia will cast judgment on the decision this parliament and the Senate is making to grab control of land management from state governments. It is interesting to note the responses to research conducted by the Roy Morgan Research Centre last week, 8 December 1993. Western Australians were asked, `In your opinion, should the federal government's Mabo legislation be allowed to overrule the WA state government's Mabo legislation or not?'. Sixty-six per cent of people agreed that the state government should not be overruled and only 27 agreed with Mr Keating's proposal.

I point out to my friend and colleague, Senator Teague, that this is something akin to a more substantial result than that achieved as a result of the fantastic effort in the South Australia state election, described across Australia as a landslide. I am trying to give the Senate an understanding of the strength of feeling in Western Australia, the state from which I come.

Sixty-six per cent of Western Australians answered yes to the question, `Would you support a request to the High Court to determine which Mabo legislation should deal with the Mabo problem?'. On the other crucial question, `In your opinion, which government's Mabo legislation should the High Court rule in favour of, the federal government's or the state government's?', 60 per cent of Western Australians supported the Western Australian state government approach and only 25 per cent supported the approach of the federal government, which is, of course, to control it all from Canberra.

There is enormous distrust of this federal government, particularly in states like South Australia and Western Australia. We do not trust the federal government and we generally do not trust decisions being made 3,000 miles away from where they will take effect. The opinion of the Western Australian population, reflected in the Roy Morgan survey, is indicative of that. I repeat that that is an even stronger opinion than that passed on the South Australian state Labor government only a few days ago when South Australians ejected the Labor Party from government.

I have only a minute left in which to speak and I have many more points that I would like to make. It is sad that the Greens and the Democrats supported the decision to reduce speaking times because this is a bill that demands that each senator have as long as possible to put heartfelt views on the record. I thought it incredibly hypocritical that Senator Chamarette should have had to seek an extension of her speaking time.

One of the other things that I might mention in closing is that it was Senator Chamarette who put before this Senate a notice of motion that basically said that, when the Mabo legislation came before this chamber, she would move a motion to suspend standing orders to allow a delegation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander representatives to appear before the bar of the Senate. She was so determined to ensure that this legislation got a full and fair hearing that she was prepared to move that motion. But when the opportunity came to ensure that the legislation got a full and fair hearing through a proper select committee process, she decided not to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Native Title Bill 1993 is one of the most important pieces of legislation to come before the parliament this year. In many ways, it is already overdue. I regard it as a failure on the part of the present government and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) not to have arrived at a consensus with the states and put before this parliament legislation which is a part of a united solution that involves the states and the Commonwealth. We were close to a consensus in the middle of this year when the premiers met with the Prime Minister, but a solution was not found. There was a lack of leadership from Mr Keating.

PARA.TAB: The matter before us touches upon some essential principles of justice for the original inhabitants and their descendants in this country. It also touches upon the foundations of secure investment, whether in pastoral pursuits, mining, forestry or fishing—in any use of Australian land.

I will be brief in my remarks. I listened most carefully to the speech of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, and I commend every word of his speech. In my view, he very aptly summarised the position of the opposition. He talked about the current international debate with regard to land law, of the move away from any notion of terra nullius in various countries around the world and his acceptance, reflecting the views of the opposition, of the High Court's parallel decision on this important matter.

I also wish to refer to the speech of a new senator, and increasingly my friend, Senator Chris Ellison. His technical grasp of this bill, of the Senate committee inquiry, of which he was a prominent member, and of the consultations that have taken place in regard to this bill were very aptly summarised in his speech. I have much to learn from his contribution with regard to some technical elements of this legislation.

I heard a majority of the speeches, mostly when I was out of the chamber and in my office. I wish to refer to two of them. Senator Chris Evans from Western Australia—another new senator—was the first speaker from the Labor Party. I think he summarised the Labor Party's approach to this matter very honourably. I disagree with his conclusion, I disagree with a number of his arguments and assessments, but it was clear from his speech that he was sincere and that he had thought through his own approach to this bill. I regard his views as typical of those expressed by the present Labor government. He was very fulsome in his support of the Prime Minister—it is not surprising that a new Labor senator would speak in this way about the Labor Prime Minister.

The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Cheryl Kernot, gave a very considered, carefully prepared, speech in which she put forward the strong commitment to justice for all Australians, including Aboriginal Australians, that she has expressed over recent months as a member of the reconciliation commission. I have had discussions with her in past months and many of us in the opposition would express in similar ways much of her commitment for justice for the Aboriginal people. I disagree with Senator Kernot's final assessments with regard to this bill.

This matter has been in fact quite divisive. This divisiveness has been expressed to a greater extent in the speeches that were made in the House of Representatives and in the Senate than in the four contributions that I have specifically mentioned. There has been divisiveness in the way the press has handled this issue over the last six months.

I believe it has been divisive chiefly because of the inherent uncertainty that flows from the High Court's Mabo decision. When there have been various alternative approaches to try to limit that uncertainty and when there have been differences of assessment as to the right pathway to limit the uncertainty, we have seen division grow in the debate and in the community at large.

All sorts of wild statements have been made by the government that it actually did have a solution that was going to work. This is so manifestly not true that it leads to a huge reaction by those who have current real interests in this country of ours, such as those with a rightful and lawful use of land in the form of such things as pastoral leases and mining leases.

The Prime Minister in his failure to consult sufficiently with representatives of these groups has by his very isolation not solved this growing sense of division. We now have a sincere senator like Senator Chris Evans saying that we should not delay this debate because there is a fragile consensus that the Prime Minister has put together and that, if it were to be put off even until next week, let alone next year, that fragile consensus would evaporate, the bill would fail and maybe no solution would emerge. I do not agree with Senator Chris Evans's assessment. On the other side, we have had a very credible response from many in the opposition, and some in the minority parties, that this legislation has been put together without a convincing legal foundation and so unprofessionally that it is going to fail.

Reference has been made by many honourable senators in the debate to the approximately 200 amendments that we will be debating in the committee stage, presumably tomorrow. We have in front of us a bill, the Native Title Bill 1993, and yet introduced only today were government amendments, totalling 75 or thereabouts, as well as about 50 amendments from the Greens and about 50 amendments from the Democrats. We are supposed to have some confidence that after a committee stage, with up to 200 amendments—carefully assessing which word, which clause, which phrase, which approach and which legal vocabulary—we will eventually end up with a workable bill.

I believe this is not a reliable way for this Senate to determine legislation that will serve Australia well over the middle and longer term. It will not even serve us well over the short term. So we have this division of opinion. I hear a sincere and fluent senator from the Labor Party such as Senator Chris Evans and I disagree with him.

Eventually it will come down to the numbers in the Senate. It is haphazard at the moment because we do not know what will happen to the amendments from the Green senators or the amendments from the Democrats. We in the opposition are so lacking in confidence about this legislation, so opposed to some key elements within it, that we are not interested in trying to find a set of amendments that would satisfy it. It is genuinely the opposition's view that this whole bill should be rejected.

Let me reaffirm a number of principles that I believe are typical of the approach to native title not only of the opposition but also of many other senators, despite this difference of opinion about this legislation—legislation that the government wants adopted and legislation that the opposition seeks to reject.

There are some principles and objectives that are pretty common to all of us. Firstly, we accept native title, we accept the legitimacy of the High Court to have made that determination, and we accept the High Court's decision. Many advances have been made in common law over the last several centuries in the tradition of British common law, including Australian common law. Some of our real advances in the rights of people and individuals have been won through a common law approach by enactments in courts such as the High Court. I accept the High Court's decision. I have looked at it in detail. If I had been on the bench, I believe I would have come down with a similar conclusion.

We had quite an unusual conjunction of circumstances in Murray Island, in the Torres Strait. We had a succession of ownership from ancestor to inheritor in a long, unbroken line. That inherited land was actually in the possession of the heirs and there was no other title issued with regard to it. So we had traditional owners actually occupying traditional land and no other title having been given in respect of that land. It is my view that the High Court made the right decision in awarding that land, with the concept of native title, to those owners.

Whether or not there is any other community, or more than a few or more than a handful of communities, amongst the Aboriginal population of Australia which has the same conjunction of characteristics as those in Murray Island is still to be tested. For example, in my own state of South Australia, those that come nearest to that conjunction of circumstances have already been given title to land by statute law. I refer to the Pitjantjatjara people. I was present when the Pitjantjatjara land title was handed over by my friend David Tonkin, then Premier of South Australia, in a ceremony in a creek bed near Ernabella.

The second principle is the Racial Discrimination Act. I do not believe anybody wants to abrogate that act or its principles. We do not wish to see racial discrimination in Australia. Thirdly, I subscribe—and I believe most of us do—to one Australia, with one law for all. That should not be taken to mean that there is an overlooking of any particular right of a particular group of Australians that is a part of the one law of Australia. I see native title as being an appropriate law, or appropriate ownership of land, for a particular people and as a part of the overall one law of Australia. Fourthly, I believe that there must be just recognition of Aboriginal land interests. I believe that most Australians, and most members of this chamber, in all parties, recognise that.

My fifth point concerns the principle that where land is denied to owners, there is just compensation. Sixthly, I believe that until December 1993 such compensation arising with regard to native title should be met by the government rather than by those who had lawful possession of the land prior to this issue arising, whether by freehold or even by lease.

The final principle that I refer to is the practical one of trying to limit uncertainty for investment in Australia—investment that generates wealth for Australia, jobs for Australians, and mineral, pastoral, forest and fishing products. The whole reason for this debate and for this bill is to try to weigh the impact of the High Court's decision with regard to native title and then, by statute, to limit the uncertainty that various implications of that decision would have for various industries and various users of land in Australia. Why then, in the last few minutes available to me in this debate, do I reject this bill and why indeed does the opposition reject the bill?

Firstly, I really do believe that the bill leads to more uncertainty, not less. It certainly involves uncertainty for pastoral leaseholders and mining leaseholders in Australia when we—especially those of us who fully accept the High Court's decision—should have been intent from the beginning to map out how to limit to the maximum extent and to a just extent this degree of uncertainty. Miners, farmers, foresters, fishers and anyone else with a legitimate use of land should not have to be anxious. They should be able to follow through with their investment or with their own work to the fullest extent in the confidence that they have the same access to land that they had two years ago, 10 years ago and 20 years ago.

Secondly, we reject this bill because it compounds the uncertainty that I have just referred to by a complex system of tribunals to determine any claims. This will inevitably lead to lengthy and complex litigation—to more uncertainty. I defy anyone in the chamber to say that there is a simple line as to what is, by this bill, made more certain and how we can see the limits of uncertainty.

Thirdly, this bill trespasses on native titleholders. It projects land ownership in the name of Aboriginal people by way of certain corporations, certain groupings of Aboriginals, which are not necessarily the native titleholders. I believe that, should this bill be passed, there will be disputes between native titleholders and various Aboriginal corporations or entities.

Fourthly, this bill trespasses on the Australian constitution's apportioning responsibility for land matters to the states. The uncertainty is serious because it affects us all. It jeopardises investment in pastoral industries, mining, fishing and forestry. It diverts economic activity away from Australia. It increases the fears and anxieties of Australians and divides Australians from one another. I reject the bill because it increases the uncertainty of the question of native title in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike Senator Teague, I have deliberately not listened to anyone's speech on the Native Title Bill, because I wanted to say what I wanted to say and not get involved or be tempted to get involved in responding to other people. For a number of reasons, I am opposed to Prime Minister Keating's response to the High Court decision.First, I believe that it increases the uncertainty of that decision and, secondly, I believe that it has caused an enormous amount of fear and concern amongst Aborigines and other members out in the community.

PARA.TAB: One of the key problems with this legislation, apart from its complexity, is that it expands the High Court decision far beyond that which was brought down. A situation will be created where this legislation is challenged in the courts. There will be court cases on all aspects of it. It will become a battle of the lawyers. We know before we start that it will be the lawyers who finally determine what all of this legislation really means.

The bill is flawed because it will cause conflict. Its very complexity will ensure that. In Western Australia—most of my speech relates to Western Australia and the concerns which exist there—there will be conflict between the Aborigines who live in the south-west of the state and the urban areas, those who live in the pastoral areas and those who are still involved where crown land exists. In Western Australia, something like 80 per cent of the state is crown land and pastoral land combined.

It will cause conflict between Aborigines and the rest of the community, between Aborigines and miners and between Aborigines and pastoralists. The legislation does not properly address those problems. It does not work through in the best and most comprehensive way, I believe, the handling of those problems. I have already mentioned court cases. Not only will there be court cases over the claims but there will be a number of challenges to this legislation in the High Court. A lot of that will be brought about purely and simply because the consultation process between the states has not been satisfactory. The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, and those on the other side of this chamber will regret the isolation of Western Australia in that consultative process long into the future. I will say a little more about that in a moment or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you consult with someone who wants to destroy the Aboriginal people?

—I will not respond to the nonsense that is now coming from the other side of the chamber. It is absolute and total rubbish. I will come to that a little later. Who is going to pay all of the bills for the court cases? They will be massive. We are not talking about a few thousand dollars; we are talking about millions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: There will be an enormous impact on investment. We have already heard that a number of the major mining companies are reconsidering their investment portfolios and are now looking at opportunities overseas. In fact, they are doing more than that.
