They are going into detail about where they might be able to take out their next operation—and it is not in Australia. That will have a huge impact on the total structure and fabric of Australian life. But the area where it will hurt most is in the jobs that the mining industry generates. Those jobs losses will be shared by all, including Aborigines.

I want to touch on the process of consultation. There is no doubt that when the first difficulties were met by the first COAG meeting, the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, was effectively locked out of the consultative process.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't want to be in it.

—We have got some rabbits up on the hill today. It would be a good idea if they hopped back in their burrow and stayed quiet. Mr Court was locked out of it. If Senator Burns does not believe us, he should talk to Julian Grill and Graeme Campbell, who are good Western Australians, even if they do sit on the other side of the political fence. In effect, Mr Keating said, `To hell with Western Australia'.

PARA.TAB: The legislation before us does not have the type of consensus and support required when dealing with a decision of the High Court. Unfortunately, all the other state premiers, to varying degrees, have decided to go it alone without full and proper consultation. I want to put on the public record that this bill will shake the very foundations of the federation of Australia. It might even destroy it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Burns can laugh all he likes, but it might even destroy it. We have heard comments from Mr Keating, Mr Walker and Mr Tickner to the effect that Western Australia had nothing to worry about with the Commonwealth's approach because it would not have a large impact on that state. However, some time later Mr Keating came to Western Australia and he was questioned by journalists. One article in the Sunday Times of 10 October 1993—I will hold it up for all to see—had the headline `Prime Minister admits WA has a lot to lose with Mabo'.

PARA.TAB: It is an absolute tragedy that the Prime Minister of this nation was not prepared to effectively address the legitimate concerns of Western Australia. It is obvious from the Prime Minister's statement that WA is the state that will be most affected by this legislation. It has the most complex set of concerns in dealing with this issue, followed by South Australia and the Northern Territory—and I am not trying to put one in front of the other.

It is very easy for Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmania to go down the route that this legislation puts before us. It is very easy for them to say, `We will accept it. It will only marginally affect us'. I congratulate all of my colleagues on this side of the chamber and in the House of Representatives who have stood up and said, `We want this legislation to be fair to all Australians', and for not abandoning Western Australia. I sincerely thank them for what they have done. They have ensured that all aspects of this legislation and its impact on the progress of this nation are taken into account. We must remain a team.

On this side of the chamber we believe in federation; we are not centralists. I have had a very long association with Aboriginal people. In my formative years, in my whole time at the Bindi Bindi school, which is 100-odd miles north of Perth, there were more Aborigines attending the school than Europeans. So I grew up with Aborigines. I still see some of them from time to time and they are still good friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should know better.

—The rabbits are bad today. Of all the Aborigines in Western Australia to whom I have spoken—obviously, I have not spoken to them all—not one of them has told me that he or she supports this legislation. I want to put that comment on the public record.

PARA.TAB: In terms of land system allocations, usages and access, I believe that Western Australia has the best record of all the states. I say that for a number of reasons which I will briefly go through. First of all—and Senator Teague gave an example in relation to South Australia—14 per cent, or approximately 325,000 square kilometres, is now held in various forms of titles relating to the Aboriginal people. We have legislation to cover sacred sites.

We put in place a program of buying stations—I think it was in 1985 or thereabouts, certainly in the 1980s—and now 39 stations out of the 400 leases, that is approximately 10 per cent, are owned and run by Aboriginal people. I emphasise that point—owned and run. Like other stations in Western Australia, there are good ones, there are not so good ones, and there are some that need some help. I again point out that those particular people are frightened out of their wits by this legislation. They are very concerned that they are going to find themselves locked into court battles. On top of that, we have excision legislation. I think there are now 33 excisions or thereabouts in terms of that particular piece of legislation.

Another point that I want to make in terms of that and the traditional usage, which exists in Western Australia and goes back to the days of Lord Forrest, is that there has been a statutory right for land usage on virtually all pastoral land in Western Australia. There are similar situations in the Northern Territory and in South Australia, but not to any degree, if any, in the other states.

The next point that I wish to raise deals with the constitutional problems of this bill. It will be challenged on a number of grounds in the High Court. To give one example, it will be challenged on the fact that it interferes with the constitutional right of the states as far as land management is concerned. If this legislation is passed, it will totally rewrite the statute books in regard to the management and allocation of land in Australia. That will mean, as I have already said, long and lengthy legal debate and battle. The validity of this legislation will be in doubt for years and years to come.

A further point that I want to raise relates to the role that the National Farmers Federation, particularly Rick Farley, has played in this matter. I have to say that I found very offensive a letter that appeared on my desk today addressed to Dr Hewson. I found it offensive in two ways: firstly, as to the accusation contained therein, which I will deal with in a moment; and, secondly, in that the letter was written to Dr Hewson requesting some assistance in terms of a particular aspect and that the letter was circulated low, high and wide. The author of the letter has done it purely and simply because of the things that he has consistently been saying. In my view, he has totally misled the pastoralists and the farmers or the member organisations of this nation for months and months. He suddenly discovered that what he was saying was not correct. I must make the record absolutely clear and say that the letter was signed by the President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Graham Blight, and not by Mr Farley. But I have no doubt who was the author of the letter.

I want to read the answer to a question that I put to Senator Gareth Evans, who was with us in the chamber a minute ago, on 20 October 1993. I will not read the whole answer because it is on the public record. Part of that answer stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether they have been extinguished absolutely or whether they have been extinguished to the extent of any inconsistency is an issue that remains to be determined by the High Court. That is the language that some of the judges used—`to the extent of any inconsistency'.

At the time many of us made it quite clear to the NFF that there was an enormous amount of doubt about whether or not pastoral leases were actually validated. There is a significant difference between validated and valid. That point was not listened to. We see in the Hansard of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of 6 December that Mr Farley stated:

In our view and on our legal advice, the bill will provide security of tenure for pastoral leaseholders. The bill provides that any lease which is found to be invalid at any time, provided that lease was issued before 31 December 1993—any invalid lease issued before that time—will be validated and the act of validation will extinguish native title.
I apologise to Senator Vanstone because she has heard all this before. Later in the proceedings he was questioned by Senator O'Chee. The Hansard states:

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you see clause 214 being in any way different from 213, given that 214 presumes that the leasehold in question is already a past act?

PARA.TAB: Mr Farley—Let me make the point that the legislation, as it exists, deals only with the validation of those acts which are previously found to be invalid. The legal advice we have received in relation to the valid grant of particular leases is that the valid grant of a lease has extinguished native title. In the absence of native title, the renewal of a valid lease should not be open to question.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet we have before us this letter. What this letter tries to do is put the blame back on the coalition if this matter is not dealt with. I said to Mr Farley of the NFF going back many months that there is a serious problem. The pastoralists must lay the blame for any problems they have with this legislation fairly and squarely at the feet of Mr Farley. By not telling the whole story he has created an enormous inconsistency.

PARA.TAB: I would like to conclude my remarks by stating a couple of points. I firmly believe that the reconciliation process must be kept separate from the Native Title Bill. I think we will confuse a lot of issues if we put these issues together. I also want to ask a question in terms of the reconciliation process because I have some problems with it. I raised this matter in the press some time ago. Why, in Western Australia under the administration of ATSIC, was $8 million out of $50 million allocated last year for housing not used? Why was it returned to the central system when 1,300 Aboriginal families were looking for housing in Western Australia? I think that is something that needs addressing very seriously.

This legislation may give about 12,000 Aborigines native title but what about the rest of the Aborigines? This legislation is divisive and it discriminates against Western Australia. The elders I have spoken to in Western Australia do not want this legislation. I will not support legislation that is unfair and unjust. Australia is one nation and I wish it to remain that way.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put on the public record my concern about the Parliamentary Library. A letter was tabled in this chamber which may imply that a parliamentary librarian had not provided me with correct information. On 19 November, I made a statement in the Senate that I believed at the time to be correct. I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been informed by the Australia Council that one Paul Keating attended the meeting in 1989 at which the fellowships were decided, including the first fellowship for Mr Tozer.
I was referring to the awarding of a second Australian artists creative fellowship which was announced this year.

PARA.TAB: I obtained this information from the Parliamentary Library. On 18 November, my office specifically asked an officer from the Parliamentary Library to find out the members of the advisory panel that decided the fellowship recipients at the time that Mr Tozer was awarded his first fellowship. This officer from the Parliamentary Library sought this information from an officer at the Australia Council—an officer who also provided information about other matters relating to these fellowships.
At 6.10 p.m. that day, I received a fax from the officer from the Parliamentary Library stating:

SPEECH.PARA: Advisory Committee Members in 1989: Professor Donald Horne (Chairman), Tony Bishop, Kelvin Coe, Betty Churcher, Reuben Fineberg, Ross Gengos, Mary Vallentine.
Underneath the names of the members was the following statement:
In addition, at the meeting which decided on the recipients of the fellowships were: Paul Keating, Cathy Santamaria (DASSET), Linda Nesdale and Klaus Cusio (Australia Council).

Immediately upon receiving this fax, my office phoned the officer in the library and asked him to confirm that the contents of the fax and, in particular, the statement that Mr Keating was at the meeting which decided the fellowships, were accurate.The officer confirmed that he had been told by an officer from the Australia Council that Mr Keating attended that meeting.

PARA.TAB: On two further occasions prior to making my statement in the Senate, my office rang the officer from the Parliamentary Library and asked him to reconfirm that the contents of the fax were what he was told by the officer from the Australia Council. The library officer was adamant and in no doubt that this is what he was told by the Australia Council. Prior to my making the statement in the Senate, I was also told by another unrelated source that he had also been told that Mr Keating was at the meeting at which the decisions were made. Hence, my statement was made in good faith.

On 22 November, my office received a phone call from another officer from the Australia Council who stated that Mr Keating did not attend the meeting at which the decisions were made. On 1 December, I received a letter from the Acting General Manager of the Australia Council dated 26 November which the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) tabled in the Senate on 6 December. Had the minister not tabled that letter addressed to me, I could have dealt with the matter by replying to the Australia Council; but since it is on the public record and some doubt has been cast on the ability of the librarian to accurately convey what he was told, I felt the need to put my point of view on the public record. The letter from the Australia Council stated:

SPEECH.PARA: As a matter of record only, I think I should formally correct the statement made by you in Parliament.
He quoted the abovementioned statement that I made and said:

(I understand that this information came not from the Council but from an officer in the Parliamentary Library, who, it appears, had taken down the information incorrectly over the telephone from an Australia Council officer.

I do not believe that for the letter to say that was necessarily the best way for that matter to be dealt with. It would have been better if the letter had said, `There appears to have been a misunderstanding. This is the Australia Council's position on what actually happened'—whether Mr Keating was at the meeting or not—`We believe that is what was conveyed to the library, however, there may have been some misunderstanding and we would like to put the record straight'. It would have given me the opportunity to do that.

PARA.TAB: The minister chose to table the letter, thereby intimating that it was the librarian who made the error. I would rather put on the public record that the Australia Council believes that the information I gave in the Senate was not correct. I believe that the officer of the Parliamentary Library took down as accurately as possible what was said. There could have been a misunderstanding on either side. The error could have been made by the person asking the question or by the person taking it down. I suggest that there was a misunderstanding at some point, not necessarily the librarian's, and that the minister has tried to correct it, but it would have been better had it not been tabled.

The Parliamentary Library has served me well in this way. To have that on the public record is not in the best interests of the relationship that we have with the library. I would hope that in future, if there is thought to be an error, that can be sorted out and we do not have to have this sort of situation arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly tonight on a matter relating to the extraordinary story of Mrs Magda Bardy, who, by an ironic twist of fate, found that she was living very near a person in Sydney whom she believed to have been responsible for the imprisonment, which led to the death, of her first husband in Hungary in 1951. I first raised this matter in the Senate on 20 May this year. Since then a number of developments have occurred which I want to bring to the attention of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Bardy, who has an OAM and who for many years has contributed a great deal of time and energy to sheltered workshops in Sydney, and her son, Ivan Somers, have been seeking from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, information concerning the processes that led to the approval of Mr Vajda as a migrant to Australia in the 1950s. Mrs Bardy and her son have also sought documents under freedom of information. These have now been received. They show that a Mr Vajda, a dentist, who arrived here under the assisted passage scheme in 1957, made no mention of a job that he had in Hungary as an officer with the AVH, the Hungarian secret police, or that he had served two years of a six-year gaol sentence imposed by the Military Court of Budapest.

On 30 May 1993, on the 60 Minutes program, Mr Tibor Vajda, a retired Sydney dentist, acknowledged that he had been the deputy head of Department 6 of the AVH—or as he described it, a `political police force'—under the head of which department he had questioned prisoners. He had also said on this program that it was not impossible that it was his signature at the bottom of the page of the secret police document concerning Mrs Bardy's husband's imprisonment, although he also said that he had only very occasionally signed such documents when his superior officer was away.

He has also said that this document was an administrative document which came into existence after a person had been arrested and interrogated so as to record the decision of the head of the State Defence Authority, or AVH, as to what should be done with the person. He believed that it did not show that he had a major role to play in the imprisonment of Mrs Bardy's first husband, despite acknowledging the signature `Tibor Vajda' as possibly being his own.

It is difficult for any of us here in the Senate to assess the facts relating to this case and to respond appropriately. My purpose in drawing attention to the matter again, following my raising of it in May, is to highlight the very complex issues that arise from it. If Mrs Bardy's claims are correct, then clearly it is possible that someone obtained firstly, permanent residence, and, secondly, Australian citizenship by withholding information which would have resulted in a rejection of both applications; that is, to settle, and that of citizenship.

Mr Vajda entered Australia when the Immigration Act 1901-1949 was in operation. That act provided that any person convicted of a crime and sentenced to imprisonment for one year or more was deemed to be a prohibited immigrant. Prohibited immigrants entering or found within the Commonwealth were guilty of an offence under section 7 of that act. If convicted, a person would be liable for up to six months imprisonment or deportation from Australia. However, there was a 12-month time limit for commencing criminal proceedings under section 7. The current Migration Act 1958 does provide the minister with powers to cancel any valid visa at his or her discretion. The Australian Citizenship Act, however, does not allow a minister to revoke citizenship if fraudulent information was provided to obtain citizenship more than 10 years prior to the fraudulent information being presented. I think that is section 50(2) of that act.

The 10-year provision is longstanding and has been in the act since 1958. I believe, however, that this particular case shows that it is possible to discover new information many years later relevant to whether or not the government of the day would or would not have bestowed citizenship on a foreign national. I raise the question of whether there should be some grounds on which it can be revoked, no matter how long ago the fraud—as it would be—took place. I acknowledge that the reason for the 10-year provision was to give certainty to the status of Australian citizenship, and that is a very important consideration.

I would hope, therefore, that this case and the issues that arise from it may come forward in the context of the current review by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations of the Australian Citizenship Act, as it is relevant to section 50 of the act. That will depend, of course, on whether the submissions on these matters are received by the committee in the course of its inquiry.

The other point that I raise in conclusion is that this matter, in this particular case, highlights the importance of our immigration checking procedures. It is a matter that has concerned me for some considerable time, as I think you would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President. There are a lot of questions being asked and concerns being expressed in this area. The case I have referred to tonight goes back almost 40 years. We do need to be confident of the integrity and quality—particularly the quality—of our checking procedures in the 1990s. This case highlights the critical importance of the government ensuring that full character checks are undertaken in assessing all new settler arrivals and that there is, to the extent possible, the information necessary to enable those checking procedures to be carried out in a way that makes us all feel confident about the integrity of the process.

The case of Mrs Bardy and Mr Vajda is a very interesting one. It is a very sad case in many ways. I do not know how it is all going to end, but it is one of those cases that captures the imagination from time to time and—more than the imagination—captures the heart. It is a matter that should certainly be of interest to the Senate, although I do not pretend to suggest that the Senate ought to have a role in its solution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last 12 months there have been contributions to adjournment debates, questions put on notice and other contributions by members of the House of Representatives and the Senate on the question of Macedonia. I wish to refer to this matter this evening in the adjournment debate, it being the last opportunity, realistically, before the parliament rises for me to reflect on and make my own comments on the contributions that the other members of this parliament have made.

PARA.TAB: I wish to distinguish between Macedonia, as I see it, as a northern part of Greece and a country which has been a province of Yugoslavia in the past and which uses within the title of its name the same word—`Macedonia'. The authentic and, I believe, genuine use of the term `Macedonia' is by the Greek people in the north of Greece with regard to the whole heritage that we now know as Macedonian. I believe that the use by slavonic people in the south of former Yugoslavia of the term `Macedonia' throughout this century is confused and usurping.

Let me be clearer. In the northern part of Greece, based on Thessaloniki, the language spoken by the people is Greek. The Macedonian cultural heritage includes Alexander the Great and Philip, both of whom were Greek speaking, and the scholar Aristotle, who with other Macedonian writers wrote in Greek. The Macedonia of the Greek cultural symbols includes the star of Vergina, the white tower of Thessaloniki and the Dmitria festival. The predominant religion of Macedonia is Christian, as expressed for centuries and now today by the Greek Orthodox Church.

The confused and usurping use of the term `Macedonia' is by the former part of southern Yugoslavia, which is mostly a Slavic people, with a close affinity to Serbia and Bulgaria, where the Greek language is suppressed, even though spoken by a minority of residents of Greek origin. This southern province has now become an aspirant, independent country distinct from Serbia. It is currently admitted as a member of the United Nations under the name which has the initials F-Y-R-O-M. The name submitted to the United Nations is `Former Yugoslavic Republic of Macedonia'. The people of this emerging new nation have Slavic names—not Greek—the Slavic language and a predominant church which is neither Greek Orthodox nor Serbian Orthodox but independent.

On 5 November last year in the House of Representatives, Mr Ron Edwards, the former member for Stirling, spoke urging his government to recognise FYROM under the title `Macedonia' as an independent nation. This led to others debating this matter. The government has not agreed to the request of the former member for Stirling. Since then he has lost his seat and this issue has been taken up by others, particularly in the Senate.

On 6 October, Senator Chamarette, also from Western Australia, put two questions on notice, No. 641 and No. 642, both directed to Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, asking him about matters arising from her concern for a Slavic oriented minority in northern Greece and others of this disposition, living now in Australia and calling themselves after FYROM, whose human rights are alleged to be restricted by the governing authorities in Greece.

Let me make it quite clear that I believe all of us in the Senate—certainly including myself—would want all minority people in every country to be accorded the full human rights set out in the United Nations conventions. On 1 September this year Senator Spindler also referred to the same issues referred to by Senator Chamarette. He based his adjournment speech on Amnesty reports, Helsinki Watch reports, an article in the Times of London and in the Economist.

A couple of months ago, on 21 October in the House of Representatives, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), a New South Wales Labor member who claims to represent more people of the FYROM background than anyone else in Australia, made an adjournment speech in which he urged the Australian government to recognise the FYROM. Again, the government has not done so—I believe for reasons which are the basis of my own views as well and which I am reflecting in this speech.

On 28 October Mr Hollis then placed a question on notice asking the foreign minister matters of fact with regard to the United Nations membership of the FYROM and with regard to why Australia had not recognised this emerging country in the Balkans. I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the answers given to Mr Hollis and the answers given to Senator Chamarette, as well as their questions. I have shown them to Senator Evans.
Leave granted.
Mr Hollis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 October 1993:
(1) How many countries recognise Macedonia.
(2) What impediments are there to Australia recognising Macedonia immediately.
(3) Will Australia recognise Macedonia; if so, when; if not, what difficulties would arise in Macedonian authorities opening an office in Australia to perform consular and other functions.
Mr Bilney—The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable members's question:

(1) As at 12 November 1993, forty (40) countries are known to have announced, or acknowledged, recognition of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (FYRM). For many of these countries recognition flowed automatically from their support for the FYRM's membership of the United Nations in April 1993. Many recognised the Republic as the "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia", the interim name under which it was admitted to the UN, some as the "Republic of Macedonia" and some have avoided specifying the name under which they have recognised.

(2) & (3) Australia, along with a number of other nations, has been awaiting the outcome of bilateral attempts between Greece and the FYRM to resolve the name and associated issues before moving to recognition of the FYRM. Australia supported UN membership of the FYRM but this did not in itself amount to recognition, which in Australian practice requires a separate and deliberate act and cannot be inferred from any other action taken by the Government. Only duly accredited consular or diplomatic representatives can carry out the functions which are the sole prerogative of a consul. The opening of an office by the FYRM to perform consular functions and the accreditation of a consular representative cannot proceed until Australia recognises the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The issue of recognition remains under continuing review.
Senator Chamarette asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: With reference to concerns raised by members of the Macedonian community in Australia:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that many ethnic Macedonians from Greece who were child refugees of the Greek Civil War (1945-59) and are now Australian citizens are denied entry to Greece.

(2) Is the Minister aware of a case reported in the media in July 1988 of 50 West Australians of Macedonian origin being detained at the Greek border for several hours, under duress, before being turned back over the border.
(3) Is the Minister further aware that there are about 550 such child refugees in Australia and that many of these are consistently denied the right to return to Greece.
(4) What influence can the Australian Government exert to assist these Australian citizens to re-enter Greece, to be reunited with their families and to reclaim their ancestral property.

(5) As the Greek community in Australia is one of the major beneficiaries of Australia's policy of multiculturalism, what is the Government's attitude to the apparent hypocrisy of the Greek Government which pursues a policy of monoculturalism to the point of denying the presence in Greece of any other nationalities, and indeed seeks to suppress any vestiges of other cultures which may appear.
Senator Gareth Evans—The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(1) I am aware that a number of holders of Australian passports, who have been identified by the Greek Authorities as having actively espoused views on the "Macedonia" issue contrary to Greek views, have been refused entry to Greece on the basis of their alleged anti-Greek views. Some of those refused entry were child refugees from the Greek civil war (1946-49).

(2) A number of Australian passport holders were refused entry into Greece in 1988. I am aware of community claims that those refused entry numbered in excess of 50, although this figure cannot be verified. The incident referred to followed a reunion held in Skopje to commemorate the fortieth anniversary of refugees leaving Greece, the holding of which had generated considerable tension in Greece.

(3) I am aware that in the 1986 census, some 4,000 people claiming to be of Macedonian ethnicity indicated that they had been born in Greece. Some of these came to Australia as child refugees, although there are no specific statistics on the number of child refugees. The figure of 550 is a community estimate.

(4) The Australian Embassy in Athens has in the past queried the decision by Greek authorities to refuse entry to certain Australian passport holders, but the Australian Government recognises that ultimately the Greek Government has the right to apply such conditions of entry and entry procedures as it sees fit.

(5) The Greek community in Australia benefits under the Australian Government's policy of multiculturalism, as does the broader community. Ethnic communities in Australia, whether they be Greek or any other nationality, will continue to benefit from this policy irrespective of the internal political or human rights situations in their countries of origin. The Australian Government supports the observance of internationally accepted standards of human rights, and has made representations to the Greek Government when there is evidence to suggest that allegations of abuse of human rights may have some basis in fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I concur with the answers given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on these matters. I note that the opposition also has a very similar expression of views on these issues. I now seek leave—I have also shown this to Senator Evans—to incorporate in Hansard two pages of a speech that the shadow minister for foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) gave as a lecture to the Hellenic Council of Western Australia on 3 December this year. The two pages that I refer to are most of pages 4 and 5 of his speech, which touch upon this matter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation in Bosnia-Herzegovina shows that at present, the crucial need elsewhere in Former Yugoslavia is stability, a breathing space to enable the various parties to adjust to new realities.
The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is a case in point, and one I know is of concern to the Greek community.
The Coalition strongly believes it would be inappropriate to recognise a new state under the name of Macedonia against the objections of Greece.

The Coalition recognises that the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is in a difficult position as it is effectively in a state of international limbo. We recognise also that such a situation should not continue indefinitely as it is not in the interest of the people of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and it has the potential to further destabilise the region.
But a precipitate move towards recognition might also destabilise the region further.

Whilst the Coalition has consistently supported the rights of the peoples of Former Yugoslavia to peaceful self determination, subject to the protection of minority interests within existing borders, the issue of international recognition cannot be considered in a vacuum.

Accordingly, when the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia seeks recognition as an independent state under a new name, the international community should address the question as to whether such recognition has the confidence of adjoining states and will enhance order and stability.

The Coalition believes it essential that the international community not simply replace one problem—how to manage the break-up of Yugoslavia—with another—destabilised relations between independent states in the Balkans.

Greece strongly objects to recognition of the new state under the denomination Macedonia and has further sought legal and political guarantees that the new state harbours no territorial claims against Greece and that it abstains from hostile propaganda against Greece.

Subject to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, in Prime Minister Papandreou's words, giving up any "irredentist claims", Greece has indicated its desire to pursue economic and political cooperation with the new state.
The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has applied for membership to the United Nations under the denomination "Republic of Macedonia" which remains unacceptable to Greece.
The United Kingdom, France and Spain proposed to the UN Security Council a formula for compromise, but this was not taken up.

With the election of the Papandreou Government in October, the Greek position on the issue has been clarified. Whilst Prime Minister Papandreou has indicated his appreciation of the efforts of the UN over the issues, he also made it clear that the new Greek Government will not accept use of the word "Macedonia" in any way in the name of the new state.

I note Greek European Affairs Minister Pangalos' comments of 28 November, warning the other countries of the European Union in strong terms not to attempt to unilaterally upgrade their relations with the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
The tone of Mr Pangalos' comments illustrates the strength of Greek feeling over the issue, a depth of concern of which the Coalition is very much aware.

Whilst Mr Pangalos' comments may have ruffled diplomatic feathers, they certainly demonstrate that the spirit of October 1940, the spirit which led Greece to say "Ohi" [OKHI] to Mussolini's demands, has not dimmed.
Because of the depth of Greek feeling on the issue, the Coalition would not prescribe to the Greek Government solutions to this very complex issue.

We would, however, urge Greece to keep the lines of dialogue with Skopje open, because as events elsewhere in the Former Yugoslavia have demonstrated, the stark alternatives to dialogue and negotiation can be conflict and bloodshed.
Whilst the situation with regard to the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is tense and difficult, it is and hopefully will remain peaceful.

But wherever we look in Former Yugoslavia there is the potential for further conflict. In Kosova, in Slavonia and in Krajina the situation is fraught with menace. I reiterate my hope that as President of the European Union, Greece will be able to help defuse these crises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I thank the Senate. Of course, I support the views of my close colleague Andrew Peacock in the remarks that he set out. They are very consistent with the opposition's policy on this matter that we have discussed. I refer also to correspondence that a number of senators have received from the Hellenic councils, be they of New South Wales, Western Australia or other Hellenic councils in Australia, that are broadly supportive of much of what the foreign minister has said in his answers, and of what Mr Peacock and I have said.

PARA.TAB: I also refer to the Aegean Macedonian Association of Australia, which has quite the contrary view—the view that was the basis of the questions asked by Mr Hollis, Senator

SPEECH.PARA: Chamarette and Senator Spindler. I am aware of their letters. I am aware of answers that have been sent in response to their letters by the parties in this parliament. I refer finally to a letter by the Hellenic Council of New South Wales to Senator Chamarette dealing with this whole question. It is too long to seek to incorporate in Hansard.

I conclude by saying that I believe in the coming months there will be an appropriate time for this country to recognise the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia, when it has a named linked to its capital, Skopje, or some other name which does not put forward any usurping concept that it is in fact the inheritor of what we know to be the Macedonian heritage, or that it is in any way to be seen as rightfully having within its territory what we know as northern Greece, including the region around Thessaloniki.

PARA.TAB: I look to Greece to take the presiding role in the European Community to pay a conciliatory and sensible role in this debate. As soon as there is an appropriate name for this former republic within Yugoslavia that is acceptable to Greece, France, the UK and the other European nations, it is likely to be acceptable to Australia. With a few other criteria, it would be subject to recognition by this country. In the meantime, I urge the two persuasions that have communities in Australia to base on fact the arguments that they put to us senators and to the community so that we all recognise the rights of minorities to the full human rights of the United Nations conventions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Treasurer contact Austrade in 1986 to request assistance with a delivery of Australian wine to the current United States (US) Secretary of Treasury (Mr Bentsen).
(2) Was the Treasurer's action in response to any request from Mr Bentsen; if so, what was the nature of that request.
(3) Did the Treasurer make any particular request as to what label, type, vintage and quantity of wine should be delivered to Mr Bentsen.
(4) Was any direction given regarding who should pay for the purchase and delivery of the wine to Mr Bentsen.
(5) Was the wine delivered to Mr Bentsen for his personal use, or was it intended that the wine be used for matters related to Mr Bentsen's official duties as Secretary of the Treasury.
(6) What was the cost of the wine sent to Mr Bentsen, and who paid for its purchase.
(7) Where was the wine delivered, at what cost and who paid for its delivery.
(8) Did Mr Bentsen or the US Government contribute to the cost of purchasing the wine; if so, to what extent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(8) As the then Minister for Trade, I met with the then Senator Bentsen in 1986 on official business. During the course of that meeting, Senator Bentsen commented most favourably on the quality of an Australian wine that he had tasted on flight from Australia to the USA some time previously. He indicated an interest in obtaining a quantity of that wine for a fundraising function he was planning.

In an entirely appropriate response, I offered my assistance in the matter. Accordingly, I arranged for Austrade to contact Senator Bentsen and I asked that Austrade do all that it could to assist Senator Bentsen in obtaining the appropriate quantity of the wine.
It is my understanding that Austrade subsequently arranged for the wine to be supplied to Senator Bentsen under normal commercial terms.

My intervention with Austrade on behalf of Senator Bentsen and Austrade's efficient follow up to the request for assistance was obviously highly beneficial, both in terms of the commercial interests of the Australian wine industry and of Australia's diplomatic interests.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 18 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the `Four Corners' program on 4 October 1993 which raised allegations that the training program `Money and You' has the characteristics of a cult movement:

(1) Does the `Money and You' program qualify under the training guarantee levy; if so, in the light of the disturbing nature of the program, is the Government reviewing its eligibility under the training guarantee levy.
(2) What action is the Government taking to ensure that other cult-like training programs do not benefit from the operation of the Government's training levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under the Training Guarantee, employers must spend 1.5 per cent of payroll on eligible employment related training or pay the shortfall to the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).
The Government does not determine which training programs are eligible. The Parliament set up a legislative framework which requires that, to be eligible:
the object of the program must be to develop, maintain or improve employment related skills;
there must be no other significant object of the program, such as recreation; and
the program must be structured as required by the Act, before it is delivered.

Employers decide whether a particular training program is an eligible training program for their employees. If they are not sure, they can ask the ATO or apply for a training advisory certificate from a Registered Industry Training Agent.

The Government does not determine the eligibility of programs under the Training Guarantee. However, the ATO audits a sample of employers each year to ensure that training meets the requirements of the legislation.

(2) The Government believes each business should be free to choose the training that best suits its needs. It encourages industry to choose quality, skills based training by promoting best practice and providing assistance to develop high quality training options closely aligned to the needs of industry.

A major evaluation of the Training Guarantee, due to report in late 1994, will examine the effectiveness of the scheme in promoting more effective industry training and increasing the skills of the workforce. One of the questions which will be examined is whether the program should be changed to limit the range of eligible training. Surveys currently being conducted by the ABS will provide further information on the types of training undertaken since the Training Guarantee came into effect.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the industrial action by staff of the Cash Receivables Section of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) banning the banking of taxpayers' cheques for the payment of taxation liabilities:

(1) Will taxpayers be exposed to late payment additional tax and penalty interest pursuant to sections 207 and 207A of the Income Tax Assessment Act as a consequence of the non-presentation of taxpayers' cheques.
(2) What is the value of the unpresented cheques held by the ATO arising from this industrial dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Taxpayers will not be exposed to penalties as a result of the delay in presentation of their cheques. This is because there were no delays in crediting taxpayers' accounts; the industrial bans only affected the presentation of cheques.
However penalties may apply in cases where cheques are subsequently dishonoured.

(2) When the industrial dispute was resolved, the value of unpresented cheques held by the ATO as a result of the dispute totalled $943.2m. Cheques were withheld in only nine of the 24 Branch Offices. All cheques have now been presented.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Training Courses

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 2 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the 1992-93 financial year:
(1) How many training courses were conducted for departmental staff.
(2) Where were the training courses held.
(3) What expenses were incurred on: (a) airfares; (b) other travel; (c) accommodation; (d) conference facilities; (e) any other associated expenses.
(4) What was the duration of each course (number of days).
(5) How many staff attended each course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The answers provided are the best possible given the time available and given the Department's people and finance management systems (NOMAD and FINEST).
(1) A total of 1 751 courses were conducted for Departmental staff.
(2) The number of training courses held in each State/Territory were:
ACT—624; Western Australia—107; New South Wales—494; Northern Territory—46; Victoria and Tasmania—274; Queensland—110; South Australia—96.

(3) The Department's expenses for training, including airfares, other travel, accommodation and conference facilities were $1 666 156. This figure was compiled from aggregate figures supplied by each of the Department's Central Office program areas and each State/Territory Office for the Public Service Commission's annual Human Resource Development survey.

(4) Most courses were of 1-2 days duration while some major programs such as training for overseas service lasted for 15 days or more. An average of 4.56 days of formal training were received by staff in the Department.
(5) The number of staff attending each course was 15-20.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 19 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: When will the scope and guidelines for the assessment for comprehensive regional assessments be finalised as required by the National Forest Policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The National Forest Policy Statement provides for a comprehensive regional assessment process whereby a State or Territory Government can invite the Commonwealth to participate in undertaking assessments of environmental and heritage values of a region, and identify each Government's obligations to protect those values. This joint assessment is expected to provide a basis for a regional intergovernmental agreement which will cover all aspects of the ecologically sustainable management of forests in the region.

A broad-based Interdepartmental Committee has been established to coordinate Commonwealth involvement in the comprehensive regional assessment and agreement process. Officials of relevant Government Departments are currently preparing a discussion paper on the development of regional forest agreements based on comprehensive regional assessments. Importantly, the paper will specify Commonwealth obligations which will need to be addressed in the comprehensive regional assessment process, including assessment objectives, broad methodologies and basic data requirements.

The paper is expected to be finalised shortly. It is anticipated that the paper will form the basis for discussions with State Governments, industry and non-government organisations in developing the comprehensive regional assessment as an effective cooperative planning process.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Housing Local Government and Community Services: Video and Kit

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local

QUESTION.PARA: Government and Community Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Housing and Urban Development Division, Accommodation Support and Communications Section, of the department spend $55 000 on video production and a kit on housing and older people.
(2) If this is the incorrect amount, what was the correct amount.
(3) What is the content of the video and kit.
(4) What is the purpose of the video and kit.
(5) How many copies of the video and kit were produced.
(6) Where will the video and the kit be put to use.
(7) Can a copy of the video be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department, through the (then) Accommodation Support and Communications Branch, has contracted with the Australian Pensioners' and Superannuants' Federation to produce a video and an associated kit on housing choices and older people. Payments totalling $55 000 have been made as per the contract.

(3) The video consists of people discussing their choices in housing as they grew older. Their current housing arrangements are featured, and the reasons for making these housing choices are discussed. A range of options are covered, including relocation, dual occupancy, retirement villages and renovation of the current home.

The kit consists of information on a range of housing types and living arrangements to expand on the material covered in the video. Topics covered by the kit include: buying and selling a home; home maintenance and modification; sharing a home; and dual occupancy. Contact points in each State and Territory are given.
(4) To inform and raise awareness of issues relating to housing choice.
(5) The contract specifies that 500 copies of both the kit and the video be produced.

(6) The video and kit will be distributed to various community organisations for older people, and will be used in seminars, workshops and similar situations. Broader distribution arrangements are under consideration.
(7) A copy has been provided to the honourable senator.
